review: Although I'm not a fan of sci-fi movies about extraterrestrials, Arrival was incredible. The story is very interesting and told in a clever way through science and politics instead of the overused premise of aliens destroying the planet for domination. Amy Adams delivered another brilliant performance that earned her an Academy Award nomination but not a win. She's definitely overdue for an Oscar.
Arrival was stupid.  Pretentious film that spends all its time analyzing coffee cup stains.

Not so much a movie about aliens invading Earth as much as it is a study of language and how societies use it. An interesting take on the genre of movie that will split audiences in half by it's ending.
A must watch for independent thinkers and people who value the everlasting perspectives of the cosmos. Challenging to understand but it makes it that much more amazing.
This is not your typical alien movie, it's much more realistic. It's actually about communicating with the aliens. Not sure what to think of the ending thoug.
Fucking CCP propaganda! Be clear that the three stars is purely for the sci-fi content; I am not a communist.
unfortunately it was just okay

This movie is fantastic. The performance of Amy Adams is unparalleled, and the approach to the storyline is fantastic as well. It is a cerebral movie and may have suffered from marketing as a Sci-Fi action drama, but this is deeper than a typical alien invasion shoot 'em up drama. The pieces are laid out during the first act and leave the viewer confused, trying to put them together, and when they eventually come together it snaps so neatly and satisfyingly. This is a fantastic movie that has more in common with films like Inception than Independence Day. In my opinion, one of the best films of the year.
I am as confused as you are (in a good way). I think this is what Memento wants to be but cannot be.
Cinematic genius! So thought provoking. Definitely a must watch.
An amazing movie!!I loved it!!

The reason behind why she does so is just as wrong. She "wants to live what she's seen in the future". Selfish act af. and an invalid thought that every woman want to experience motherhood.
One more negative aspect of the movie: it's way too slooooooooooow. I watched it to the end because the alien line was interesting a tiny bit.

This movie is a creative and beautiful sci-fi film which actually manages to provoke emotions from viewers, at least it did in my case, and seeing by other reviews, any others feel the same way. The movie is never boring, nor slow; throughout it constantly provokes thought and reaches into your heart. It is simply beautiful. The shots, action, and its carefully, elegantly and dare I say again beautiful portrayal of language and its affect on all life. Thematically, visually, and emotionally this movie hits the mark and is a sci-fi film, whether a passionate fan or stranger of the genre, that people should definitely watch - you will most likely enjoy it :)
Overall a well-made and interesting film with some great performances, but for me it was somewhat spoiled by an overly-contrived central parable that forced viewers to take sides for no purpose.

Despite being critically acclaimed, 'Arrival' is another one of those films that is praised to the heavens with critics but has wildly divided audiences judging from the nature of both the positivity and negativity. Though it has to be said that the positive reviewers have been far more mature than the negative ones, many of which to me being disgustingly condescending.

'Arrival' is a very different sci-fi film, and one can definitely see why people will love it and be moved by it as well as seeing why people will hate it and be alienated. To me, 'Arrival' is not as good as reputed and is not a masterpiece, but even if it didn't do much for me it would have gotten a 4 at least. From personal opinion there are far worse films out there that are far more deserving of 1/10, and it would be insulting to put 'Arrival' down there with them. Even if the film didn't much for me, the good things would still be acknowledged and there would be real effort to be respectful of other people's opinions regardless of agreeing or disagreeing with them rather than being insulting and inventing ridiculous and untrue conspiracy theories. Those who hated it do need to grow up and start accepting that not everybody hates this film and that those who loved it are being genuine, and no being angry at being disappointed by it is not an excuse. Coming from a younger film lover than most on this site who's autistic and disabled but those have not gotten in the way of being understanding of people's opinions, what's your excuse?

Back to my thoughts on the film, 'Arrival' is a meditatively paced film, and is not an action filled or jam packed with constant narrative. While this may understandably alienate viewers, neither of these are necessarily bad things especially when there are great to masterpiece films that are the same. Of the four films seen of Denis Villeneuve so far, 'Arrival' may be my least favourite, and his most polarising, least violent and most gentle, but that is just testament to how very good 'Prisoners' is and how fantastic 'Incendies' and 'Sicario' are.

The criticisms are understandable and am in agreement with some. It does drag in the middle act, softening and slacking too much. It does get confusing in the later stages, where things can get ridiculous and predictable.

Forest Whittaker and particularly Michael Stuhlbarg's characters are underutilised and underwritten with both having very little to do, the two do make the most of their roles one has to give them that.

However, 'Arrival' does look wonderful. This is particularly true in Bradford Young's cinematography, being fluid and its tactile quality is of sheer beauty. It's beautifully and atmospherically designed and lit, the special effects have grand spectacle and the editing is some of the best of its year.

Johann Johannsson's music score is another standout, it has a haunting creepiness and has a heart-pulsating and emotional beat. It not only adds a huge amount to the film, it also enhances it. Denis Villeneuve's direction is his most subtle and least hard-hitting, which is not only a good thing but the right thing, the approach he gave to 'Prisoners' and 'Sicario' would have ruined an atmosphere that's the complete opposite.

In terms of how it's written, 'Arrival' is not perfect but it has a movingly raw emotion, thoughtfulness, subtly suspenseful mystery and gives a compelling realism to its character especially the protagonist. Likewise the story (yes there is one), with a poignant emotion and a clever and powerful, if perhaps not the most logical, twist.

The acting is one of 'Arrival's' best assets, all round it's very good even if some characters are better realised than others. Amy Adams in particular is astounding, she has rarely been more poignant. Jeremy Renner also underplays effortlessly.

All in all, divisive film but count me as one of the people who liked it but in an appreciation way than a loved it way. 7/10 Bethany Cox

Out of the countless films I've watched, from various genres, directors, actors and award winners. My mind always jumps back to this one. I am still unable to translate my feeling towards this masterpiece into words - and I don't think I'll ever be able to.
I'm not here to feed any egos. They really thought they did something here. And they did, but They could have done it so much faster. For a movie about time it sure does drag.

I've seen many "alien" movies in my time but this one is quite unique, it sums up for me what I think would happen if aliens came to earth. The story is a beautiful one, although somewhat somber at times. I was mostly impressed by the imagination used to create language in this; many writers have created languages for many of reasons, however this really takes our understanding of language outside the box, to try and create a believable non human communication system. It was also very well shot, and perfectly paced. Definitely underrated.

A riveting story with excellent characterization and complex storytelling, it's the rare movie that treats its audience like intelligent beings. Deliberately withholding information at points to let the viewer fill in blanks and figure things out before they happen on screen, Arrival is an example of an original concept excellently brought to life.

By the end we are stunned! 
What is time? And what will we do with the time we have? 
Beginning is the end, the end is the beginning
What a filmmaking!

A good sci-fi movie. Amy Adams is fantastic, the first act is among the best in the "first contact" genre, and the makers made great decisions about how to portray the aliens and their ships. The sound is also fantastic. The story is really good, but it suffers from a pretty heavy handed treatment, especially towards the end.

This is a must-see alien encounter film. It is a thinking person kind of flick. Great acting, even pacing, some action and great special FX with very unique aliens that are here to instruct and guide us.

By far my favorite movie, it plays with so many scientific concepts and beautifully delivers the message of unity and understanding that it strives for. The aliens are unsettling yet calming it really puts the audience on the edge of their seats. 5/5 stars super engaging!

I watched this way to late at night to understand fully, but still ugly cried multiple times. I think I have a maternal attachment to Amy Adams, seeing her slightly sad makes me want to die. 
This film is beautiful, thoughtful, timely, and enthralling. To wholly appreciate will require re-watches, but that won't feel like a chore.

Arrival is an out of the ordinary sci-fi movie, with its most essential focus being a mother and other "real" things. Denis Villeneuve made a masterpiece in more than one ways. The imagery is monumental and simple the same time, emphasizing that here not the CGI, the spectacle or the pace is the major driving force of this story, but the people themselves in it. Besides this it also offers a stunning plot with some twists.

I feel strongly that this film is a masterclass in film-making, as it is able to merge the epic scope of the sci-fi genre, with a story that ultimately centres around motherhood.
Without spoiling the film, I'd summarise it as an
exploration of the human condition and what it means to be a mother, wrapped under the guise of an alien blockbuster. On a cinematic level, this film is near perfect. Denis Villeneuve manages to create a synthesis of the real-world environment with excellent CGI, creating a more grounded,
realistic alien film that isn't very common. The score is unbeatable, with the heart-wrenching melody of Max Richter's "On the nature of daylight" swelling in the epilogue, emphasising the heart-wrenching climax of the film.
Of course, Amy Adams is superb (as always), as she so fluently, pardon the pun, portrays a confident linguist who creates a realistic balance between her career and her motherhood. This is an incredible character that Amy Adams fantastically portrays. Jeremy Renner is great too,
as is Forest Whitaker, but Amy Adams is definitely the star here.
To conclude, I implore you to watch this film! It is
groundbreaking, as it has not only completely redefined the sci-fi genre for me, but it has reshaped my philosophy regarding mortality and love, and made me think of things in different ways. The film forces you to delve deep into
your own life, it forces you to confront your feelings and your regrets, yet you're never taken out of the film - you remain completely immersed in Villeneuve's frighteningly authentic world. I never expected a film that on the surface seemed to be about the arrival of aliens, to instead stir my
emotions in a way that very rarely happens with a film.
Unwatchable. Boring. Slow. I tried three times to watch this and couldn't. I LOVE science fiction but this was like watching paint dry. I disagree with the praise heaped upon this "film".
Extremely short-paced, felt like most of the movie was empty without a real driving story. I would have hoped for more action.

It was sci-fi but more FIction than SCIence. At least it was honest enough to ask initially "whence did they come, moreover how did they arrive here: Faster than light travel?" But then it sidetracked into impossible fantasies about time-travel or illusions of it. In short: Forget it; -Do not waste your time watching this film.

I have never had a movie make me stop for 30 minutes after and really contemplate the actions on the characters on the level I had to with this movie. To make the choices she made. To decide it was worth it. It's absolutely beautiful and heartbreaking. This movie is incredible. A gift.

HEAVY SPOILERS
An impressively complex yet comprehensive Science Fiction/Thriller story that doubles as a commentary on the importance of language. As foreshadowed by the protagonists Louise (Amy Adams) initially interaction with her co-lead Ian (Jeremy Renner) this is an exploration on the universal necessity of communication between sentient creatures. This is inclusive of not only humans and aliens but of humanity itself. The film also successfully presents an argument for why language is the most important weapon. Not to hurt or destroy but to defuse a conflict and mutually benefit everyone. Several factors come into play that raise the stakes of the movie. The first is the inability to communicate which plays out a number of different ways among the nations. Fear and paranoia are exploited by both the media and internet personalities which leads to protests and an assassination attempt later in the film. Pressure is placed on the governments to give answers they don't have. Thus tensions are placed on relationships between the military authority and Louise which slowly escalates and crescendos at the end and almost results in the death of our protagonists. The next factor is miscommunication which plays out as the alien language translating to "gift weapon" to each major location the aliens landed. This causes mistrust and fear between the world powers and they cut off communication for each other. Slowly but surely they begin to mobilize against the aliens believing them to want planetary control. Louise frantically tries to deescalate the situation to no avail. She knowing communication is the best way to solve this and believing the aliens to be friendly takes matters into her own hands and goes to talk to the aliens herself. Entering the chamber she  exposes herself to their atmospheric accommodations and talks face to...head? With one of the aliens whom she has come to know. She learns that they do indeed wish to gift them all a weapon but the weapon is not a scientific advancement or a destructive tool of conquest. Each power was given a piece of their language. Before departing Louise is given their entire language by the alien and when she returns she realizes she can understand it. She also begins to realize something else. Throughout the film we see what we thought were flashbacks to Louise's life and the death of her daughter. But it turns out that the film utilizes the theory that language determines the way your brain thinks and see's the world. Using this they introduce the concept that the alien language is a palindrome. Its the same backwards as it is forwards. Because of these things Louise is not having flash backs but flash forwards due to her increasing exposure to their language. Now she is able to see how everything in her life will play out and manipulate time to gain access to the phone number of the leading force of hostility towards the aliens. Using language she is able to reach him in an emotional place due to her ability to hear what she said in the future and prevent the attack on the aliens. Using only her words and the capabilities of language she prevents a major military conflict. The film wraps up with a corny but cute "I wouldn't change a thing" moment that is flipped on its head between our two leads as Louise is literally choosing to not change a single decision she has yet to make. However I will say she is able to see her own divorce in the future and it is implied she allowed things to happen the same way so that leaves me questioning why she would choose to go down the same path and not try and prevent it. But I suppose she can only remember the future not feel it in the moment so perhaps the nuance is that she has fallen in love with him currently and knows someday things won't be the same and she will fall out of love. It is human nature to do something that you desire despite knowing it will only end in pain so I suppose it does make sense but it also could be because she wants to experience the existence of her daughter and all the love and happiness that she has brought but also has yet to bring. Brings up a lot of ethical questions of selfishness and selflessness, is she being selfish in going down the same path or selfless in giving her daughter life even for a short time. Either way this is a movie that rewards thinking and knows how to subvert expectations in a satisfying way. In addition it presents a compelling argument about language and an entertaining exploration of a potentially possible scenario someday. I just wish the visuals weren't so cold and gray. It felt very bleak and for me that just makes it less appealing to ever revisit. But things are rarely perfect and this was still a hit on the nail for me. Give it a watch if it sounds like your thing.

I cannot get enough of this movie. The mood and tone are set right away, and pull you into a fantastic watch. Not only were the ideas there, but they were executed perfectly. Arrival is one of those movies that will leave you thinking about the story long after the credits roll.

Seriously overrated, I think. A boring, low pace movie with no action and too much sappy stuff with the daughter, the one-sided romance and the constant half focused, half scared look on the main female protagonists' face. The unrealistic lack of cooperation between similar research teams, the lack of depth in approaching the challenges and downright weird strategies to encounter the aliens did not help the plot forward. The aliens were boring, treelike creatures. Why bother showing up? Still, I get why the movie got high reviews. It is somewhat entertaining and definitely different. Overall, not a winner for me. Two stars is fair, I think.

This is one of those rare movies where it exceeds its source material. The theme of time is incredibly well represented and it really comes together at the end. The soundtrack complements the film perfectly, especially the Max Richter song, On the Nature of Daylight. The song would bring anybody to tears on its own but is amplified by this film's revelation. This is one of those films that requires your full attention. Arrival will definitely bring you back a second time, or more.

A dazzling sci-fi epic that creates a beautiful spectacle on such a grand scale out of the mere arrival of extraterrestrial visitors. The arrivers feel truly.....well...alien. Their mysterious presence and the tense build-up to their arrival is expertly handled. The characters trying to learn and understand their unique language in an effort to communicate with them was fascinating to watch unfold. The discoveries and tension keep building up until they come to fruition in an amazing climax. Amy Adams is sympathetic, albeit a bit on the meeker side for someone who's such an accomplished scientific figure. But still an engaging performance nonetheless. My only major issue is the ending resolution, where it's revealed that (SPOILERS!) Amy Adams's character knew that her daughter was going to die of cancer and cause her husband to leave in grief, yet still chooses to go along with it anyway because it's "worth it". Which is frustrating, because I could easily see this working if this was the only way she could preserve peace between Earth and the aliens via those time visions she received. But the movie implies that she still has the choice to not go through with it. That she merely chooses to do so out of some forced attachment to an imaginary daughter that she only saw for a couple of visions, some of which involved her in immense pain and grief during her final years of life. It almost comes across as some unsettling warped pro-life angle to this messed up scenario. Why give someone life if you know they're going to die a horrible death in their youth and cause so much misery? Why not just adopt? There's not even abortion involved, it's just the absence of procreation. And this all could've been avoided if they just implied that this had to happen, that this wasn't her choice. It would've made the ending that mirrors the beginning so much more powerful with the movie's themes about time being a circle. I know it's just one flaw, but it's a major one that really drags down the movie's otherwise fantastic score for me. Regardless, the visual artistry and alien linguistics plotline more than make up for the movie's drawbacks. A skyrocketing experience like no other.

This film is truly one of the best science fiction films out there. I was mind blown by that twist. It has a very deep message that a lot of people should know. "Despite knowing the journey… and where it leads… I embrace it. And I welcome every moment of it."

Now Denis wanted to talk to aliens. I remembered watching this in the theater and was surprised that it wasn't actually about alien invasion. Just like the previous movies, the second time viewing with some prior understanding made me appreciate this piece of art. 

The music and cinematography resolved so well with each other. Whenever the characters came into the spacecraft, it was an entirely immersive, quiet, yet slightly intense because I, like the characters, were stepping into the unknown. Like Enemy, the whole scenes were filled with one blue color, creating a sad yet again immersive tone. 

Just as immersive was the performance by Amy Adams. Her character had to deal with a trauma while talking to these aliens. Such sadness filled her face, as well as the voiceover. 

This time Denis explored the dual nature of language. It can divide as well as unite people. It's a weapon as well as a gift. Denis cleverly reaffirmed the main purpose of language as a gift by capitalizing on the Sapir-Whorf hypothesis. Not only that, this usage also became a way to beautifully explore the nature of time and apply it to build Amy Adams's character and how she confronted her trauma. I just loved how everything seamlessly coalesced and nothing felt forced.

Besides that one exposition scene that explained the nature of writing and language, I don't have any problem with this movie.

Overall, a beautiful, emotional, and immersive movie with a daring theme about a common tool that can unite us all. 9.5/10

Some claim that Denis Villeneuve is the new Christopher Nolan. Admittedly, both clearly have a drive for the extraordinary. But a look beneath the surface shows that the two directors can hardly be compared. While Nolan repeatedly overdoes it with his penchant, as he did most recently with Tenet, Villeneuve's Arrival shows that, as a presumed Nolan counterpart, he takes a completely different approach. In contrast to Nolan's repetitive brainfuck, the Canadian created what is arguably one of the most intelligent sci-fi films of recent years.

What Villeneuve clearly has ahead of Nolan is his knack with the ensembles in his films. No actress could have embodied the lead role of linguist Louise Banks better than Amy Adams. Although Jeremy Renner and Forest Whitaker are also likable in the supporting roles of a physicist and military colonel, Adams carries the film single-handedly. The character is fragile and conflicted from the start, and because of intimate glimpses into her private and thought life, we always know why that is. The way Adams manages to suggest this rollercoaster ride of emotions is quite great. She usually has barely seconds to catch her breath before she has to move on from profound thoughts about her deceased daughter back to the mysterious enigma of the aliens landing on Earth. Even the way Adams behaves in some scenes while trying to communicate with the mysterious beings is comprehensible. You immediately want to join her and assist in the difficult research. This makes for a complex film character with numerous facets that you can empathise with at all times. Yes, Adams often plays the broken woman with a dark past. Only in Arrival she certainly doesn't always come across as an emotional wreck, but rather determined and enthusiastic about her responsibility despite her stroke of fate. Jeremy Renner's character, the physicist Ian Donnelly, is a nice touch and shares many interesting scenes with Louise. However, he is overshadowed by Adam throughout. This has little to do with Renner's performance, which is excellent as always, but the character simply lacks complexity. The same applies to Whitaker's Colonel Weber, who, after an initially strong presence, plays second fiddle more and more as time goes on. This is also less due to Whitaker's acting than to the lack of X-factor in his character.

So why is Arrival now so much more thoughtful and better than, say, Tenet? Villeneuve shows such a fine hand in his directing that the film never comes across like one of the many forced sci-fi flicks with mega effects and explosions, but rather resembles a slowly told thriller. Not because there is so much suspense, Arrival is no Sicario by any means, but until the end you don't know what the aliens' intention is and to what extent the protagonist's life plays a role. The final leaves you stunned, amazed and above all overwhelmed. Despite a few hangs in the middle, Arrival is another Villeneuve masterpiece with which the best director of our time revolutionised science fiction with his unique signature.

Denis Villeneuve is one of the outstanding directors working today, consistently producing brilliant films one after the other, but Arrival may just be his most heartfelt to date.

His direction is fantastic by taking the sci fi genre and giving it new light. This film is all about communication and how language impacts how we live life, so by conveying this message through the use of aliens invading earth (a cliche narrative choice with Sci Fi) Villeneuve is risking being ordinary, but becomes an original, imaginative filmmaker in the process.

The film has excellent performances from Amy Adama and Jeremy Renner, alongside it's beautiful cinematography and soundtrack shot by Bradford Young and composed by Jóhann Jóhannsson respectively. The incredible screenplay via Eric Heisserer puts the cherry on top. An all round complete picture.

The film has many deep meanings which would suggest multiple viewings are essential in understanding the films complete idea, but Arrival is an underrated gem in my opinion and highlights Villeneuve's status as one of Hollywood's prominent directors working today.

Whenever you see a film about an alien invasion you expect some big action scenes filled with explosions, however Arrival (2016) proves that it isn't a necessity in making a great movie about alien invasions. Many elements are tackled throughout the two hour runtime, trying to communicate with the aliens, understanding their intentions as well as others which are unveiled once watching the film, however Arrival (2016) never feels silly, constantly grounded and engaging, also largely helped to the fantastic cinematography, the best in recent years.

Familiar tropes are deployed, however Arrival (2016) executed them in a way which has never been done before and a way which remains unique to this film, which in time leads to one of the cheekiest plot twists in recent times, it all tops off one of sci-fi's greatest.

With the massive delay attributed to Denis Villeneuve's upcoming Dune, here's an opportunity to immerse yourself in his previous work. Arrival is him at the peak of his powers (as usual I suppose) and is actually a good companion piece to Tenet (2020) in some ways, although Arrival is the better film. When strange objects appear on earth, Amy Adams' linguistic professor is sent to aid the effort to understand who the visitors are, and what they want. It's best to leave it at that, and considering the subject matter, it's a strangely beautiful film, which also shares similar threads to District 9 (2009).

Excellent film, with a good tempo and great soundtrack, strange story (especially when it all comes together later) but that isn't to say it was a bad story, it certainly all paid of in a meaningful and well done end. Excellent film overall.
Somewhere within the top 10 movies of the century. Science fiction as it ought to be: well-crafted story, and all about humanity.
esta película es buena y totalmente emocionante algo mas que estimulante

A high concept sci-fi movie about a professional linguist who is recruited to communicate with mysterious aliens that suddenly appear on Earth. Amy Adams' performance is nothing short of brilliant, and her interactions with the heptapods are phenomenal! It's an incredibly well structured movie that improves upon repeat viewings. If you like sci-fi and want to see a unique spin on alien encounters, look no further!
Absolutely incredible movie.

Summary: When 12 massive spaceships land on across the world, countries that don't always see things the same way must try and work together. A team of top linguistics experts is assembled with the mission of communicating with the newly-arrived aliens.

Takeaways: Communication in all forms is incredible. Interacting across languages, cultures, and, in this case, across planets, takes patience and understanding. Throw in the layers of fear and ethics, and you have an interestingly relatable sci-fi drama.
An intelligent science fiction movie.  Interesting twist on time/space.

After watching Tomorrow war and Quiet Place II this week, I got tired of movie where aliens cross the stars, but are dumber than your average beagle.  Needed to rewatch a thoughtful movie about intelligent aliens that don't exist just to be scary and shootable.

Denis Villeneuve is a wonderful director whose style combines a melancholy sort of bleakness with a glorious flair and passion for cinema evident in his work. Arrival is perhaps the crown jewel. The film is so satisfying to look at yet never bombastic, the design mesmerising in an individualistic sense. Adams is good in the lead role, although I still view her best leading work as choosing good roles rather than driving a film forward. The same goes for Renner and Whittaker. Stuhlbarg shows his range in a grave departure from A Serious Man, although his character is quite simple. The drama unfolds with a tranquilising, captivating stillness provoking profound reflection. The story's beauty transcends the science fiction genre as a meditation on moral dilemma while never forgetting its roots. I have never witnessed a film that so effortlessly weaves multiple areas and surfaces in a fantastical yet somehow bare manner. The only reason that this is not five stars is that characters outside of Renner and Adams are quite uninteresting.

The movie was pretty good up until the ending. The ending was kind of a dud. It seemed like the writers had a really good subject to work with...communicating with aliens...but then they didn't have an idea on how to wrap the movie up and pulled an ending out of their butts that got a consensus vote from the crew because all the ideas were equally bad.

Hands down the best Alien movie ever. No stupid action sequences no stupid over-the-top dialogues. 
Based on real-world theories, linguistics, concepts, and consequences. 
A pure brain teaser minus the future telling emotional bs.

A must-see film. So many sci-films exploring alien life explore war, science, or many other factors individually. The things this film explores and the peacefull manner in which it does makes this a must see for anyone who is after a film they can engage the deeper parts of their minds with.
Arrival was able to keep tension built up throughout the entire piece while also telling a moving story.

)
Arrival is a beautifully structure sci-fi film which touches on every level.

Villeneuve best work!

The one thing that surprised me the most about Arrival is how meticulously crafted it is, how ambitious it is, and how powerful Amy Adams' performance is.

When I was about to watch the film, I honestly thought to myself, "okay, another alien movie," but it completely slapped me in the face afterward. It's an unexpectedly great movie that cleverly answers the questions, and all you can say is, "What just happened?"

Overall, it's a revolutionary sci-fi film that takes a splendid approach to telling the story of first contact from a technical, rational standpoint. A perplexing exploration of language and time told through the lens of a first contact narrative.
Phenomenal sci fi film. Great performances and a wonderful approach to telling the story of first contact from a technical, rational perspective.

Overrated... it's not your typical or traditional alien movie, this movie is mega slow lots of flashbacks and repeat, try to solve this alien language and repeat time its running out, if you are brave to watching this try to watch it as a documental do not expect the typical sci-fi entertainment.

I'm convinced at the end that this movie really is not about the arrival of aliens to Earth. It's about the different definitions of life for humans and the alines. For us humans, life is about making choices without knowing what is waiting for us in the future. For the aliens, life is about not making choices with knowing what is waiting for them in the future. For us, our past is the past and our future is the future. But for the aliens, both their past and future appear as if it is their present.

A new extraterrestrial perspective had arrived brings unorthodox point of view. Revolutionary Si-Fi approach, much better than Aliens bust out eating everyone. Hands down best of Amy's, at least for me; better than being superman's GF. Love how Denice bring this together tactfully keep audience stick to the screen the whole ride. Enjoy yours:-)
I love Denis Villenueve. The cast is great, and the movies is suspenseful. Thought-Provoking.

Arrival is such a slick and engrossing sci-fi story. It is one of the cleanest, most grounded, and most cohesive movies I've seen in a long time. Its non-linearity is so wonderfully complex and simple at the same time and is interwoven within each plot point. The soundtrack is exhilarating, ominous, and emotional. Jaw-dropping is the right way to describe how I feel for how well done this movie is.
Villeneuve is a visionary director and I'm fascinated by everything he creates.

So superb!!!
The sound effect and special effect are too amazing.The ending is so touching.I really love the performance of Amy Adams. She is really the soul of this film.She definitely deserved the nomimation of Best Actress in 2017 Oscar .

Arrival will challenge you to think.  If you want your film enjoyment served up in an obvious and easy to follow way, then this isn't it. This is truly great sci-fi. It contains a concept that will spark new thoughts. You don't have to believe the concept (no spoilers) to enjoy and benfit from its ramifications; its deep consequences for the human lifetime. Arrival is in my all time top 5 movies because apart from being supremely well made and enjoyable, there is much more than superficiality to it. It could gift you something that will stay with you forever.

A mind-bending exploration of language and time told through the lens of a first contact story.  Denis Villeneuve's "Arrival" is bold, beautiful and clever, ending on a twist that makes you think long after the credits rolled.  A true work of art.

It was interesting, but I wouldn't say I was touched by the morale like everyone seem to. I think that, yes, it is a good reflection on the humanity and the need of language, how languages define someone, but I didn't feel so much emotions. I was surely not the fault of the main actress who was super, but maybe it is the fact that, for me, there was no real sad moments. Also, I would say the end disappointed me a bit because it was really complicated and I'm not sure I understand everything. On the other hand, the end solves a problem that I found during the movie. Indeed, maybe you'll find the movie chaotic with his timeline, but the end explains everything. Now, the movie has great points too, not just bad. I would say that it goes in a better direction than a lot of sci-fi movie with this "Aliens psychology" sort of thing and it exploit a much different and deep subject into the alien touch. Also, the images a pretty good. I really liked the dark environment and the mist everywhere, it was visually well-done. So, despite the fact that I wasn't really touched by the movie with a really confusing end, I would say this film scores great because of its acting, visuals, wall-breaking type of sci-fi and a great scenario. A good movie, overall.

This is the best sci-fi movie that I've ever saw, but is also so much more than just a genre, it is poetic, mind bending and powerfull.
It afected me for life, in terms of philosofical thinking about how much mankind can acomplish when science is put it to the test, ina true sence.

Arrival is like that friend that sounds smart, but doesn't know what the hell he is talking about. This movie just keeps on throwing unlogical stuff at you without even trying not to be. Only thing that is to like is the out of order story telling and the alien scenes.

Who would have thought that a movie about linguistics could be so compelling and interesting.  Denis Villeneuve, the Director of Blade Runner 2049, is a brilliant storyteller.   This film is an interesting story about First Contact by an Alien race and our attempt to communicate with it.  Amy Adams plays a Professor of Linguistics.  She is believable and emotionally engaged in the role.   Jeremy Renner is a scientist and his, usually, credible and likable self in the role.   Forrest Whitaker plays a US Army officer comfortably.    This is a thoughtful and intelligent movie.  This is not Independence Day, or E.T.  It is a very different type of Alien movie.  Without revealing too much, there is a back story that runs through the thread of the entire film that keeps you confused and engaged but is valuable to the story.  This is probably best watched more than once because it is really high thinking, for sure.

If there was ever a movie that could be called a pure science fiction masterpiece, Arrival is it.

Arrival very successfully takes its time telling its story, while staying very intriguing. Amy Adams brings her excellence to set and Jeremy Renner is good enough. The story is told beautifully and brilliantly, though begins to lose itself during its dragged out finale. The effects are mostly pleasing to look at, and isn't overkill. The soundtrack is wonderfully done by Johann Johannsson, and really adds to the art of the film. Dennis Villeneuve's Arrival does have a rough patch, but for the more memorable portion, isn't just a film, it's poetry.

Finally an alien film that seriously tries to make a plot out of logic and a sense of reality. It's all about understanding intentions. There are of course enough of those who neither realize and comprehend its purpose or want to accept the simplicity in it, and one basic aspect with this film might be to create a mirror for them. How boring it must be not to be open minded, also dangerous.
Amazing movie from Denis Villeneuve! Absolutely would recommend!

A film with some potential, thoroughly squandered. I've never been particularly enthused by Amy Adams, and this film reminds me why. She lacks charisma, presence and command of my attention, leaving me to just meander my way through the film, quite nonplussed about anything. 

The ending was quite ridiculous, the slow burn spiralling into nonsense and farce. Wasn't a huge fan of the way the military blokes were presented. Woman was the key to everything and those damn men standing in her way.

Super interesting and very unique. The film succeeds in making a story about trying to understand aliens entertaining and even thrilling. The movie is unpredictable and has a nice message. I can't help but feel that the time-related aspects detracted more overall than they added though.

[SPOILERS] The idea of alien language rewiring a human brain to perceive time as non linear and therefore enabling it to see the future is somewhat cool, the ominus aliens, their signs and spaceships are artistically interesting. What annoyed me was the writing style ala 90s Hollywood, which is apparent the first 10 minutes - how Louise got selected to try to communicate with the aliens, the conversation with the physicist in the helicopter, later the attitude of stubborn colonels undermining the scientist's work, the bad bad Chinese army and cliche predictable romantic subplot. Near the end of the movie we find out that the ill daughter flashbacks are actually the future visions which is fine but the fact we never find out what's the big thread that aliens need human help in 3000 years, is quite a letdown. The acting is nothing to write home about. 5/10 because I see how it can give some people a little bit to think about and it somehow resembles the vibe of "Annihilation", a bit newer and better movie.
Never seen a sci-fi movie quite like this one. Denis Villenueve is a masterful filmmaker!

There seems to be two separate stories here: (1) a woman who can see the future and (2) aliens that need to pay a visit to earth in order to setup some future exchange   of services, 3000 years later.  Neither of these stories is clear until the end, how they tie together is entirely by chance, though their tying together is entirely necessary for the alien's objective to work (I guess they got lucky?). Neither story is very compelling or satisfying at the end.  It is not clear why this movie scored so high, it is not the least bit memorable. Also, it is a lame (and also not interesting) twist that Amy Adam's character knows she and Renner are going to marry, divorce and lose a child to cancer, but she doesn't tell him that outright.

I mean, just wow. Such a well thought out plausible approach to one of the countless on film scenarios of encountering alien life. Both plausibly executed and beautifully displayed, with a heavy punch of human emotions; this was a favorite of mine. Pure awe, all the way to tears flowing.

This movie has one of the best beginnings I have ever seen in a sci-fi film, and yet it manages to only devolve into a obvious twist ending. It left my friends crying and sad, this confused me. Why did they not see how incredibly unoriginal this movies ending was?

(SPOILERS AHEAD) 

When I asked them why they liked the film, they replied that the ending was powerful. This is what bothers me, because the ending of this movie is the same ending in Kaufman's Eternal Sunshine. The message: would you stay in a relationship even though you know it will fail. That is the ending of Eternal Sunshine, a great film that it seems Arrival ripped off.

Gets better on multiple viewings. The ending is beautiful, makes me tear up and gives me goosebumps every time I see it. The song choice for the ending is perfect. Denis Villeneuve is a genius.

"Arrival" é inovador, mesclando conceitos ambíguos a uma premissa talvez antes nunca explorada, subvertendo tudo que esperávamos sobre o longa.

A atmosfera do filme é muito bem construída aqui, moldando o plot desde a primeira cena do filme. A subversão dos até então "flashback's"; a elegância da fotografia, respeitando muito bem as magnitudes, o que deixa claro que esse filme foi feito para telões; o background da trama é bem definido pelos telejornais, o que gera uma influencia grande da trama, tanto nos acontecimentos quanto na nossa percepção dos acontecimentos. A OST é magnifica, tanto no conjunto como no clímax.

A compreensão do tempo é muito bem representada aqui, com um plot inteligente e uma abordagem como eu disse acima, inovadora. Enfim, todos esses fatores - e muito mais - tornam a experiencia incrível. É um filme essencial para os fans do gênero.

Arrival is a movie that will make you feel nervous and intense BUT, I expected more. 

Arrival is a movie that I really enjoyed, the first act of the movie made me excited, want to see more and want to know what will happen at the end, to be more specific, I wanted an answer to the question "why are they here?", and the first act builds that so well.

Amy Adams' (plays: Dr. Louise Banks) performance was absolutely incredible and so powerful, loved her character and her acting was amazing, her face expressions, body language, and her eyes are everything, she was acting with everything. Forest Whitaker (Plays: Colonel Weber) was also amazing, very cool performance that surprised me. Jeremy Renner's character (Ian Donnelly) was so useless, even the character said that in one of the scenes, he said that he is nothing without Dr. Louise Banks (Amy Adams) and she is the one who is doing everything.

The directing was so amazing wasn't surprised that Denis Villeneuve was nominated for an Oscar. 

The cinematography and colors were so amazing, especially that shot when we first see the aliens aircraft, the incredible long take encompassing the entire area with the fog surrounding it, loved it so much. One thing that grabbed my attention is the whole "color tone", the off white-ish color that is dark, gives u that feeling of fear, feeling of confusion of why these aliens are here, it was just amazing and really loved it so much.

The music was so cool, it builds a lot of emotions inside of you.

the production design was so beautiful and simple, deserved an Oscar nomination.

The sound editing and sound mixing were two things that were really powerful and although I didn't watch that movie on the big screen with all the sound effects that are in the theatre, but it was still a thing that was so amazing and grabbed my attention.

Arrival is a movie that is not the best but also not the worst, the 3rd act or to be specific; the ending makes you want to watch the movie again and makes you think about the movie from its begging. A great story with a great directing, cinematography and production design but felt like it could've been way better but 
For sure recommend it.

My rating is: 8/10

So glad it took the overdone alien first contact action flick and added a realistic setting. Highly grounded in sci-fi is what makes this one of my favourite films.

Rewatched it for the first, after 3 years. Remember vividly a lot of stuffs, one the few movies I used to constantly think about 3 years ago. Script is a masterpiece, way to tell that story in that way, beautiful. The concept of time travel seen in a new light.

The soundtrack is addicting, was listening to it out loud and my mother told me to stop it because it felt like 'someone was dieing', I replied HannaH.

The cinematography of that first scene of spaceship was gorgeous. Many social commentary about conspiracy theory, majority of them were correct as we can see from pandemic. I actually gained a lot of respect for linguistics, always thought of it as a useless study area but boy was I wrong.

Rewatching it, caught many foreshadowing. The movie literally says everything at the beginning.

Loved the themes, her taking the decision of have that child. Its not about the goodbyes but the memories we make before the goodbyes. She would rather find & lost than never get it. The parallelism with one the heptapods(alien) dieing yet the other one not caring because their time isn't linear, they could go back in memory.

The only thing cerebral about this steaming pile of dog ____ is that it is completely braindead.

The supposedly "high-minded" concepts are mishandled throughout the movie.

You can't learn how to see the future by learning a language.

If "reading" a ring has no start, it would be like having pictographs for sentences, which would be quite cumbersome for society at large, and hinder the development of computer systems.

Aliens that can see the future wouldn't need to figure out how to communicate with humans, as they could just look into the future to when they already knew how to translate.

Even if the movie were devoid of the ridiculous "future sight", advanced aliens should be smart enough to send some innocuous probes to record & decipher human communication, then send messages to us instead of hovering mysteriously & menacingly over Earth.

And the future Amy Adams shouldn't be surprised by what the Chinese general told her, because she should have known it already, as she already learned it in the past from her future self.

The first time I saw Arrival, I fell asleep. The second time, I didn't. Denis Villeneuve continues to impress his audience after Prisoners and Sicario (the latter I saw but not reviewed yet). The cinematography is what we expect Villeneuve's films to be like. It's stunning. The performances especially Amy Adam's performance. Don't go into the film excepting big laser battles and action because this is a slow-paced film. That's one little criticism I have with this film. It's a little slow. Also, the plot for some people may confuse people. It requires a second viewing upon first viewing. It took me a while to think about this review. Also, I can't stress enough how much this film reminds me of Shutter Island. I mean come on! They both use the same song "On the Nature of Daylight". The plots both seem familiar to each other. But hey, that's just my opinion. Overall, Arrival is a wonderfully directed film, with a great cast, and stunning production design. It's also a film that plays with our minds. And in my opinion, it succeeds at that.

One of the best science fiction films I've seen. The tension between science and politics in the movie is intense and interesting, and feels spot-on for the sort of thing that might actually happen in a first-contact scenario. I also love the movie's sympathetic portrayal of science and scientists -- a rarity in today's often anti-intellectual culture. An incredible twist toward the end of the film marries a fascinating plot point with a mind-bending storytelling device. In doing so, "Arrival" asks a deeply important and relatable question about human nature and questions the ways we perceive and experience the world around us.

I don't think this movie is about that "what makes us human". Personally I think it is about creating your own reality. The whole movie developes around the ability of a character to understand a language. In a way, Adams' character is a child (humanity) learning to speak. She has to go through all the tribulations of learning a new language, a powerful one at that. The premise is quite interesting and it took me two views to get it: Your language (the way you express what you think) determines your reality. They even mention it at the beginning of the movie, with the Sapir-Whorf theory. This is by far a very metaphysical proposal, and a very adecuate one at that, one that has been told to us by great master of ancient ("For by your words you will be justified, and by your words you will be condemned"). In a way, language IS reality, it is the only way we have to describe it and thus create it. So it would make sense that a more powerful language would create a different, more powerful reality. In the movie, learning the aliens' language would opne the doors of time and space for you, and this can be wither a weapon (as first understood by humans) or a gift, as later realized by Adams. Of course the ability to thread between past, present and future could be a powerful weapon, or a great gift. Once she realizes this, it is quite interesting that she still chooses to have her baby, aware of the outcome, but the most important choice she makes, while having the ability to visit the past or future, is to live in the present. Powerful message indeed. So now you know, choose your words carefully.

Upon rewatch, it didn't take long into this re-watch to realize that the first time I watched Arrival, I watched it wrong. I saw it as a puzzle meant to be figured out instead of a story to be absorbed. What did the aliens want? What were they trying to say?  How were Amy Adams and Jeremy Renner going to figure it out? What did Louise's flashbacks have to tell us?

Because I saw the movie as a mystery, I was looking for clues and IMO tipped its hand WAY too early. "If you want science, call your father", was the first big hint that these flashbacks were flash forwards and that Ian was Hannah's father. Any uncertainty I might have had was erased by "Non-zero sum game". Having "solved" the movie with 25 minutes left, I mentally checked out not realizing I was missing the entire point.

If I had understood the ending I would have given it 5 stars. Good movie!

With all the big budget spectacles, I often wonder if studios have forgotten the basis of any good movie: a theme and an interesting story. 
Arrival reminds us of that, taking one the basic concepts of humanity - language and communication - and turning it upside down. It certainly is an intelligent movie, with good acting, directing and storytelling.
Although the images and cgi are compelling to support the plot, the cinematography is not what makes this movie excellent. It is how the images are used, and the many little details that support the overall tone and emotions, letting you feel what our protagonists feel, and playing with your emotions in a way you wouldn`t expect - making this an absolute great watch.
Recommendation: evade spoilers before you see it.

This is one of the coolest movies I've ever seen, and I'm old enough to have seen most of them. I feel sorry for those who call it boring because, if you truly were bored, you either didn't understand it, you have a short attention span and can only focus long enough to see movement and shiny things, or you have no feelings. Either way, you are disadvantaged and the poorer for missing out on appreciating one of the most profound films ever produced. Why is it a good film? First, there are no films that defy being categorized like this one. Sure, it's called a science fiction but, honestly, its way more than that.  In terms of a genre, it's actually a combination of a science fiction with squid monsters, an intellectual study on communication and how it might affect your thoughts and actions, an exploration into the nature of time and its perception, a commentary on human behavior and the state of mankind such as man's tendency to jump to conclusions and make rash decisions, a mystery to be solved, a romance, a story of great grief and loss and, finally and most importantly, a bitter sweet statement on the value and beauty of life, all life, even life that doesn't last that, in the end, includes everyone's life.  Secondly, Arrival does all of these things very well and weaves each element together seamlessly into something beautiful and thought provoking.  It makes a statement like a philosopher.  Like a great poem or piece of art, it forces one to think, to wonder, to feel, to understand love, to feel grief and loss, to ponder what is and what is important.  I'm richer for having seen it and I give credit to those who achieved it.  I can't believe they were able to do it and to do it so well.

A música principal do filme já foi usada em Ilha do Medo, só me fez sentir saudades desse filme e me lembrar que A Chegada é uma tortura.

On my list of the top five science fiction movies of all time. The Arrival was an incredible experience. The movie has an opposite premise compared to the other movies from its genre(Indepence Day, The War of the Worlds, etc). The Arrival parts from a premise of a friendly first contact between aliens and humans, when humans tries to develop a communication with the Heptapods.
One of the things that I have admired in this movie was its atmosphere, the way the movie makes you feel immersed, the way that the events happen, the way humanity reacts from an alien visit from the movie tries hard to make a realistic scenario and succesfully achieves it! Since the scene where Dr. Louise Banks see the news from a televion and the first time she sees the alien spaceship. The movie, once again, succesfully makes you feel immersed and uncomfortable, it makes you ask to yourself: Who are they? And what do they want?
When comes the scene which Louise and Ian are learning how to make contact with them I though that was fair. Although some linguistics affirms that one of their techniques was not one of the best, it felt realistic. More realistic parting from the assumption that the Heptapods had no difficulties in understanding them.
One of the things, I can't consider if it's a con or not, but the movie struggles to be a realistic movie, from the alien visit to including the political scenario to the movie, but in the movie China and Russia are considered the most important countries of the planet, "each step China takes, other 12 nations will follow". And constant references of the Venezuela were made on the movie. That part actually wrapped my stomach, no country in the planet, even USA does not have this power, I've noticed that this part tried hard to make a propaganda for their political view, that didn't fit well in the movie. Needless to say.
One of the things that caught my attention too was the camera angles, the movie began with the camera aiming at the ceiling and slowly pointing the camera to the scenario, the movie began and finished with this camera animation(this camera movement was repeated some times throughout the movie).
The Arrival has its pros and flaws, I'll give it 4/5, the only part of the movie I didn't like was that forced political view propaganda, ignoring that, was a pleasant experience.

Greatly expanding upon Ted Chiang's original (and terribly titled) novella, Villeneuve's thoughtful, laconic adaptation shifts the focus ever so slightly away from the heptapods themselves and their language toward the human characters and their communicative failures. In developing the social and geopolitical implications of the alien's arrival while simplifying the actual linguistic import of the source material, the film deepens the emotional resonance of the story beyond the original text's meticulous exploration of the Sapir-Whorf hypothesis; instead, here the arrival of extreme alterity could just as well stand for the need to address the exigency of unthinkable climate change (incomprehensible yet demanding response) as it does the appearance of extra terrestrials. In this sense, the movie is also ultimately far more hopeful than the novella: As in the latter, we may never fully be able to communicate with the wholly Other, understanding their motives or plans, but here we can still at least learn to speak and listen to one another.

I give out five-star ratings when a movie is not just good, but is also memorable enough to leave me dwelling on it for a long long time. And boy did I not know Arrival would end up doing just that ! It's funny even thinking that I chose to watch it on Netflix just cause I was bored. But it subverted all the conventions of a typical sci-fi flick in leaving a message so beautifully surreal yet still so highly relevant to our global community. Adams (and even Renner) are amazing as always, though it is Villeneuve who is at the peak of his craft, masterfully going back and forth in between the flashbacks and Louise's present in such an emotionally impactful way. This is definitely a movie that will always be up there for me! (credits to Max Richter as well for that final song which is just pure gold)

I must add though, that there definitely are some flaws. The story isn't quite complete, and the characters of Renner, Whittaker and Stuhlbarg feel unnecessary, which wastes such high talent. Ultimately, however, this is not the movie's focus, and is something that can be easily overlooked.

Perhaps the most brilliant sci-fi movie of the 21st century, Arrival still amazes me years after it came out and the first time I saw it. The original story by Ted Chiang is indeed in itself a work of genius that goes into detail about complex physics and linguistics while still being undeniably hard to put down for a layperson. But Villeneuve takes Chiang's work a step further by taking audiences on an emotional thrill ride, that deals with issues of diplomacy, motherhood, love, loss, science, linguistics, and the dynamics of human interaction in a seamless and intelligent way. It is the only movie about Aliens that has made me cry, and it is a perfect flick that will be a classic in years to come.

I don't know why I waited so long to watch Denis Villeneuve's film THE ARRIVAL. I have been a big fan of Villeneuve's films since PRISONERS which shook me up, deeply, for over a week..it hit so many personal buttons. Such a brutal film and yet so beautifully made. I could not get that film out of my mind for months and I don't know if I can ever watch PRISONERS again. That said... I don't know what I'm feeling after watching THE ARRIVAL. THE ARRIVAL has shaken me to tears and I don't know why.. maybe the answer will come to me in a few days... maybe it never will... maybe someone on Facebook can help explain what I'm feeling. 
      However, I am a huge fan of Mr. Villeneuve's work. For me, He so carefully crafts the tone of a film that you have no choice but to be hugely affected by it whether that reaction is positive or negative and to me that is what great art is all about. I'm surprised that I still have not seen his sequel to the original Blade Runner. I think I'm a little afraid to see it.. his films make me feel and think so much that I find them a bit overwhelming, but I have a great admiration for his talent!

Everything about Arrival is excellent. From the very first moments of contact, this scenario screams 'real'. Or, if not real, then at the very least 'plausible'.

Out of all the science fiction movies I've watched over the years, Arrival is the only one to evoke any sense of actual believability. If an alien species were to visit earth, the events portrayed in Arrival are almost exactly how I believe things would actually transpire.

All of the performances are fantastic, but Amy Adams really steals the show. Her portrayal of Louise Banks is engrossing and, again, believable. Jeremy Renner does a great job as well, but he shares so much screen time with Adams that his performance is very much understated.

I loved the sound direction for this film. I loved the sounds the aliens made, and I loved the distorted sensation that the characters were subjected to in their presence. The musical score is spot-on, as well. Tense, but not overbearing.

The aliens themselves were exactly how I would imagine aliens would actually appear: not human-like at all but, instead, strange and otherworldly and in complete defiance of anything we have ever seen.

I really enjoyed the plot of Arrival. I'm very interested in the concept of time and the flow of time and everything that it entails. The idea of an alien language being able to manipulate the flow of time is - to me - completely unique and unlike anything I'd seen or read in science fiction before. The use of flashbacks, and the eventual reveal of them being flash-forwards, was executed very well.

Arrival is one of the best science fiction films I've ever seen. It is smart, beautiful, dramatic, and thought-provoking... everything you could ask for in a movie.

Arrival is one of the greatest movies I have ever seen (if not the greatest). From the very beginning, Arrival sucks you into a thought provoking and emotional story. Director Dennis Villenueve is a master at creating spectacular visuals and the first look at the "shell" in Montana was one of the greatest shots I have ever seen. Amy Adams & Jeremy Renner create spectacular performances as their characters and if they didn't, they deserve at least an Oscar nomination. Arrival also teaches you about language and how it can be messy and how you can rewire your brain into a new one when learning a new one (I am learning Spanish and this is actually true as sometimes it gets hard for me to write in English as the order of sentences are flipped around. This is a great movie and I recommend it to anyone with time on their hands and are looking for a thrill ride.

For those who haven't seen it: STOP READING ABOUT IT. GO INTO THIS MOVIE BLIND. Do not read spoiler-laden reviews. Do not read anything about it. Avoid trailers. If you go this movie knowing anything other than its basic premise (Aliens have landed, we try to figure out what to do), you WILL regret it.

This is perhaps the best sci-fi movie I've ever seen. It transcends the genre, over its storyline, evolving into something much greater than what its title, box art, posters, trailers, or any marketing materials could possibly convey. Its storyline starts out a tense first-contact-with-aliens affair, but unravels into something intricate, challenging, delicate, and utterly emotionally and intellectually compelling.

Simply put: Every aspect of this movie is impeccable. As a whole composition, Villeneuve has achieved near-perfection.

I could fawn over this story's plotline forever, but it's too special to reveal much through analysis. Trust me: It's genius. It's the movie I've basically always wanted, executed brilliantly.

The two obvious stars here are Amy Adams's performance and Denis Villeneuve's direction. Adams's performance has been much-lauded, but Villeneuve's direction cannot garner enough praise.

Direction is obviously outstanding. Scenes are expertly crafted to give the audience the best-possible perspective coming from the viewpoint of the central protagonist: Dr. Louise Banks (Amy Adams, who got robbed of her Oscar for this performance). This is so crucial: Scenes which are disorienting for Dr. Banks are disorienting on-screen; we feel the chaos surrounding; we feel her intimate confusion. Not only does this make us empathize with her character, but, in the movie, she is an expert linguist and brilliant person. This makes us, the audience, feel intelligent. For such an intelligent film, it's a real treat.

Pacing is excellent. It starts out slow and tense, but absolutely never boring. It ramps up precisely before it needs to, steadily building up to a crescendo that's so magnificent, detailing it in praise would be close to spoiling it.

The film's bleak and minimalistic aesthetic is outstanding, with sparse set pieces and dark, muted, earthy color tones both complimenting and focusing on the aliens and their spacecraft-a work of sci-fi minimalistic perfection. It's the glorious antithesis of oversaturated Michale Bay schlock (in almost every regard, really.)

The sound design, too, is brilliant. It's subtle, but captivating. Jóhann Jóhannsson's musical score perfectly compliments the aesthetic and narrative. It serves as neither background noise nor show-stealer. The non-musical sound design, however, is often breathtaking. It is brought into and out of focus with surgical precision, maintaining sublime quality throughous. But when it's in the spotlight, it elevates this movie, becoming one of the defining traits that make this one of the greatest sci-fi films ever.

My only minor complaint is backhanded praise: that this film deserves to be longer. It could easily work with an extra 30 minutes instead of having less than 2 hours of runtime. I'm loathe to imagine what might have been cut by studio executives, but relish the idea of a Director's Extended Cut. 

When I think about other minor complaints ("this one scene, that other scene, was this a plot hole or sloppy writing?") that popped into my head at one point or another, after digesting the film, in retrospect, every single one made sense. No other science-fiction film has required me to suspend my disbelief so little.

This film is nearly perfect. And I only say that to hedge my bet, because no imperfections come to mind. This film was a revelation. It was transcendental, monumental, and hopefully genre-defining.

The awesome plotline, pacing, aesthetic,  sound design, and acting (especially by Adams) are all precisely put together by Villeneuve to craft a cinematic art piece that is both immensely intellectually and emotionally compelling. It is a masterpiece, easily one of the greatest sci-fi films of all time.

- Arrival takes you out of this world and brings you home. -

After watching Arrival with my work boyfriend Ben, we had to go outside and have a smoke - and I don't even smoke.

This is one of the most intense, emotionally draining and sublime movies I have seen in YEARS. Director Denis Villeneuve (Sicario) excelled in making a film, not just about aliens, but the human desire to connect. It is fascinatingly complicated to explain, but this is what I would compare it to:

It's like watching a YouTube video that is narrated by a scientist as they describe how infinite space and time is and how fleeting our lives are - all whilst the most beautiful score plays in the background. I slowly fell in love with aliens and Amy Adams (Julie and Julia) and by the end of it, I questioned everything about my own existence.

I can only give a short synopsis because I don't want to reveal any major spoilers.  Here is what you need to know:

Louise (Amy Adams) is a linguistics professor who has spent her entire life studying communication. She knows about a billion different languages (don't quote me on that, it's probably more like 40). In the opening scenes of Arrival, 12 alien spaceships land all over the world and Louise is called upon to communicate with the one that landed in America. What happens next is a space roller coaster of emotion, science, math and language.

That's about all I can tell you about the plot. Not because I am lazy, but because I want you to experience what I did - going into a movie you know very little about.

So instead, I will tell you about the rest of my evening as we tried to make sense of what we'd just seen.

Ben and I sat on the bench outside the theater with our legs folded.  We gushed with mutual revelations of "Oh god I didn't even pick up on that."

Ben asked me "How on Earth (pun intended) are you going to review this?" I shrugged my shoulders and said, "maybe I will write it in the symbols that the aliens used to communicate with humans, but then I realized I am not a linguistics expert or an alien, so that idea was quickly abandoned.

However, I feel that I am an expert in spotting talent and Amy Adams has been on my radar for awhile now. We discussed how I thought she was a great actress but the characters she's played in the past have annoyed the living crap out of me. But there was no such annoyance in sight with her portrayal of Louise in Arrival. Adams plays her exquisitely.

There is no dramatic speech about "this is our Independence Day." She doesn't scream and cry that the world is ending. Adams subtly and superbly plays a woman who is hiding a secret but doesn't know it. Adams is so good in fact, she had me singing "somebody is getting an Oscar nomination" all the way to my car.

The last thing I did with my evening was call my mum, because this movie makes you want to call your family. If you don't have a family, then it will make you call your friends. If you don't have friends, then it will make you search the skies for aliens to talk to.

Why? Because this epic Sci-Fi film is not really about the threat of aliens, it is about communication. It is about understanding each other and our differences. We are all asking the questions, do you hear me? Do you see me? Does what I am saying matter to you?

After watching Arrival, it was not a question of are we alone in the universe, it was a question of, why would we want to be? And if there is ever a day when extraterrestrials come down to Earth, if I'm still alive, then I will be the first to shake their hand - or tentacle - or whatever.

As famous philosopher Paulo Freire once said - "only through communication can human life hold meaning". Therefore isn't the meaning of life found through how we connect with each other, through love and understanding? (Woah, wait...did I just discover the meaning of life?)

This review was first published on Narrative Muse, http://narrativemuse.co/movies/arrival, and was written by Jules Raynes. Narrative Muse curates the best books and movies by and about women and non-binary folk on our website http://narrativemuse.co and our social media channels.

Arrival is a love letter to language. "Language is the foundation of civilization. It is the glue that holds a people together. It is the first weapon drawn in a conflict." Is the first line in a book by the main character who is a linguist given the duty of translating the language of an alien species. The real main character of the film is the Sappir-Whorf hypothesis which states that how we think is informed by our language. In the film one of the ways a nation tried to teach the aliens language is through the use of Shogi which is a Chess like game. If the aliens are only taught words related to a competitive game then they can only describe things in terms of competition. As the film puts it "Give them a hammer and everything is a nail" It makes the audience consider how language has effected our perspective and how we might be limited by it. What would a language look like if it had no limits and caused our perspective to shift in the direction of infinity? Words are intended to represent concepts, causality is a concept at the root of making predictions, if we understood causality perfectly and codified that understanding into language then we could accurately make predictions. In the film the aliens possess such a language and as a result predict the future.

Arrival is a very well written story being made by great directing and acting. But the catch is you won't appreciate it until you watch it for the 2nd time. The first time I watched it, I did not like it too much because much of the imagery made very little sense for me to understand what is going on enough to appreciate the style of story telling. It did not help this is not the kind of movie with action-packed thriller to keep you interested while not knowing what is going on. But after I learned the twist towards the end from the first time, and watched it again for the 2nd time, everything became crystal clear, which finally allowed me to appreciate the brilliance in the way the director/writers chose to do the story telling. It is a pretty risky choice from commercial success stand point. But I have to applaud those involved to stick with the artistic choice to make this film. If you don't have patience/time to watch this movie twice, this is one of the rare instance where it is actually better for you to learn about the plot twist spoiler before watching this film.

Arrival is a misleading movie. The film will make you think one thing and then another, all while having a great cast and a weak story. Arrival is probably one of my least favorite movies of 2016, which I haven't watched until now. Here is my non-spoiler review of Arrival.

9/10 points go to the ACTING category. Amy Adams, Jeremy Renner, Forrest Whitaker, and friends give great performances. Adams makes a convincing character who's name I have already forgotten. Renner plays Ian, who is the only reason there is one point off from this category. He literally gives a stupid and idiotic delivery for his last line of the film. I won't say it, as it is a spoiler to the end.

4/15 points goes to the WRITING category. The story is basic. Weird aliens come to Earth, people want to know what they are, and Amy Adams is seeing stuff she can't explain. The first 30 minutes of the film and any sequence with the aliens is amazing. The rest is pretty bad. History is determined, but Adams doesn't know what to do/say. Adams is seeing stuff, but doesn't even care about what it is. There are even parts where it seems like present and unknown tense are coming together. The story is not written to well.

10/10 points go to the VISUAL EFFECTS category. The aliens look real, and so do the shells. No problems here like about everything else.

4/10 points go to the CHARACTERS category. The characters are basic. We get little development from them. There is a tiny bit of development for Adams and Ian, but I won't tell you because it is a spoiler. Many people can only be called "people who scream and complain a lot", which is pretty basic.

2/5 points go to the DEVELOPMENT category. There is a bit of a conflict and a bit of a compromise. There is a bit of an answer to a question that doesn't get answered. There are a lot of plot holes. This movie also, as I previously said, has a bit of character development which is a spoiler.

2/5 points go to the ORIGINAL MUSIC SCORE category. The score is basic, it is very noticeable most of the time, and that is a bad thing. I didn't find the score at all or even a bit interesting. 

3/5 points go to the DESIGN category. The design in a bit cool I guess. It is a bit original and is a bit lame at the same time. It is pretty dark sometimes, and I don't like that. I like the movie's way of showing that things are a bit rushed within the way that things are unorganized. I don't know if that was or wasn't untended by the director.

10/10 points go to the DIRECTION category. Everything that seems planned is done well. Most of the delivery is pretty good. Yeah. That's about all I have to say about the direction of this movie. Nothing stands out.

4/10 points go to the VISION AND SOUND QUALITY category. You can barely hear the actors for most of the movie. The movie is very dark for many scenes which is pretty bad. Some of the scenes do look good. The editing is also pretty bad for most of the film's random vision scenes that Adams is having.

7/20 points go to the MY OVERALL CONSENSUS category. The film is boring, seems unorganized, and overall, I thought it was pretty bad.
