I hereby officially announce the beginning of the Oscar race, let the fight begin! It took a while this year! Gosh, as soon as this movie arrives it begs to be praised and saying what makes it good is as easy as understanding quantum physics. First of all, you have to understand that, more than anything, this is a character study. No, it's not a movie about aliens, an invasion, or even a conflict between beings from outer space and humans. It's primarily about a character and her inner conflict and psyche. We're start to finish with Louise to learn of what she makes of what's happening around her and how that is changing her. This is done beautifully in Sicario and in that sense it seems pretty similar the way we follow Kate (from Sicario) and Louise, making sure that we're constantly enthralled in order to understand them. This is done by shifting a little bit of the attention from what surrounds Louise to her expression and by having a performance to match it. No surprise there, but Amy Adams just blows it out of the park giving a subtle and realistic performance that is absolutely translucent to the character's inner state. Many haven't noticed, but Amy is the new Leo, having 5 nominations and no win but this season, whether with this one or Nocturnal Animals, I believe she has a good shot of getting that gold! Furthermore, this film not only has a fantastically substantiated script and plot, but also has the technical side to support it: the cinematography is rich and very identifiable, the sound design is well thought out and the aliens and ship's design is marvellous. The music is also close to perfection as Jóhannsson accentuates and gives even more meaning to important moments, and keeps quiet when he should. I also like that this movie takes such a fresh approach to the genre, as it manages to make a film about a translator actually damn gripping! I'm a fan of this trend of intellectual astute sci-fi movies that is being developed recently. And like Interstellar, this one comes with an even better grounded and believable twist.  The end gives meaning to the film, making it more than just about some aliens, but about communication, loss and the way we conceive time. Never this year have I felt the need to see a film exactly after I saw it and Arrival is, undoubtedly, the best movie I saw this post-Oscar year. Please, if there's a movie to spend money on right now, this is it!

[Ger Review]
Kommunikation als wichtigstes Instrument der Welt. Gerade in der Zeit des Internets ist es möglich mit jedem Menschen auf der Welt zu kommunizieren, da ist es verständlich, dass es auch Missverständnisse gibt. Dass diese aufgrund von Übersetzern gelöst werden können ist offensichtlich. Aber wie geht man mit Lebewesen um, die eine komplett unerforschte Sprache sprechen? Dieses Thema setzt Arrival brillant um. Er konzentriert sich komplett auf die ersten Interaktionen zwischen der Menschheit und den Aliens, ohne dabei in eine CGI-Schlacht auszuarten, Dabei ist er keineswegs langweilig. Es steh immer eine Spannung im Raum und man möchte die ganze Zeit wissen, warum die Aliens auf der Erde sind und was sie den Menschen mitteilen wollen. Amy Adams kauf man die Rolle der Linguistin und Jeremy Renner die Rolle des Physikers auf jeden Fall ab.Der Film bietet großartige Bilder und einen überwältigenden Sound. Auch die Musik ist sehr schön. An dem Film gibt es eigentlich nur auszusetzen, dass er anfangs ein wenig zu langsam beginnt (dabei aber auch nicht langweilig ist). Ein Film den man auf jedenfalls gesehen haben muss! 9/10

So are they trying to say that the reasons that the aliens were here were to task us with a linguistics puzzle requiring human collaboration/unification to solve which would then be rewarded with the gift of a "crystal ball" language? Oh those crafty aliens always have something up their sleeve. That's quite a reach of a premise and for serious sci-fi, doesn't pass the sniff test. I would think an advanced alien race would have a much more direct, less puzzling approach - nice try, I guess. I must say I love Amy Adams and will faithfully watch any movie she's in start to finish as I'm very fond of her delicate, thoughtful style. She is excellent in this and carries the movie all by herself. If you have the patience to wait until the puzzle gets solved and can deal with the far-fetched premise, you may enjoy this.

They went a bit over the top creating a foreboding, depressive mood. The overall production seemed low budget, perhaps the need for dark, blurry scenes and much of the dramatic action in a tent. The arc of the climax seemed a lot like Interstellar, seeing the future vs. time dilation, the future phone conversation vs. the pocket watch and quantum entanglement, both saving the day. As all good stories the guy got the girl in the end.

At its core Arrival is not an alien movie but, as the featured image suggests, a human movie. It's a movie about the power of humanity and our need to overcome divisive rhetoric and fear in order to survive. It's especially poignant in the current U.S. political climate, when it's not difficult to imagine a historically significant event bringing us to the edge of catastrophe.

It's hard to find fault in any aspect of this movie, so instead, I'll stick to what works well. Amy Adams' initially flat performance is incredibly nuanced - don't disregard her as a contender for Best Actress. The sound mixing and score are beautifully handled, creating a space for the movie to breath and feel and exist without shoving emotions down the audience's throat. The cinematography is stunning, aided by beautiful scenery and near-flawless visual effects.

Finally, screenwriter Eric Heisserer (previously wasted on projects like The Thing and Final Destination 5) handles the source material from the sci-fi short story "Story of Your Life" with aplomb. I'm seeking out an original copy of the story now, to see how much he adapted, and how much was just not screwing it up (a real danger in Hollywood these days, no matter the quality of the source).

I'm on the edge of my seat eager for the Academy Award nominations (three days!) to see how many Arrival pulls in. Simultaneously, it won't surprise me if this low-budget, indie film is too nuanced to get the recognition it deserves. Never fear - I may not be the Academy or Roger Ebert, but this movie has my full endorsement.

Arrival is a film that challenges you to change your perspective-- on alien invasion films, on sci-fi, on time, and on life. It's an incredible film studded with everything that makes films great: the directing, the acting, the cinematography, the writing, the score, all of it. Adams brings her best in the lead role, somehow playing both reserved and in your face and creating enough nuance that the rewatch feels like an entirely different film. The real hero of this film however is Denis Villeneuve who directs every shot, conversation, and reveal with impeccable precision, further cementing his reputation as one of the best directors of the age. Arrival is a near flawless film that will excite you, intrigue you, and break your heart.

Amy Adams and Jeremy Renner shine in their separate roles, especially Adams who becomes the person we always want to be... a human with a soul. I was impressed with this movie. Though it was a little too slow for my personal tastes, I cannot deny the artistry that went into it. The movie did a great job of balancing the process of deciphering the language of the aliens with the tension provided by increasing unrest. At the end I was worried that the plot was going full Interstellar, but they actually pulled it off and made it mostly make sense. If the end of Interstellar made 40%-50% sense, Arrival made 95% sense. Amy Adams gives a great performance as usual.

If I have one nitpick, it's that the movie takes a while to get going. They do a masterful job of building the tension before we see the ships and then before we see the aliens, but I would have preferred it had been a bit faster. In particular, the sequence where they go up the man lift the first time drags on for quite a bit.

Overall, I would recommend this for anybody looking for a thoughtful sci-fi movie.

The Arrival of a Lifetime

In Denis Villeneuve's movie, Arrival, linguist Louise Banks (Amy Adams) is the United States' last hope to prevent a catastrophic world war. Upon the arrival of 12 massive, foreign ships, the world becomes plagued with chaos and fear. Throughout this sci-fi, Inception-esc film, the unexpectant viewer is taken on a high-intensity, unpredictable, and yet, perfectly engineered rollercoaster of excitement and suspense. 

However, one cannot review this movie without mentioning the inspiration behind it: "The Story of Your Life". This is a short story novella written by Ted Chiang that is centered around language. Chiang's inspiration for this novella was the philosophical theory of free will. To incite further thoughts, Chiang poses the question, "If you know what's going to happen, can you keep it from happening?"   This century old ethical question is addressed in Chiang's novella. 


This exciting production takes place in the barren plains of Montana, where professor of linguistics Louise Banks and her team are tasked with an urgent, classified assignment. She is asked to put to test her extensive knowledge and skills of language and translation in just a short period of time; that is, before other countries lose faith in each other and begin pointing their fingers. While diligently working to complete such an extensive task, professor Banks is afflicted by an unknown, futuristic paradigm of what language will entail one day. However, it becomes apparent that the extraterrestrials haven't come for any reason other than to save themselves. 

This review, while not full of complete story lines and time frames, is in simple words, a spoiler. 

The method the extraterrestrials use to save themselves is unexpected by most viewers. This large-scale theme is perfectly illustrated in a single scene. The scene commences with an unauthorized military man entering the alien ship and placing C4 within the chamber of communication. Without this knowledge, Dr. Banks and her associate, Ian Donnelly (Jeremy Renner), rush to the pod in attempt to decipher the alien language. As the C4 explosive is about to detonate, the alien sacrifices itself to preserve the life of Dr. Banks and Ian Donnelly. Ironically, however, Dr. Banks is the only person capable of deciphering, understanding, and later, teaching this completely foreign language. Even more so, it is precisely this language that will save the alien species from utter extinction by allowing those who know such language to see the future.  

With this ability to see into the future, the viewer finally comes to an understanding of the continuous, what-seem-to-be flashbacks troubling Dr. Banks. Indeed, such visions are not flashbacks by any sense of word; they are, in fact, the polar opposite: flash-forwards. Throughout the entirety of the movie, Dr. Banks develops a continuously growing knowledge of the alien language and, for that reason begins to see into the future, which contains glimpses of her current unborn daughter. 

These reoccurring visions illustrate a deep sense of humility and maturity in Louise Banks. Knowing that her daughter is going to be born with a terminal illness, she happily accepts fate and looks forward to cherishing every moment with her future daughter. Beyond that, if this language allows for future knowledge, the extraterrestrials' knowledge is no confined to time. Simply put, they know their future. They know that C4 is going to explode and injure them. However, just like Louise Banks, they knowingly accept this fate. 

With a language like this, what is the limit? When knowledge isn't limited to the bounds of time who's to say what can and cannot be accomplished? On the other side, are humans mature and moral enough to accept this almost all-empowering language? This also alludes to Ted Chiang's novella and the inspiration behind it. Exists free will? If so, can one prevent the known future? All of these are questions that rise from this movie. 

Because of these "flash-forwards", Arrival takes on this Inception-like plot twist at the end. It is truly intriguing. Inception was a dream within a dream, induced by a particular party of interest, and used to influence a man's decision for the party's own benefit. Likewise, Arrival is a flash-forward, revealed by the extraterrestrials to Dr. Banks for their own interest. The reason the aliens show her these "flash-forwards" is to merely convince her to learn their language and therefore, be the architect of their future salvation. 

Regardless of comparisons, this was a perfectly executed film. How often does one witness a professor of linguistics as a "save-the-day", hero type character in a movie? On top of that, the portrayal of genuine, pleasant aliens is a scarce sight in today's world. Although their actions reflected self-indulged motives, the extraterrestrials came to give humanity a tool: their language. 

While completely enthralled by this film, certain questions came to mind. What happens to humanity over the next 3000 years, prior to the saving of these aliens? How does their language affect modern society and technology? What was so strong as to threaten the existence of these advanced extraterrestrials 3000 years from the time of the film? Of course, being a science fiction enthusiast, the idea of a sequel, prequel, or anything in-between this movie's timeline is captivating.     

All in all, this brilliant depiction of extraterrestrials and linguistics merged together forms what is now one of the most authentic, captivating films within the science fiction genre. In a single word, brilliant. This movie was nothing short of brilliance. The original integration of a linguist savior for an alien species is captivating, exciting, and refreshing.

Alexander Lawrence
Sproat
22 October 2017

Arrival of this movie review. 

	What if you could perceive time all at once? What if you could know the past, present, and future? "If you could see your life from start to finish, would you change things?" said Dr. Louise Banks, main character played by Amy Adams in the movie "Arrival" 
The movie is extremely well put together and makes one think deeply about what is going on in movie as well as that their life means to them. Dr. Banks made the discovery that the language of those arrived does not represent sound or speech like the languages we know today but rather meaning and complete thoughts. She said "When you learn it you begin to perceive time as they do. 
"I used to think this (speaking of birth) was the beginning of your story. Memory is a strange thing, It doesn't work like I thought it did. We are so bound by time, by its order. I remember moments in the middle. And this was the end. But now i'm not so sure i believe in beginnings and endings. There are days that define your story beyond your life. Like the day they arrived." 
The movie has an extremely deep message. As Louise learns the language of the heptapods, she, like them, begins to perceive time as all at once, knowing past, present and future. She uses this ability to provoke our finite minds into contemplating the idea of seeing our lives from start to finish and if we would change things. It is implied that many of us would indeed change some aspect of our lives if we were to know the big picture, thus, teaching us to be wise in our decisions and relationships to not have any regrets. 
4.5 stars because the acting was semi good in the beginning but improved throughout the movie.

This movie contained half written points almost from start to finish.  She learned their language- okay, fine.  But no one else did, despite her sharing everything with the brightest minds on the planet.  She also explained her ability to see through time as being something gained from learning their language, yet again, she was the only one who could do it despite all 12 pieces being shared with the brightest minds... and she could only see to the point of her having a baby.  The aliens themselves existed outside of linear time yet the one that died was never seen beyond that linear point in time.  And the aliens simply left without a goodbye once the planet decided not to destroy them.  All in all, a very boring movie.

Arrival, directed by Denis Villeneuve is such a different and interesting film to watch. Reading from a book by Dr. Banks, Ian Donnelly (Jeremy Renner) says, "Language is the foundation of civilization. It is the glue that holds people together. It is the first weapon drawn in a conflict." Which is true, very true in this movie the meanings of the languages that which Dr. Banks reveals them is such a beautiful thing to watch. In the beginning it is very difficult to understand what is going on, but the details and scenes that are shown to help you get a better understanding of why this is happening is very touching to the heart. It amazes me the abilities that Dr. Louise Banks (Amy Adams) has in the film and her discovery of why this is all happening across the world. She did a very risky thing to reveal the reason behind their arrival. And she opposes one question that really makes you think, "If you could see your whole life from start to finish, would you change things?" Overall, I am amazed by the way in which this film was portrayed and I would definitely recommend this to anyone I know because it make you think a lot about your life.

The name Denis Villeneuve is quickly becoming synonymous with great films. The man who directed Sicario, Prisoners, and Blade Runner 2049, brought us this smart tale of humans attempting to communicate with aliens. The premise sees a linguist (Amy Adams) and physicist (Jeremy Renner) work together with the government in an attempt to communicate with the invaders from another world. I appreciated that the story focused on that aspect instead of some fight with the other beings. The fact that we never know what the aliens or military members with Adams and Renner would do, made for some great tense scenes. There's a particular one with a ticking bomb that stood out as excellent. Adams shines above everything else with one of the best performances of her career. She portrays her desperation to understand these creatures, in the midst of some haunting visions, expertly. She and Renner played off each other well. There are some pacing issues, as things moved at a crawl in a few of the scenes towards the middle, but it picks up with a great ending. The twist is fantastic, though once it becomes clear they still wait a bit to reveal a bit of an obvious part. An original take on the alien concept, beautifully shot and handled by a skilled director and led by top notch actors.
Love Amy Adams Performance.

Smart and visually arresting science fiction tale about earth's first contact with aliens. Mysterious floating monoliths appear around the world and linguist Amy Adams, with help of physicist Jeremy Renner, work with the government to try and communicate with the aliens amid global fears and international political tensions. This story is more "Close Encounters" and "Contact" than "Independence Day" or "War of the Worlds," where the main focus of the story is on how to communicate with the aliens, while reassuring the military brass, primarily Forrest Whittaker, that everything is okay and they don't have to attack. This tension of whether they can successfully communicate and avert a conflict with this new species (and whether other countries around the world might tip off an interstellar as well) makes for good ticking time bomb of dramatic tension, but it's really Adams who give the film an emotional human center, desperately wanting to connect with to these advances creatures, while at the same time is haunted by visions of her daughter. Directed by Denis Villeneuve, who's next project was the new Blade Runner film, brings a strong visual style to the proceeding, but never in a way that is distracting to the story or style for the sake of style. My only complaint about the film is that it does move at a rather glacial pace, though in the end, the film does deliver with a terrific mind-bending of an ending, that makes the wait well worth it. Overall, "Arrival" is not a film for anyone wanting slam-bang science fiction, but is great if you're in the mood for something along the lines of "Solaris" or "Moon."
poor quality, good acting

SPOILER ALERT....



Ok. ready? This is NOT a sci-fi movie. This is a movie about if you knew what your life would hold would you change anything? Its a very well done movie but heartwrenchingly sad.

TRIGGER WARNING: involves childhood cancer/death.

This movie was amazing. It was absolutely beautiful and so unlike the dystopian alien massacre movies that dominate this category. It was refreshing and captivating- near perfect. I would highly suggest watching this movie if you want to feel both inspired and challenged. It's not as predictable as a lot of other mainstream movies; they give you just enough plot points and knowledge to follow a thread but not enough to draw all-telling solid conclusions (most of the time). The only major thing I had an issue with was:
**Warning: major spoiler ahead!**
The fact that Ian left Louise over something so petty!
I say 'petty' rightfully because this is an advanced scientist who has openly communicated with aliens, defied gravity, and knows that Louise can see the future (because obviously you don't just shield someone from a bullet while you listen to them speak Mandarin and save the world without questioning their actions later). 
He is this accepting of everything around him but yet he simply can't accept that his daughter will die early of cancer? We all die in the end- does that make life pointless or does it free us to enjoy what we have? If our lives were already written out would that make our actions hollow or valuable experiences we should really give ourselves into?
It really surprised me that a man of his understanding, acceptance, and intelligence left Louise over the pain of knowing his daughter will die early of cancer- and that Louise chose to have her anyways.
Most parents wouldn't trade anything in the world for even a minute of their child's life- would he have rather not had her at all than get to enjoy her beautiful life and fill his heart with love for her? 
I mean I get his divorce from her is used as a plot device to 1. Keep the pieces of the story from coming together too quickly, and 2. To demonstrate to the audience that things like the probability/knowing of death and heart break shouldn't keep us from following our hearts. 
BUT STILL. It pisses me off. I hate that such a seemingly deep character made such a shallow choice. Hannah always has been, and always will be theirs. Nothing in the world could've ever changed that- dead or alive, she always belonged to them. Before she had even existed she was theirs. 
e.g.
I wouldn't say I made the wrong choice picking my dog out as a puppy if I knew he was going to die of a degenerative disease 13 years later. I love him more than I can handle, and he will always hold a piece of my heart. Forever. No dog I would've picked out would live for eternity- and would I sacrifice the love I have for him specifically and the life he's lead for the sake of avoiding heartbreak? Never. 
You can't fight life- you can only embrace it and accept it for what it is.

You should not watch Arrival, because everything you need to know about the movie is right on the cover: Amy Adams staring solemnly into the distance, while Jeremy Renner gazes longingly. Oh yeah there's aliens that apparently deserve better placement than the black guy from Battleship Earth (arguably a better alien in that movie than the Cthulhu Heptapod things were in this one.)  

What makes this movie terrible, and not just able to be avoided unless you need some background noise for Netflix and Chill, is that your primal lizard brain really wants to like it.  The visuals are on fleek, and the score is one of those maudlin pastoral dirges that make you want to go to bed and die.  Speaking of dying, Amy Adams' kid dies.  That's not a spoiler because that's literally how the movie opens.  Just throws it right out there on the Thanksgiving dinner table.    It's gonna be a real depressing 2 hours, and don't you regret not clicking on the Avengers instead because, of course, now SHE wants to see what happens since dying children are like glue traps for millennial chicks and you're too invested at this point.

As for the rest of the synopsis, there are these aliens that come to earth in twelve of those old native american grind stones that you had to smash corn with when your 6th grade class visited that pioneer village, and they speak only in coffee stains.  Swear to God you're going to watch it not believing me and then go, "Oh damn, he wasn't kidding like when he said Eleven dies in Stranger Things 2."  Evidently these coffee stains allow you to see the future ONLY IF YOU ARE AMY ADAMS despite the fact that Jeremy Renner did just as much work and actually cracked the fact that the only way to save the world was to embrace this clumsy allegory for Globalism.  Where's your pay gap now, ladies?

So Amy and Jeremy try to stop Forrest Whitaker from blowing up the grindstone squids despite the fact that one of the Heptapods says something in Caffeinese translates to "Use Weapon" and that's usually the time the aliens should have actually stepped back and thought, "Oh hell, that was probably a really stupid thing to choose as our first words to a militarily developed native race in whose yard we happen to be parked illegally."  She eventually steals a phone and tells THE ONLY MILITARY GENERAL IN CHINA EVIDENTLY what his wife said right before she died and as they say in China, "If you can remember what my wife told me on her death bed, then I have to call off my alien war."  So he tells future Amy Adams his personal phone number knowing that present day Amy Adams would then know it because when red headed white girls bust out fluent Mandarin, you suddenly learn everything about FTL Time Travel (which this claimed to be but absolutely wasn't).

Oh yeah, also also Amy Adams keeps going back and forth in time every time she reads what the aliens are saying like she's having photosensitive time-seizures.  It's not confusing however, just remember that every time you see her with her kid, that part of the movie is completely vestigial to the main story and cutting it out would actually make everyone feel better.

So the aliens take Amy Adams up into their ship, and basically lay out the whole plot of the movie in subtitles because the director of this movie spent way too much time reminding everyone who watches this movie that humans are flawed, and are capable of getting sick and dying at a young age.  Oh yeah, and she goes from knowing about 4 words in Coffee stain/Caffeinese/whatever to being able to carry on entire existential discussions with aliens capable of INTERPLANAR TRAVEL yet know dick about grammar and conjugation, and talk like they came from super advanced albeit somehow still REALLY into Frank Lloyd Wright squid world on a J1 Study Visa.  Whole thing is just silly.

Oh yeah, and instead of deciding not to have a child so as to prevent it from suffering a horrible death, and just explain it to Jeremy Renner who will believe her because she just made the aliens go away and those people probably would know stuff like that,  she voice-overs this whole thing about embracing the inevitable because as soon as Jeremy Renner admits that he loves her he also leans in and Whispers Joe Biden-style, "I want to put a baby in you", or "let's make a baby," or something super appropriate for a pre-first date phase of courtship.  

And then it literally ends.  And you're trying to conceal the genuine fury that Hollywood had the nerve to put a SCI-FI label on a Nicholas Sparks story.  What did the aliens eat?  What forms of government did they have on squid world?  Why did they talk in coffee circles?  what was the magic intelligent ink that they used to talk made of?  can you send me the PDF on how to learn that language so I can (trigger warning) Trump my friends who brag about knowing Tolkien Elvish.  These are the questions that should at least be teased with the hint of an answer if you're going to qualify as a legit science fiction film.  

But no.  All we learned about the aliens is they really like to see Amy Adams cry.
How did this movie get such great reviews??  This movie was horrible, boring, anticlimactic and had an ending that made absolutely no sense.   Waste of time.

So..."Arrival" was basically the 2007 Sandra Bullock movie "Premonition" combined with "Close Encounters of the 3rd Kind." Cinematically, it was pretty. Story/Plot-wise, it was predictable and boring. I fell asleep watching it.

Another sign of the times: the Chinese are our friends despite some initial misunderstandings. It's not a bad film but in trying to make a popcorn movie with a PhD it rather falls between the two.

On the strength of the director Denis Villeneuve's repertoire, more specifically his previous outing Sicario (my favourite film of 2015 hands down!) and with a age old movie premise and a stellar cast ,this academy award nominated movie is one that had intrigued me before viewing and left in awe long after. This director is undoubtedly on top of his game (Blade Runner 2049 promises great things in his hands!) and this movie is another shining example of the impressive catalogue being constructed by this maverick movie maker!
The film itself deals with twelve mysterious spacecraft's arrivals across the globe. A cross section skilled team--lead by expert linguist Louise Banks (Amy Adams) are brought together to investigate the reason behind their visit. As the world teeters on the brink of global war, Banks and the team race against time for answers. 
What transpires is a Spielberg/Nolanesque two hour emotive, powerful and visually stunning piece that is lifted to extra heights due the extraordinary performance of Amy Adams (how she wasn't nominated for this is simply beyond me!) who brings both strength and vulnerability to her magnificent role!
Twists and turns aplenty the viewer is constantly engaged and the spectacular cinematography also adds to the wonderful film on show.
Quite simply a must see experience, a film with lofty ambitions that it pulls of quite brilliantly!
A great film to leave you pondering the human experience.

Arrival is a really neat idea for a film. A language professor must communicate with aliens that have arrived, and figure out why they're here. The film has some stellar acting, and a neat premise. The payoff, however...well, you'll see.

The process of the first two-thirds of the movie is really neat. The slow build-up of understanding the language is shown very well, with Adams giving a great performance. I also enjoy the interplay between her and Forest Whitaker, the career army man.

I take issue with Jeremy Renner's character. It is not made plain in the entire film why he is there. He's supposed to a scientist, and he is shown doing scientisty things, but they have no effect whatsoever on the plot. It might have been a good idea to pull back the focus to flesh out the mission a little more.

Once we get to the third act, the big sci-fi reveal happens. Here's the problem: you've already established a certain level of strangeness in the film, and this third act adds a whole new layer. It really pulls the rug out from under you. It might work for someone who was ready for that level of sci-fi, but I was not. It got really complex, really fast, and I felt whiplash while watching it.

It left a bad taste in my mouth, and looking back now a few weeks later, doesn't seem as egregious (hence the largely-positive rating). In the moment, it really took me out, though.

If our first contact with an alien race turns out to be as boring as this movie, then  I hope it doesn't happen.   Big disappointment considering the nominations,  which makes it one of the most overrated movies of 2016.   Their ships look stupid, the aliens themselves look stupider,  and there's generally a lack of awe  at this event.  Only Jeremy Renner shows any signs of life, everyone else is sleepwalking including Amy Adams  who is blander than Top 40 radio.   She's a highly skilled linguist recruited by the military to communicate with these aliens, but none of her studying makes any difference as her only breakthroughs occur through memory flashes interacting with her daughter.  Naturally the military gets trigger-happy solely in order to inject some form of tension which is utterly predictable.  There's a fairly nifty revelation at the very end, but it's relied upon far too heavily to have a Shyamalan effect and cannot salvage the dreary experience until then.  I enjoy heady sci-fi like Ex Machina and Interstellar as recent examples, but Arrival comes up well short with the only truly clever aspects being the aliens' writing method and the title.  Opt for another viewing of Close Encounters instead.

Arrival is excellent on every level from Amy Adams' performance, to the music, sound design, the script, the cinematography and the plot as a whole. Arrival centres around an alien presence that has arrived on earth and humanity's response to it. Amy Adams' character, Dr. Louise Banks and Jeremy Renner's character, Ian Donnelly, are called upon by US forces to try and communicate with two of the new alien lifeforms and establish why they are here. It's a very refreshing depiction of an alien encounter, focussing on language and communication rather than a run of the mill action or horror trope. This is a very interesting look at humanity and time and it is definitely worth watching.
A different take on an alien invasion.

my favorite film <3

Amy Adams lifts this science-fiction drama to new heights.  She plays a renowned linguist who is summoned by the United States Government to attempt to communicate with extraterrestrial forces that have landed.  The intent in this film, however shocking, is not scary.  Adams is unremittingly believable as the linguist who leads a team into new territory with the understanding of language.  She makes split-second decisions that could alter her life and the lives of those around her.  The message at the end is as profound as any that a film could make.  A seemingly effortless foray into a new direction for science-fiction filmmaking.

Finally, a Hollywood sci-fi alien movie with a linguist as the hero!

I don't even remember the last time I give 5.0 out of 5.0 rating for a film on RottenTomatoes, but the film "Arrival" definitely deserves this perfect rating. Seeing this film is like discovering a holy grail for students and fans of linguistics alike. As a polyglot, I love being able to see a sci-fi depicting a linguist trying to figure out an alien's language and the consequences of being able to communicate in their language.

I profoundly appreciate the fact that Hollywood is able to explore the theme of alien visitation without having to rehash the heap of manure in form of "Alien Attacks!!!" or how an "American Superhero saves the world from those alien overlords!!!" that has oversaturated the monde of American films in recent decades.

Amy Adams' emotional performance as the linguist (and as the only character who matters in the film, really) also helps to bridge the aliens to humans...and bridge the aliens' language to the viewers of the film.

In a way, this cerebral theme of alien sci-fi is reminiscent of Interstellar (except for the fact that the "alien" in Interstellar is of a completely different entity...I don't want to reveal spoilers here), in a way that the opening of the film provides major clues to the key of the plot.

Because, as the film "Arrival" reveals later on, the key to life and everything else may lie closer to us than we think.

Although it sometimes lays on the exposition a bit too thickly, Arrival is a uniquely mind-bending and slow-burning take on the alien-maybe-invasion genre. I am genuinely really surprised at the praise this movie has been given, because my opinion on this movie is completely different. I have to be honest, I didn't like "Arrival". I am really confused as to why people seem to love it so much, because the entire movie was a snooze for me. It didn't seem to really have anything actually interesting in it, and personally I just got extremely bored with it. I will say, Amy Adams (Dr. Louise Banks) did a great job in this movie, her role was definitely difficult to pull off, but she did it marvellously, and to me she was the best part of this movie. The movie is about an alien landing on earth, and the whole movie is about the entire world trying to figure out these alien's purpose of landing on our planet, and to figure out whether or not these aliens are harmful. When they try to find out these alien's purpose, however, the movie completely drags on, for what feels like forever. They are slowly piecing the puzzle together, but I just felt as though they did it in a way that was incredibly boring, and didn't at all capture my interest in the story. It does slightly pick up towards the end, however because the beginning was so boring to me I just didn't really care much for it at that point. I really am shocked with how high this movie is rated, because personally, I think that "Arrival" is definitely not worth watching.
Eerie, complex and admittedly a little peculiar, Arrival is Dennis Villeneuve's beautifully told sci-fi craft.
It could have been interesting as the concept and the aliens are pretty cool, but the painfully slow pacing and lifeless performances made it an ordeal to sit through.
An intelligent and engaging film lead by a strong performance from Amy Adams.  A faithful adaptation of the short story perhaps takes itself a little too seriously but it is definitely worth a watch!

I thought the movie started out well....it had my interest...it wasn't a typical sci fi movie....it explored a subject i find fascinating.....then it took a rough turn.  Could have ended much better and it took on a topic that I just struggle with (for purposes of not spoiling I won't say much more)
I put up with it the first time to see the aliens but when i saw it again i realized how bloody lame it is. too much romance, too much dreaming about your kids, not enough aliens!

I wasn't interested in seeing this in the cinemas. There was just something not quite right with the trailer, it really didn't make me go "Wow that looks brilliant" more so "Oh look, yet another Alien/Space movie." That being said, I am so glad I decided to watch it. Great storyline that allows the audience to become attached to the characters quickly and suspends belief in order for you to follow the ambitious plot line. Good performances all-round. Great SFX and brilliant soundtrack. Can see influences from Nolan and Spielberg here but that isn't a problem at all, and there is a definite hint of Hans Zimmer from the soundtrack. Thoroughly enjoyed this movie and what a pleasant surprise it was given my initial thoughts on it following the trailers. Highly recommend.

GREG: (Greg Smith, Founder of Agile Writers of Richmond, VA) Scott, it looks like we ve finally arrived 

SCOTT: (Dr. Scott Allison, Professor of Psychology, University of Richmond) ... and its about time. Literally. Let s get to reviewing this next movie about alien visitation.

GREG: We re introduced to Professor Leslie Banks (Amy Adams) who is having a strange day as 12  shells  (very large egg-shaped alien craft) have landed across the world. She s visited by a Colonel Webber (Forest Whitaker) who insists she help him translate the speech patterns of the aliens. She resists but ultimately gives in when her curiosity gets the better of her. She s whisked away to a midwest town where she is paired with theoretical physicist Ian Donnelly (Jeremy Renner) and must discover the reason for the alien visit.

SCOTT: Banks and Donnelly meet two of the aliens and nickname them Abbott and Costello. Communication seems impossible until Banks attempts written language. She discovers that the aliens  writing is composed of complex circular characters and sentences, and she also discovers that the more she deciphers the language, the more strange visions she has of herself raising a child. Meanwhile, in China, General Shang (Tzi Ma) is about to wage war with the aliens, making it imperative that Banks and Donnelly crack the code before disaster strikes.

GREG: Arrival is a film that arrived without much fanfare. I don t recall seeing any previews for it in the theaters or ads on TV. So, I had very few preconceptions going in. And I was pleasantly surprised. This is an arguably ponderous film with very little action and a lot of dialog. It s a thinking-man s movie, so it appealed to me. One of the opening scenes has physicist Donnelly reading Banks  book which states that all interactions begin with language. But he differs - claiming the basis for communication is science. Whereas Colonel Webber is looking at the situation from a tactical point of view. And so the stage is set for a three-way confrontation of ideals. And in the end, it is Banks  view that wins out. I was favorably impressed.

SCOTT: Greg, I loved Arrival. It s been a long time since we ve encountered a meaty science fiction story that really makes you think. I was struck by the possibility that our language is not so much a reflection of our linear thinking but a determinant of it. The temporal non-linearity of the aliens was fascinating and allowed for some truly creative plot developments. We re also treated to some wonderfully innovative renditions of aliens and alien language. Not to mention that Amy Adams delivers a terrific performance as a hero who must piece together the temporal puzzle to save the world. It all adds up to a stellar movie, pardon the pun.

GREG: Amy Adams was definitely the brightest star in this film. Her character Leslie Banks undergoes a strong transformation from disillusioned academic to an enlightened world figure. She also exhibits uncommon empathy for the aliens. She puts aside her innate fear of the unknown and is captivated by the question of what is the purpose of the alien visit. I found her very inspiring.

SCOTT: Banks definitely goes on an inspired hero s journey -- yet another example of Hollywood finally  getting it  that women characters can make tremendous heroes in the movies. The hero s journey begins with Banks answering the  call  from the military to make first contact with aliens who have landed in Montana. She immediately assumes a lead role in her partnership with Donnelly, a physicist on her team. Her missing quality is her understanding of the alien language, and the keys to her acquiring this quality are her openness to thinking outside the box, her trust that the aliens will do no harm, and her courage to defy the military s antagonistic approach to the alien encounter. Banks possesses many of the great eight characteristics of heroes; she is smart, strong, resilient, reliable, caring, inspiring, and selfless. In keeping with the hero s journey, she encounters a love interest (Donnelly), allies in Abbott, Costello, and oppositional forces in the military and CIA. Her mentors turn out to be the aliens themselves, who have arrived to help the earth understand and change their language and use of time. In exchange, the earth will help the aliens 3,000 years from now. Everything comes full circle, which is beautifully symbolized in the alien circular linguistic characters.

GREG: The aliens are good mentor figures here. And we also see that Banks acts as a hero-mentor in that she mentors the aliens in our language. After all, it is she who instructs the aliens, not the other way around. However, this does imply a bit of a plot hole. If the aliens are so advanced, why are they so dense in understanding our language? Compare to our own understanding of animal language. It is human researchers who have taught apes to speak American Sign Language. I would think it incumbent upon the more advanced civilization to find a way to communicate with us. Arrival is a departure from other first contact movies like Contact and Close Encounters of the Third Kind where language is the source of the communication. I enjoyed the slow burn from fear to understanding for all the characters in the story. I give Arrival 4 out of 5 Reels. Dr. Banks is a great hero who undergoes a transformation from naive to educated in the ways of the alien creatures. Like many heroes we ve studied in the last few years, she has a  super power  which in this case is the ability to understand language. But it is her human innate quality of empathy which endears Banks to us. I give her 4 out of 5 Hero points. And Banks is the most excellent hero-mentor. And when you join her with the superior alien-mentors we get a mentoring experience that goes beyond what most films offer. I give Banks and the aliens 4 out of 5 Mentor points. Movie: Mentors: Heroes:

SCOTT: Arrival is the science fiction you ve been looking for in film for several years now. Greg, the plot hole you identify is not so much a hole but the key to understanding the puzzle with which the aliens present humanity. Twelve shells arrive on earth, each with a different piece to the puzzle that the twelve earth stations must share to unravel the mystery. The idea is to bring humanity together in a non-zero-sum-game-like way. This guiding principle, along with stunningly crafted heptapods and their innovative language, make Arrival a treat to watch. I give this film the full 5 Reels out of 5. Louise Banks proves herself braver and smarter than all her male counterparts in both developing a working relationship with the aliens and in deciphering their cryptic language. She encounters friends who help her and foes who oppose her, and she undergoes a profound mental transformation. In our latest book Reel Heroes & Villains, we define a mental transformation as a significant change in the way that a hero views the workings of the universe. Banks now sees time, language, and thought as intertwined. She travels the full hero s journey, including the act of giving back to society what she has learned in the form of lectures and a book on the universal language of the heptapods. She earns the full 5 Heroes out of 5. The mentorship is also strong in this film, with the aliens mentoring Banks as well as the entire human race itself. Our planet is taught how essential it is for our survival to adopt a non-zero-sum philosophy in our international relations. You re right, Greg, that Banks also mentors the aliens -- although I suspect they intentionally adopted a passive stance in the first contact proceedings to force us to do the work of deciphering and cooperating with each other internationally. Oh, and let s not forget that the future Louise Banks mentored the present-day Louise Banks via many hallucinogenic messages. In short, the mentoring is rich in this film and also merits the full 5 Mentor points out of 5. Movie: Mentors: Heroes:

Boasting gorgeous visuals, a superb performance from Amy Adams and a very smartly written yet deceptively simple story that feels utterly realistic in its portrayal of events, 'Arrival' is a striking sci-fi for the thinking man. It's Villeneuve's direction, however, that really sets the tone for the whole film and, once again, he proves that he is one of the very best directors out there when it comes to creating a unique, palpable atmosphere that affects you in an almost visceral way. The deliberately slow-pacing allows the characters and story room to breathe, and the score is well-chosen: just subtle enough so as not to overpower the visuals whilst simultaneously heightening the effect of a particular scene. Mysterious, intriguing and affecting, this is a truly memorable film.
"If you could see your whole life from start to finish, would you change things?"

It's quite surprising that this film would get such a high RT score. I would have expected it to be more polarizing. Not much happens in the film and there's a lot of introspection and navel-gazing. And then there's the ending.... I imagine that hooked most people, though I'm not sure how I felt about it. Is this basically a good M Night Shamalan film...? You decide. Worth seeing on a quiet evening.

Kinda boring... sat through this waiting to see what the big deal was, and it was all so aliens could give Amy Adams a fucking thesaurus and show her her future dead daughter. Thanks a lot, Obama. Hehe
Simply amazing... One conversation can change your life, one conversation can change the world.

Confusing the first time I watched it. Better the second time. Very compelling story. It is a thinking man's movie. (don't read that as sexist, it is a comment like guys for a group of folks of both sexes)

Arrival is fantastic, thought provoking Sci-Fi about time, and the human condition, with a fantastic performance by Amy Adams, and sensitive, accomplished direction by Denis Villanueuve. My complaints with this wonderful, smart film lie with the slow first hour, that's still good, and interesting, but hurts a film that demands a repeat viewing. My second complaint comes from Jeremy Renner's character feeling more like a plot device, than an actual person. However, Despite those flaws, Arrival is still a truly great film, with a fantastic, emotional punch to the gut at the end. See it.

A must see, instant science fiction classic with a pleasantly surprising amount of cold, hard linguistics in it. Of course, corners were cut for some concepts simply because of time constraints (to be sure), but they were fleshed out enough for my liking. They didn't phone it in on the linguistics side of the story. The effects, sometimes breathtaking, not only fit the style of the film well, but also add so much to the overall quality of the movie because of the sheer realism and impressiveness of the CGI was nothing to scoff at. I give it a 9/10 because despite all of its obvious and sweeping victories, I felt some scenes between action points and developing character back story arcs were pretty slow, and it cut up the flow of the movie at the start. This negative became less apparent over time, and the end was certainly heavy to match the rest of the movie's vibe. Like I said, a must watch for anyone into sci fi and/or heady movies.
Inspiring! Stunning sound effects.

For once a symbolic story that goes against the typical vilified alien invasion type plot. A beautiful message linking advance communication and precognition skills. One of the most emotionally driven sci-fi movies of all time.
great acting and direction but the story is obviously stolen from others...just not as interesting as I would have hoped

A mind-binding approach to the usual alien landing type movies.  Don't expect a shoot-em-up - aliens killing everyone type film, there's more of a story here that keeps you to the final scene. It probably deserves better than my 3 star rating, it's just that I'm picky, but it is worth watching.
Interesting idea, but the whole future/past thing didn't make much sense. Also story felt a little thin
What a confusing mess.  This movie was loaded with suspense...and then had zero pay off.  This movie is easily one of the biggest wastes of time I've seen.

Beautiful, elegant, and it will rip your heart out and feed it back to you before the movie even hits the five minute mark. 
Then it will do it again. And again. 
Its implications are deeply emotional and thought-provoking, its message is difficult to put into words, and that's precisely what makes it so outstanding.
If you enjoy simple, clear-cut, linear stories- and, mind you, that's fine-, this movie is not for you. But if by chance you're looking for something with a little more to it, something substantial that will fill your appetite for heavy material and expand your understanding of the universe, watch it. 
And bring a box of tissues, just in case.
Thoughtful sci-fi drama with all the visual trappings of a blockbuster but none of the bombast. Engages the heart and the mind like all the best sci-fi.
Stats ok, body is great, ending is a bore

Good sci-fi slightly askews what we already know to be true. Good sci-fi does not need to violence, but understands its prevalence. Good sci-fi knows exactly when it's ok to be juvenile. 

This movie hit on every mark for me. Seldom do you watch a movie with high expectations and come out the other end completely satisfied and Arrival did just that. I can't believe it took me this long to see it.

Amy Adams is one of my favourite actresses so most of the stars go for her but I truly didn't find this movie appealing in many ways.  Some of the pacing was arduous in some places.  I am also getting sick and tired of some of America's political undertones of hierarchy, self-righteous heroism If I were from some of those countries they made into antagonists I would be slightly insulted only because this was pure fantasy sci-fi - not based on any historical fact or events.  Presuming how other countries will respond or react to an alien "arrival" is pompous.
This movie is moving, well thought out, beautifully presented, and a wonderful performance but Adams. The best movie of 2016 and 2017.

Interesting concept. It took a sensitive nurturer to figure it out and make communication universal and beneficial. Time continuum is neither here or there. Difficult to grasp the ramifications but this movie gave it a good spin. The movie is a bit slow. It takes it's time to make some important revelations.

Slow-moving, dying-to-be highbrow sci-fi flick with little payoff. Plenty of atmosphere, plenty of intrigue but, inevitably, plenty of questions and convenient plot jumps. Looks great, but ultimately, unsatisfying.

The movie tries to capture large, all-encompassing themes, however only delivers re-hashed premises oft-times visited in myriad sci-fi television episodes & film. Akin to mind-blowing speculation long ago postulated in 'Twilight Zone' & 'Outer Limits' television-series episodes (many of which were adapted from acclaimed short stories), 'Arrival' seems so full of its own grandeur, the plot & direction simply becomes a plodding & boring snooze. This is in no way a landmark film, by script, special effects, or direction, however Ms. Adams' performance may be considered laudable.

Science fiction has gotten a slight bit stale and predictable as of late, and even though it's my favorite genre it's hard to stomach movies that use sci-fi as a means to go full ham on spectacle.  That stuff is enjoyable, but it lacks impact.  Arrival is one film that really bucks that trend, plays with your expectations, and ultimately is an incredible story told in a very unconventional way.  There's a terrific story to be told with a strong central theme at its core, but I won't go near any explanations for fear of spoiling the ingenious twist.  Amy Adams and Jeremy Renner both have fantastic performances throughout, and really offer a terrific look at the characters and how they develop throughout the course of the film.  A chilling, ethereal soundtrack accompanies the whole film and an excellent audio mix bring the contemplative movie to life.  Arrival is clever science fiction that is insanely engrossing from start to finish.
A nice blend of art-house and sci-fi with satisfying results.
One of the worst movies I have ever saw.
Fascinating to watch but I'm not quite sure what the synopsis is referring to with the life threatening choice or mind-blowing ending.
gg gud but lacks weiners and pus

The past few years have saw multiple massive sci-fi films released, such as Gravity and Interstellar. When I first heard about Arrival, I expected it to have the same impact on me as the other two had; intriguing, but I didn't think too much about them afterwards. Luckily, I was wrong about that, as Arrival proved to be one of the most fascinating, thought-provoking films of 2016. Amy Adams (Batman vs. Superman) had a fantastic year in movies (even after the film that I just linked her with), and she owns the screen in this movie. The story, when several massive monolith-style ships arrive (surprise) on Earth and humans attempt to both communicate with the creatures inside and work together as a unified planet, keeps you guessing at every turn. The imagery and cinematography is stunning and keeps your eyes glued to the screen by its sheer spectacle. This extremely smart movie will keep you on your toes and will have you thinking about it well after it is over. Give it a watch and experience it for yourself.

When this was released at the cinema last year it did not stand out as a must see film and I was surprised when I read so many 5 star reviews afterwards.  I had seen the 2 lead actors in many films before but neither of them have ever been in any films I would rate this highly and so this completely surprised me, it was unlike anything I was expecting.
The film is about the arrival of alien life on Earth and humanity's reaction to this which varies from attempts to communicate and understand to declarations of war.  Anyone expecting an action packed alien invasion movie will be disappointed.  This story is played out with a lot more intelligence and respect for it's audience and it has the greatest emotional gut punch I've ever experienced in an alien movie.
This is the first film by director Denis Villeneuve that has stuck with me, Prisoners, Enemy and Sicario all had their merits but were far from outstanding.  I'm now looking forward to his next project, the Blade Runner sequel.

Amy Adams is a linguist who must translate the language of a visiting extraterrestrial aliens in the film about first contact. This is based on a short story by sci-fi writer Ted Chiang. Reminded me a little bit of a similar movie called Contact which is based on a novel of the same name by Carl Sagan.

Ya desde su planteamiento inicial, y todo el argumento que vendrá a continuación, Arrival es una película tremendamente fresca y original. Sí, cierto es que podemos ver ciertos reflejos de grandes clásicos como Encuentros en la Tercera Fase, pero sinceramente ¿cuántas veces nos encontramos últimamente con películas de ciencia ficción en el que se toma un desarrollo más cerebral, alejándose por completo de la acción?

Por supuesto esto no podría quedar bien si la mano ejecutora (Villeneuve en este particular caso) no estuvisese a la altura de las circunstancias. La dirección es magnífica y eso se refleja en el gran trabajo de Amy Adams y Jeremy Renner, aunque los secundarios no están lejos de tampoco.

Por supuesto, la fotografía y edición, completan el trabajo con sobresaliente, apoyando al apartado de los efectos visuales.

Lástima que el final me dejara algo frio con respecto con el resto del relato, porque hasta los momentos finales estaba totalmente dentro de ella. Ojo, esto no quiere decir que sea malo, es más bien una cuestión de gustos que otra cosa.

Sinceramente creo que Arrival debería recordarse en el futuro como un clásico moderno de la ciencia ficción.
Beautiful! it starts a little slower but stick with it! It's really worth it!
A pointless and slow story.  Not completely boring but not worth the time wasted watching.

You want to watch this film because the story is about contact and communication with an extraterrestrial life form, right?  Well, for some obnoxious reason you will be sent off with a corny Lifetime family drama and an unexplained magical ability instead.  Horrible corny, cringe worthy ending!  (Brenner's last line almost completely destroys this movie for me.)

Arrival does begin as an intriguing story about patience and communication, and Amy Adams does deliver a great performance as a cool headed but emotionally pressured professional. But this story is very regrettably swapped out for a cheesy, "emotional" family drama instead.

It's sad because the obvious initial "contact" premise of the story is truly fantastic and well performed. But to ultimately steer the film into a completely different direction towards a focus more on the main character's emotional family life left me feeling like the victim of a really bad bait and switch storytelling tactic. 

The soundtrack sounded corny and cringe worthy, as if it were constantly and consciously TRYING to illicit uneasiness or fear in the listener / viewer, yet being painfully obvious about it to the point of distraction at times.

I can't help feel there was potential for a great story arc, but it was squandered just to tell you an over-used family drama trope story you hadn't even paid to see.  

All in all, good performances, lovely visuals, important messages trying to be conveyed. Ultimately, this is a very good film which the writer, Eric Heisserer, unfortunately took nowhere in particular.  

I just realized this film had the same writer for Lights Out, another movie I abhorred passionately.

Was a unique alien encounter movie, and story was okay, but the pacing was just too slow and the personalities a little flat (a flat affect- more just acting curious the entire film).  So it was a challenge to my weak attention span... but reasonably memorable.
Kind of interesting. Certainly a different kind of alien invasion or aliens coming to earth kind of movie.

After putting off watching this several times I was slightly pleasantly surprised.  It's difficult to properly review it as it has a good first half followed by a not so good second half.  In truth, Renners character doesnt become relevant until about an hour in.  And his final line in the movie is cringeworthy.  Near the end I started losing interest as it became a bit daft......and the flashbacks were getting annoying, although they were necessary.  Definitely not a Saturday evening popcorn and wine movie.....but worth watching.
A fantastic movie that makes you think.  Really beautifully done.
A masterclass science fiction that takes multiple viewings to truly appreciate and understand.
nice build up of story, gives you something to think and talk about, without being corny, ok acting

This movie was amazing: it was amazing of what it portrayed and how it was resolved. I think that it was amazing how the director and writers made the concept of what the world would do if aliens ever did land on Earth. How they would gather scientists and resolve the problem and question "What is your purpose on Earth?" And it's neat how they made it where Amy Adams' character came up with teaching the heptopods words and found out how to actually communicate with them and understand their symbols. The roles the actors/actresses portrayed were also good picks. This movie deserved five stars and is one of my favorites.
Finely crafted and thought-provoking.
Not a bad movie, kinda freaked me out actually, even though the caracters we're totally cool with the situation.

A beautifully acted and cerebral piece of sci-fi that's almost as smart as it portends to be, Arrival nonetheless captivates with a thought-provoking puzzler that brings to mind Close Encounters of the Third Kind...had Terrence Malick directed it, that is. 

In this PG-13-rated sci-fi drama, linguistics professor Louise Banks (Amy Adams) is tasked with interpreting the language of the apparent alien visitors after twelve mysterious spacecraft appear around the world. Contemplative is the word for this thinking man's alien invasion flick. Our eyes, ears and mind, Banks is a linguist emotionally scarred by a tragedy. She doesn't think linearly and neither does the film. Far from straight-forward, the film mindbends and timebends with achingly gorgeous photography that frames the locations as much as the characters. This is a key point. Like 2001: A Space Odyssey and Interstellar before it, Arrival wraps you up in an atmospheric spectacle while leaving a lightyear's worth of room for interpretation. The end result is both quantitative and qualitative, though director Denis Villenueve had some obvious influences. Terrence Malick never made a straight sci-fi flick but, if he did, it might look a lot like this. The beauty of nature being interrupted by an obstructive force and opaque flashbacks/flash forwards are two Malick touchstones that both feature prominently in Arrival. Villenueve's work has always been bleak and gripping but his latest definitely resembles Malick's The Tree of Life more than Prisoners or Sicario. Like those last two searing dramas, it still concentrates on troubled characters and maintains a funereal tone but the canvas is more expansive and less conclusive. For some audiences, it will make them say 'Huh?' For the filmgoers that say 'Hmm,' however, Arrival is a welcome departure from the cut and dry space franchises currently Trekking and Warring across screens. 

Regardless of where the coin falls, Amy Adams grounds the drama quotient for all viewers with a deeply emotional performance. Ever since her very deserving Supporting Actress Oscar nomination for Junebug in 2005, this artist has made bold affecting choices. That she would do this and the very different Nocturnal Animals within the same short window, both daring but singularly amazing turns, seems improbable if not downright impossible. Jeremy Renner and Forest Whitaker turn in solid supporting performances without which she couldn't fully develop her character, but make no mistake about it: Second to Villeneuve, this is her show. And that goes for the aliens too.   

To Sum it Up: Earth Girls are Easy A
***OCTOPUSES FROM OUTERSPACE MEDDLE WITH PLANET EARTH'S INCONVENIENT TRUTH***

"Arrival is interesting and manages to say something else that we haven't seen done before in a movie like this which is to communicate and deciphering alien language. Amy Adams is the main and central character of this film, she plays Louise, the interpreter. Overall, the story is original and creative enough to forgive the execution which isn't cohesive enough in my opinion to follow through. Also, this constant hazy look to the film makes it hard for me to suggest watching it over and over again."
Only somewhat underwhelming in scale, Arrival is a showcase for good acting, effects and ideas. B+
This has been one of the best movie experiences I have ever had, the imagination and creativity the moviemakers used is excellent.
I love a movie that keeps you thinking after its over, this movie delivers. Amy killed it and Im definetly rewatching this masterpiece.

Arrival is a beautifully complex film that centres on the role of humanity in this world rather than the "arrivals". With this, the movie brings a new look to the sci-fi genre, as it deals with themes and emotions that many can relate to in the modern world. Arrival proves to be one-of-a-kind and one of the best in the genre, not just for pure action or the cliches we tend to see in such movies, but for its creativity and thought-provoking ideas it presents to the viewer. It is a movie that does require utmost attention, however, the experience is truly rewarding, as director, Denis Villeneuve continues his run of exceptional movies. Amy Adams, who plays a linguistic professor, leads the movie with a strong performance, yet playing a vulnerable character who succumbs to the events that unfold. The 'arrivals' themselves are wonderfully designed and their language particularly is a topic in on itself. Crafted with great cinematography and moving music, this was a deserved Oscar-nominated film, and truly one for the ages.
Arival is the Citizen Kane of Sci-fi movies. Incredible cinematography, great plot, and great acting.
Arrival is a terrific emotional film.

I struggled with picking this one as my favorite film of 2016 because "Manchester By The Sea" affected me on a more primal level... but you cannot ignore the near flawless execution of this film, from the original story to the fantastic acting to the meticulously crafted atmosphere and tone.  Every last beat is damn near perfect.  I have heard people criticize this movie for being slow and not making sense, but I was riveted throughout the entire thing, and I can't really argue about the making sense bit without spoiling the whole movie.  Suffice it to say that the story gradually reveals itself precisely and intentionally, and is impeccably done.  I'll admit it's a slow burn, but oooh, that burn is so good!  Director Denis Villeneuve is a master of building tension, and he gets better at it with every film.  The concept of this film is entirely original and complex, it's pretty heady stuff that really makes you think.   Though the movie is technically about aliens, it is not your traditional sci-fi film.  I would categorize it more as a suspense film with a dramatic core.  It's about people, not aliens... both individually and as a group.  This movie is what "Interstellar" should have been, and more.  It's haunting and profound, and it sat with me more than any other movie this year.
Spectacular movie that brings a brilliant and different approach to alien movies. A must see.

Denis Villeneuve proves himself to be a rising super-star yet again in this sci-fi thriller that is sure to make your imagination run wild. This incredible story is only elevated by Villeneuve's masterful work and Johansson's haunting original score. This is one of the few films that has drawn tears from my eyes in the past decade.

Hugely enjoyable and thought provoking it may be, but Arrival simply dishes up, yet again,  the direct descendants of the 1950's "men in rubber suits" as aliens. Surely a highly advanced civilisation would remember a time when it was at the same stage in development to our own and reached out accordingly. Instead we get the usual galvanised forms with no clothing, objects or appurtenances of any kind and dwelling in unfurnished habitats that look like an ad for concrete. Instead we get five legged creatures drawing interesting circles. A worthy effort it's true but the paucity of ideas concerning extraterrestrial life is even more frustrating than Star Trek's famous facial prosthetics.
A nearly perfect science fiction drama.

Ficção científica que passa longe de explosões, gritarias e manobras com caças, explora de forma muito interessante a comunicação e como a linguística retrata nossa forma de pensar. Paralelamente, um drama pessoal, que ao decorrer do filme se mostra essencial e bem amarrado à trama. A alguns espectadores pode parecer maçante no começo, mas é um filme que vale muito a pena assistir, sensível e diferente das últimas ficções cientìficas (com exceção de Interestelar), o foco é a linguística.
I don't know, I didn't like it that much. Sue me.

Louise Banks teach language at some univerity is interupted in class by phones ringing. Everybody leaves. Some sort of UFO has landed in USA. And eleven other places. They are hoping for aliens, and some sort of communication. Louise is pretty darn smart and into language, so she get the job in a rush.

Very strong story - pretty realistic to be a sci-fi film. It's cold and quite bleak, never overdone but pretty and filled with subtle style. The lovestory thing is the smallest of sub plots and I like that a lot. By the way, I found the plot both smart and touching with some neat twists. The film has good pace but slower moments happen frequently - it's a good thing then, that the images, the camerahandling, the effects, the colors, the score - is all brilliant. You can't look away.

Villeneuve is an amazing director - this is as good as "Prisoners" and way better than "Sicario" if you ask me. The guy does not know how to fail, really. Good performances too, the actors need a mention - Amy Adams delivers her best role so far, surrounded by other strong names on the poster.

Arrival is "Close Encounters of the Third Kind" in a smarter and prettier wrapping. With way more depth and emotion. A great film and a great debut for my new widescreen.

9 out of 10 circles.
Although slow and redundant at times, Arrival is superbly acted and delivers some of the most beautiful cinematography of the year along with a captivating story of love and discovery.

Do not listen to the rating; this rating by others. This movie is a total waste of two hours and is so uninteresting, disjointed and confusing so just skip watching it and you will miss nothing at all.

This kind of movies which I'd like to watch again. It's not a pure sci-fi movie, nor about aliens, tough guys with laser guns. It's more about common people. About us.
