In my opinion the movie performed poorly. It was a disappointment. The subject of language and communication and how it was addressed by the writer was brilliant. But the script was rather poor. It felt like the book wanted to focus on the character and her psychology while the movie focused on the Aliens, thus making the character only marginal to the main storyline.
Not much character development either, apart from the endless dullness of the main character, which in the end has no major impact on the main story, that is the ARRIVAL of the aliens. The movie spends a awful lot of time creating a mystery mood that leads practically nowhere. Although i initially liked the suspense, in the end it was not justified. The gloomy mood of the movie was also not justified by the peaceful nature of the aliens nor how it ended. There was no sunshine in the end, no hope, no better future. Just more dullness. 
The love relationship between the two scientist comes out of nowhere and it leads to nowhere. There is no positive change and no finale, neither in the movie nor in the way events are supposed to end. We see a person with a dull life who has a brief moment of joy and ends up with a dull life again. What's the point?
Although the overall design, graphics and mood was really good, all the cool things the aliens represented ment for nothing. They didn't change anything, save anyone or made a visible impact on earth events. The title is misleading. It should have been titled "First contact". It would have made much more sense.
The chinese antagonism is also a big overused cliche. So lame to make the chinese aggressive when in fact they are known for their pragmatic and patient diplomacy. And what for? The chinese decision to attack is not justified. It is based on the assumption that the chinese are hostile by default, thus fueling more stereotyping. The los of cooperation with the European allies is also lame. Everyone knows the USA and the EU will never antagonize each-other.
I could go on and on. In my opinion, the language and communication part was fun to watch, the aliens were also nicely done. The rest was just a lame collection of cliches, bad scripting and poor directing.?

Finally a movie with a plot twist that is a legitimate mind nuke! I'm going to have to re-watch it now, knowing what I know, to see how I perceive/experience it. Without a doubt the best movie I've seen in the last few years.

This is one dark movie. Very dark. Need a flashlight dark. It adds to the gloomy, ominous tension, in the latest alien encounter Hollywood blockbuster. Here's the good news: instead of turning into some crazy CGI battle zone, "Arrival" keeps on keeping on with the intellectual storyline, which as it turns out, is pretty damn engrossing.

Clever is just the start here. "Arrival" is brimming with original, quirky, brain-teasing quandaries on various levels of the human experience, and how an alien intrusion could turn everything we know upside down.

Not only is the narrative quite delicious, but the circular unfolding of events, the inventive communication mysteries of another life form, and the questioning of scientific knowledge, is revelatory. Saying more would spoil this carefully concocted, multi-layered masterpiece. Be warned: there may be repeated viewings in your future to decipher all that flows off the big screen.

Arrival is the vastly overrated, but very well-made science fiction tale about alien spaceships who arrive on Earth seeking our help, and the fate of humanity rests in the hands of an accomplished linguist who learns how to communicate with them. This film is less of an alien invasion story and centers more on the themes of communication, linguistics, and fate; a cool concept, but to me, the execution left much to be desired. It's directed by Canadian auteur Denis Villeneuve and stars Amy Adams, Jeremy Renner, Michael Stuhlbarg, and Forest Whitaker who all deliver solid work, but the storytelling and pace put me to sleep. Critics are raving that this is a "thinking-man's sci-fi", which I'm all for, but not at the expense of entertainment purposes and this film was a DRAGGGGGGG to get through. Adams and Renner have very little chemistry throughout; her character being extremely bland didn't help, and I was largely unsatisfied with where their characters ended up. The pacing is also unbearably slow which left an air of self-importance around the film that honest-to-goodness, made me fall asleep while watching it. The big reveals that come at the end are admittedly very cool, but once again, the execution of said ideas is very uninteresting and were not nearly as mind-blowing as the movie thinks they are. I REALLY wanted to love this as I'm a big fan of the director's work, but perhaps the enormous praise this film got and massive hype surrounding it worked against my expectations by the time I finally saw it. I thought the technical aspects of this film were great, but to me, story comes first, and this film didn't impress me nearly as much as the film community wanted it to.

This movie was a sci-fi that wanted to soar but that fell down to earth with a very dissapointing thump.  It addressed lofty sci-fi questions about the nature of the universe; the relationships of humans to each other; as well as what a possible relationship with aliens might look like.  Just when you think that the movie is going to have an illuminating and profound message that calls humanity to be the best of itself and stretch beyond normal limits of possibility with a dazzling complexity of future/present/past time and choices; and you think that despite all of the technology and math the movie has dwelled on, that relationships are what truly matters.  Relationships that show a depth of caring even for aliens that seem difficult for humans to relate to, as they are very uncomfortably alien in nature.  But then there is a twist in the plot that renders the main character ironically less human and compassionate than the aliens, despite a sudden amazing talent that manages to save the day.  She makes a choice which seems to be incredibly selfish and disregards any personal pain and suffering she brings to those she supposedly loves, in a decision that she makes over and over, despite knowing the painful future outcome.  It is questionable why this is the territory the movie wanted to navigate when it is hard to see that she is making this decision out of anything but a selfish love.  The outcome of her decision is questionable and controversial - and renders this character completely unsympathetic and unlikable, destroying any heroic sense you might have had of the character.  The aliens seem more compassionate and loving, ironically, than this character.  Overall, the movie's message is muddled - it can't seem to decide what is truly important - technology or relationships.  In the end, the main character's decision renders her own future pointless.  She may have saved the planet, but she cannot save herself from a loveless and compassionate-less future.  I don't think that this is the message that the movie was going for.  It deliberately tries to confuse and muddle its own plotlines to obstruct people actually figuring out what Amy Adam's character was deciding and why.  The movie leaves a depressing taste in your mouth. Why give a character a power which renders her powerless?  Or is that the point?  I like profound sci-fi, but not sci-fi that twists itself into knots just to turn a success into a defeat.  Yuck.  Next time I will watch Galaxy Quest for the tenth time instead!   This movie makes Space Odyssey look cheerful!  Even Interstellar, despite its anti-climactic and somewhat disappointing ending, had a dram of hope left in it and a positive sense of love and compassion driving it - which this movie "Arrival" completely lacks.

I am completely clueless on how this movie gets such high ratings. Is there something I am missing? It honestly is almost unwatchable.
The movie starts out with a few flashbacks involving this main character and her daughter - no explanation of who she is - what happened to her daughter - why there is no husband(or significant other) - you know the normal things that make you connect with a character.
Then all of a sudden - some government/military guy is coming to whisk her off to talk to aliens based on the fact that she once translated some Farsi for them? Jesus - it's just nonsense. After 40 minutes I turned to my husband and asked - are you getting ANYTHING out of this movie?
Nope - not at all. I can suspend belief fine when I can at least connect with the characters so I care about them - but I could have cared less about anyone in this movie. And the way it is shot is all fuzzy and dark - so you have even less idea what is going on. Anyway - enough said I guess . I continue to be disappointed that filmmakers think packing visual effect into a movie makes it better than bothering to make us care about the characters.

It is difficult to find ways to critique a film like this where so many aspects of what it means to make a great film can all be found in Denis Villeneuve's "Arrival". 

With a story that is centered around the idea of communication, writer Eric Heisserer brings to the screen a daring example of humanity's unwillingness to work together and fear of the unknown. Told by Villeneuve in an amazingly introspective way, the story of Dr. Banks (Amy Adams) presents a hyper-realistic narrative of the importance of cooperation and the sciences (and cooperation in science), and the perils of selfishness and fear-mongering. Something as simple as talking to each other has so many nuances that most of us never consider or realise. This is a heavy, thoughtful movie no doubt, and through it all is threaded the simple and repetitive yet heady score of Jóhann Jóhannsson. The circular structure of the music, the themes, and of course the aliens' writing too, ties everything together beautifully into this well-rounded story.
 
That is why I give this film a full 5/5 and why "Arrival" is my pick for Best Picture 2017.
Mind blown. Amazing from start to finish!

Arrival is a film that opens your mind to lofty concepts such as the nature of time, geo-political affairs, and of course, language. 

The plot, stripped down, is about a woman named Louise whose life purpose is to receive 'the universal language,' from the aliens who visit earth. She passes the language on to humanity in a mass produced book called The Universal Language.

In Louise's communications with the aliens, we see the theme of time recur again and again. The aliens write in sentences that are wrapped in symbols, all of which resemble a ring, or more accurately, an ouroboros, which is a snake eating its tail. This ancient symbol represents the cyclical nature of time. Birth, life, and death is a repeating cycle. 

But the story introduces us to a new way of thinking about time. Perhaps a less pessimistic way. In the story, the words "language" and "weapon" are used interchangeably by the aliens in such statements as, "weapon opens time." And "use weapon." Alternately, "language opens time" and "use language."

And the caveat the aliens give humans with the gift of the universal language, is that in 3000 years the aliens will need the humans' help. For what, we don't know. 

What we do know is that the two greatest task we face as humans are 1) curing aging, and 2) interstellar space travel. Both of the these task will come with a new way of thinking about time and that is what the movie offers at it's most basic level.
In a genre with so many superb films, Arrival seems too bland on the surface , but it's deep in scope.

Moda sam zato to imam dosta godina old fashion girl, ili pak, mladji blogeri i filmski novinari nisu odgledali sve to sam ja, ili pak, mnogima nedostaje ?vrst teoretski okvir u kome ?e se kretati kad piu o filmu...Ili sam samo uobraena, ta znam, te posle dueg vremena elim da napiem tekst o nekom filmu, koji ?ini mi se, nije dobio poten osvrt na naem medijskom nebu.Film Dolazak je jedan od najreprezentativnijih filmskih ostvarenja koje sam gledala u poslednje vreme. Inteligentan i provokativan, prati pri?u o dolasku vanzemaljske civilizacije na zemlju, sa kojom treba uspostaviti prvi kontakt. Ulogu spasitelja, gle ?uda, ima ena. Dosta. Utopijski  san o ujednjenju ljudske rase, spremne da u budu?nosti spaava i druge svetove. Kao vreme iz Epa o Gilgameu, u kome majka glavnog junaka, ?ini herojsko delo, ujedinjuju?i svoga sina, okrutnog vladara Gilgamea, sa svojim ljutim neprijateljem Enkiduom, ne bi li postao bolji ?ovek. Izuzetno. Gluma Amy Adams maestralna. Svedena, senzualna, blaga. Mater dolorosa. Predvidjam Zlatni globus za koji je nominovana kao tuma? glavne uloge i jo ?itav niz nagrada. Ipak, pri?a ne bi bila spektakularna, da uz onu vanzemaljsku, ne nudi jednu istinski ljudsku, toplu i strasnu. Oplakivanje smrti k?eri i pronalaenje ljubavi svoga ivota, koja je i izgubljena radi nerazumevanja. A glavna junakinja je, o ironije, po profesiji ?uvena lingvistkinja ?iji zadatak jeste da stupi u prvi kontakt sa vanzemaljcima. I pored vidljivih geografskih i jezi?kih greaka u komunikaciji na kineskom mandarinskom ili postavci 12 vanzemaljskih lokacija po na izgled nepovezanim stratekim ta?kama sveta, film obiluje mnotvom izuzetnih umetni?kih i nau?nih veza. Od muzike Maksa Rihtera, koji je oven?an nagradom za najboljeg evropskog kompozitora, do literarnog predloka koji je posluio za scenario. Re? je o kratkoj pri?i Teda Chianga Pri?a tvoga ivota. Autor je ina?e jedan od dobitnika nagrade Hugo, koja se dodeljuje decenijama unazad za dela spekulativne fikcije i spada u najzna?ajnije u svetu. Film obiluje inteligentnim asocijacijama i oma je mnogim drugim umetni?kim delima, od onih iz sveta filma (Abot i Kostelo su imena vanzemaljaca sa kojima komunicira heroina ) do onih knjievnih kakva je novela o Tripodima Jhona Christophera, jo jednog autora iz anra sci fi. Ono to film ?ini istinski uzbudljivim je ?injenica da je ljudima za komunikaciju izgleda potreban vanzemaljski susret, to je kao tema ve? pokrenuto u kultnom Avataru.Ipak, meni je najvie panje privukla teza koju neguje film, a ti?e se jezi?kih teorija.Junakinja  kae da je sve u jeziku, uz  pretpostavku da postoji sastavna veza izme?u jezi?nih kategorija i miljenja. U filmu se jasno anticipira Sapir (ameri?ki lingvista) Whorhova (Sapirov u?enik) lingvisti?ka hipoteza koja, iako nikad  napisana kao takva, zaista nudi miljenje obojice nau?nika. U antropologiji je formalno nazvana tako, posle njihove smrti. Oba naucnika su za ivota ispitivali odnos izmedju miljenja, jezika i kulture. Danas se ta teorija koristi u biznisu. Ta hipoteza tvrdi da postoji veza izme?u jezika kojim se realnost opisuje i samog opaanja, tj da jezi?ki kod uti?e na kognitivne procese, pa u skladu sa istom razli?ite nacije imaju razli?it odnos prema stvarima, pojavama, vremenu, novcu i tednji. Govornici razli?itih jezika u istim drutvima, sa istim socio-ekonomskim parametrima - dohodak, obrazovanje, bra?ni status, broj dece.., imaju razli?ite preferencije ka tednji, na primer. Dakle, ipak je sve u jeziku, to ja negiram ve? dugo vremena, bahato se razbacuju?i savrenim poznavanjem maternjeg ali i vremena, koje je najvaniji faktor za razumevanje filma. Ina?e, istinski prekrasne jezi?ke krugove vanzemaljaca stvorila je umetnica Martine Bertrand Svaka preporuka.

It's amazing how far sci-fi, as a film genre, has come since its inception.  From Metropolis, which is recognized as the first feature-length sci-fi movie in existence, to Invasion of the Body Snatchers and the entire 50s sci-fi renaissance, as it were, to 2001: A Space Odyssey.  From there on you have Close Encounters of the Third Kind, Star Wars, Blade Runner, The Matrix, District 9, Inception, Ex Machina.  The genre has certainly seen its ups and downs, particularly when it comes to films focusing on aliens arriving on earth.  There aren't many movies, at least as far as I can tell, that focus more on what this situation would REALLY be like.  It wouldn't play out like the Independence Days of the world, where the aliens declare war on humanity and we've all got to take a stand against them.  The first film, I believe, that really took a look at this from a more real-world standpoint would be Close Encounters, who looked at the arrival of the aliens as something to marvel at.  It wasn't a scientifically-driven movie, in the least, but it was a movie that looked at the wonderment such a event would attract.  Which is where this movie comes in.  And I know Contact was released TWENTY years before this movie, but I don't really remember much of it.  But I digress, for those thinking that this is gonna be another Independence Day, where humanity is at war with aliens, then they'll be sorely disappointed.  This is an intelligent, thinking-person's sci-fi.  The film sees a linguistics expert attempt to figure out the alien's language in order to figure out what they want, why they're here and how they got there.  But, of course, it's not just as simple as that, as there are twelve heptapods, as they call it, spread out through the entire world.  There are heptapods in Russia, Pakistan, Sudan, Venezuela, China, UK, Australia, among others.  So figuring out their reason for being here is, really, a worldwide collaboration.  But, of course, with countries like Russia and China being involved, their talks with the aliens in the heptapods are a little more sensitive in nature.  Particularly when you take into consideration that the aliens, who have their own complex language, might not understand the meaning of some of the words they use or the context with which someone like China or Russia might view them in.  For example, there's a scene where the aliens communicate to Louise to 'offer weapon', there's a big deal about that, because the government is unsure of whether they want weapons, if they're offering a weapon or if they would like to do a trade.  Things are further complicated when some of the soldiers on base, having been fueled by stupid conspiracy videos (imagine InfoWars or some other bullshit) plant some bombs inside the heptapod in order kill the aliens.  It doesn't work, of course, and there are a few moments where it seems that a worldwide conflict between humanity and the aliens is imminent.  The film isn't about that, this is about avoiding war at all costs.  The film takes a really interesting and thought-provoking approach   Reviewing this film is tricky, because I want to avoid spoilers, but the film focuses heavily on Louise's family life.  You get to see flashbacks of her life with her daughter who passed away from cancer in her teen years.  The way the movie plays with those elements, which really make up the emotional core of the film, is one of the more pleasant surprises the film has in store.  There's also some fairly intriguing theories around language and how fully immersing yourself in learning a new language will re-wire your brain into thinking differently.  That's definitely one of the biggest themes in play here.  The perception of time is also very important to where the film wants to go.  I feel that, by its conclusion, some people might feel that the narrative got a little convoluted, but it's not a movie that betrays its own rules.  It doesn't take established concepts and do away with them in order to force in a deus ex machina.  Again, reviewing all of this is really tricky when you're trying to avoid spoilers, but it's all exceptionally well-done.  As if it wasn't obvious by the review, I thought this was a pretty damn great movie.  The film is rich in storytelling, that's for damn sure, and how it incorporates Louise's past life (something to keep an eye for) into the events that are occurring in the present.  How her memories help guide her hand in dealing with the aliens, whom they name Abbot and Costello, and how she helps to avoid an international conflict against the aliens.  In spite of everything though, the movie never really seeks to make out Louise to be a heroine, she's just doing what needs to be done.  Because of that, her character feels grounded to earth, you can still relate to her in spite of the fact that, really, she was the one of the biggest parts in avoiding this conflict.  And I say that because other countries had to follow China's lead.  They could have just refused.  But the world 'uniting as one', as it were, is due to Louise and her knowledge and understand of the aliens and their language.  The ending itself is really quite bittersweet, because of what Louise knows.  I won't get into details, I don't wanna spoil it, but it's worth a look regardless.  Amy Adams is phenomenal here, no ifs, ands or buts about it.  The rest of the cast is great as well, but Ms. Adams carries the movie on her shoulders and she delivers a home run.  It also helps when the film has a strong a script as this one, but she never slacks off.  Movie's beautifully shot as well and I didn't even rent the Blu-Ray.  I can't really say much else about this movie.  I thought it was great and I would easily recommend it.  It's not the best movie I saw from 2016, The Wailing would take that honor, but don't let that, and the fact that this is a dialogue-heav sci-fi flick, dissuade you from giving this a shot.

An intelligent first contact film, who would've thought! This is actually a very good intellectual film that asks the question of what will actually happen in a realistic way, when Aliens do make contact with us and how paranoid the human race is when communication doesn't go as planned, the ending was a little jarring as, personally, I didn't really understand it, but after reading up on the meaning of it all, it made a lot more sense, would I watch it again? Probably not, but it is worth your time.

The first half is undeniably brilliant, rightly recognizing that the language barrier would be the most difficult piece of any first contact situation. That said once the movie devolves into it's sillier and more sentimental final act, it becomes less effective.

I was wondering why the movie came out on Valentine's Day and now I know. I'm sorry but when aliens come to earth I expect them to have a grander impact on humanity than this movie portrays. Two hours of what can only be described as the absolutely worst, drawn-out, confusing and pretentious Sci-Fi movie ever put out on digital acetate.  And the folks at 21 Laps Entertainment have you believe this "blockbuster" cost $99 million to produce. Oh Lord, someone pulled the digital layers over our eyes. If you read the positive movie reviews raving about how artsy and intellectual this is-  then please consider these movie critics are delusional and intellectually fake.

Let me state The Arrival is nothing short than overrated On many facets, the movie falls totally over the cliff, As I was watching this unravel during 112 minutes, i challenged myself that the best was yet to come, . This Arrival in my opinion ranks as being one of those undiscovered genres all by itself. Heck - even Harvey Weinstein couldn't have cocked it up that bad. But here we are boys and girls. Wow...So to the folks at The Academy of Motion Pictures and Sciences and to esteemed members of the BAFTA, its very likely you won't see my nomination being sent in anytime soon.  Very sorry guys. 

All things said, digitally enhanced and scored, it's a total piece of crap and please forget the hipster rave reviews about how amazing the plot is and how warm Amy Adams acting was. Remember the phrase - The Emperor has no clothes? - Well, don't fall for it boys and girls. I had more fun watching my delicates spin-dry in my new Samsung tumble dryer. Oi Vey. My better half challenged me to see beyond its main plot and to read more into it. Sadly I gave up looking for something that simply wasn't there in this flick.

But wait, there was a moment - the Producer and his team decided to throw a couple of cheap tricks used at the end of the movie to explain what is so unexplainable. Denis, It doesn't pass the smell test. At the half way mark, I already felt ripped off. On top of that, the script hides the relationship between some of the characters. Like I said, the whole thing makes for a confusing ending for the average moviegoer, like myself. It's almost like you need a movie whisperer or a Cliffs Notes aide to help you figure it. And no, I wasn't expecting Sigourney Weaver or some epic battle either.

On a positive note, what I did like was the 12-pod style looking spaceships - it fueled me to see what would happen. The idea and design was novel, the spaceships seemed intriguing, but sadly we don't get to see anymore of the inside of the spacecraft. Somehow I wanted more, I wanted to roam inside the darkness of the labyrinth. But no, the digital team could have added to the ideation palette here but didn't. And so, rather that, the movie instead took considerable time trying to get me hooked on the decryption of the aliens rorschach ink-blot-like language. 

Underlying this, the viewer quickly senses there are communication gaps amongst some of the 12 countries who each have an alien spacecraft hovering in it. The Chinese are cutting themselves off from peace talks, so too are the Russians, then the Americans....oh Gosh, it sounds like they were fearful of some wall being built. 

Was this one of the messages I needed to take away? That people will agree to disagree or was it to think about how Amy Adams "Hannah" and the overall movie was essentially a Palindrone - spelt backwards it could be viewed the same both ways? Regardless, Amy also boasts a top secret clearance as a linguistics professor and tries everything through mental flashbacks to befriend the shadowy aliens hidden in the mist, trying in vain to figure out their language - or was I missing the point it that .

To that end, I propose the film producers seriously consider dusting off their Arri Alexa or CineAlta cameras and get something better off the ground for a movie that cost $99 million.

I first saw Arrival at its sneak preview last Feb 7th. Then I saw it again this morning with my sister. Denis Villeneuve, (Prisoner, 2013 & Sicario, 2015) has beautifully directed this film that keeps you on edge of your seat.

Plot: 12 mysterious gigantic spacecrafts have landed across the globe. Linguistic professor joins a US army team to learn aliens' language and communicate with them to to know what they came for.

The film opens introducing Louise Banks (played terrifically by Amy Adams) and her daughter Hannah, where her name is palindrome which means it is said the same forwards as well as backwards which kinda gives us a clue how the movie ends. Before she was asked to join the army at one of the locations in Montana where one of the spacecrafts has landed, the government has been able to interact with alien visitors in some forms, but they couldn't translate the sounds. Louise couldn't translate the strange noises from the audio file brought by US Army Colonel G T Weber (played impeccably by Forest Whitaker) she said, she has to be there for her to communicate with the aliens directly. 'Language is a foundation of Civilization', which is probably one of the most memorable lines I heard in a movie in years. We also met Ian Donnelly (effectively played by Jeremy Renner), a theoretical physicist who helps Dr. Banks to study aliens' language.

There's a huge question in this film, Why are they here? Are they here to invade us or to help us? Every 18 hours the spacecraft opens to let them temporarily interact with aliens directly. The aliens are known as heptapods because of their 7 legs or tentacles. Because it is impossible to communicate with aliens through the sound they make, Dr. Banks came up with an idea to communicate with them visually. She writes her name on a white board to introduce herself while Aliens communicates by making symbols with distinct patterns and shapes. Dr. Banks was having flashbacks, moments with her daughter that were shown in the film many times. As the session goes on, the more they get ideas about their intentions along the way.

Arrival is beautiful is great in its own right. It film doesn't rely on visual effects but it gives us stunning images that takes your breath away. Plus the chilling score from Jóhann Jóhannsson who composed movie scores from (Prisoners, Theory of Everything & Sicario) and Max Richter. They uses different tones in the film that are truly haunting and unsettling to hear. But that doesn't end there. The ultimate twist of the film comes when Dr. Banks realizes that she sees future. Those flashbacks she had were not memories from the past but events from the future which explains everything we experienced watching the film. The way it was told in the film makes it compelling to watch.

Arrival is unlike any other psychological/alien-invasion or sci fi films we've seen that keeps us guessing how it's going to end but it is a dramatic take of humans' first contact of the third kind. It's a type of movie that invites you leaving the theater and actually talking about it. I was engaged by every inch of this film. I walked out and I thought a lot about it. It works on you on ways you're not really aware of.

Please DO NOT wait to see it on a device you can hold in your hand. See this film

Seriously thought provoking script, masterly made, Finaly a sci-fi that is not just an excuse to invent new weapons for destruction but a real reflection on humans as a species. of course the americans are the ones that comme up with the truth again but hey it's an american movie... what can you do

With his debut Incendies in 2010, Denis Villeneuve really hit the ground running and has been one of the most consistently interesting director's for the last 7 years.  There's a host of films and genres that Villeneuve has explored in that time; from the nightmarish surrealism of Enemy; his unflinching kidnap thriller Prisoners and his drug cartel action drama Sicario. If you put aside his forthcoming Blade Runner sequel, you could say that Arrival is his science fiction warm-up to attempting to re-engage with that much loved classic.

Plot: 12 mysterious, alien spacecrafts land across the globe with the whole of mankind questioning their intentions. Expert linguistic Louise Banks (Amy Adams) is hired to attempt to communicate with them. In the meantime, frustrations are leading earth to a global war and the answers Louise begins to decipher could mean the difference between saving or eradicating humanity entirely.

The renowned astrophysicist and author, Carl Sagan once wrote "The nitrogen in our DNA, the calcium in our teeth, the iron in our blood, the carbon in our apple pies were made in the interiors of collapsing stars. We are made of starstuff." This is a theoretical topic that courses throughout Villeneuve's film and, at one point, even referenced directly. 

Based on Ted Chiang's "Story of your Life", Arrival is not overly concerned with being a big-budget science fiction film. It certainly has these elements (and they are very well executed) but it's more concerned with mood, atmosphere and exploring the very nature of our existence through language and our relationship and understanding of time and space. In doing so, Arrival has much in common with Robert Zemeckis' 1997 film Contact (which itself was based on a book by the aforementioned Sagan). Both use the form of extraterrestrial communication as a device to understand ourselves and it's this communication angle (and the reveal that results from it) that eventually turns Arrival on its head. It's an angle that has split some viewers; is it too clever for its own good? Does it disappear up its own wazoo? Or is it a clever sleight of hand that questions our linear and literal perception of events? I'm siding with the latter but these questions are better left to the individual viewer. 

What can be said, is that Villeneuve has done his homework on this. Much like Christopher Nolan's approach to Interstellar, Villeneuve extensively ensured the film's scientific ideology was accurate by enlisting the help of renowned scientists and tech innovators who advised on all the terminology, graphics and depictions. As Villeneuve is in no rush to tell his story, he demands a patience and a willingness to open up to the films theories and possibilities. It can often be a bit weighty and does occasionally tread a fine line between absurdity and suspending your disbelief but there's much to ruminate over and Villeneuve is aided immeasurably but his cast and crew; Bradford Young (who previously impressed me with his work in A Most Violent Year) delivers some stunningly captured cinematography and Jóhan Jóhansson's score perfectly accompanies the mood and imagery. At the forefront, however, is a quietly effecting performance from Amy Adams. She brings such subtle emotional depth that she contributes hugely to your ability to buy the films premise in the first place. It's a performance that I'm very surprised has been omitted from this year's academy awards. 

I struggle with the 'masterpiece' label that has been thrust upon Villenueve's film but there's no doubt that Arrival is a delicate, thoughtful and accomplished piece of work. If he applies the same level of intelligence and challenging material to his Blade Runner 2049 then the continuation of Ridley Scott's master of the genre may well be in good hands. 

Mark Walker

Exceptional movie! 

Much like Titanic was not a documentary about the ship and its eventual sinking, but instead a love story about Jack and Rose... Arrival too is not a story about aliens and first contact as much as it is a story about the human condition and the power of love.

Rarely can a writer or director pull that off, but where James Cameron did it quite successfully with Titanic, Denis Villeneuve and Eric Heisserer have successfully done it here.  The sci-fi, while interesting and thought provoking to say the least, is just a backdrop for the story of Amy Adams character.

I don't want to give away any spoilers beyond what's been said, but I can tell you that if you like your sci-fi to go beyond laser cannons, space ships, and your typical fare... this is your movie.  For those of you that get dragged to every Star Wars or Star Trek movie by your boyfriend or spouse... this movie will be the one that might finally turn you on to the genre.

Director Denis Villenueve also does a masterful job with the narrative structure of the film that has a great payoff in the end.

It's good.

The movie Arrival is one of the most boring films I have seen all year. This is a genre which I call sentimental scifi. Meaning that we have a scifi film which is really just genre that tries to garner empathy for a character. I have to say I was not convinces with Amy Adams' role in this movie. She is too one dimensional, and by the end her character along with the whole story does not make any sense. 
The plot is about language and communication. Therein lays the problem. Spielberg already did it with Close Encounters of the Third Kind and that film was genius. Spielberg did not need to over complicate things. He shared the concept that music is a universal language that could be used to communicate with the aliens. The main character in Close Encounters of the Third Kind is an every day man who is chosen to experience something far beyond his imagination. Arrival uses a know it all scientist with amnesia to try and translate circles. The aliens use her memories to convey a message, ie Interstellar, and the movie Contact. The dialogue is cliche military talk, and stuff pulled from movies such as Contact, and Independence Day. The only thing great about this film was Jeremy Renner's acting. He is awesome in just about anything. The music is really good. The special effects and cinematography are top notch. This film would look excellent in 4k. The main problem is the writing. It's been done way too many times. I give Arrival a 6/10.

I highly recommend "Arrival". It is a wonderfully tragic film about humanity and human communication and knowing the consequence of deliberate choice - not fully understanding the consequence, but knowing the consequence. It is beautifully written, beautifully acted, especially Amy Adams's turn as linguistics expert, Louise Banks, and beautifully directed by Denis Villanueve ("Prisoners" and "Sicario", also highly recommended), and Johann Johannsson's score is an emotional and moving and important element as a vehicle that moves the viewer effortlessly through Louise's journey to discovery. "Arrival" is a film that will stay with you long after it has departed. "Independence Day" it ain't.

Despite all the mindless action and sex that hits the big screen every year, every once in a while there comes a film that's a little more . . . cerebral. Arrival (2016) certainly fits this category. Not only do you really have to pay attention to what's happening in this film, it makes you question how we perceive our world as it is right now. Never before have I seen the topic of encountering alien life forms approached from such a realistic and logical way. It makes sense that we wouldn't be able to understand them, so the first step in establishing an understanding is to establish communication.

Much like Christopher Nolan, who has done a number of great, "cerebral" films including Memento (2000), Inception (2010), and Interstellar (2014), I have recently come to appreciate the directorial talents of Denis Villeneuve. From his previous films like Prisoners (2013) and Sicario (2015), I've seen him deliver powerful messages about who we are as humans and how we deal with evil. In Arrival, once again the enemy is humanity itself, and the angry and violent mistrust it has against anything it doesn't understand. Fortunately, despite its repeated visual motif of black and white, Arrival shows that peace can be found in the gray area of language interpretation.

While I don't want to give away the twist of this film, I have to say that the way it was presented certainly makes for a powerful impact once it has been realized. I will simply attribute this to the talent of Denis Villeneuve and the superb screenplay used to guide the audience along to the stunning conclusion. If you haven't seen any of Villeneuve's films yet, now's a great time to start. I certainly will look forward to his next piece, if this is the type of work he's putting out right now.

A fantastic, cerebral, and realistic approach to a classic sci-fi scenario, I give Arrival 5.0 stars out of 5.

An amazing balance of drama and emotion. Unlike your usual alien movies, Arrival focuses mostly on us, the human race. From our first reactions upon learning of the extraterrestrial presence, to our basic emotions of love and hate. As if it weren't enough, there is some great language philosophy submersed within the plot, specifically the effect of submersing yourself within a new language along with its way of thinking. Denis Villeneuve is proving to be a force among modern directors, however prefering visual and emotional strength instead of the physical action which most sci-fi movies of today are made up of.

Arrival is the movie that Interstellar wanted to be. It takes a sci-fi topic, tries to ground it in actual science, and weaves in an emotional core to the film without compromising the science. It's important to mention that Arrival is deliberately paced, and by that I mean it moves slower than molasses. I tolerated the plodding storyline because I was totally invested in Amy Adams and Jeremy Renner. They add a lot of heart to this movie and make it work well for me. I loved how the movie explained some of the linguistics and the understated way they handled effects was brilliant (aside from one scene where the effects were poor.) The reason it didn't rate as highly for me as many other sci-fi films was two-fold. For one, they fast-forwarded through a large chunk of the language discovery and that was one of my favorite parts. It was a strange choice, in a movie that had so many slow moments, to rush through anything so intriguing. The other thing that bugged me was the fact that I guessed what was going on well before it was revealed so the second half of the film played out without much surprise. It's not a huge flaw for a movie to be predictable, but in this case I felt like I was missing something when they revealed certain things and I already expected them. Aside from my little complaints, Arrival is a very good movie, and I can see why it was so highly regarded. It's one of those hard sci-fi movies where the ending leads to all kinds of deeper questions that can't really be answered, but you feel like you might be able to puzzle it all out with more viewings. I didn't love it as much as I anticipated, but it also didn't disappoint me all that much.

WHAT I LIKED: I don't think you can truly appreciate how different and innovative 'Arrival' is until you see it, because literally everything here is entirely fresh and unexpected, and delves underneath everything we think we know. For a start, the story itself looks below the very essence of the challenges we'd likely face when literally interacting with aliens, which is something I've never seen or even considered in a movie before. In turn, this allows for the exploration of some very fundamental themes that again, tend to get glossed over in film. All in all, this makes it a genuine eye-opener; shining the light on the systems we take for granted, and suddenly making us acutely aware of the very basis of humanity's function - not just communication and time, but also love and life or death. It's all the more despairing and gripping then, to see the world rip itself apart as it tries to deal with these concepts, as you're equally struggling with the monuments level of careful consideration and reflection this movie demands.
It could have easily felt void of emotional heart though, and with Villenueve on board that was definitely a big risk, but Arrival actually has huge emotional weight thanks to  a brilliantly layered lead who's arc is intertwined with the overall story to truly invest you, and translate the overall concepts it tackles. Couple that with a very well-realised set of world building aided by unsurprisingly incredible cinematography and visual effects, as well as a very appropriate score - the result is an experience that makes you invest ten-fold and think an awful lot indeed.
WHAT I DIDN'T LIKE: The set-up could have been slightly more elegant in its pacing, but at least it cuts to the point quickly.
VERDICT: From the genre, to humanity itself; 'Arrival' is a film that delves underneath everything we know, and the result is Villenueve's best film. That's not just because its themes are so powerful though; this thing's got soul, too.

A few disclaimer statements up front about Arrival:
1) From the trailers first scene last year, Arrival kinda looked "interesting" but not interesting enough for me to get my butt onto a cinema seat to see it either at TIFF or when it was first released in November of last year.
2) For those whom I spoke to who did see it, some liked it.  Some had to give it a few shots to get through it all.  Others didn't "get it."

3) Since it was nominated for Best Picture and Best Director Oscars, I had to go see it (to make first hand, informed opinions on what should win best picture).
4) I've seen just over half (5) of the 9 best pictures and ....

5) Arrival would HANDS DOWN be my pick for best picture!  Without a doubt!   Arrival's intricate, Memento-ish, holistic awe and wonderment builds by implanting questions and "WTF is going on"ness for three-quarters of the movie until the completely mesmerizing and "Are you serious??" shocking twist happens.  The last 20 to 30 mins is when either your mind gets blown off, out, all over the theatre or you go "I don't get it.... what just happened?"
6) Amy Adams was absolutely riveting and captivating.  So much that she was definitely smacked in the face with her Oscar snub for Arrival.  She was dark and gothic-glam in Nocturnal Animals (the best thing about the film was her).  But her performance in Arrival was flawless.  Whether she would have beaten out Emma Stone in La La Land, who knows.  But she HANDS DOWN deserved to be there (in a category where I've only seen one best actress flick - Stone's La La Land).

A short post disclaimer review:

Obviously I cannot ruin the twisty surprise. Which means I can't give too much away or what "clues" or "insight" to lookout for.  Just keep in mind that Canadian Denis Villeneuve (who - in one of the rare post-movie credits "Behind the Scenes" segment - had always wanted to do Sci-fi) jumps into the "mind"verse of Christopher Nolan a la the previously mentioned Memento and Inception.  
Villeneuve's previous pictures have also been psychologically engaging; from the likes of the dark dark but mindducking Prisoners, to the political military insurgent Sicario.   He will also be handling Blade Runner 2049 with Ryan Gosling.  Villenuve's handling of the masterpiece Arrival is no different.  The colours are subdued and toned down.  The camera always seems to be and keeps moving (it's rare a scene is ever stationary).  His Montana landscape shots are beautiful and expansive.  His incorporation of the global alien arrival drop zones with news media footage is seamlessly integrated and provides a greater scope and foundation to the "us versus them" political and military phobic terror.  Yet Villenuve's emotional captivation handling of the radiant performance of Amy Adams as Louise is so touching, traumatic as well as eye opening, it fits in so influentially within the international "big picture" directorial scope and vision.
Speaking of "fitting," I give a standing O to editor Joe Walker for weaving a non-linear timeline into a perfect final product; where scenes that originally made you think "why is the movie jumping around so much" or "what was that scene truly about?" make you have a completely different revelationary reaction towards the end once the twist is revealed.  The twist ONLY works because of Villeneuve's detailed and "non"abstract (in the end) filmmaking and Walker's editing.
However, even the two of them couldn't have made the movie so profound without the masterful contributions of others: such as cinematographer Bradford Young (Selma) and music/score composer Johann Johannsson (who worked on Villenuve's previous films Sicario and Prisoners as well as the Stephen Hawking movie The Theory of Everything).   I would highly recommend to stay around for the behind the scenes doc, as it will truly put you in awe of Young and Johannsson's involvement and contribution in making Arrival spectacular.

EVERYONE on the film deserves kudos and their fair share credit; even down to costume designers (for the quarantine garb) and the special effects gurus (in handling the hetapod aliens; the exterior and interiors of the space ship; and Adams' final interaction scene with the alien).
Forest Whitaker as Colonel Weber is apropos, and Jeremy Renner is also fitting as Ian as his storyline evolves (when he and Adams' have their truck tailgate chat, I was like "Why is his character even being focused on as he truly doesn't seem to be contributing anything?") and how it integrates into Adams' Louise.  
Hands down my favourite movie so far in 2017, and my biggest rooter for winning some Oscar gold.

I usually enjoy Sci-Fi movies, the ones that give you something to think about. When I saw the arrival I was scared that it would be an "interstellar like time related movie", damn I was wrong.
The arrival tells the story of a linguist - expert who is sent to communicate with aliens who have landed on different parts of the worlds. The movie shows the process of understanding their language and also why they are on earth.
What appealed me the most was the music. It is so well timed and it matches perfectly the characters' feeling. Sometimes it is just a few notes but it is enough to amaze the viewer.
The story is told beautifully, the mystery around the aliens fades gently during the movie and the spectator slowly understands the plot and some elements from the beginning. The only negative point is the finale which was a bit too fast for my taste.
I enjoyed the philosophy around the language. The fact that they think differently because of the aliens' language and also that they can perceive time differently with it. Great discussion subject!
Otherwise I was pleasantly surprised by Amy Adams's performance, I wasn't expecting much but it was great.
I highly recommend this movie. Always.

This movie had no clichés.  It was intelligent, unique, mind-boggling.  At the same time, it was a bit boring, though its originality was interesting. However, it missed somewhere.  What was refreshing was its realistic take on aliens visiting earth. The chances of an English-speaking alien having two arms and two eyes with height roughly six feet tall is one to a million.  This alien, a cross between an oceanic giant hand and an octopus, showed no violence, which was a welcomed change from most Hollywood films.  But this movie missed human connection somehow.  Ian was supposed to be this top scientist, but the film TOLD us that; they did not show us.  All he did was ooh and ahh to Dr. Banks, who never cracked a smile and who was an alien to any sense of humor.  This top linguistic doctor could roam around the military base at whim, where military officials didn't or couldn't stop her.

I started the film thinking this is like Space Odyssey and finished thinking this is as anti as can be.

In my interpretation of Space Odyssey, the monolith represents human nature, which is beyond good and evil. Is using a bone as a weapon to drive rivals away from the water hole good or evil? Neither because it is human to want to ensure our own survival.

In Arrival, monolith x 12 is here to unify humanity. Personally, I think things worked out because the aliens worked with 12 nations independently. If they only sent one monolith, they would not have had the opportunity to test 12 different approaches. Yes, different people doing different things will create conflict and conflict will create winners and losers at least in the short term. In the longer term, the rival ape men might find a bigger water hole elsewhere.

In terms of cinematography, I loved every moment of Arrival. So I'm sort of hoping that I misunderstood the message and the film is not suggesting that we all unify around THE RIGHT ANSWER. Otherwise, I think Arrival represents everything that is wrong with the world. When people try too hard to grasp the truth, they find themselves bound by narratives created by others.

Science fiction films tend to stratify into 3 categories, in my mind. The most commercially successful are really just adventure films set in a science fiction universe. These focus on action and fantasy, with futuristic or high-concept elements. They leverage classic story archetypes and superlative visuals to produce enjoyable escapism. Star Wars is the exemplar of this sub-genre, and although Star Trek aspires to greater scientific rigor, it belongs here too.
 
The second set similarly uses science as a backdrop for noir. These are the darker films, the dystopian adventures. They may not be as hopeful or as fun, but they tend to be more pointed. These films typically propound on a "what if" premise, plumbing the dingy depths of possibility. The best are often imaginative, twisted interrogations of human nature or society. This is Blade Runner, The Matrix, Dark City.
 
Finally, there are what I like to call "thinking" films. They are headier, and explore ideas that fundamentally change reality or alter our perception of it. They eschew spectacle and adrenaline to allow the audience to dive deep on a single premise. These films are typically smaller in focus, slower, often centering around the journey of a single character. Usually less accessible movies, Hamlet might opine that these "pleased not the million, (but) 'twas caviar to the general". I would count 2001, Interstellar, K-PAX and others as "thinking" sci-fi. Arrival fits securely in this group.
 
Arrival is a big budget take on a small story, focusing almost myopically on Louise, a linguistics expert who is conscripted to help communicate with extra-terrestrial beings who arrive suddenly above the Earth. Her journey of consciousness as she learns to comprehend the aliens serves as the plot, using the events of the story more as context than narrative. Director Denis Villeneuve deftly uses arresting visuals and frank, realistic sensibilities to relate a story that might otherwise be esoteric. It's fantastic elements are believable because of his steady hand, and even the few quibbles i had in hindsight melted away while watching the screen.
 
Arrival is an experience. It is thoughtful and beautiful, and has lingered in my thoughts since viewing.

while there are elements of "alien invasion/human misunderstanding" this is actually a pretty unique spin on the genre for Hollywood. It has a deliberate pace and the learning to communicate with the aliens feels earned rather than easily granted. It's also unsettling in places (with the slightly distorted dreams) and the bending of physics can get a little trippy in the final act so that while the aliens may not appear threatening their representation of the unknown still is. I'd read the short story the film was based on over 15 years ago and feel the executed the language and other revelations pretty well. Villeneuve has gone up in my expectations as a director, showing he's not afraid to leave gaps for the viewer/actor/scenery to fill. Amy Adams is on a roll of late taking on varied work and quickly becoming an actor whose presence in a film has me interested. Renner doesn't really get that much to do which is a bit of a shame but nice to see him do something different from special-ops guy. He's actually pretty good at the everyman role. The film lacks the spectacle of "interstellar" but is far more coherent with what at times is quite a similar plot.

Dennis Villeneuve materializa o notoriamente intricado e provocante roteiro num jogo imagético que destoa do plano coerente e acorrentador do Tempo a fragmentação e deslocamento dele. Aqui, a criatura humana que desejar desfrutar duma fita acerca de criaturas extra-terrestre travando guerra ou sendo involuntariamente embrenhados numa sofrerá infalivelmente decepcionado. A fita arrola sobre ou, se quisermos abusar do efeito poético,  pinta retratos ora deslumbrantes quanto ao aspecto, ora assombrantes, quanto a substância significativa que evoca, da criatura humana profundamente afetada pelas cadeias lançadas pelo Tempo em si ou, doutra forma, dolorosamente afetadas e amofinadas pela noção linguística dele, como, de forma geral, asserta a teoria Sapir-Whorf. No contato com aquelas criaturas não-terreais, a Dra. Louise aprende uma outra forma de estruturar seus pensamentos com uma fascinante maneira de se abordar a linguagem, isto é, adaptando às suas estruturas cognitivas a noção do fazer linguístico não-linear, de tal modo descolado do ou oscilando no eixo temporal.  Não obstante, e ainda mais surpreendente, pode-se 'manusear' os acontecimentos, impedir ou entabular guerras ou conflitos, a criatura humana se acha, ainda, incapaz de ludibriar a morte ou dor... Então, tudo se repete, mas o desfrute é potencialmente maior nesse reviver, é tudo que nos resta em últimas vias.

Arrival is a thoughtful and legitimately clever science fiction movie and Amy Adams is terrific as a language interpreter hired to establish a dialogue with a recently arrived alien species. The only problem is that the aliens communicate by emitting dark vapour that formulates intricate circular patterns. It is then up to Adams to use her skill and resourcefulness to interpret this 'universal language'. In an age of pseudo-clever Hollywood films like 'Interstellar', I was quite surprised by the subtle shadings in this film. It is rare indeed.

It is hard to truly comment on the film without including spoilers, but I will do my best. 

Arrival is a film that I find I am forced to wrestle with rather than simply appreciate. To be honest, I am still not entirely certain how I feel about it. It is a good film, to be sure, but I remain conflicted about how good it actually is. I count myself among those who were able to predict (at least somewhat) where the film was heading about half-way through, and so my experience with the film became less about measuring the wow factor of the initial surprise of the ending and more about noting the ways in which it manages to piece the narrative together. 

The heart of the film is in the question it poses, and it is the nature of how you respond to the question (which is drawn out of the film's poetic finish) that I think will impact your overall experience of the film and it's characters. Adams plays the professional linguist professor Louise Banks, who gets pulled into an investigation of these mysterious pods that have appear rather suddenly in 12 different locales around the globe. Right from the film represents this investigation as a global concern, an element of the story that becomes increasingly important to the developing tension. What we know of Banks from the get go is that certain traumatic events have played a role in bringing her to the love of linguistics that she is now being asked to give in service to this global push for answers- why are they here and what do they want? 

Adams gives a very good performance, really giving herself to the sort of patient unveiling that the story demands. Arrival is an intelligent Sci-Fi that moves slowly but with great intention, and Adams expertly navigates the pacing by making good use of the space the film affords her to kind of linger and play around with different emotions. It becomes very clear early on that this is a personal journey for her, one that is going to pull out some different conflicting emotions, and Adams ensures that, as an audience, we are able to take this journey with her. 

This film has been defined in other spaces as the next "Contact". Here is where the tension likely begins and ends for me. I loved that film. I liked this one. And yet what I loved about Contact is the pure sense of awe that it inspired in the moment. Arrival didn't garner this same level of emotion, for whatever reason. What Arrival did do, though, is manage to linger. The more I consider its central question, the more it seems to pull me into the experience of the film. There is something about the way it managed to do this (and continues to do this) that separates it from Contact in a way. The central question of Arrival is far more specific and intimate than the more generalized reflection (of faith and meaning and the expansiveness of the universe) that Contact evoked. And it works to Arrivals benefit. 

So by no means is Arrival a mediocre film. It is a very good film. Does it belong in the best picture category? Does it deserve all of the nominations is has managed to garner? I am not sure. Even though any film is this to some degree or another, it feels like Arrival remains that much more of a specific and subject experience. Which means it should make for some enriching discussion and dialogue (in most circles), but it also might render it somewhat allusive in the realm of that subjectivity.

Arrival (La Llegada) es una interesante, aterradora, conmovedora y muy relevante película de ciencia ficcion, imprescindible para cualquier amante del genero. Dirigida por uno de los mejores directores de la actualidad, el canadiense Denis Villenueve, es una muestra de ciencia ficción inteligente que no necesita alardear de grandes escenas de acción y efectos especiales.
 El film se centra en la llegada de los extraterrestres a nuestro planeta y los esfuerzos de un equipo encabezado por la lingüista Louise Banks                       (Extraordinaria  Amy Adams)  que tiene la labor de aprender a comunicarse con ellos para determinar si sus intenciones son hostiles o pacíficas. 
'La llegada' es una película sobre la importancia del lenguaje, el miedo a lo desconocido y a provocar un grave conflicto por no comprender a nuestro receptor. Del mismo modo que las anteriores excelentes películas de Villeneuve (Prisioneros , Enemy y Sicario), la película es al mismo tiempo compleja, oscura y misteriosa. (Con muchas ganas de ver ya su proxima pelicula que seria la secuela del clasico de ciencia de ficcion "Blade Runner").
 El ritmo de 'La llegada' es deliberadamente sobrio, el espectador recibe la información que necesita justo en el momento adecuado para ir atando cabos al mismo tiempo que la protagonista. Como un reflejo de cómo funcionan muchos puzzles, la película se fragmenta más cuanto más se acerca Louise a averiguar por qué los alienígenas han llegado y qué quieren de nosotros.
Técnicamente, la película es una maravilla. La próxima comparación se va a convertir en un tópico del que vamos a terminar aburridos, pero tanto la música Johan Jóhannsson (tremendamente emotiva, pero también sensorial y oscura, apegada a los espacios que acompaña), como la fotografía de Bradford Young (rica en texturas y en elecciones muy concretas de la luz, como un guión que subyace entre las palabras), remiten a atmósferas y estilos del cine de Kubrick. Arrival, siendo tremendamente realista, contiene misterio, tensión, incógnitas que no son tramposas. En conclucion Arrival es una maravilla, muy merecido sus 8 nominaciones al Oscar, hasta me atrevo a decir que merece ganar el premio a mejor pelicula, la unica injusticia es que Amy Adams se quedo sin Nominacion.
En conclucion pelicula imperdible y perfecta, no apto para el publico que esperan solo mucha accion y efectos especiales de peliculas de invasiones extraterrestres.
Calificacion: 5 de 5 estrellas (Excelente)

"Arrival" starts off as a great sci-fi film (in the vein of "The Day the Earth Stood Still" or "Contact") grounded in reality. Unfortunately, the narrative of the movie ends up falling apart 3/4ths of the way through when an M. Night Shamylan-esque twist is thrown into the plot. It does pay off in a clever way towards the end, but the line of logic to getting to that point is convoluted at best, shoddy at worst. It took me completely out of the movie, which I was enjoying otherwise. While the other actors in the ensemble (including Jeremy Renner and Forest Whitaker) are given little to work with in terms of shallow characterizations, Amy Adams is terrific in the lead role (and definitely deserved a spot on this year's "Best Actress" Oscar list). Johann Johannsson's rousing score is also a highlight of the movie. Overall though, aside from those criticisms, it is still a solid flick.

Denis Villeneuve nos deja evidenciado una vez más quién es. Después de grandes filmes como "Incendies" y "Sicario", nos plasma un trabajo cinematográfico que sin duda formará parte de la mejor herencia del Sci-Fi. Hasta el momento ninguno de sus trabajos nos ha dejado sintiéndonos incompletos o inconformes con tan elaboradas cintas llenas de investigación, sustento histórico y apego a la realidad; "Arrival" no es la excepción y definitivamente entra como parte de las mejores películas del 2016. Se trata de una excepcional obra maestra en la que se reúnen varias temáticas que apuntan a diversas conclusiones, pero nunca perdiendo el hilo central y conector de esta elaborada y genial historia. Miedo, asombro, sorpresa, confusión, valentía y ternura son muchas de las emociones que "Arrival" nos deja y en las que nos envuelve. 
La ciencia ficción ha sido un área tan amplia, tan experimentada y, sin embargo, tan incomprensible que por ende nos hace aclamar y aplaudir este espectacular filme de Villeneuve. Después de que 12 OVNIs aterrizan en distintos puntos de la tierra, la lingüista Louise Banks (Amy Adams) tiene en sus manos la labor de contactar con seres extraterrestres. El reto que esto significa es prácticamente inimaginable y imposible, pero el recorrido que emprende junto con Ian Donnelly (Jeremy Renner) nos deja pensando profundamente acerca de lo que somos, de la manera en que hemos asimilado la comunicación humana de forma tan normal y cotidiana que nos cerramos a que existan formas impensables de realizarla, por ello se nos brinda una experiencia emocional cuya huella puede dejar a cualquiera impactado y pensando por un largo tiempo. La crítica que se hace al perfil del órgano militar del estadounidense es excelente, aunque los clichés de la historia romántica y de los roles de varios países y su forma de enfrentarse al caos se hacen presentes. Asimismo, el soundtrack pudo haber sido significativamente mejor. Aun así, esto no es suficiente para derribar tan impetuosa y satisfactoria obra de ciencia ficción. También abundan las excelentes imágenes y tomas de las que uno puede admirar los distintos ángulos, analizándose desde diferentes perspectivas, creando una obra donde cada uno de sus elementos se fusionan tan espectacularmente que mantiene la atención del espectador. Efectos grandiosos y ambiente deleitante se pone frente a nosotros, sumado a la más que sobresaliente actuación de Amy Adams son otros ejemplos del por qué "Arrival" merece nuestra atención, merece ser galardonada y ser vista muchas veces más. 92/100

" Arrival delivers a must-see experience for fans of thinking person's sci-fi that anchors its heady themes with genuinely affecting emotion and a terrific performance from Amy Adams."  That says it there.  There's no action...no weird alien encounters...just a thoughtful exploration of what an encounter would be like and why it might occur.

I found fascinating the breakdown of how to interpret a new language.  The circular nature of the story.  The question of would you change your future if you knew it.  I found it all entertaining and interesting.

I'm a fan of Amy Adams and disappointed that she didn't get an oscar nomination (I think she's had 5 so far).  The only other nominee I've seen this year is Emma Stone in La La Land. Between the mistifying production design, Jóhann Jóhannsson's blood-curdling score of intense strings and brass, and an overall cold atmosphere shot in a sort of monochromatic manner, Arrival is, in some ways, a horror movie. The way the film portrays an "alien invasion" as a sort of spontaneous event, something nobody could possibly prepare for and have no idea how to properly handle the situation, is very much terrifying, mostly because it so effortlessly captures just how true such a situation would be. And as we're thrust into the situation first-hand, led by the pairing of linguist Louise Banks and theoretical physicist Ian Donnelly, the shrouded secrecy (which is quite literal in this case: the mysterious beings are hidden in a thick fog) only gets more chilling. Why are these beings here? Are they peaceful? Will they annihilate us in an instant with one single miscommunicated phrase? These tensions grow continuously during the film, as the military grows increasingly paranoid. At one point, an ultimately ambiguous phrase from the mysterious craft is received. Their first instinct: panic. Immediate interpretation of the message as a threat.

The film comes from Denis Villeneuve, who has continuously established himself as a master of building secrecy and tension, from intense crime thrillers Prisoners and Sicario to the mystifying and surreal Enemy. As a very cerebral, haunting film. Arrival certainly falls in line with those films, and yet also stands as perhaps Villeneuve's most emotionally involved film in his career. At its core, it's very much a film about humanity. Throughout the film, we're greeted with flashbacks to Louise's life pre-invasion, and the way Villeneuve and screenwriter Eric Heisserer link the flashbacks to the current narrative is truly clever and genuinely heartfelt. In an age where this coukd be a cynical blockbuster where the aliens are instantly relegated to the "bad guys" for America to save the day from, it's nice to have a film that, for all of its horrific and unnerving aspects, is ultimately the exact opposite: a film about global teamwork and optimism and hope and, quite simply, life itself.
Arrival is an incredibly produced and thought-provoking sci-fi work that is excellently directed, and it succeeds in everything from the technical elements to the performances.

After reading some scalding reviews of this movie, I felt as if this movie required some helpful input. Some call it "boring," or say that they "fell asleep." I'd like to say to this, it is not a blockbuster action flick, but a somber thought provoking movie, that elevates intelligent mystery over blockbuster action. Those who enjoy thought provoking themes and don't mind a distinct mood and feeling will enjoy this.
Much of the movie uses an atmosphere to set a tone, and that tone is consistent throughout the movie. Whereas movies like Interstellar portray visions of epicness and mastery of cinematography, Arrival suceeds in implementing a humanistic nature. It treats the viewer as intelligent, trusting the viewer to draw their own conclusions about the events of the film. 

If you desire something unique, thought provoking, and intelligent, look no further.

It does not matter how many millions of dollars you throw into transferring a bad story into a film, the result is the same...a bad story. Arrival is a boring attempt at telling yet another 'the aliens have invaded the Earth' story. The plot is fragmented, hard to follow and to be quite honest by halfway through the film I had lost all interest and was very tempted to walk out of the cinema. I have seen better attempts at cinematic aliens in the B movies made in the 50's and 60's. The 'spacecrafts' are a joke...they look like some strange variety of banana. By the end of the film I was totally confused as to whether it was the end, the beginning or even the middle of this convoluted story. The mixture of 'space ships, aliens and special people who can see into the future is very badly orchestrated and fails miserably to pass any intended message to the audience. I would class this film as a very poor 'B' movie made for television not a 'Hollywood blockbuster' that cost 47 million dollars to matter how many millions of dollars you throw into transferring a bad story into a film, the result is the same...a bad story. Let's say this. If the aliens knew they would need help they would know what the problem is that they will face. If they know the problem then they would know the solution. If they know the solution then what was the whole point of this?

Solemn, maudlin and pretentious - this bum-numbing low-budget remake of Contact also has a pair of uncharismatic performances from Amy Adams and Jeremy Renner, investigating a huge floating rock piloted by ink-squirting squid. If that floats your boat, then you'll also enjoy Forrest Whittaker at his most self-pityingly morose. Interstellar has a competitor in the sci-fi Razzie category.

Arrival seems very plausible, which is why it works. It feels like a realistic response to an extra-terrestrial encounter. This isn't an action-packed alien invasion blockbuster -- it's a deep-thinking drama about trying to understand the incomprehensible. Amy Adams carries this movie, and Jeremy Renner isn't annoying. This is slow, but smart science fiction.

Dennis Villeneuve proves he is one of the greatest directors out there. His vision, pacing, and suspense are unparalleled, and that comes into full scope in Arrival. I'm not one for alien movies, but this is what an alien movie should be. It's smart, realistic, and grounded. It gets you wondering what an alien invasion would truly be like. How would we handle it? Would it bring the world together, or tear it apart? Villeneuve hits the nail on the head.
The visuals are near perfect, often jaw dropping. The score by Johann Johannsson is haunting, yet wonderful and sets each scene superbly.
The character development is complex, and Amy Adams puts on a performance of the year, if not decade. 
The ending is as satisfying as any ending I have ever seen. Beautiful, and possibly even tear jerking.
What I like best about the film is that it makes you feel something. It makes you think. It makes you appreciate the good in others, and that finding common ground with others can be ever-important in making the world go round. On a more personal level, it gets you appreciating every moment of life for what it's worth.
Bravo to Villeneuve, Johannsson, and Adams for an exceptional film whose impact could last decades.

Arrival es la nueva película del aclamado director Denis Villeneuve (Conocido por películas tan interesantes como Enemy, Prisioners o Sicario) y pelea con grandes argumentos por alguno los puestos más altos en el género de la ciencia ficción.

Críticos como Roger Ebert han hablado mucho sobre el rumbo que están tomando las películas de terror con ejemplos como "Babadook" o "It follows", donde se rechaza el modelo del "jumpscare" (subidas de música e imágenes impactantes) por un estudio de personajes y el tratamiento de temas más profundos como la depresión o la angustia existencial. 

La cinta de Villeneuve así como Interestelar de Nolan o Prometheus de Ridley Scott son un ejemplo de este mismo modelo aplicado a la ciencia ficción. Arrival o La Llegada (como ha sido denominada en países de habla latina) es una película que rechaza el modelo de invasión alienígena de acción y decide realizar un estudio del personaje de Louise, una experta lingüista que obtiene la oportunidad de intentar mantener una conversación con los "visitantes". Y esto lo realiza dando respuesta a preguntas realmente interesantes como ¿De que modo nos enfrentamos a aquello que nos aterra?

Es difícil hablar de Arrival sin correr el riesgo de revelar parte de la trama pero si podemos definir aquello de lo que trata esta película es probablemente la comunicación. La cinta nos recuerda la importancia desmedida de esta capacidad y explota este hecho tan aparentemente sencillo de un modo realmente inteligente. ?
En el reparto encontramos probablemente uno de los puntos más destacables de la película junto al guión, y esto es sin duda la actuación de Amy Adams como Louise. Se trata de una actuación que esta recibiendo muchos rumores de Oscar a mejor actriz principal y no son infundados ya que de algún modo toda la película carga sobre los hombros de la actuación de Amy Adams y en lugar de flaquear consigue hacer, si cabe, aún más destacables algunos de los puntos más interesantes de Arrival. Sin embargo en el reparto también hay uno de los puntos más flacos de la película y se trata de la actuación de Jeremy Renner que aunque está principalmente correcto, logra que algunos de los momentos de más importancia de la película parezcan algo cursis y melodramáticos. Da la sensación de que Renner creía estar actuando en una película diferente y con menos aspiraciones.

La cinematografía de Villeneuve a manos Bradford Young es sin duda otro de los puntos absolutamente sobresalientes del largo y nos regala planos que quitan el aliento. Del mismo modo que utiliza planos cerrados aportando un sentimiento de opresión y tensión palpables, también utiliza planos amplios con mucho espacio para respirar y empaparse de la imagen en aquellos momentos donde nos revela información imprescindible. Juega muy bien con esta dicotomía que sin duda hace de esta película una pequeña y extraña joya.

En definitiva Arrival es una cinta ambiciosa que logra mantener muy bien su tono y sus aspiraciones, y nos cuenta esa historia que hemos oido tantas veces con una perspectiva nueva y fresca que no deja a nadie indiferente. Tiene algunos de los mejores momentos cinematográficos del año y probablemente la mejor actuación de la carrera de Amy Adams desde The Master. Villeneuve se está forjando un nombre en el panorama actual del cine comercial haciendo películas con tintes indies que le hacen uno de los directores más interesantes del momento.

This movie really makes you think? How would you communicate? What would you say? How would you react? What if it could happen? Not many movies make you stop watching to discuss what you would do anymore. This one did. I was happily surprised!

Arrival is, undoubtedly, the best science fiction film of 2016. This because it's so different from other sci-fi films we've seen in the past. It's one of those rare films that'll keep you engaged from the opening title to the end credits. Amy Adam gives her best performance and proves why she's one of the best actors working today.

The space aliens finally arrived (like, what took so long, dude!) only in this interesting turn they're not concerned in taking over ... they just want to talk. Amy Adams is yet again excellent as one linquist tasked with deciphering their burps and giggles, with a twist ending on the horizon. Thought provoking yet slow as molasses.

Arrival es un cinta de SCIFI Muy Fresca, Simple, Predecible y con buenos efectos.....Y si...Es mejor que Interstellar.

Es un día Normal en el Mundo cuando de repente aparecen Naves Espaciales en todo el mundo...pero no crean el caso, solo están ahí varadas sin hacer nada, es ahí cuando la CIA contrata 2 Expertos para poder Traducir a que vinieron estos Aliens.

Si buscas una Película al Estilo Independence Day no lo hallaras, La cinta no tiene Acción en Ningún Momento pero ni siquiera se ven las Caras de los Aliens y a un asi Funciona muy Bien por eso dije algo Fresco para este Genero...Solo hay Intriga y Tensión.

Y quizás sea el único pero su Plot Twist me pareció Predecible, porque ya veía venir que lo de la Hija era en el futuro y cuando llego el momento no me sorprendió en nada, Jeremy Renner llega a ser incluso de relleno y aveces hasta no hacer nada en la Cinta y es me dio Conflicto, Ademas de su Relación con Amy Adamas es Forzada.
La cinta gira en torno a Amy Admas de principio a fin.

Tenemos otro problema y es que la Película Funcionaria mejor si durara 1 Hora con 20 Minutos porque hay momentos muy de Relleno en los que no pasa absolutamente nada y llega a ser hasta cierto punto aburrida en especial sus Primeros 40 Minutos.

Eso si no le quita lo Interesante y la Tensión que te Transmite, Arrival es mi Película Menos Favorita para los Galardones pero su CGI es de lo mejor y aprecio que su trama sea simple y lineal.
No como Interstellar que todo es Forzado y trata de ser Complejo para llamar la Atención.

Arrival es mil veces mejor que Interstellar, Llega a ser Aburrida pero tiene algo que te Mantiene Intrigado y pegado a tu Asiento y si amas el SCIFI la amaras, es por eso que Recibe Mi Clasificación de 3/5

Bolstered by some breathtaking cinematography, an other-worldy soundtrack by Jóhann Jóhannson, a perfect performance by Amy Adams and one of the most socially and politically thought-provoking stories of the decade, "Arrival" enlarges director Denis Villeneuve's collection of critical successes while also delivering a sweet and fresh take on the alien genre.
