Oltre a questo c'è anche la grande tematica di fondo della libertà di scelta delle persone e un sacco di altri temi divisivi e molto profondi. C'è un ma: in tutto ciò, il film è complesso e girato bene ma, mio modesto parere, il regista è molto ambizioso ma non abbastanza capace da rendere un film, sulla carta, veramente interessante in qualcosa di incredibile.

2016's Arrival is a science fiction thriller directed by Denis Villeneuve (Prisoners, Sicario) and is based on the short story The Story of Your Life by Ted Chiang adapted by Eric Heisserer who wrote the screenplay.

Amy Adams stars as Louise Banks, an expert in language and translation who is called upon when a number of alien vessels appear on Earth in various locations. The intentions of the aliens, who are attempting to communicate are not known and Banks is brought in by Colonel GT Weber (Forest Whitaker) to attempt to understand their language, and to understand what their plans are.

Alongside Banks as they begin to attempt to communicate with the aliens is Dr Ian Donnelly (Jeremy Renner), a theoretical physicist.

The film progresses with both their ongoing attempts to understand the aliens, but also against the backdrop of increasing tensions across the planet. These tensions are taking the form of looting and fuel / food shortages, but also the knowledge that other nations are attempting their own communications with the aliens (including Russia and China) and that these may lead to a different, more aggressive stance towards the visitors.

Amy Adams, who I remain of the view that she is incredibly underrated, delivers another standout performance, in her role through the film with essentially the whole narrative of the film resting on her performance. From the initial entrance into the craft, all the way through the efforts to communicate and interspersed cut away moments, she shines throughout the film.

The score (by Johan Johannsson)  too stands out with usage of what feels like aboriginal music in some parts and haunting orchestral score (which in part uses Max Richter's 'On the Nature of Daylight' at other moments through the film.

Villeneuve direction of this matches the quality of his previous work, which when you look at the work he's delivered, is a significant achievement. Tension builds throughout the scenes (especially those on the alien craft) and he has woven a film together that is thought provoking, moving, and really really smart.

That, ultimately is one of the main achievements of the film, it doesn't dumb down its content and delivers a very clever film that manages to keep getting better throughout. In the recent series of smart science fiction that Christopher Nolan has been a large part of with Inception and Interstellar, it really stands out as an achievement.

I'd really encourage anyone that hasn't seen it to make the effort. It is easily one of the very best films of 2016.

Arrival is a new film directed by Denis Villeneuve, one of the best directors working currently, in my opinion. The story follows a linguist, Louise (played by Amy Adams), and a scientist, Ian (played by Jeremy Renner), who are hired by the army to decipher the language of the aliens that have landed on Earth in their spaceships. I'd hate to spoil anything about the plot and how it all comes to a close, but I'll have to spoil certain things, so I'm putting a spoiler warning here! With that said, this is a brilliant movie, really. From the very beginning it draws you in and it's consistently intriguing throughout. It never becomes dull, too long or even pretentious. It is a slow burn movie, but the story concerning the aliens is fantastic and the ending payoff is highly satisfying and made me think more about what I saw earlier. The aliens are very well designed and their language is the big mystery of this movie. Following Louise and Ian learning their language and teaching the aliens English was very entertaining. I had a lot of fun watching them teaching each other. It felt so much different from any other alien invasion movie I've ever seen. This isn't the kind of an alien invasion movie where the aliens are just attacking and trying to destroy the world, there isn't any action in this movie. It consists the most of conversations with the aliens, deciphering their language, learning their past and it feels much more interesting than just another big blockbuster with aliens. The cinematography is breathtaking. Especially the first time we see the alien spaceship, it felt reminiscent of the scene when we first see humans interacting with the Monolith in 2001: A Space Odyssey. The movie is visually stunning all throughout its runtime, as is every Villeneuve movie. The soundtrack by Jóhann Jóhannsson is sublime. His score is one of the best of the year [2016] and I'm still re-listening to it as I'm writing this review. Beautiful. The characters are very well developed, especially Amy Adams' character. Ian isn't as developed, we don't know anything about his life except that he's a scientist, but his character serves more as an element to Louise's development and when you look at it that way, he served his purpose. Forest Whitaker is also good in this movie, though not a very interesting character. There's not much to say about him. The star here is definitely Amy Adams and her character. Amy Adams delivers an incredible performance and when certain things are revealed about her character, it makes her even more interesting. The ending was powerfully emotional. I'm not going to say what it is, but I will say it's one of the best twist endings I've ever seen. The thing I didn't like about this movie is just one scene. That's it. Just one little scene that felt very out of place and held no real purpose. You'll know what it is, it's quite noticeably unfitting. All in all, Arrival is a fantastic alien invasion movie that will definitely be remembered as one of the best. I highly recommend watching this movie, it's worth it.

I consider sci-fi to be in many ways, the hardest genre. It's incredibly rare for a science fiction film to be perfect, the opportunities for flaws are endless. Arrival is smart, exhilarating, well-crafted in every conceivable way and not an experience I feel like I've had before. I can't remember the last time I was this all-around satisfied by anything, and I'm really just in disbelief that we have this huge movie with movie-stars and such that's revolves around fucking linguistics.

In a world where Hollywood has imagined mankind meeting alien life countless times, making it fairly difficult separate yourself from the much with yet another entry in the genre, Canadian director Denis Villeneuve offered a stirring riposte. This is sci-fi with a Master's degree that doesn't falter on Hollywood razzle-dazzle; there's an A-list cast; there's scale and bluster; there's special effects that wow; there's pace and tension; there was even a grand IMAX release, should you be so inclined. But it is also an intensely cerebral piece of work, transforming Ted Chiang's short story about a linguist who is called in to communicate with extra-terrestrials after 12 space vessels that ominously land in various locations around the world, into an atmospheric wrong-footing puzzle which plays with narrative conventions and linguistic head-scratchers. And thanks to an emotional, career-best performance from Amy Adams, it never loses sight of its humanistic core. Not bad for a movie about aliens.

Quite literally a complete and utter waste of time. The very definition of '2hrs-of-your-life-that-you'll-never-get-back'. Flat, blank, characterless, with nothing of any real genuine intrigue or purpose. Another example of 'nothingness' masquerading as supposed 'art'. The plot-holes are in their masses, but that's not the issue here - the "film", plainly, is just boring, pointless, vapid; to unbearable levels; and on all fronts (the look on Forrest Whittaker's face throughout says it all). None of the characters have any depth, all more cardboard than actual cardboard would permit, and everything is narrated with no soul or verve; unintentionally lifeless; dire. There is no feeling or emotional-engagement - whatsoever. And the film, based on a short-story (which painfully shows), desperately yearns to be dark, meaningful, existential - but there is simply no substance to any of it. You obtain nothing. Gain nothing. Just nonsense. The art of storytelling, gone amiss. And to add insult-to-injury, the underlining "message" (if one can call it that) at the end is so naff and inconsequential, that you wonder if a computer or a robot has produced and made the film, thinking it were 'avant-garde'. There is no payoff. Don't bother. Or if you dare to test its (unendurable) shallow waters, on its imminent release, make sure you've plenty of work around the house to do.

Arrival revolves around a linguist named Louise, played by Amy Adams, who is recruited to assist in confronting an alien species that has landed on Earth. 12 UFOs appear randomly around the world, but humans are finding it difficult to communicate with the aliens in order to find out what they want. Louise, paired with a mathematician named Ian, played by Jeremy Renner, sets out to find a way to talk with the aliens.
Director Denis Villeneuve is one of the most exciting directors working today. Prisoners is chilling and Sicario is a masterpiece. Both movies go far beyond their generic genres. Prisoners goes beyond most suspenseful thrillers by studying how its protagonists deal with grief, loss, and uncertainty. Sicario goes beyond cartel action dramas by studying humanity pushed to the brink, beyond boundaries and comfortability.
Arrival carries that tradition by going beyond general science fiction action films. But it also defects from Villeneuve's previous films' focus on revenge by taking on more optimistic motivations, though they're not immediately obvious.
Every behind the camera aspect of this movie is spectacular. Villeneuve's direction combined with Bradford Young's cinematography create a chilling, somewhat somber world that's beautiful to look at. And it's all set to a moving score by composer Johann Johansson, that builds alongside the movie in it's scale and emotionalism.
Even the aspects of the movie I was already expecting moved me. I thought the alien ship reveal wouldn't be powerful since it's presence is the basis of the movie's advertising. It takes up most of every poster and commercial, but it's reveal is built up in a way that it's still incredible to see. Exploring the ship and seeing the aliens themselves is even more astounding. It's a completely new and fresh feeling that most movies don't give you.
The story itself blossoms throughout the movie into many different directions, each one extremely interesting. There's the response of the public, who are uncertain and afraid of the aliens. There's the response of other countries, who are interpreting the alien language on their own, sometimes in unfortunate ways. The combination of the fearful public and aggressive militaries put pressure on the US military to get an understanding of the aliens and why they're here before war breaks out. But there's also the story of Louise herself. We explore her past, her experiences with the aliens, the importance of her being there, and the importance of conversation. But it handles it's diverse plot incredibly well. It's as political as it is philosophical. It's massive and at the same time intimate. This is the kind of movie Interstellar was desperately trying to be, but ultimately fell short.
Amy Adams is devastatingly powerful as Louise. It's a very strong lead performance, possibly the best of her career. She carries this movie and gives us a character we can heavily empathize with. She's smart, strong, and brave. By the midway point we fully believe she can be the hero the movie needs, for the world and for herself.
Jeremy Renner starts off as an alright main supporting character, first getting worse, then getting considerably better. At one point he has this cockiness, this forced fun guy attitude that should be now referred to as the "Chris Pratt trope". The lovable bad-ass. A fun character but one who's definitely starting to wear his welcome. But he fleshes out a bit, and we see him start to relate more with Adam's character and become more relatable himself. That being said, his character isn't super useful in terms of story progression. Adams gets most of the job done by herself, and while Renner plays off her well, I feel the movie would've played alright with Adams as the lone protagonist.
This movie has a few more imperfections. When Louise is recruited by the military, it's explained that she worked with them before, but how she was recruited for that previous mission isn't explained. And because of that, it's not immediately believable that she is this genius linguist, it feels more like she was picked at random. It was just kind of confusing. Also, the explanation of why the aliens are here wasn't ideal. I mean, it's not bad, and it's different from what I was expecting, but it's reveal was just kind of "oh". Also Forest Whitaker and Michael Stuhlberg are great in the movie, but are a bit underutilized. Though I understand to have more of them would mean to take away from the development of Adam's character, so it's not terrible, but I like those actors so I like when they have more to work with.
The one thing that I thought would bother me but somehow didn't is how it is basically Exposition: The Movie. We are forced to learn everything through character dialogue. And most movies don't know how to do it properly, and are very boring because of it. But like a page out of the David Fincher handbook, dialogue scenes are exciting, riddled with tension and importance. We pay attention because we want to, not because we have to. I mean, we have to, but the wanting to is a nice caveat.
But there is an event or revelation in the movie, an unexpected turning point, and I gotta say, it kinda blew my mind, and helped me get over whatever issues preceded it. It was a complete surprise and took the story to a new level of greatness. I won't spoil what that is, but I will say don't arrive (no pun intended) to this movie late. Every scene matters and honestly might need re-watching to be fully understood. And maybe that revelation might not be super impressive to you, or maybe you'll hate it for being a departure from the straight-forwardness the movie had built until then, but it can't be argued that it's something different, something we don't get very often in film, and I feel like that deserves to be cherished.
Arrival is held together by its dedication to communication and discovery, introducing us to something new at a gradual pace and that keeps us invested and excited. It's thought provoking, and we are motivated to learn alongside Louise. It's a rare feat for a movie, and I can't wait to see what rare feat Villeneuve pulls off next.

This film is beautiful and crushingly bittersweet. The brilliance of this performance also seems to be practically invisible to most American theater goers, as far as I can tell from all the head scratching in the lobby. Despite its central device, a theory about language and experience that the film uses to in ways that could strain credibility--and a few similarly odd features (Adams' character is really chosen because her translation of "war" from Sanskrit was morally neutral--and the general somehow knew of and valued such an interpretation?)--I would say that Arrival is one of the best films I've ever seen. More thoughtful than heady (as some reviews have it), this film is graceful, well paced, and an innovation in story telling with regard to its forward chronological structure. Just a great film. Even those moronic philistines and geeks who've since Interstellar or thereabout have begun to appreciate films based solely on their scientific cogency or wrote connection to real things they learned in their undergraduate science course will like this film in some way. Watch it.

The marketing of 'Arrival' was greatly focused om "them". But the film takes multiple different steps inwards. It's all about the human perspective and their reactions to the unknown. Humanity is the main character here, not the aliens. It takes time to understand the story, and for some of you; a rewatch might be a good thing, since it's not a pure linear film. It's a slow moving drama that got much to tell about the basics of humanity & morality. If that isn't a thing for you, then pick a different film. Amy Adams as Louise Banks is the major player, and this might be her best performance to date. Natural chemistry and over the top mother-daughter depth is a wow! Character inside might be a lacking aspect in the first act, but the film is heavily focused on build-up, and most of the inside doesn't arrive until in the final act. The character inside develops greatly throughout the film, it follows the non-linear storytelling. Sure even more inside to side-characters would've been great, but the focus lies greatly on Louise Banks for sure and we get a lot of inside to her! But we don't really get that much to Ian Donnelly for example. 

'Arrival' got a clear structure and a stunning build-up. The film takes one step at a time and generally never felt rushed nor uneventful. Sure one rushed moment did exist on a personal level, surrounding the understanding of the aliens. I felt that the editors missed an important plot-point. Another nit-picky aspect can be the uneven pacing at several places throughout the film. But it's not a flawed film. No way. The third act is a major part of the structure. It's where the basic plot and characters blend together into a higher purpose. Some aspects of it did however come off as a bit flat -- the film showed several inventive moves, but some lesser ones did appear in the ending. Once the basic plot was revealed; there wasn't that much more to be excited by. The film fights hard ethical and inventive questions, but it does on the other hand have several a bit too simple moments. It's pretty much the same with the expositions -- who the writers integrated very well into this flick, but they were a bit too noticeable throughout the story. 

'Arrival' is a huge groundbreaker among other sci-fi films of 2016. It's one of those slow-burners with classical sci-fi elements like time, morality, culture, religion, humanity, who we really are, and what is the nature of humanity really? Who's the real antagonist; them or us? 'Arrival' might take inspiration of previous sci-fi works, but it's one of a kind -- and let's not forget the stunning direction from Denis Villeneuve. Just the visuals alone might bring an Oscar to this stunning sci-fi flick.

Despite the fact that this movie has aliens in it, please, for the love of what's good, don't expect the movie to be an action-packed alien invasion movie. It is NOT that kind of movie. Arrival is a slow-paced mystery drama that touches on the less hostile side of things when it comes to first contact. It stars Amy Adams, Jeremy Renner and Forest Whitaker primarily. Amy Adams plays Dr. Louise Banks, an accomplished language expert recruited by the government in an attempt to decipher or communicate with the extraterrestrials on their intention of coming to Earth.
Overall, I would suggest the movie to people who enjoy themselves a little bit of mystery or just simply wanting a refreshing take on the stereotypical alien invasion storyline, which really pays off in droves. The true genius of the movie, is unrealised up until the climax of the movie, and boy is it worth waiting for.

I remember reading Ted Chiang's "Story of Your Life" way back when and being completely blown away. It's one of the very best short stories I've ever come across, infinitely memorable and perfectly structured, every sentence in the correct place. It's also one of those pieces of fiction that is markedly not cinematic, something easily described as unfilmable. Yet French Canadian art house auteur Denis Villeneuve has done just that in the form of "Arrival".

Ted Chiang's story is about a linguist who is given the ultimate dream job of communicating with the first alien visitors to Earth. It's an absolutely enticing depiction of a wonderfully detailed process where a language completely alien reveals its nature. As a reader who doesn't understand linguistics at all, I found this all insanely addictive. We also get memory flashes about the linguist's relationship with her daughter, merging the personal with the scientifically intriguing into a whole that's as stimulating as it's touching. The very structure of the story brings with it mind-bending speculations involving philosophy, ethics and reality itself through peculiar points of view that play freely with temporal mechanics.

Reportedly the film project started with screenwriter Eric Heisserer who decided to take on the impossible task of adapting Chiang's ingenious creation. The resulting script seems to me exactly what you would expect a Hollywood adaptation of a brilliant, endlessly intriguing and smart story to be: dramatic, but formulaic and hideously simplified. The linguistic thrill ride has been reduced to tidbits of technobabble and montage scenes. Only the feel of a challenging process has been retained with little of the actual process remaining. All those lovely, poignantly funny scenes of parenthood tracking the maternal experience from a child's birth to adulthood have been turned into dreamlike flashes of the ideal, portraying the daughter mostly in early childhood, mostly angelic. The short story's main premise that allowed for the most ambitious and brilliant ideas on perception has been given the role of a mere twist near the end.

What Heisserer adds is the dramatic ticking clock. In the film, all of 12 alien objects land all over the globe, creating an immediate diplomatic crisis. This leads to a horribly clichéd but depressingly plausible conflict between scientists and government, aka the impatient military, as well. The most depressing thing about the script is that when Heisserer pitched it for the major studios, they still found it too smart and wanted him to dumb down the science even further. Some studio also requested that the protagonist was changed into a man. No wonder Hollywood is in a crisis. "Arrival" got made as an independent feature and was a big hit.

If you look at the script alone, "Arrival" seems competent but pretty standard, even forgettable Hollywood fair that doesn't do justice to its source material. Fortunately, the project was taken on by Denis Villeneuve. I remember blown away by the director in 2010 when I saw his completely masterful political Middle East thriller "Incendies". The director came to be known for emotionally devastating and addictively complex stories directed with particular aesthetic eye. His move to the U.S. and English films spelled a reduction in complexity, but his ability to visualize psychological experience remains top notch.

In Villeneuve's hands the "necessary evil" of the plot's political ticking clock becomes effective. In the story the scientists' work was more realistic as it took months and was unhurried. But in the film the urgency actually lends its own sense of authenticity. Villeneuve gives his stars- Amy Adams in the lead as linguist Louise Banks and Jeremy Renner as sidekick mathematician Ian Donnelly- an opportunity to portray insecurity and fatigue with devotion. The whole feel of "Arrival" is hazy, sleep deprived and uncertain, in one word alien. It's at its very best during a couple of sparsely distributed dream sequences that would feel like simple nightmares if not for their genuinely otherworldly, peculiar atmosphere. Close-ups of the involved actors' exhausted faces ground everything, makes what's going on relatable. Even those clichéd flashes of Louse's motherhood fit the aesthetic web of "Arrival".

Cinematic storytelling isn't as resonant with us as the linguistic storytelling of literature, which often makes movie adaptations seem as explanatory in relation to their source text. What is alluded to in text and left for the reader to interpret themselves, has often been underscored and written open in an adapted screenplay. It occurred to me that- if you abandon the dull linearity of time- Chiang's superior short story "Story of Your Life" operates perfectly as a really good interpretation of "Arrival" the movie. It probably works really well to see the movie first and then read the deeper, analytical short story on top of that.

As a lover of science fiction I'm often frustrated with how the genre is handled by the movie industry which embraces the visual possibilities of speculative settings but rarely has the courage to utilize the endless narrative and especially thematic potential inherent in them. "Arrival" tries and mostly succeeds in this, maybe not in the most ambitious manner, but still. It's good, very well acted drama that feels realistic yet mystical. It has great intensity and aims to challenge the viewer, which is always something to be thankful for.

A rare type of Spielberg-Nolan style science-fiction drama full of metaphors that is steep in its specific themes told in a sense of realism. The film is an unusual discovery, it starts emotionally, moves in a deliberate pacing, slowly builds up a puzzle of complex paradox and ends up stunningly impactful, amplifying the questions of existential dilemma. It does not need any action sequences, it is all about life, language and unity that bring to the twisted concept of the overall plot development with several hints throughout the entire story, further surprising audiences to view it from different fascinating ways. Amy Adams gains respects for her brilliant performance as a believable thinker and expert communicator while her emotions are handled well in order to engage the entire structure of the film. The theme song "On the Nature of Daylight" in both the opening and ending of the movie, as well as scores composed by Johann Johannsson enhance the the atmosphere of the film especially the thrilling suspense of invasions, the horror moments during the contact and the emotional depth on life perception. The arrival of the extra terrestrial amazes viewers on how creatively a science fiction may diverge from its generic aspects and link to life - telling us that life is a journey without destination and to live as if the answer is, even if you have known everything about the future.

One moment is all it takes to change our lives, to define a species. Director Denis Villeneuve (Sicario, Enemy, Prisoners) presents this moment with a profound silence uncharacteristic of science fiction. No great battle, no chaos or destruction, just the arrival. Sometimes the most terrifying action is nothing at all.

The film opens to Dr. Louise Banks (Amy Adams), a distinguished linguist traveling to work as a lecturer at the University of Montana. All around her people scramble to see screens displaying news although Banks continues to her lecture hall unaware. Almost immediately after beginning the lecture a phone goes off, then another. The world has just changed, the scale of the change however, is hidden for a few more seconds.

After tentively switching a news channel on, they learn of a mysterious object in rural Montana, massive in size and visible for miles around floating just metres from the ground. Speculation suggests an experimental military ship until more objects are found across the world, 12 in total. Villeneuve plants the audience into his world, desperate for any sliver of information but before any possible understanding can form an alarm rings around the lecture hall. The whole state is on lockdown while governments across the world scramble to figure out what is going on. As Banks enters the parking lot we see people rushing to get back to family and jets flying overhead, in a deafening array of sound. 

The next day by contrast is eerily quiet, Banks travels to work as usual although it soon becomes apparent that she's the only one. Here she is approached by Colonel Weber (Forrest Whitaker) to join a military task force at the landing site. Working alongside a theoretical physicist, Ian Donnelly (Jeremy Renner), they must not only establish the methods of communication with the unknown visitors, but decipher it and be able to communicate back. Some nations faced with a landing do not have peace as the primary objective on their agenda. China and Russia mobilise their respective armies to defend the populous from an expected invasion and it becomes a race against time to avert war with potentially peaceful extraterrestrials. Chaos is a persistent threat illustrated through widespread rioting and looting by people under the impression that the end of times is upon them.

Every few hours Banks and Donnelly travel to the bottom of the spaceship from a makeshift base nearby. Cinematographer Bradford Young (Selma, A Most Violent Year) achieves an almost tangible level of anticipation as the sheer scale of the pebble shaped ship is slowly revealed to us. This feeling is very shortly dwarfed in the sequence following as the team make their way inside. For all the advanced technology of both alien and human design depicted, there was a certain irony in using a scissor lift to bridge the gap between the 2 civilisations. When the aliens are eventually revealed, dubbed heptopods for their 7 legs, Banks is unable to make sense of their whale like cries. With the relations of world nations seeming to crumble around them, failure is not an option and upon seeing words and sentences in a visual form and not noise, a deeply complex and beautiful written language is revealed. The further she plunges into this language, the more her reality begins to shift and in doing so changes the fate of her world.

The climax of Arrival is both staggering and satisfying as several confusing elements from early on suddenly become crystal clear. With fabulous cinematography accompanied by a soul-stirring score by Jóhann Jóhannsson, this is truly a first contact film like no other. Villeneuve delivers a poignant message underlining the utter necessity of communication that transcends the screen and resonates beyond.

Everyday society is wondering when the aliens will come, it's an idea reflected in short stories, novels and movies. Just the fact of receving the visit of people from other space constitute a scientific breakthrough. The implications of communication, etiquette and approach goes down to a single question: are you come in peace?

Several directors have portray aliens like friendly, mysterious or a real threat to humanity. James Cameron "The Abyss", Steven Spielberg "Close Encounter of The Third Kind" Robert Zemeckis "Contact" are to me the most influential movies of Dennis Villeneuve "Arrival"

Linguistic Louise Banks (Amy Adams) is been introduced in the movie as a mother and wife, she holds her baby, when she start talking, walking and becomes a teenager, until she passed away. She seems to be alone, even visually. Perhaps as a linguistic she knows how the world communicate, but she is unable to communicate emotionally with her love ones. During the emotional scene you can hear her voice over "But now I'm not so sure I believe in beginnings and endings. There are days that define your story beyond your life. Like the day they arrive..." Her nihilistic words are the vehicle to the arrival of a large group of extra terrestrial. 

12 spaceships appear across the planet (China, Greenland, Siberia and Black Sea in Russia, Japan, United States, Sudan, Venezuela, Sierra Leone, Wales, Pakistan and the Indian Ocean. All the government of these countries are looking for answers. So they decided to bring specialists in several areas to obtain information about the aliens as well their intentions. Jeremy Renner plays physics professor who also works with Louise to find ways to communicate with the aliens.

Villeneuve develops an impressive environment, where atmospheric sounds are very important for the movie. The story encapsulate Louise character, close ups where she is with her daughter and open spaces when she is alone, in fact when she is in a group her position is always ahead differentiate herself from the rest. To me Louise connects perfectly with Ryan Stone (Sandra Bullock) in Gravity a smart professional who is grieving the lost of a love one, in the middle of a situation require her to develop a new set of skills and abilities to reach a goal. 

The political tone of "Arrival" express how divided are nations in peril, but also able to work together when you take risk on your own. Governments set rules that meant to be broken just to make things right. Like in the The Abyss the government secret agenda presents them as the real enemy, not the aliens, which for the audience are friends.

The film is powerful and keeps you thinking about the timeline of the story, specifically when are we located. The experimental music by Jóhan Jóhannsson is a masterpiece, Bradford Young cinematography is engaging as well Joe Walker film editing.

TIME â?? AS IT WAS IN THE BEGINNING, IS NOW, AND EVER SHALL BE-
Before Einstein came up with his brilliant theory of relativity, the world was a much simpler place. Relativity broke the notion of â??absolute timeâ?? by proving that the measurement of time is relative to the observer observing it. Thus, time can no longer be generally define as a constant one way flow from past to future.
Whatever the definition of time is, the one certain thing is that time whether in a straight trajectory (like in Christianity, Islam, and Judaism) or a circular motion (like in Hinduism and Buddhism) exists. Furthermore, the movement in time (at least to what human beings are able to observe), flow in a one way direction. 
Too bad this movie's message got lost in translation. The is movie is an indictment of just how poor the communication skills are of the director and screenwriter

Somehow flashing back to teaching her very young daughter (who has grown to teenage before dying of some disease) how to read and communicate is a key to doing same with the aliens.
Oh, and the aliens are like giant squid, or octopuses (pi?), with tentacle arms and starfish-like hands.
And as so often, they are 'misunderstood aliens', who apparently have come in peace.
And they don't communicate well, cuz they say 'weapon' when they mean gift.  And this confuses the armies, that want to destroy them.
  And they know the future, and we are to realize that time is not linear, but cyclical.  That aspect of Eastern religions has served humanity so well.
Perhaps 'cerebral', but Some would say it was 'slow'.
And 'dark'.  Many of the scenes were inexplicably too dark (why do so many moves do that?)   The postscript doc said it was purposely 'monochromatic', with very little color.
Oh, and stay til the end, after the credits, for the promised short 'documentary' style interviews with actors and directors, all praising each other and the film.
All that being said, i confess that i myself enjoyed it and found it interesting, if not impenatrable. 
So, i awarded '3 Stars to Arrival.

Nor to be confused with 'OROVILLE',
ARRIVAL, arivaderci.

'Arrival' is the Sci-Fi movie that we have all been waiting for; it doesn't follow similar story lines that is typical of most alien films, whereby the plot simply comprises of aliens descending on Earth, find out that humans are dangerous and destructive to themselves and them, thus causing all out war - we have seen this time and time again, but 'Arrival' really sets the bar high in modern times for the genre.

This movie straight from the beginning shows off beautiful visuals and cinematography, courtesy of the bright cinematographer 'Bradford Young', which really resonates with the unique plot this film has to offer.

English and Science are the two subjects that are significantly key to the plot of this film, giving a sense of realism as to what we do as the human race to understand ourselves from a language perspective and our place in the galaxy and the universe, as well as our voyage for other intelligent life and how they might communicate.

'Arrival' will keep you guessing and mentally put you on the edge of your seat. You will be analytically questioning everything that is happening in order to make sense of what is occurring as the film unfolds. Things may seem confusing, but ultimately become more clear towards the the final act of the film.

This is a film that requires a lot of attention and the ability to think outside the norm - A strong contender for 2016.

I avoided all of the spoilers and discussion about Arrival until I could get to the theater to see it this week. It was worth the effort as the story was fantastic. Amy Adams was superb in her role of an expert linguist tasked with trying to understand the visiting aliens before humanity is pushed over the edge. I wasn't sure where the narrative was going until the end and I wasn't disappointed.
Heartbreakingly beautiful

We are the future we create. This is what Arrival is about: The critical role that foresight plays in harnessing our fears and arriving at those critical decisions which create our future. The film's characters replay this theme over and over as they revisit choices to provide a short life of freedom or a prolonged life of critical illness care, decisions to go to war or not, to be with another or not, and even the approach for alien first contact.  Each choice is portrayed in a certain 'fog' (seen as news blackouts, Louise's confusion, and even Aliens in fog) that represents the lack of clarity we all have in the present of what the right thing is for the future. The aliens' purpose simply was to fulfill the plot's main point by observing that our only 'weapon' (which Louise points out to be a tool) to move past this is to more consciously place ourselves in the flow of time - to truly understand the choices that lie before us and have the foresight to make decisions wisely for the outcomes we seek. As the aliens (real or imagined) stated, 'the gift' they were giving ('the weapon that opens time') that helps us today will help everyone in the future. The ending shows that the real battle with time is in our minds and how we arrive to take control of it.  A good film, though with very nuanced cerebral points left open for a great deal of interpretation and possible to miss entirely.

Arrival is a very interesting movie that plays on a few themes. Honestly I don't want to ruin it for you, but if you're looking for an alien action movie, please look elsewhere. 

Arrival is a thoughtful Sci-Fi; more deep and pensive. It peaks your curiosity in a gentle, as well as stressful way. You follow the main character and are sometimes swept away in her memories as she goes through a trying period of time; trying to make sense of the hovering spaceships dotted around the world.

A more human approach to Sci Fi than is typically portrayed. Very enjoyable. Highly recommend. A good movie if you don't want something too hectic, but interesting enough to keep you going.

Like some of the genre's best, Arrival's strength is in framing an effective science fiction story around a seemingly-unrelated topic and intertwining the two until they become inseparable. In this case, we deal with the fabric of linguistics - the desperate search for a communicative first step - and how even something so dry and cerebral can make for great theatrical drama. Amy Adams is quietly empathic in the central role, a frazzled interpreter with a strong sense of personal loss who pours herself into the work. Against the backdrop of your typical plastic-sheeted, pop-up government research facility, she's our human connection to a very clinical, inhuman situation. Jeremy Renner and Forest Whitaker are around, and give their roles an earnest effort, but they're too cookie-cutter and predictable to amount to much. As is much of the third act, unfortunately, when we discard the delicate analysis of words (both spoken and written) and give in to more bombastic, military-driven temptations. At its core, the film really has one great revelation, and while that's effective at first, it's then rehashed and hammered until its sharp edges grow dull. I still see a lot of promise here, and while it's in the groove it makes for an authentically strange, different viewing experience. The work of Arrival's sound design team plays a big part in that, and will surely be recognized when awards season rolls around. The plot's blunt, heavy-handed climax, though, can be a bitter pill to swallow.
intellectual sci-fi illustrating the importance of communication as well as the beauty of language.
not very interesting...

Amy Adams does a great job role as Louise while working with The US Army to talk to the aliens by communicating, deciphering what the ink blot that the aliens.. She takes off the hazmat suit and helmet off.. Another Oscar nominated movie.. Sci-Fi movie. One of Amy Adams/Jeremy Renner best movies besides since American Hustle was nominated for a few Oscars but last Oscar nominated movie that I saw was the FIghter.

'Arrival' initially introduces itself as a sci-fi thriller, it does give us just that, but with an excess of emotion and drama-thanks to a narrative that is 
supplemented by its genre that probes certain questions about humanity. 

Starring Amy Adams as expert linguist Louise Banks, leading a team to investigate a mysterious spacecraft. Their investigation is accompanied by political chaos and panic which leads Earth on the verge of global war, forcing Banks and her team on a race to find answers.

Cinema has considered a wide range of depictions when it comes to extraterrestrial visitors, and we are familiar with the good-hearted kind (familiar with E.T.?) and the aliens-on-an-annihilation-wave kind ('War of the Worlds,' 'Independence Day'). 'Arrival' definitely improves what audiences can expect out of a sci-fi film, and it doesn't settle for the exciting thrills of a blockbuster. 

'Arrival' has a lot going on on its mind, honestly speaking, this film isn't about the aliens. 'Arrival' is ultimately a human drama told under the guise of a sci-fi flick. And that despite using the generic sci-fi premise- What are the intentions of the aliens? With certain tweaks and circumstances (as sci-fi films tend to do) it doesn't finish in the generic fashion you expect because it delivers an emotionally satisfying narrative, thanks to Amy Adams. That's what makes 'Arrival' special and unforgettable.  

Overall, another solid outing from Dennis Villeneuve's direction and Amy Adam's performance helps sell the film that's already incredibly executed and ambitious in concept.
interesting story line.

Arrival is amazing. See it now. Not only is it incredibly thought-provoking, but the film is going to absolutely overwhelm your senses in all the right ways with unbelievable special effects, music and sound mixing. Some may be disappointed the only character with any depth is the lead, and even she's barely more than 1 dimensional, but Amy Adams and the aliens do their best to make up for this flaw.

Why this has received such high ratings is frankly beyond me.  It is one of those films which appeals to the pseudo-intellectual sci-fi buff! In addition, whilst not wanting to give anything away, the whole premise of the film makes no temporal sense (you'll understand once you've wasted your two hours watching it). Save your money and watch Rogue One a second time!

For me movies are all about story with a clear inciting incident(the landing of the alien ships) and a controling idea that is understandable.  The landing of the aliens worked as an inciting incident, but I never understood the controling idea, that is what the story was attempting to convey.  The statement by the aliens, "We are here to help humanity ended up begging the question, help with what?  Help how?  Those questions were never answered.  The controling idea could have been the future-seeing-ability of the main character leads to first contact.  But, that idea never was developed and led to nothing more than, "do you want to have a baby."  Beyond the fundamental story flaws I felt no emotional connection whatsoever with the main character despite obvious attempts by the screenwriter and director to create the emotional connnection.  The clay figures and child drawings could have been an effective tool in conveying the message of the film, but the director chose to simply point the camera at them to I suppose create mystery but in my opinion only succeeded in creating vagueness.  In the end there was nothing that connected all the vague symbols in a way that was really engaging.  I did like the fact that for once a Scifi film did not protray the so-called aliens as malevolent creatures come to destroy humanity.  For ET officianados, the space ships shape will recall the egg-shaped artifacts many believe are alien in origin found in many archeological sites and referenced in creation myths.  I wathced the movie intently and with great interests, but in the end was disappointed by a meaningless, highly contrived ending and left we wondering why I watched the movie in the first place.

Full review:

http://indiannerve.com/arrival-movie-review-we-need-to-talk-24614/
Everyone has done their homework on this film, from director to writer to actors.   A fantastic sci-fi film that takes you out of this world and then right back to your heart.

Lets starts honest

I really liked Arrival. Until it turned weird. Then, not so much anymore.

With a class A cast including Amy Adams, Jeremy Renner and Forest Whitaker this should have been a great movie all the way to the end. Except that it wasn't. It was a great movie until it stopped being that. I had high hopes for it and as such I was left slightly disappointed.

Arrival is a good story with a ton of potential for greatness until it got whacked on the head and it all went belly up. For some reason I can't help comparing it to the 1997 movie Contact, starring the iconic Jodie Foster, which kind of had the same problem. Great movie with a great story until the moment it went all pear shaped.

The Story

Twelve pods of unknown makeup and origin have appeared overnight at seemingly random locations around the globe. As to be expected the media goes nuts and social services break down. School is out. Louise Banks (Amy Adams) is a successful linguistics professor who stands in from of an empty class room the next day. She highly regarded in her field and has done highly classified consultancy work for the government in the past. Because of this it comes as no big surprise when she gets approached by the military. They need her help in decoding the language of the aliens and once that is done they want her to establish communications with the visitors. For this mission she gets a team of people and works closely together with Ian Donnelly, a theoretical physicist, portrayed by Jeremy Renner.

All twelve pods have positioned themselves at seemingly arbitrary coordinates all over the world. The local governments are scrambling to establish contact with the aliens and try to learn as much as they can about 'their' pods. They all have a fall out about how to proceed and one by one they end up shutting down communication with the rest of the world. Everyone is now acting isolated without knowing what the others are doing or how far they are with their work to decipher the purpose of the visit. This of course creates an explosive situation that threatens to get out of hand when gossip has it that the Chinese are contemplating to nuke their pod in search for answers. This of course is not an ideal situation for anyone, as no one knows if and how the aliens or the neighbours, for that matter, will retaliate.

Here is where it went wrong

In between her work Louise has these strange flashbacks to her family, mainly her daughter. Except that we learn she doesn't have a family nor a daughter. These flashbacks are just that, but that the events have not actually happened yet. They will happen in the future. And that, because she now speaks the aliens language, time doesn't follow in a straight line for her anymore but in parallel strings all mixed up.

Say what?

This is where is turned south for me. I am good with weird and strange. But that was too much for me. In that moment the movie lost its credibility in my eyes. I know there are concepts out there about time and space and astro physics. In fact I am very interest in the subject. I have read several read books and listened to countless podcasts about it. But the way it was done in the movie is just ridiculous. I am very sorry.

Final thoughts

I suppose we can draw similarities to todays society, which is rather trigger happy. We constantly on the cusp of a global catastrophe even without the presence of aliens. This raises the question of what will it take for humankind to step back from the abyss. What is needed for people to start working together instead of against each other?

Arrival also touches on another question. A moral one that people ask themselves daily. If you knew the future and the way your life would turn out to be, would you change anything? If you knew that by accepting the greatest gift and joy you would ever get, you would also set yourself up the the most desperate pain. Would you still chose the same path?

Its a powerful message. I just wish they would have found a different way to convey it.
I liked the philosophy behind it and the ideas it brought up, but it wasn't much of a movie. There are no "goose bump" moments and it was not very entertaining.

The screenplay by Eric Heisserer is creatively written. The cinematography is really good. The choreography is good. The score and effects are good as well. "I have to report that "Arrival" is a kind of movie that delivers a must see experience for fans of thinking person's science fiction that anchors it's heady themes with genuinely affecting emotion."

Arrival est un film réalisé par Denis Villeneuve. L'image y est donc magnifique, les plans sont parfaitement composés, la structure est travaillée jusqu'à l'excès et rien n'est laissé au hasard. En revanche, Arrival est aussi extrêmement austère et refuse totalement de simplifier son propos pour plaire au plus de spectateurs possible. C'est parfois son problème. En effet, le deuxième acte se trouve être assez répétitif et l'explication du twist final assez chaotique. Cela n'aide pas qu'Amy Adams soit assez inexpressive. Quant à la musique de Johann Johansson, elle est conforme à ce à quoi on doit s'attendre d'une de ses collaborations avec Villeneuve. Arrival est un film très étrange, ce qui n'en fait pas forcément un très bon film.

Denis Villeneuve's 'Arrival is a rare movie that had on my brain an effect similar to that produced by a good novel. Actually I see this story more as science than fiction ("Interstellar" offered me the same wonderful feeling).
Impressive, exquisite this movie comes in Christmas time to offer us a lesson of humbleness, understanding, patience, acceptance, to wish to the whole universe peace and good will.
I watched this movie as a linguistic metaphor of the non-verbal communication between beans, humans or not. The whole story is revolving around the deep roots of languages and communication, mistakes that are made because of misunderstandings.
Psychologists agree that the sound people love to hear the most is their name. Everyone has a name and everyone matters. The main idea of this movie could be, in my humble opinion, that science, art, math and physics, creativity, expressiveness, philosophy, religion, all are rooted "in the word" and work together to create a better understanding of words, of their connotations, literal calque, etymology.
The story of the sailors who met the aborigines and asked them, "what were the things that jumped around and carried babies in pouches?" The aborigines said "kangaroo."
Later the sailors found out that "kangaroo" meant "I don't know". Well, this made up story proved the point of Dr. Banks ( Amy Adams): miscommunication.
Louise, having the "weapon" to see the future, is able and chosen to receive "the gift" of the alien language.
"If you could see your whole life from start to finish, would you change things?", asks Louise, accepting her own cross to carry.
Talking about languages and understanding, this movie offers interesting and true points:
"Language is the foundation of civilization.... The first weapon drawn in a war".
"If all I ever gave you is a hammer...Everything's a nail."
"You can understand communication and still end up single".
"Memory is a strange thing. We are bound by time. By its order.
Well, the list can continue. The whole movie is built around the little test of dr. Banks.
Colonel Weber, refused by Louise in the beginning to work with him, is going to Berkeley to get Louise's competitor. "Ask him the Sanskrit word for 'war,' and its translation," Louise tells. Apparently, the Berkeley linguist said "gavisti" means "an argument". Louise replies:"it means a desire for more cattle".
Amy Adams deserves the 2017 Best Actress Oscar. Denis Villeneuve also: great director, outstanding actress. Merry Christmas, Universe!

This is not your typical humanity unites to fight the coming alien invasion movie. Matter of fact, it's not like any "aliens come to Earth" movie you've likely seen on the big screen in the past dozen years. It's beautiful with a haunting score (that I'm totally buying). It's a thinking, feeling sci-fi flick with a unique subtle edge. I enjoyed this move immensely and recommend it as a break from the standard sci-fi fare.

This movie isn't bogged down in outpourings of unintelligible scientific theory through dialogue. The science is a given; the explanations inescapably plain language. No one is arguing that science isn't the way or questioning scientific truths considering the alien arrival. In fact, if you're not careful, you might miss how very rooted in scientific theory this movie is. The science is the foundation on which the work of the movie happens. Once conversation between Donnelly and a fellow mathematics expert casually reveals alien recognition of our mathematical concepts. This elite team works together facing what could be the crisis to end all crisis and science and language are the tools necessary to guide us through with any chance at survival. It's a moment for hard science and social science fans to get a wee bit giddy; while keeping the movie accessible to everyone.

Arrival begins with a voice (Amy Adams) speaking of beginnings and endings. We watch as she talks of joy and (re)lives a horrible and deeply painful tragedy. The movie segues smoothly to present day Dr. Banks at work on campus the day "they" arrive. The look and feel of the scenes are vivid, almost entrancing.

Linguistics professor Louise Banks (played by Amy Adams) leads an elite team of investigators when gigantic vessels enter Earth's atmosphere and hover over 12 locations around the world. As nations teeter on the verge of global war, Banks and team race the clock to find a path to communicate with the extraterrestrials. Banks takes a chance on behalf of all humanity and her choice will either save mankind or plunge the world into war.

The cinematography gives everything an ethereal feel to everything pulling you in to each moment as though you're truly one of the crowd watching stunned as events unfold. Dr. Banks' is disturbingly calm when a military Colonel (Forest Whitaker) approaches her requesting a translation of a "recording." Until this moment, Dr. Banks' seems soft, pliable. When pushed to draw conclusions about what she's heard without being given answers to questions she believed vital - but the Colonel sees as attempts to manipulate him into taking her to the arrival site - to making a useful assessment; Dr. Banks stands her ground. She erupts from her numbness to throw out a challenge at the Colonel's back as he exits her office. It's your first hint that mayhap there's more to Dr. Banks than appearance leads one to believe. Her introduction to the team, and to Dr. Ian Donnelly (Jeremy Renner) happens on a midnight ride through the sky. An over-reaching theme of the movie is deftly if simply introduced: Banks' life's work places language at the basis of everything; the first weapon in war whereas Donnelly scoffs claiming the entire premise to be wrongheaded and posits that in fact science is in fact what anchors us to bedrock.

Everything unfolds at a steady but inexorable pace with an increasing sense of urgency with every discovery, or set back. The director, Denis Villeneuve, lures the audience further with glimpses of Banks' memories that seem to confuse just as much as the assist Dr. Banks in her work all against a backdrop of frantic populations and paranoid world leaders demanding to know what "they" want. It adds a layer to the story drawing attention to not only Dr. Banks' role as translator but as a bridge between science and the senses. Her fate begins to feel as vital as the outcome of her task as alien communicator. Arrival is at its bedrock a movie about communication and commonality. It's about language and meaning. It's collaboration and cooperation. It's about setting aside fear and human hubris of trying to interpret the actions of an alien species through the lens of our motivations and history.

The movie deviates from the source material (I suggest you pick up a copy of Stories of Your Life) but only in ways that allow for good storytelling and more opportunity to explore questions about the nature of choice. The casting and acting are equally great. Although there are moments where the disconnect between Dr. Banks and Dr. Connelly from the rest of the crew is a bit too obvious. There are moments when you wish for more perspectives beyond Banks' lens particularly as you begin to realize she might just be an unreliable and inconsistent narrator. But Villeneuve makes sharp choices drawing on the identifiable elements from the current societal climate for punches of realistic hysteria playing out in the streets and glimpses of the vitriolic rhetoric pushing for a "show of force" by radio personalities and news media. He creates an environment where the inevitable breakdown between mission and mankind drives home the point that we are sometimes our own worst enemy.

The script for this movie was so bad that at times the actors were often working hard because they had nothing to work with. 

The plot is so inane, so vacuous, that the praise heaped on this turkey comes across as grating. It's your typical "the universe revolves around us pseudointellectual bourgeois types" drivel. 

The "aliens" were contrived (octopus people- please!) in every way, and were nauseatingly anthropomorphic in terms of plot-function. The ending was as much of a clunker as Sagan's overrated turkey Contact, with its deus ex machina conclusion and its almost word-for-word theft of dialogue of Charlie Sheen's The Arrival 1996, when the cast is running around trying to verify the signal. Compare the two movies side-by-side if you don't believe me. 

I can't account for the star-struck nonsense I've been reading about this turkey. Too many brains starved for oxygen would be my guess.

In my review for last year's "The Martian", I'd mentioned that there's been a sci-fi trend of annually-attempted successful narratives that gone out of this world in one's journey. The line "out of this world" states the limitless boundary of the sci-fi genre with wondrous, yet fictitious predictions what could be possible, then it gets tested by scientific accuracy to estimate the so-called length. Although, that applies to sci-fi flicks that aren't ridiculously improbable by flawed execution - referring to the "Independence Day" overblown sequel as an example. As we were in the final quarter of the movie year that's known as the awards season - and time of the main contenders, the sci-fi entry "Arrival" became the representative contender for that genre.

"Arrival" went for another routine of humanity being tested by the unknown as multiple spacecraft mysteriously appeared around the world, and the only action being taken is militaries sending in elite teams to investigate and try to communicate in their respective locations. Leading the US elite team is expert linguist Louise Banks (Amy Adams) as she interprets and understand the mysterious visitors' nature, while the rest of the world is under fearful impression that would lead to a global war. To prevent further miscommunication and misunderstanding, Louise and some of her team is on a race against time to get answers, even if it means risking her life and possibly mankind as well.

When the movie ended, the one word that kept repeating in my head is "something". The movie was quite something by its aestheticizing atmosphere from Adams' performance to the conceptual approach towards the mystery with couple conventions and the twist through diegetic clarification. Speaking of the twist, it's a fresh experience when reversing how it was presented to the actuality of those scenes, even though it was an apparent main idea that may need another look at to see how whole the idea is. The climatic revelation is a different spin to the one in "Interstellar", within the similar encounter seen in "Independence Day" with a more gentle, yet cautious approach, while the cinematography seem to have a [somewhat] similar vibe to the exhaustive "2001: A Space Odyssey."

Complimenting on the atmosphere that's immersive when experiencing it in the theater, it's actually the definitive soul of the film rather than the human performances that supports the idea, or the communicative ideology. The main element of the atmosphere is the composed score by Jóhann Jóhannsson, who created a chilling, echoing vibe that dimensionally emphasizes, and resonating from, the presence of the mysterious encounter. It's all part of being overall thrilling next to the topically unfortunate timing of how politics, both domestic and international, decided on drastically threatening measures based on miscommunication and misunderstanding, and we're resonating Banks' stress when racing against time. To sum it up, it's an emotionally engaging experience from thrilling to, in some cases, stressful towards a payoff of a conclusion.

Prior to the experience, nearly a month and a half after its release, Amy Adams' performance is genuinely terrific between the acting level in an artistic film and a sci-fi film, which is what this film is a combination of based on the inspired style at a new twist and added depth.

"Arrival" is the latest sci-fi entertainment that's worth seeing in the theaters to experience its immersion (like "Sully" a few months prior) and smart storytelling through an aesthetic atmosphere, with the human aspect being led by Amy Adams' performance. It's genuinely is one of the best films of the genre, and of the year generally, despite the minimal boost of interest before the reversing flip. (A-)

Arrival tenderly exploits the nature of human presumptuousness; we assume too much, when we know too little. All the while, delivering an inspiring, brilliant, endearing plot, and a breathtaking performance by Amy Adams.
If you liked Close Encounters, Contact, and Interstellar, you'll like Arrival, too. Still thinking about this movie and it's simple message "Use weapon", which by itself is not a spoiler.

There are a bunch of excellent sci-fi themes here for science fiction purists.  However there are a number of flaws that make this movie a less than perfect experience.

PROS:
It presents a thought provoking science fiction theme and the plot has some interesting surprises.  There is also a lot of, at times,  moving emotional content about family and love.

CONS:
This movie moves ploddingly slow.  It is not for those suffering from ADD or who have never watched a movie made prior to 1980.  The movie is also incredibly depressing.  It paints a bleak picture of marriage and international relations.  Don't expect to leave feeling hopeful about life.

However the biggest problem with this movie is the overt and covert propaganda for the usual far left utopian fantasy/nightmares.  First,  as will be increasingly true henceforth,  it is filled with Chinese propaganda.  

China owns much of Hollywood now and thus you will find nods to our current overlords in a lot of recent films.  In this one we find that it is China who leads the worlds consensus,  it is China who is the world's military superpower.  America is helpless to stop China.  Only by appeasing Chinese warlords can we make progress, etc. etc.

Beyond that it is filled with the usual globalist tripe that we have been forced to accept in all media channels.  Global governance good?  Yes.  Fly over rabble evil and stupid?  Yes.   Technocrats are here to save you?  Yes.  Military bad and evil.  Yes.  Normal marital relationships?  Outdated and not needed.  On and on it goes,  and this movie's propaganda is actually low key compared to others!

Arrival is causing quite a stir in cinemas, it's captivating plot and philosophical nature leaving audiences speechless. The reasons why are clear, but I 
couldn't help feeling a little disappointed. Was it a great movie? Yes. But was it the best of the year? No, not in my opinion. Mild spoilers ahead in what 
could be one of my more controversial reviews. 

Directed by Dennis Villeneuve based on the short story 'Story of your Life' by Ted Chiang, the film follows linguist Louise, played by Amy Adams, and 
physicist Ian, played by Jeremy Renner, being recruited to deal with the sudden arrival of 12 alien ships across the globe. There's no denying this is a 
well crafted movie, expertly directed by Villeneuve. There are a number of truly breathtaking shots, really taking advantage of the scale of the ships 
and nature that surrounds them. The cinematography is truly beautiful and is worth the price of entry alone just to see it. 

The acting is also a key part. Amy Adams is definitely on track for an Oscar for her performance in this film, her brave but confused languages expert 
going up against the stubborn male army generals making for an interesting role. Her relation with her daughter is also incredibly well done, especially 
when looked back after the film has ended. Renner's character is given less to do but is excellent given his lack of material. I thought his scientific 
background would be used as a foil to Louise's language background but this wasn't really played upon, with Renner simply being pushed to the back 
with a forced relationship because the plot demanded it. This is more a problem with the writing than the acting however and the cast certainly do an 
excellent job. 

The soundtrack by Jóhann Jóhannsson is also very well done, combining uplifting and warm music for intimate and family scenes and scary, alien 
sounds for scenes involving the extra-terrestrials. The effects for the most part are good with the ships in particular looking incredible. There is one 
particular scene involving a Heptapod, the alien species, appearing in a room which is meant to be shocking but falls very flat due to the unconvincing 
CGI. 

The film features a twist ending, not a sudden one in the same nature of The Sixth Sense, but instead revealed slowly and can be guessed quite early 
on by the more invested viewers. The nature of time plays into the ending with questions raised about "if you could change the future...". This is the 
issue I have, as Louise makes a choice which seems incredibly selfish. While it can be argued she had no choice due to paradoxes and similar time 
cliches, none of these ideas were explored to any degree to make this seem definite and even so, makes the whole topic of "changing the future" 
irrelevant and not worth mentioning earlier. The lack of free will for the protagonist also seems like a dark tonal shift against the optimistic nature of 
the film so far. However, a disappointing ending with more focus on the journey seems rather apt given the subject matter of the movie. 

While this review comes across as very negative in tone, the film is actually very good. It's positive aspects certainly outweigh the negatives and I 
seem to be in the minority as many critics have given the film highly positive reviews. I definitely feel this demands a rewatch, especially with 
knowledge of the ending, which may raise my opinion of the film a little higher. It's definitely worth your time and is worth seeing on the big screen for 
the cinematography alone. Despite its drawbacks, I would recommend the film and expect to hear more about it at the next Academy Awards.

Superb science fiction drama about much more than aliens and how humanity greets them. And in the end it doesn't leave any bit of information given or shown to the viewer unused or unimportant, which gives it a nice rounded feel. It is clever story telling in that it tells of a defining moment in human history and yet also a very personal story that never takes over the messages or the meaning of the film, similar to "Interstellar" or "Contact", both of which it in consistency and clearness is superior to. It is by far the best genre film of the year and it is the kind of film that you want to see again.

All right! So to break the ice without verbose explanations, let me just say : This movie is brilliant! As brilliant as a movie on science fiction can be - an originality of its own, and no cluttered baggage.

Now, to comprehend the brilliance of this movie, one has to take a solitary step back and try to recall all the sci-fi movies which were conceptually mind-blowing, original, and overwhelmed you so much with its broadened horizons , you could literally feel dizzy?! What comes to mind? Alien? Interstellar? Blade Runner? Matrix? Inception? Yes! I am talking about such conceptual brilliance in a movie. And Arrival passes it with flying colors - sometimes so overwhelming, it surpasses the benchmarks too.

Coming straight to the script - the beauty and realism of a protagonist who is unperturbed by the commotion around regarding an unknown event, sets the tone of the movie. Unlike in-your-face surrealistic heroism, the people with knowledge tend to be realistically unaware of the happenings - especially when such an extra-terrestrial event takes place.

The design of the space-ship and its locales are just so haunting and mind-numbing, it translates from the emotions and mannerisms of the actors in the movie to the audience seamlessly. Same goes with the design of the aliens which is unique in its own might, and reminiscent of the haunting originality of the Alien franchise. But what takes the cake - is the graphic language of the aliens which is so unique and interesting - one may never even fathom such creativity. All of it while the earthlings were unable to communicate via the audible approach being used by the aliens - another realistic incidence of such a contact!

It is not unrealistically snappy as it takes the protagonists hard work and time to even begin to comprehend the subtleties of the alien linguistics, and the translation is mostly lost. This is one of the best representations of such a scenario, as one does not simply create a dictionary for a species in a day. Not to forget the other subtle but important precedence of various alien ships landing in various parts of the world - and not only in America (a hilarious joke among non-residents of USA).

This movie is haunting and beautiful on so many levels : The music is numbing and characteristically "alien" which transcends the various fears and emotions of the characters into the audience without trying too much. The visuals are mind-boggling and overwhelming - reminiscent of Alien and Interstellar, but more subtle, haunting and less heroic. The story itself with its great twist (a trope of Shyamalan) and the concept of time ( like Interstellar), has a beautiful philosophical and emotional value, almost unseen in the majority of science fiction flicks.

The best quality of this movie is that it subtly takes away from the alien event, and rather focuses on the emotions, consequences and life-changing transformations of the earthlings and the people surrounding the event. It does not make the aliens the incident of importance - but rather a process which changes and focuses on the conscience of the human race.

Let me warn you though - this is not a movie for the audience who want snappy and action-packed entertainment from a science-fiction movie. In some parts, the movie is rather boring, as it delves deeper into the comprehension of the event, and in the end, it is just plain acceptance and moving on - there is no big climax waiting to happen. Also, to add to the frailty - the CGI in some parts of the movie is questionable, considering that it was such a well-made movie with high production value.

It may seem like this movie tries to borrow from franchises like Alien and Interstellar, but in the end, it creates its own unique world and manages to shelve away any such comparisons- thus creating an original idea and sci-fi masterpiece altogether. It is a fresh addition into the big names which redefined the genre of sci-fi easily sitting beside Matrix. Blade Runner or Alien.

Verdict : Brilliant and redefining cinema, and one of the masterpieces in science fiction. 4.5/5

P.S : The movie is based on the short story "Story of Your Life" by Ted Chiang which was the winner of the 2000 Nebula Award for Best Novella as well as the 1999 Sturgeon award.

Smart, thought-provoking and original, "Arrival" is a spellbinding science-fiction film that you won't forget. Unlike any blockbuster that has been released thus far in 2016, Denis Villeneuve's latest film is a visually stunning blockbuster that keeps you at the edge of your seat from start to finish. Anchored by a magnificent performance from Amy Adams, it is a genuinely thrilling film that keeps you engrossed. Director Denis Villeneuve is a master at create nail-biting tension and proves yet again why he is one of the most talented directors working today. With all this being said, "Arrival" is a slow-paced affair that drags in the middle. As a result, it may not appeal to today's mainstream audiences. Nevertheless, it is a mesmerizing film that stays with you long after you leave the theater.

The political message was huge in this film. A very strong message of peace in general. One that I can stand behind. The personal message of (spoilers ahead) knowing one's future and not changing anything was very powerful. Outstanding acting from Adams, Renner, and Whittaker. Especially Adams who continues to show that she has huge acting chops.

This movie took major props from Contact. Spoilers follow. I also really liked Arrival end it added some original storylines, but by and large Contact was all over that movie:

- Jodie Foster's relative dies early in the movie and is revisited via a flashbacks. Same with Amy Adam's character.

- Foster has a "science vs faith" romantic interest. Adams has a "science vs liberal arts" romantic interest.

- Big government is constantly pressuring Foster and nearly taking her project away from her, same with Adams

- Foster and team spend a good portion of the movie decrypting a signal sent from aliens. Same with Adams.

- In Contact a subversive tries to blow up machine and individuals die. Same in Arrival.

- In the book Contact, the message they finally decrypt is pi (a circle that appears on the screen in binary form; this doesn't make an appearance in the movie, but it is the culmination of the book). In arrival the aliens are also communicating via circles.

Again, good movie. But some credit should be given to Sagan as well. That is all.
If you want to see a well-made movie with a good theme? See Arrival.

Arrival is the restrained sci-fi movie that we've wanted for years, not the over-the-top action movie where humans vs. everything else inevitably leads to humans winning. It turns the trope of aliens being exactly what we're afraid of them being on its head to show us a mirror of who we could be. The acting is genuine and immersive, which gives the audience more of a sense that the players are actually in the situation that the plot presents, rather than a visual representation of how the ideal person would react to a situation if they had a week in the shower to think about each line. Some parts aren't as memorable as others, but Amy Adams does a brilliant job of leading the audience through the story by simultaneously exploring the plot as the audience and revealing just the right amount to keep the outcome in the air until the very end.

The visuals help the story, but don't dominate it. They're immersive, believable, but distinctly science fiction, which is a refreshing change from the earth-shattering explosions, giant monsters, mech suits and green screen overuse that dominate so many other movies these days. I don't buy many movies on blue-ray these days, but this will definitely be one of them.

I guess it doesn't take much to make an amazing movie. Just an incredibly original story by Ted Chiang, great directorial choices by Dennis Villeneuve, and a great performance from Amy Adams. The film's pragmatic approach to an alien landing really separates it from other sci-fi films, and then the story hits another gear and separates itself from all other films of any genre. A couple of pacing holes are present but can't come close to bringing this movie down. I have always believed the best films are the ones that have you thinking well after you've left the theater. This is one of those films.

A beautiful, heartbreaking, and thought provoking story with cinematography and pacing that matches perfectly. The film creates a quiet tension using sound design that is lost in many alien and sci-fi features. Amy Adams is a chameleon of an actress and plays a convincing and multi-faceted role. CGI is tasteful and political commentary is not overbearing. Definitely worth a watch.

This movie had me, my fiance, and our best friend discussing its content for hours on end.  Evocative music, excellent cinematography, and moving performances by several actors made this film more than just a movie.  Arrival became an experience that provokes the heart, inspires the imagination, and inspires reflection upon life, our concept of time, the human condition, and religion and the Divine.  Furthermore, this film succeeded in being very timely in the aftermath of a divisive American election and world conflict, yet its content is very timeless applying to all of humanity at all times.  There are one or two scenes I would change or remove from the movie that would make it almost perfect, but altogether, this was an excellent movie.
