Arrival review. The low period of movies this year has officially been kicked in the teeth with my third movie in a row that has blown me away. Arrival is a stunning movie that I fear far too few people will see. Slow, thoughtful, beautifully filmed science fiction is probably a niche area. This movie sits somewhere in between Interstellar with concepts and visual appeal, and a movie like The Notebook in terms of creating memorable emotional scenes. Yep, Interstellar and The Notebook. From the opening sequence I was deeply moved in a way that I haven't felt since Up. Amy Adams and Jeremy Renner are so soft, nervous and lovable. This is not an alien movie to make you run in terror. The alien presence is really just a backdrop to make you feel true human emotion. And those two leads win you over and take you on a wonderful journey. If you happen to be like me and love science fiction AND love studying language (probably a rare combination) then you will feel this movie was made for you. In the mean time I will just feel this movie was made for me.

I wouldn't call this film genius, but from a conceptual and filmmaking perspective, it did an amazing job in combining a couple existential and sci-fi ideals. To get rich depth in something lacking in complexity is an admirable feat in any medium.

* Review without spoilers * 

Wonderful... I came out of the cinema telling myself that it was certainly one of my favorite movies of all time. After, of course, in hindsight, we can relativize, but this movie will subjugate you, whatever your cinematographic tastes are. Some will say that this movie is a cousin of Interstellar, others will speak about 2001: a space odyssey... There are indeed some similarities between these movies. Some places will make you think of Kubrick, the scientific popularization will make you think of Nolan, but with Villeneuve, everything takes a completely different level. Not necessarily a higher level, but a completely different level. Arrival is a more human movie than those mentioned above and has a higher level of reflection. 

From the first second, we dive into the story and we never really emerge, even once the screen has turned white again. Throughout the movie you will think, you will ask yourself questions, you will have doubts... 
The trailer is nothing compared to the entire movie, you will necessarily be surprised. 
The film direction is really amazing. Villeneuve takes his time and lets live some strong shots. 
The actors are very good, and Amy Adams is obviously excellent (will she finally win an oscar after 5 losses ?). 
Even the soundtrack is perfect. If you are interested in this subject, go around the internet and you will realize that there is something special about the music, something related to the very purpose of the movie. 

The blend of all this makes it a pure piece of jewelry. Chills have crossed my body several times and especially during the first 5 minutes, which is extremely rare. I wont say more to avoid spoilers, but I will ask you to go watch it and make your own opinion. At this very moment when everyone has their eyes on Star Wars, I wonder if the real SF event of this year is not Arrival after all...

This is a fantastic entry in the "alien visitation" genre. On the plus side, the idea that language would be the first area of exploration and insight with respect to an alien species introduction to earth is a refreshing change of pace for this kind of movie.

The final twist is so deftly handled that I am in awe of the director and writers. They pulled it off exceptionally well. The main question it asks and answers is: If you knew every thing that would/will happen in your life (good or bad, joyous or painful), would you live it anyway?

Director Denis Villenueve brings us a rather different film that proves that bold new takes on familiar films can pay off in his latest film: Arrival. While not much was revealed in the trailers, believe me when I say that Arrival is well worth your time and stands as one of the most visceral and outstanding film experiences in years. Out of respect for the filmmakers who have taken much effort in concealing this film's secrets, I will only discuss what is revealed in the trailers. With that said, lets dive into one of 2016?s best films.

The key to any great film is to take a cliche and turn it in a way to make a story feel original and that is just what Eric Heisserer did with this screenplay. The story here is very simple but so intricately detailed that you simply can't help but get invested in this film. The plot revolves around a linguist, named Louise Banks, who gets recruited by the government to make contact with aliens who have randomly appeared all over the globe. This is literally the basic plot and the entire film with her and her partner trying to make some form of conversation with the aliens. the writer's decision to tell a character based story rather than a big action feature is just what this film needed. The subdued nature of the story as well as the character development is nothing short of captivating. To top it all off the payoff of this film is incredible with one of the finest twists in recent memory.

The acting here is also phenomenal with Amy Adams starring as the main character Louise. Adams' delivery is spectacular with so much heart and drama that she has you pulling for her all the way through the film. Jeremy Renner plays her partner and provides the necessary weight to counteract the areas that Louise's character lacks. The two have impeccable chemistry and easily carry this film from start to finish. On top of that we get a great performance from Forrest Whitaker as well as Michael Stuhlbarg who represent the government in the film.

The real star of the film however is Denis Villeneueve in the director's chair as well as the cinematography and sound department. This film looks stunning from start to finish with shots that will warp your mind and give you chills. Not only that but Villeneueve's pacing is perfect all the way through. This is a film with no real action of any kind but he makes it fly by with little to no downtime. Each scene is constructed in a way that you are in suspense and intrigue through the entire film and you just can't help but get totally wrapped up in the events of this film.The sound is also chilling because majority of the film is silent with just the right mount of music throughout to keep you on the edge of your seat.  Villeneueve always makes fantastic films but Arrival just might be his crowning achievement.

All in all Arrival is a masterclass in scifi and drama. The story is written expertly, the acting is fantastic, and the direction, cinematography, and sound all blend together and are absolutely flawless. I didn't discuss everything for the sake of the secrets of the film, so do yourself a favor and experience this film on the big screen for a one of a kind experience.
This was a great show. Its not what you think... and that makes it a great show.

As a retired aerospace engineer who worked on the space program, I was looking forward to seeing this movie, but I was disappointed.  There are very few sci-fi flicks about alien visitors that are believable...this one fails in that regard too.  I found the space ships and alien creatures in them to be more someone's wild imagination than what I could believe thay might be like. In addition, I found the end very confusing as it flashes back and forth in Louise's mind.

I knew of the theory of all language being intertwined with the reality of the languages creators. And non-linear time is a plausable although strange concept. But how did Louise know the words of a dying woman in China? Please explain.

On the positive side:  l liked the music, which I felt really set the mood throughout the movie.  I can usually tell in the first minute or two if I'll like a movie by the music and the first scenes.   I loved the fascination with language and the addition of the relativity of time as a factor in how the movie plays out.  I liked that no one has done something exactly like this before and I couldn't really guess what was going to happen (although nothing really happens much at all throughout the movie, at least not in the current time).  I'm confused by all the people saying that the ending didn't make sense or was a let down.  It seemed to me that the ending was the logical result of all of the visions that she was having, and it didn't take a genius to figure out where that was going, at least after awhile. Overall,  I thought it was cool.  I love movies that play tricks with time.    I liked that it left a lot to wonder about, and yet it also left me feeling that it wasn't complete, and I wished that there were more to the movie. I felt it was only the first chapter in a good classic sci fi book and I wanted to keep reading. I wonder if the written version goes into any more detail.  I would like to read this story in a longer, more detailed, book.  On the negative side, I felt that the desire of the nations, and evidently of some rogue soldiers, to destroy the ships so quickly was a bit contrived and a little unbelievable, yet a generally acceptable, although overdone, theme in a sci fi movie.

Saw Arrival today - it's incredible.  It is intelligent, thought provoking and at times emotionally stirring. Will leave you thinking about it afterwards. Visuals were stunning and sleek. We noticed the theater was silent apart from reactions.....people were completely engaged and that is rare these days amidst cell phones and such. Acting was incredible, Amy Adams as usual delivered. If you're even remotely interested go see it in the theater.

Best film of the year (so far)

What is your purpose in the film? Every shot of this film has a specific purpose. Every reference is linked neatly within a visual argument. This is the summer blockbuster without the unnecessary panning, half-second shots and nonsensical explosions. 

Do you want to be inspired, be drawn to reflection and leave the cinema with a smile, go out and see Arrival.

I would be worried about Villanueve if I were Christopher Nolan. Just sayin'.

UGH!  I loved this thoughtful and inspiring "alien flick". Any Adams is really becoming one of my iconic faves. She kills it every time. I can't wait to see this one again. So refreshing to see an alien movie with no explosions and laser sounds!  So, so good.

One of my favorite movies of 2016. Itâ??s not often that a movie whose main plot point is that aliens have arrived from outer space makes us think deeply about the actions we take as humans, but that is exactly what Arrival does. It is also why it is one of my favorite movie of 2016. The people who will be disappointed are those coming to the theater looking for this to be an onslaught of invasion/ID4 type special effects thrills. It is a deeply thoughtful movie with sci-fi elements.
 
 I think many people have dismissed this film as â??just another alien arrival movieâ?? but it is so much deeper than that. It is a movie that is far more cerebral than it is celluloid. There are the kinds of things the thinking sci-fi fan will revel in. This movie taps into emotions in a way that is subtle and not manipulative. The story is presented with just the right sense of urgency that keeps you interested, but not overwhelmed. The success of this film in my opinion is largely the result of two key things: Its Director, Denis Villeneuve (Sicario, Prisoners), and the lead actress, Amy Adams.
 
 The story focuses on Dr. Louise Banks (Amy Adams), a renowned linguist and college instructor living a quiet life after the death of her child. Quiet, until the day 12 huge mysterious orbs appear around the world and the military determines she is their best chance at getting a dialogue going with these aliens. Jeremy Renner plays Ian Donnelly, a theoretical physicist. Yes, itâ??s geeky like that and he will prove key to the story. 
 
 Villeneuve has created something that is both imaginative, fulfilling, and masterfully done. Arrival is already garnering Oscar-buzz with its 10 Critics Awards nominations recently announced and I predict it will go on to garner some Oscar nods as well. It may have been out for over a month now, but it is still not too late to catch this movie that will be talked about for quite some time.

An absolutely fascinating, riveting film that made my head hurt in the best way!  I'll be mulling over this one for a long time to come.  Thus, repeat viewings are in order.   And yes, it speaks far more to the topics of "human" and communication than alien arrival.  Best Picture, Best Actress and/or Best Screenplay- not at all a stretch!  FIVE stars!

this movie has so many subtle levels of storyline, that I continued to pull it delicately apart for days afterward.... finding more and more as I mused on the scenes...  very Memento ish in that you were never quite sure just where you were in the story at any given moment--- until all became clear at the end- with subtle hints of how some things previously viewed in the future - may have been changed ....

A lot of scenes are shot of Adams in close-up, with limited to no make-up, relying on here reactions and expression to move the story forward, and she accomplishes this seemingly with ease.  Jeremy Renner is also very good.  Denis Vilieneuve is on a hot streak unlike any director i have seen recently.  The film demands and deserves to be seen on the big screen.  Check it out!

A beautiful, emotionally charged and intellectually stimulating movie. I cried intermittently for a while after seeing it just processing the experience and emotions. Definitely the best movie I've seen all year.

Arrival: diversity, tolerance and unity, should be embraced through skillful communication, in the light of challenging cultural differences.

Carl Sagan's Contact (1997) was an interesting film about how it will be like to make contact for the first time with an alien civilization, and the story danced around the conflicting rhetoric of God vs. Science. Arrival feels like Contact for a new generation, it is a hunting movie with a similar rhythm and pretences to sound persuasive about something, in this case: how peace in the world can be achieved through skillful communication, in times of globalization and cultural differences.

I have a bachelor degree in Social Communications and Multimedia, while attending University, I enjoyed my linguistic and semiotics classes, in fact, I completed my thesis by making a semiotic analysis of one advertisement campaign. I am bilingual, and for these two reasons, this movie stroke a chord close to my own personal experiences with language and communication. I understand the difficulties in communicating messages across different languages and mediums, it is not an easy task to come across with the original intended message. I was taught about how most of the problems in our societies are due to poor communication, and since then, it is an idea that I get to live with forever. The movie captures that idea very well to my surprise.
The story begins with a hunting narration about time...then, we see Louise Banks (Amy Adams), a linguistics professor, losing her daughter to cancer, and later, we find Louise yanked out in the middle of a quest to make contact with an alien civilization who just landed on earth in spaceships with a half-sliced egg form hoovering above earth around the world. Louise is contacted by the US Army to help the make contact by deciphering their language with hopes to understand their intentions before attempting an act of war.

The tone of the movie is hunting and no real action scenes ever take place, it is a very close experience to Contact, with amazing photography and sound effects, so, if what you are looking to see is an action packed film, like Independence Day, I recommend to skip this movie entirely and move on to a different Sci-Fi film, because Arrival is like an experimental low-tempo indie song, and not a pop-fast-beat dance tune.

ARRIVAL is one of the most ambitious movies of the year, but that doesn't exactly mean it's one of the BEST movies of the year.  It's strong direction and intellectual approach are unfortunately undone (somewhat) by some of the curious areas the screenplay chooses to focus on.  Essentially a TWILIGHT ZONE episode writ large, ARRIVAL is fundamentally a cerebral, big science fiction tale about language and communication, and in the early going, the movie is basically masterful.  Its first act is an incredibly authentic and believable portrait of how the world would likely react to the appearance of alien vessels on our planet, and director Villeneuve demonstrates that he has tight tonal control as well as a gift for crafting sequences that draw the audience in.  In tandem with the evocative (and at times austere) cinematography and screenplay's intelligent and methodical plotting, the first two acts of ARRIVAL are extremely satisfying.  Amy Adams is effortlessly good, and completely sells her character's skills; this is one of her better performances.  Adams is eventually asked to shoulder the bulk of the movie's emotional content, and this is the arena in which the screenplay stumbles somewhat (though it's no fault of Adams' efforts); the script constructs a major subplot that is, frankly, just not as compelling as the central storyline, and then proceeds to make the denouement almost exclusively about that subplot.  This is a bold choice that will work for some, but not others.  I'm in the "other" camp, as the movie basically turns into a different kind of story than the first half sets us up for.  I would have preferred the movie stick with its more heady approach instead of going for the heartstrings, but so it goes.  The script also leaves some of the narrative particulars as things to be inferred by the audience rather than spelled out for them, which I appreciate, but - again - some might want things handled in a somewhat more concrete way.  In the end, ARRIVAL didn't totally click for me on the level it seems it did for others, but I admire the intentions behind the film, and I'm always thankful for intelligent, plausible sci-fi.

So I've been wondering how to review this movie. Clearly I think it's amazing based on me giving it 5 stars, but still I found it difficult.  Mostly because of a surprise twist in the middle of the movie that I just was not expecting at all. This twist then leads to a scene which I'm sure some could consider a Deus Ex machina moment. When I first saw the scene I was also thinking "what the" but as the movie progressed past it and I thought about it more, I accepted it, even embraced it. I won't talk anymore about so as not to spoil the movie. 

Overall, as I mentioned, I loved this movie. To me it's the Contact of this decade. An intelligent first encounter movie that makes you think and actually makes some sense. No the aliens aren't going to immediately destroy us and some how our military and ingenuity are capable of defeating a species that can traverse the stars. How humanity reacts to the presence of these beings and our own strengths and failings are at the core of this film, just like it was in Contact. 

Also just like in Contact this movie predominantly rests on the shoulders of its heroine, in this case a linguist played by Amy Adams. As much as her performance was panned in that other alien movie (with a red cape) she delivers in this movie. Her non verbal acting really conveys the awe and fear at meeting an alien race for the first time and her surprise at finally understanding why the aliens are here. 

Her supporting cast also did a good job, including Jeremy Renner and Forest Whitaker, but really it's Amy Adams who stars in this movie. A great alien movie that will keep you thinking about it long after you leave the theater.

It's the end of the world as we know it! A much discussed and sometimes feared story has come true which, honestly, always sounded a bit ridiculous to actually happen in the real world.

I am, of course, talking about this new sci-fi drama Arrival" where mankind is greeted by huge alien spaceships in the sky who seem to be coming in peace... wait, did you think I was referring to Trump becoming the next leader of the free world?

But yeah, these two events have a very similar plot summary so it's only fitting that I had the chance to experience them in the very same morning.

Directed by Denis Villeneuve - the man behind Prisoners", mindbending Enemy" with Jake Gyllenhaal, Sicario" and currently filming Blade Runner" sequel -, one could expect Arrival" to be a thinking person's sci-fi. And one is not wrong.

It is a 116 minute slow-burner all heavy on atmosphere and light on explosions or any quick thrills. 

If you wish a quick reference to any recent well-known movies, the result is a bit like Christopher Nolan's Interstellar" crossed with Terrence Malick's The Tree of Life". 

Robert Zemeckis's Contact" (1997) would not be very far either, because Arrival" also focuses on fragile yet brave female protagonist whose quality acting is one of the main pillars carrying the whole experience. The other one would be overall atmosphere, deliciously dark and ominous. Some will like it, others will probably find it depressing and maybe a bit slow for their taste.

I haven't read the award-winning short story by Ted Chiang that Arrival" is based on. Wikipedia says that the major themes explored are determinism, language and Sapir-Whorf hypothesis which sounds mighty dry and mostly sci-fi geek friendly. 

So it's nice to witness movie makers adding some mainstream appeal which comes mostly in the form of Amy Adams's great performance. 

She truly holds the movie together as a woman going where no-one has ever gone before. You will believe her hesitations, the tears, and also the silent determination when the going gets tough. 

This kind of role is tricky because of the need to play it out mostly alone, often in close-up where every detail and tone has to be clearly seen and felt. Think Matthew McConaughey's mighty turn in Interstellar" but decidedly less showoffish.

So it's mostly Adams's one-woman-show, and a quite rare chance to see her doing something memorable and worthwhile on screen. She accepts too many decorative pretty girl roles, even in more ambitious projects. 

The all-male supporting cast is good too, especially star players such as Jeremy Renner and Forest Whitaker. 

As stated above, I don't know the original story but "Arrival's" message is rather spiritual and not "dry" at all. Essentially it is a reminder that mankind's future depends heavily on our ability to understand and connect to the world, rather than attacking and overpowering everything we find foreign or downright alien. 

It's a call to rise above the inflexible ego-based mind the western society so dearly values, and to find balance with our intuitive side.

Overall, Arrival" is a good movie although I wasn't especially happy with the final act which seemed rushed. It felt like somebody grew impatient near the end and wanted to add something impressive" just in case the people were not happy with this slow-moving tale. 

I do not want to talk about it here in detail but, for me, it lessened some of the movie's overall impact. Mostly because there was not enough time to play it out as properly as the stuff that had come before.

But yeah, if you are into more intelligent sci-fi and don't prioritize explosions, Arrival" is good to go.

La película especial para los que somos traductores.

Review pequeña:

Uno de los principales propósitos del arte son: 1. Entregar un mensaje y 2. Hacer sentir algo. Siendo, a mi parecer, mucho más importante el primero, ya que también abarca el segundo, al menos en el cine. Especialmente en el cine más comercial.

En resumen, Arrival, muy centrada en el diálogo, profundiza mucho en un solo tema (la gran importancia del lenguaje y de la comunicación) y logra entregar un mensaje y una moraleja, a diferencia de muchísimas películas actuales que tratan de abordar varios temas para ser entretenidas, pero como consecuencia no logran desarrollar a fondo ninguno y terminan diciendo nada. Además, posee una narrativa un poco más compleja de lo habitual, pero a la vez muy bien ordenada a través de un buen montaje (orden en que aparece cada escena).

En cuanto a su arte: tiene diseños creativos (naves, lenguaje, aliens), algunos momentos con bella fotografía y un soundtrack que a veces escapa a la repetida fórmula actual de Hollywood mediante un sonido original. Todo muy digno de un sci-fi. Ya que estas cosas no son el centro de la película, se encuentran solo en la medida exacta, pero con cariño y personalidad. Algo que, sin importar su cantidad, se agradece mucho, ya que en general es difícil encontrar cariño en el trabajo del arte de las grandes producciones hoy en día. 

Al final, lo más importante de todo es que logra cumplir en dos horas el objetivo de desarrollar bien un tema y entregarnos el mensaje que quería su autor.

Arrival is one of the best that I have seen this year! Right from the jump you get an amazing opening sequence that to me really attaches you to the character Louise Banks played by Amy Adams. And this is one of her stand out performances so far in her career. I went in to this movie completely blind without seeing any reviews or any trailers, so honestly going in I was expecting this movie to be just another "SIGNS" type of film that we've seen 1000 times. But the way they did this film was beautiful, like they way they focused on the communication aspect and not just the war that you often see from films of this nature, so it felt very fresh and new and exciting. And most of that was carried by Amy Adams and the way she was able so easily to connect with the aliens, it seemed like she was really talking to them. Sticking to the actors and there performances in this film, in this movie Jeremy Renner plays a scientist, that is kind of like Amy Adams side kick in away, I just wish they would have done more with him and his character, because I feel like Renner has never really gotten an opportunity to shine in a movie like this, it feels like his character is never used to his full potential, and I think Renner is a very talented actor that just hasn't gotten that golden opportunity. 

Another thing I really enjoyed is the directing of this film by director, Gavin O'Connor, who has directed things like Warrior in 2011, and more recently The Accountant in 2016. O'Conner just does amazing in this film, like the first scene that you actually see the alien pods, it just blows you away. He really steals the show in this movie, it is honestly some of his absolute best work ever!

Now lets talk about the ending... I don't want to get into any spoilers, but to me although I loved the ending, if feel like it would've been better if they further explained it. It felt so rushed at the end and leaves you asking questions. Most of the ending makes perfect sense but there is just this one aspect that doesn't quite add up. 

All in all this movie is one of the best of the year hands down, I would definitely recommend this film! I loved and left the theater asking questions and really excited about the movie, and this is a film I could definitely see stealing the show come Oscar Night!
I'm never disappointed with Villeneuve, this is a truly remarkable movie.

Very slow-building and thought provoking, "Arrival" was the latest masterpiece from Denis Villeneuve, one of the best working directors in films right now. The core story is simple: 12 alien ships land across the world and mankind tries to find out why they are here, before the world goes apeshit in the growing mass panic and our idiotic shoot-first-etc. attitude. It was quite similar to "Contact" in this way and shows just how stupid mankind really is but in the end, it has a clear message it want's to say, you just have to really pay attention, for the movie tends to be at times quite complex.
What starts as a good but slightly slow paced movie gets elevated into rarefied air by the best 5th act in a movie in a long time...sci-fi for smart people ...come back to me ...indead

I saw trailers for this movie but didn't really know much about it.  After hearing on the radio it was a "must see" in theaters and seeing that it had over 90% on rotten tomatoes I decided I "must see" this in theaters.  I'm a sci-fi guy from day one and love movies in general and really like not knowing much about a film then being blown away by that film.  This DID NOT happen last night.  This isn't sci-fi it's a artsy overthought emotional movie that people that think they are smarter than everyone else love. It deals with time (maybe even time travel?). It deals with communication and it's importance in life and history.  Great subject matter, poorly executed. I literally had less questions about suicide squad (which was pretty terrible) than this movie.  I took my 12 year old son who didn't understand it at all basically because he's 12 not 50. So as I tried to explain it to him I couldn't even start without questioning everything I said. It's a 2 hour movie that's out of sequence almost like a pulp fiction but with only 2 scenes that make you go oh cool. Spend a dollar at red box and thank me later.

Not to be confused with Charlie Sheen's "The Arrival".  Arrival was not so much suspenseful as it was cerebral and engaging.  Much better than the abysmal 2nd installment of Independence Day.  I don't know that I found it enjoyable enough to watch a second time.

A Chegada poderia ter sido o melhor filme do ano. E chegou perto, estava quase lá. Dois tropeços, no entanto, fizeram o filme passar de uma obra mestra a um filme "muito bom, mas que poderia ter sido tanto mais".

O primeiro (e menor) é perceptível no momento que surge, que é a necessidade de preencher a cota da "fórmula hollywoodiana de filmes", em especial de sci-fi, ao colocar as "diferentes formas" que os países entendem e respondem à chegada dos aliens. Desnecessário, proselitista e maniqueísta, pasteuriza algo que poderia ter sido substituído por algum outro argumento bem mais inteligente e bem menos "preconceito americano/hollywoodiano" com relação ao resto do mundo. Soou como uma necessidade de cumprir um requisito básico da produtora, que espera que um filme de ficção científica tenha.

O segundo é descobrir, na segunda metade do filme, que todo o enredo e questionamento até ali nada mais foi do que um artifício de roteiro, um "plot device", um acessório/muleta para justificar o verdadeiro enredo do filme, que é um drama pessoal baseado em uma premissa de "tempo cíclico". O Drama em si é muito bonito, e a ideia básica do filme, sua história, visual e tudo o mais realmente foram muito bem montados e tudo MUITO bonito. Mas, ao chegar ao fim, fiquei me perguntando se, caso o artifício usado fosse outro, e não alienígenas, faria qualquer diferença na história. Um desenvolvimento de quase 1 hora de filme é desperdiçado ao não se criar uma função real para ele na história, além de servir de pano de fundo ao drama pessoal da protagonista. Os aliens chegam, colocam um mistério e vão embora sem qualquer impacto, e sem que esse mistério demonstre qualquer nível de relação com a mensagem principal do filme. Não só os aliens poderiam ser substituídos por qualquer elemento "sobrenatural" (ou até mesmo natural) que o autor quisesse: ainda é proposto no filme uma questão "a ser resolvida" neste aspecto, que nunca é mencionado novamente, como se tivessem esquecido de que aquilo necessitava algum tipo de resolução, ou se o filme tivesse perdido seus 20 minutos finais. E no fim te deixam pensando "ok... e tudo isso para o que, mesmo?".

Há muitas referências interessantes no filme, e várias fontes de onde parece ter "bebido": A Origem, 2001 Uma Odisseia no Espaço, Contatos Imediatos de 3º Grau, Contato (esse último faz uma presença perceptível, aliás), entre outros, são evocados, mas parece que faltou "um pedaço", ao não vincular todos os dilemas levantados pelo choque entre Humanidade-Aliens com os outros aspectos do filme.

Acabamos com uma excelente ideia, desenvolvida pela metade, e sem um fechamento de "tempo cíclico", tão falado e trabalhado ao longo da história.

Um filme muito bom, mas - que pena - deixamos de ter uma obra prima.
Different, good, but weak relationship ending.

Que maravilloso ver una película que aun siendo una película de alto presupuesto tiene muy presente que el cine solía ser el 7mo ARTE. Es que para mi el cine blockbuster está tan mal hoy (lleno de franquicias, segundas partes, festivales de efectos especiales para público fácilmente impresionable, muchas películas que son una sucesión de escenas sin sentido ni peso dramático cercano a la realidad, etc etc. Mucho amor por el dinero y poca pretensión artística) que ya se está cayendo de esa definición. Si tienes algo que decir, algún punto de vista que aportar, y lo haces a través de metáforas, ya sea musicales, visuales, literarias, etc, wn, eso es ARTE. Los autores de "Arrival" tienen algo que decir, y utilizan toda la película para canalizar brillantemente su visión de la vida. Y por momentos casi hasta llega a ser un breve estudio de la raza humana.

Que delicadeza de película que es "Arrival". Sus premisas son bastantes simples, pero me parecen bien desarrolladas. Me parece super atinado, encuentro muy poco real cuando en las películas pasan cosas brígidas a cada rato. La vida no es así. La peli intenta graficar de la forma más seria posible como sería enfrentar un primer contacto con una raza extraterrestre, y a partir de cierto punto se la juega valientemente por sus ideas creativas. Le encontré influencia de "Encuentros cercanos del 3er tipo". Tb se podría decir que va + o - en la línea de películas ciencia ficción inteligentes tipo "Interestelar", "Gravedad" o "2001 Odisea del espacio". Pero tiene identidad propia, años más adelante creo que se hablará de "Arrival" por sus méritos. 

Creo que la peli tiene toda la sutileza que suelen NO tener las películas sobre aliens, lo que por supuesto la hace más creíble. Que delicia ver una película de ciencia ficción sin que se flaitee (Lo que para mi es cuando ofrece una sobresaturación de efectos especiales y explosiones a diestra y siniestra a propósito de nada). Tb creo que para los temas que trata la edición de la película está hecha de forma impecable.

Esto es 7mo arte. Se puede, aun cuando tengas un presupuesto enorme y tengas que responder ante un comité de finanzas más que ante un comité creativo. Película oscarizable creo (película y actriz... aunque no creo que gane). 4.5 de 5

Arrival is certainly different than any movie I've rated previously.  Normally a movie can catch my interested easily, hold me through the middle, but maybe lose me on the ending.  Arrival was almost a complete 180.  I loved the premise, but somewhere after 20 minutes I found myself getting a bit uninterested in part due to its slow pace.  Don't get me wrong, Amy Adams is, and will always be, a fantastic actress.  She had a lot of touching scenes in this movie, but even she couldn't hold a flat drawn out plot in the middle.  With that being said, the ending left me speechless.  Knowing the finale now, maybe I would have found the beginning somehow more interesting.  More-so, I can't help but wonder if that was the director's intention.  Truly a movie better left vague until you've seen it for yourself.  4 inky circular symbols out of 5.

Amy Adams, perfect as ever, gives a riveting performance as a linguist brought in to decipher the language of the alien visitors to determine why they have come to Earth. The story pushes the definition of language far beyond any traditional concepts. This is not an 'action' flick a la Independence Day, it is more of a mystery and watching Amy Adams solve the mystery is fascinating. Don't blink or you just might miss something.

This is a movie about linguistics and fate and the aliens are just Deus ex machina to justify the apparent delusions the protagonist is having. There are some interesting elements, but the pacing is slow. The payout isn't enough to erase the slow pace of the movie. The movie feels like it is in two halves. A strong opening where these aliens arrive and there is all this potential, and then the effort to resolve the aliens' presence as quickly as possible to get back to the story about the human protagonist. The storytelling starts to rely on exposition through the end. The movie also uses vagueness to disguise some plot holes, which made it feel like the writer didn't actually know the answers to the questions raised about philosophy and time. I am wondering if watching this film twice would reveal something more to me. Either way, I didn't hate it, but I didn't love it either, and I wasn't so bored that I left early.

Denis Villenueve offers a great film, but one that is exactly what the trailer put forth, this is not a Sci-Fi War film waiting to happen, or a modern-day horror. It's a character-driven piece about politics, life, humanity and communication.
"Arrived" is like a finely woven silk tapestry that made me ugly cry. I loved every second of it. Amy Adams is spectacular.

In 1961 two iconic science fiction novels were first published: "Solaris" by Stanislaw Lem and "Stranger in a Strange Land" by Robert Heinlein. Both novels inform the story of "Arrival". "Solaris" is a meditation on memory and the difficulties of communication and, as portrayed in the superb Russian cold-war era film by Tarkovsky, on the dangers of miscommunication. "Stranger ..." builds on the idea that learning a extraterrestrial language has the capacity to radically alter human perception and so, human capabilities. This is not pure speculation and the interactions between brain function and language are an active area of research.

"Arrival" is an exceptional film that builds on the concepts introduced by Lem and Heinlein. And in its full implications can even be considered profound. In addition to its conceptual intensity, "Arrival" is superbly acted by Amy Adams and supporting caste. The score, with Max Richter's "On the Nature of  Daylight" at the beginning and end the film, matches the mood and the story line perfectly.

"Arrival" is the best sci-fi film that I have seen in years and a film that will stay with for many years to come.

"The arrival" reminds me of several other films, such as signs, interstellar and even melancholy, because like all these examples he tries to bring something new, and succeeds. We have here a film that goes beyond the classic cliché of alien invasion, we have a philosophical film, it really is not easy to be digested, but it takes, "The arrival" talks about time, life, future expectations, peace and unity , All with a seemingly simple plot. "An alien ship lands on the ground and a linguist is called to try to communicate with her," yeah, that synopsis can fool you, and a lot. The linguist in question is Dr. Louise Banks (Amy Adams), in trying to communicate with these extraterrestrials she ends up learning to see the world in another way ... Technically the film is also incredible, with many scenes of filming in off , Spike Jonze style, he plays the melodramatic way flawlessly and with a beautiful photograph, mixes and beautiful soundtrack, the film places Denis Villeneuve as one of the biggest names in the new generation of cinema that is emerging, and is not For less, Denis is spectacular, we must also talk about the acting, Amy Adams is incredible, perfectly interpreting all the news and dramas that passes his Louise. Finally, "The arrival" is a good news, it is a film that goes beyond its two hours, is a film that goes beyond that cheap science fiction, it has a message, even if we could change the bad things that happened in our Lives, it would not be worth it, because it is these things that build the human being, Congratulations Denis Villeneuve.

I went to see "Arrival" today at the Alamo. In summary, it was terrible. I heard good things about it, and really like the cast, but yes, it was terrible. The aliens and their language were the only good thing about it - no complaints there, they were cool and could have been fascinating. If you need more detail, I would call this mess "Beautiful Wim Wenders-style incomprehensible gibberish. It was as if "Contact" (1997) and "Until the End of the World" (1991) had a baby, and then that baby snacked on lead-based paint until it was old enough to vote.
Instead of action, drama, tension, conflict, or a plot, the viewer is treated to:
-Complete waste of a very good cast, to the point that even Forest Whitaker must have had Forest Whitaker Eye. 
-Soft-washed flashbacks straight out of a Hallmark condolence card used to substitute for a coherent plot.. not all sciencey like "Interstellar", either. Just, "lazy writer". 
-Poignant strings and piano music to stress how poignant the moment is, not so overpowering as Hans Zimmer's keyboard in "Interstellar", but more like having George Winston as an inconsiderate roommate. . 
-PopSci mention of Sapir-Whorf, a linguistics concept that's been around a very long time, yet the best linguists on the planet need a refresher. 
-High ranking military guys that are rigid and inflexible to the point of caricature, or low ranking military guys who are bloodthirsty and stupid to the point of caricature.
-Months of worldwide mania and panic at the arrival of aliens who land in the middle of nowhere, do nothing but stay in their ships, 
have no measurable impact with the environment, and cheerfully allow humans to regularly come aboard for the purpose of bumbling through attempts at communication at a leisurely pace, showing no frustration or menacing gestures of any sort. 
-CNN style newscaster exposition, the 21st century version of the spinning newspaper that says "ALIENS LAND ON LAS VEGAS!"
-Fast forward through voiceovers, and other hamfisted exposition.

This alien invasion movie from the director of last years drug cartel thriller Sicario and next years Blade Runner sequel, Denis Villeneuve, is brimming with smart ideas about language, time and what it means to be human.

When aliens come to Earth its usually for one of two reasons. They either come in peace or with plans to attack, hell bent on wiping out the human race and taking over the planet. Whichever is their intention its usually evident very early on in the film. Not so with Arrival, which gives nothing away.

The film begins with the arrival of 12 mysterious alien spaceships that hang sentinel over the planet. Until someone figures out one very simple question: what do they want? the aliens are both friends and foes. The US government calls in Dr Louise Banks (Amy Adams) a renowned professor of linguistics and Ian Donnelly (Jeremy Renner) a theoretical scientist to help establish communication and find out the visitors intentions. At every other site where the strange, pod-like crafts have appeared, world leaders are also trying to talk to the aliens. Up against the doomsday clock of growing global paranoia as mankind verges on interplanetary war, Banks and Donnelly must decipher the language of the alien species and discover their purpose for visiting Earth to safeguard the future of mankind.

Arrival, adapted from a short story by Ted Chiang called Story of Your Life, is a powerful and heartfelt portrayal of humankind's reaction to first contact. The screenplay by Eric Heisserer screenplay is sophisticated and gripping and Villeneuve has a show stopping reveal up his sleeve. Whilst it's a very intelligent science fiction movie, it's also a very accessible. Theres a lot that should be hard to get your head around but Villeneuve makes incredibly complicated concepts simple. The visuals created by cinematographer Bradford Young are astonishingly beautiful and theres an atmospheric score composed by Jóhann Jóhannsson.

Adams is absolutely terrific in a stand out central performance as an emotionally scarred woman facing what feels like impossible challenges. She is ably supported by the affable Renner who is given a chance to showcase his acting talent outside of the action movie realm. But the film belongs to Adams who provides the film's emotional core.

This ambitious, multi layered drama joins films like Christopher Nolan's Interstellar and Ridley Scotts The Martian as a mature, thoughtful piece of science fiction. An instant sci-fi classic and definite Oscar worthy contender.

Wow, critics have really drunk the Kool-Aid on this one. It's so flawed and so boring it's hard to know where to start. I'm a definite fan of intelligent films - Inception being the best example recently; Interstellar being the worst... until now. Arrival was pure Terrance Mallick-like poetic meaninglessness. It thinks it's far smarter than it actually is. We could debate the themes, or lack thereof, but let's just stick to the biggest flaws that ruin this film. Characters - paper-thin backstories or non existent. The main character loses a child to cancer in the first 30sec montage. Result? I don't care. And THAT was the best character. They give dribs and drabs of her past but it's crosscut between two confusing timelines of the past and future. The antagonists goal - if we're talking about the cookie cutter humans - boring. If we're talking about the aliens - WTF!? They state their goals, which are both here and in the future, but we see VERY little of the former and NONE of the latter. The music - where the special effects started and where the music began was often not clear. At first we hear the spaceships sounding like humpback whales; then we hear the music sounding like whales... or was that the sfx? I've never had such a muddled auditory experience in a movie before. To sum up - this film looked good at times, it had some cool moments with the whole language thing, but it's a boring hot mess. Want a smart sci-fi film that isn't full of jarring plot holes? See Ex-Machina.

Nice little sci-fi-movie, but  twist and outcome seem like a better Outer Limits episode instead of a blockbuster. When leaving the theatre you'll feel a bit empty as if this most times good movie is missing something.

The first hour and a half of this movie was a five star movie and the last 20 lost it two stars and earned it the unspectacular moniker of "The Looper of 2016." Now, what do I mean by that? Well, much like Looper, which took a decently solid science fiction concept and ruin it with another one at the last second. In Looper it was the entirely unnecessary addition of telekinesis to an otherwise solid time travel story and with Arrival well...I won't ruin it, but its not good and invalidates a lot of the fantastic character development that happened pre-twist. Which is a true shame.

It caught most people in the theatre, including myself, by surprise even though looking back, you could see the movie provided a lot of hints for it. The problem is, an exciting last 5 minutes does not justify the stale first 90 minutes of the movie.

The plot twist with the "flashbacks" also provides no explanation on how the "universal language" works and how it can help a human see the future. As a Sci-Fi, Interstellar puts this movie to shame with ideas and theories that can be researched and a thrilling story.

Also, as the alien told Adams, "We have come to help you now so you can help us in the future.", what was so wrong on Earth that it urgently needed help?

Arrival is a watchable movie with talented actors, but lower your expectations before seeing it to avoid the disappointment of a movie that had so much promise and potential.

Fascinating movie.  A science fiction movie in its purest form. Exploring the what if and taking you on a journey. 

So much of this movie was executed to perfection.  The movie was disorienting- but as it should be.  The characters were very real and human.  And the journey was engaging and interesting.  

The first 1 hour and 58 min (or so) were a great story that stood on their own.  And then in the last two minutes they hit you with a twist that is so big your head just reels.  I actually can't tell yet if that last twist makes the movie a better movie or a worse movie.  I can't fully get my head around it and I'm sure I'll be thinking about it for a while.  It's that sort of movie where you walk out wondering and thinking. 

Note: After the movie I went and read some reviews with spoilers that explain the ending and now that I get it, I think it makes it an even better movie.  One of those movies where you want to go back and re-watch the movie with the new information to see how it changes your perception of the movie.

Now with all of this said I don't think this is a movie for everyone.  I can totally see some people finding it to be too strange or hard to follow.  But I really enjoyed it

Spoiler alerts do not read if you haven't seen the movie:

Oh where to start with this movie. I would like to say that I am always willing to give a movie a fair chance. Within the time they are given they must remain true to the mission statement and not raise more questions than they answer. In this movies case they raise questions that are unanswerable at all to the western mind, whether you look for answers in the movie or outside it. To an eastern mind set it would fit perfectly to say its rainy outside and within the same thought say its sunny.

My first major beef with this movie is it spends an inordinate amount of time with Louise having flashbacks or memories of a lost child. It is never placed in any time frame and it never really has any relation to a specific time in her life. Next the aliens arrive and she is picked to decipher their communication and help our government understand what they are saying. As the movie unfolds it still isn't clear who Ion is but later we learn it was her husband yet it hasn't happened yet. So the first part of the movie is undisclosed flashbacks .aliens, and Louise interacting with this guy named Ion who is to become her husband later. 
These loosely disjointed sub plots are left loose on purpose i maintain because once the real theme is released that time is all one and not a succession of events as we know it the movie definitely wouldn't make any sense right out of the gate.

So what is the main theme well its that the aliens have a language that empowers a thinking process to view time as a whole.Not only that but by learning this language one can actually come to see time in this way and see all things at the same time. A place where there is no beginning and no end. Which is hilarious really since this theme is introduced and supported in an ongoing time space continuum episode called a movie. Where we have a beginning a middle and an end. This constant irritation pervades the whole movie and is no more glaringly evident as when in the end with the aliens leaving and her in the arms of her future husband Louise declares " I forgot how good it was to be held by you" ! Which is an obvious reference to not a memory but to a an actual event she experienced in the future but now was aware of because she saw all of time at once. Then also it is evident when she asks about the alien Abbott and the co alien being in the movie says.." Oh hes in the process of dying" which is somehow supposed to alleviate our fears that this movie has bitten off more than it can chew. So what happens when Abbott dies? Do they sit around and see him as there still because clearly that would put a huge marker down in a succession of events that he was no longer there. Hence time is not one event but a series of events creating a beginning a middle and an end.

So its about time...( no pun intended ) and in this case the movie tries to mix seeing all events as one and time itself which has a beginning a middle and an end unsuccessfully. 
It also tries to portray the aliens as ones who through evolution have arrived as the administrators of this great wisdom and that they can teach it to us through their language. 
They are supposed to have come to give us this ability because three thousand years later they are going to need our help somehow which is also strange because of they see all things at the same time why didn't they figure it all out before it happened thus not needing us.

In closing heres the deal Einstein said if you went faster than the speed of light you would go back in time. Yet he also said nothing can go faster than that which just so you can know is 186,000 miles a second. So apparently there remains an assumption that one can conceivably go outside of time and that it is a river if you will but certainly these aliens are not those guys.

I am curious as to why this movie gets such a high rating when there is such a glaring hole in the story! If people start to travel through their timeline by learning the Aliens' language - and we see Louise teach the language and publish a book about it - why is she the only one endowed with time-travel? I mean her soon-to-be husband is right there with her as she learns it and yet, he apparently has no idea of what is coming! And also, this device had such potential and yet, it was only used for a trite pathos story of a mother choosing to have a child even though she knows she will die young. Really? Why not use this device by having a large majority of earthlings get a glimpse of the future and (the plot device would have to be adapted to allow for new choices in the present to affect the future) change the choices they make to create a better world? Especially since apparently, the Aliens came to give the gift of their language because they will need us in 3,000 years... why is that not addressed at the end of the movie? And finally, if I have to sit through one more sci-fi movie where the main protagonist have to battle uncooperative or hostile army chumps, I am going to lose it! It has not been a novel concept since ET! So yeah... end of rant... And I am a word-nerd translator, so I really wanted to like this movie!

5/5. It's very rare when a film blows me away. I went in suspecting that I would love it, and love feels too inadequate to describe my feelings in response to this film. The story is one of the most original and brilliant I've ever seen on screen. The acting was great, but some of the cast was questionable. But that doesn't take anything away from my admiration for this film. The story kept me engaged and it was so much fun to keep speculating as to what was going on. The directing is just spectacular, subtle when necessary--a subtly that complimented perfectly the heaviness of the story. I cannot wait to see this again. I highly, highly recommend this. The age old question in alien movies is-do they come in peace? In most, that answer comes quickly, with an attack. In other, rarer movies, it takes much longer to get any answers. This film is in the latter category. Like Close Encounters of the Third Kind, but the whole movie is in that communication state that they only got to at the end of the Spielberg classic. I would have liked more sci-fi action, but the story is good and so is Amy Adams. The aliens looked good as well and overall I would like to have learned more about the aliens, but it's good to questions left provoke more thought and theories, and that's a good thing.
With strong performances and a great sci-fi premise, "Arrival" is a poignant and moving film.

Se cartaz, sinopse e/ou trailer te fazem acreditar estar diante dum filme pipoca aventuresco com alienígenas, não se engane: é um filme cerebral e reflexivo, mas também pessoal, intimista e sensível, devidamente recheado de ficção científica.

Acho importante alertar que o longa exige do espectador uma atitude de abstração à qual a maioria das pessoas não está acostumada ou pela qual não tem interesse ou não se sente atraída. Já os pesquisadores das Letras ou curiosos e interessados em estudos sobre linguagem terão um atrativo a mais, já que a [dificuldade de] comunicação tem um papel central no filme e precisa ser solucionada pela protagonista  uma linguista. Enquanto ela encara o desafio de decifrar uma gramática "bidimensional", com uma sintaxe visual sem relação com a sintaxe da própria língua alienígena falada, sem poder associar fonemas com grafemas, acompanhamos a aplicação de sua metodologia como cientista da linguagem.

Pra quem já teve oportunidade de ler o conto que deu origem ao filme (história, a princípio, tão "infilmável" quanto Nas Montanhas da Loucura de Lovecraft), é interessante conferir a solução visual que os produtores deram para representar a mega-abstrata língua escrita dos aliens, formada por aquilo que a linguista suspeita se tratar de ideogramas. 

Os amigos da Linguística e afins "pegarão a referência" (cortesia do Capitão América) quando o filme fizer menções à hipótese Sapir-Whorf (a estrutura/propriedades duma língua influenciam/moldam diretamente a cognição, a consciência e a visão de mundo dos usuários dessa língua); porém, essa menção (que não existe no livro) nem é tão adequada assim ao caso abordado. O fato é que as constatações da linguista me lembraram mesmo foi de outra questão que estudei durante meus primeiros semestres na UnB: o que vem antes? O pensamento ou a linguagem? É o pensamento que organiza a linguagem (Piaget) ou a linguagem que organiza o pensamento (Vigotski)? E nem posso contar por que pensei isso, pois soltaria spoilers.

Ninguém perguntou, mas vou responder: o que é melhor? O livro ou o filme? Cada um tem suas virtudes. O conto se aprofunda e se delonga mais na metodologia científica, nas análises linguísticas e nas tentativas de decifrar a linguagem alien. E tudo isso com muita propriedade e conhecimento de causa (palmas para o autor). Já o filme se torna (ainda) mais sensível e poético graças ao talento do diretor, com algumas americanices que não chegam a comprometê-lo.

Ele começa e se desenvolve cientificamente em clima de suspense, com intervenções contemplativas, mas se conclui de forma poética. E, como dizia meu amigo Alencar, poesia  assim como fotografia, pintura etc.  não é pra ser explicada, e sim apreciada.

I went to see "Arrival" sort of reluctantly because I am not into sci-fi movies with aliens coming to take the world over and a war ensues between the good guys (us) and the Bad (the aliens) and we always win. It was a choice of seeing this movie or "Rules Don't Apply" and I am not a fan of Warren Beatty's and I understand it is really a flop so I decided on "Arrival".

The main reasons I was interested in seeing "Arrival" was because I am becoming a big fan of Amy Adams and on YouTube I saw a video titled "Arrival Ending Explained" which intrigued me though I didn't watch it until after I saw the movie.

The first hour of the movie was like watching a foreign language film without subtitles and didn't hold me interest at all. The second hour with the 12 egg-shaped UFOs all over the world set up the standard them versus us but that isn't where it goes.

Amy Adams is Dr. Louise Banks, is a language expert, who had a daughter who died at the age of 12, and is called on to help make contact with the aliens who are named Abbot & Costello by the theoretical physicist Ian Donnelly, played by Jeremy Renner, who brings the  very rare humor in the movie. They work together in ways not exactly up to what Colonel Weber, (Forest Whitaker) and a CIA agent played by Michael Stuhlbarg want from them.

The film revolves around Adams and Renner with little time for the other actors except for an important cameo by Tzi Ma who plays the Chinese leader though it is Adams who holds your attention every time she is on screen which is through the whole film.

The film is not about them versus us but about time and how it can be looked at in different ways. We see many scenes with the mother and daughter from birth until her death 12 years later and by the ending these scenes all are looked at in a way that we weren't aware while watching them.

The ending is done subtly by the director Denis Villeneuve and screenwriter Eric Heisserer instead of hammering the audience over the head but I really wished I had watched that YouTube video before I saw the film.

Adams performance is constrained, as it should be, where it could have been melodramatic. When it comes to her what it all is about she calmly accepts and understands what is happening and what happened. Renner is very strong support for her performance.

This is not an 'entertaining' film in the sense you can sit back, munch on your popcorn and enjoy aliens invading earth but to which you have to think.

"Arrival" for the most part is a boring film except for the last 15 minutes and I didn't think the time invested was really worth the first 101 minutes and time is what the film is all about.

And Amy Adams has firmly established herself as a world class leading lady.

Because sometimes we need the extraordinary to remind us to appreciate the ordinary, the simple, the light of truth that reveals to us all, that not only are we not alone but we really do need each other.  Whether it's on a deep one on one personal level or on the global stage of humanity, take a chance by faith and explore what's beyond your own perceptions of life itself. Some of my favorite films are science fiction; most of my favorite films make me think...you know, really think about the purpose off a film and its effect on my worldview. Arrival is both of those things. No cliches are allowed, from the nature of the aliens to the special effects, this is truly elevated science fiction. And at the film's core is an irrepressible heartbeat that drives the plot towards its climax with emotional momentum. 

Few films can achieve that affecting power, but to find it in intellectual alien sci-fi is all the more special and precious.

Arrival is a science-fiction and drama film released November 11, 2016 starring some big stars like Amy Adams and Jeremy Renner. The film primarily takes place in Montana as two professors are sent to study and investigate alien space crafts, or what appear to be, that have landed. The movie is full of suspense and science and is engaging for the audience within the very first few minutes.
The film begins showing a timeline of scenes with Amy Adams, who plays Dr. Louise Banks, and her daughter from the past. The daughter is sick and hospitalized. Present day Dr. Banks is about to teach a lecture to her college class when a student urges her to turn on the TV to the news. Everyone watches in silence as what seem to be space crafts have landed all over the world. A day or two later Dr. Banks is asked to report to the scene of one spacecraft in Montana to infer what this species wants since she is an established linguistics professor. Accompanying her is Ian Donnelly, played by Jeremy Renner, who is sent to help her investigate. The first interaction with the unknown species is very surreal and is the first of many interactions between the two species. The humans begin to break down and try to understand the writing of the other species uses with the time they are given. Since there are twelve space crafts spotted around the world, teams of specialists and professors work together to try and figure out what these so called aliens want. Slowly other nations start to pull away because they believe this a dangerous species that want to harm humans. Dr. Banks does not feel like this the case and truly thinks they are here to help. One day when the military tells everyone they have finished their mission because it is no longer safe, Dr. Banks sneaks away to be alone and interact with this species. What she learns is extraordinary and she must convince others somehow. Dr. Banks is able to see events of the future and uses this to tell the Chinese ruler some information to persuade him to believe what she is saying. Dr. Banks and Donnelly seem to develop a connection with one another and the movie ends leaving many with questions.
The set design for this film was quite unique and futuristic. The scenes in the spacecraft depicted an accurate representation of what one may think it would look like if they ever encountered one. Although the movie really did not travel around much and many of the set backgrounds were used several times, it did not hinder the movie in any way. 
The acting in this film was excellent at tugging at the viewer's emotions while keeping them on their toes. Amy Adams did a fantastic job playing her role as Dr. Banks and made the audience really feel her sadness and willpower all throughout. The actor's performances kept the film from falling dull and really brought the movie to life.
Overall I found this movie to be extremely thrilling and enjoyable. It brought about a range of emotions from sorrow to curiosity and I never felt myself losing interest in it. I do not think younger children or teenagers would find this movie as interesting but I do think a bit older of a crowd would really enjoy the science-fiction drama. This movie is one I have recommended to friends and will continue to recommend.

A science fiction film grounded in reality. The plot will keep you interested throughout as the leading actors offer capable performances. The film explores deeper concepts of game theory in a mature way, encouraging its audience to consider their own views of conflict resolution. However the performances are competent, rather than groundbreaking and the events of the film dance the line between believability and ridiculousness a little too closely in areas. Some of the side characters also seem one dimensional and, for all of its efforts, I was unable to connect emotionally with the leads. That said I was happy to be escorted through the plot by a capable team.

Put your thinking caps on.  You'll need it for this heady sci-fi.  Denis Villeneuve, responsible for stand-out movies like Prisoners, Enemy and Sicario (also thinkers films), brings us Arrival, perhaps the meatiest of them all.  It may involve multiple viewings, but after one and some light internet reading, I was able to fully grasp (OK well at least get close to fully grasping) exactly what the idea Villeneuve and his team had for this film.

The basic premise without spoilers is: how does language, whether written or spoken, help us perceive reality?

Without getting as complex as an official article for the NY or LA Times, Arrival is about understanding how one race understands another.  And I'm talking all of the intricacies.  Cultures are so deep, it takes years upon years to full flesh out.  While we only see a brief glimpse at Amy Adams and Jeremy Renner's characters working on one as alien as the Heptapods', it still strikes a chord along the lines of, can we open our minds to work with others?

While Arrival may feel like a big movie about playing nice with others, there are some massive themes running through this film based off theories about linguistics.  Quite frankly, it's tough to comprehend on one viewing.  Maybe even two.  And while that may have critics lauding over the film and praising it for its inventiveness, the average move-goer will walk out not quite understanding what they just paid $10 for.

The movie, outside of its themes, is superbly done with adequate pacing, tempered dialogue that's not too brash or too over-bearing with long sentences, and fine acting.  

As sci-fi movies are supposed to do (the good ones at least), they are there to open your mind to other-worldy possibilities.  Will everything involved in Arrival be possible in the not-to-distant-future?  No.  Can some of these theories somehow end up being discussed or reopened?  Absolutely.
Actual science fiction at the movies; arrival is not a fantasy or action thriller.  I would have given it 5 stars had the role of the physicist been stronger.

I'll stop gushing about it and leave you with this: it's a thinker, a feeler, and most definitely worth your attention.

Really enjoyed this, as everyone has stated outstanding performance by Amy Adams. Arrival succeeds where few others have in providing an intelligent perspective on the 'first contact' scifi theme, while at the same time managing to engage the viewer just as effectively on an emotional level and playing cleverly on the ambiguity of the term 'arrival'. Many critics have described this as a refreshingly 'hopeful and pacifistic movie' making a 'a powerful case for communication over conflict'. I would like to think so - to be honest that was my immediate impression but it also occurs to me that there is another interpretation, what better way to assimilate another species/group than to get it to think like you do?! Much more effective than any Borg. Teaching them your language, and by extension, your 'reality', has often been the path taken by imperialists without any need for blood to be shed and wasteful conflict. For an advanced civilisation that can travel between worlds and (apparently) see outside of time mere material gain probably doesn't count for much if anything, why would it? There are more subtle ways to colonise the universe.
Excellent film, Amy Adams delivers an understated but powerful performance as Dr Louise Banks in this thinking persons Sci-Fi film

great film. don't know what other planet people are on about not understanding the film. what's not to understand?! great film with a different approach to sience fiction first contact. keeps you thinking and wondering what is going to happen next. solid story and acting not heavily reliant on cgi to make it a move to view.

Arrival is basically a combination of Contact and Signs.  It has the atmosphere and feel of Signs and the story of Contact.  Though, I think it ends up being better than both those films.  This is mainly due to the ending.  Both Contact and Signs started out really interesting and engaging, but then started to lose it by the third act, and then the ending ruins it.  With Signs the ending was just lame; with Contact the ending was both lame and confusing.  With the amount of build-up this film gives us in the first and second acts the ending could have been a complete letdown just like those films were.  Thankfully, this film does not drop the ball on the ending, which makes Arrival a cut above the rest.  Despite that I would not call Arrival a phenomenon like most praise as.  It's definitely a good movie, but I was not blown away by it.
Like I said earlier, the story is very similar to contact where humanity finally has contact with alien visitors and the main character Louise, played by Amy Adams, is trying to find a way to decipher their language and communicate back to them.  The differences that, unlike Contact where the characters are deciphering a message and we never actually see the aliens, here the extraterrestrials actually come to Earth and the humans communicate with them directly, which makes the film more visually interesting.  
The film also has a very gloomy atmosphere to it, very much like Signs or a Christopher Nolan film.  If I did not know the director and people said Nolan directed this movie I would believe it, especially with the ending, which is something he would concoct.
The movie looks great in spite of the gloomy atmosphere.  The effects team did an amazing job with the visuals.  The score, while not the most memorable, also did its job at setting the mood of the scene.
The main thing about this film that prevents it from being a masterpiece for me is the characters.  Amy Adams is fine but the rest of the cast I thought was lacking.  The one thing Signs does better than this film and Contact, in my opinion, is the characters.  I was invested in Mel Gibson and his family more than the cast in Arrival and Contact.  You got good actors like Jeremy Renner and Forest Whitaker, but their characters were rather bland.  Jeremy Renner's character felt rather pointless in the film until the very end when his role becomes clear.  Even so, the film does not make him a compelling character and his chemistry with Amy Adams felt a little forced.
Plus, while you understand their importance by the end, there are many scenes that drag and drag down the pacing a little.  Also, while the ending is good, there are a few scenes that feel odd or didn't really make sense with what the ending was going for, which I won't reveal to avoid spoilers.  That's more of a nitpick, but it bugs me.  
Overall, if you enjoyed Signs and/or Contact, or even aspects of those films you'll like Arrival.  If you like Interstellar, Inception, or just about anything directed by Christopher Nolan you'll enjoy Arrival.  I'd say it's definitely one of, if not the best alien invasion film to come out in a long time.  I didn't think it was spectacular like most did, but it's definitely solid.

Amy Adams stole the show....I wouldn't be surprised if she got an Oscar nomination out of this flick.

Well... far be it from me to criticize this "intellectual" movie or i might appear stupid. 
I'm going to anyway.
So I saw this squid on the jetty the other day and it squirted ink all over the place. Obviously it was trying to communicate with the people around it.Someone worked out that it was saying "Please kill me"  and that was that.
I am totally flabbergasted that  a world of giant squids who squirt ink but have the vast and incredible technology to travel between worlds and/ or galaxies (or dimensions) do not have the basic understanding to COMMUNICATE with their intended destination.

You can imagine the conversation:  "Shit! Something BAD is gonna happen and it involves those creatures on that little blue speck in that galaxy far far away (or parallel dimension or past time) and it's gonna affect US! Let's go and WARN them!"

"OK How are we going to TELL them?"

"Don't worry, They'll get the hang of it in no time"

Of course, there always happens to be a brilliant SINGLE person who can decipher the squid writing. And,of course, there's going to be a rogue group of soldiers who just want to blow it up because they are squids and they MUST be a threat cos they don't look like us. Hang the orders, who cares what the General says?

So what's the message here??   Gee, don't fuck up the planet? That's original.

Yes, it looked good. It was VERY well executed. SFX were brilliant.  That's where it stops for me. Boring and very UN - intellectual.
Aliens, mind-bending language, musings on death and time as simultaneous moments rather than a linear stream. What's not to like?

So what can I say about Arrival that a hundred other critics and commentators have not already?  Arrival is a simple, straightforward science-fiction drama about a linguistics expert who is called in by the American military after alien vessels arrive and linger on twelve different locations around the globe.  She and a theoretical physicist must race against time to decode their language before the Chinese and Russian governments launch hostilities against the extraterrestrial presence.  Arrival is an attempt at hard science fiction and it mostly succeeds, as it is a brutally realistic portrayal of how our current civilization would react to first contact.  Furthermore, it's mostly a picture about thoughts and ideas, and to an even greater extent - human connection.  Amy Adams gives a tour de force that ranges from piquing our intellectual curiosity during key scenes to breaking our hearts as we follow her character on a roller coaster ride of emotional heartbreak.  Jeremy Renner plays well alongside her, and their methods of cracking the alien language proved as exciting as any action movie this year, for me at least.  Arrival does seem like other films in this genre such as Contact and Close Encounters of the Third Kind, but it manages to avoid being derivative or feeling like it was cannibalized from older entries in the genre.  No, Arrival carves out a unique place for itself and dares us to think just a little more about what lies beyond the horizon and about ourselves in equal measure.  One of the best movies of the year and expect it to win awards.  Because it should.

Not your typical alien movie. Actually, not much of an alien movie at all. The movie says a lot about language, interpreting it and the culture behind it. Actors were good and so were special effects. Also talked about foreign policy and how unity internationally is important.

Denis Villeneuve delivers another flawless hit, and my personal favorite film of the year. Arrival explores themes of time, destiny, and communication; all under the unpretentious and non-schlocky guise of an alien invasion. Amy Adams once again owns this movie with a heart-wrenching performance. She's the current MVP in Hollywood and deserves every bit of praise for the range of emotions she brings to this role. Even the look of the aliens and their ships is something to behold. Despite the fact that the story is not really about them, Villeneuve and co really take their time to carefully create a memorable design.

This is a movie that deserves to be seen more than once. The themes, the performances, the aliens, the storytelling - they all work perfectly. See it once, twice, thrice and so on.

There's been a quiet resurgence of the mysterious in modern cinema, and Arrival is another excellent example of it done right; it's oddly reminiscent of Stranger Things in that sense.

Everything about the movie is minimalistic, understated, and nuanced - the performances, the score, the cinematography - which all serve to balance out the larger-than-life mystery on hand, which is a joy to watch unfold. Like all the best science fiction, the revelations contained within that mystery comment more on our internal lives and the human condition than they do about grandiose intellectual quandaries.

This is a film best seen knowing as little about it as possible. I will say that the film makes a pretty big "ask" of the audience, and I wasn't entirely ready to suspend disbelief as necessary. But this was a tiny bump in an altogether worthwhile journey. A cinematic event not to be missed.

I love a good sci-fi movie and went to "Arrival" with great anticipation. My review could be summed up by words I overheard as we left our New Canaan, CT theater: "I think we've been had." 
Indeed. This is a self-indulgent, stereotypical film ("What?!? The military guys want to blow up the aliens first and ask questions later? Groundbreaking!!!") built around a very weak punchline and Amy Adams' great talent. The punchline of Jodie Foster's " Contact" came to mind. After much machination and drama, Jodie ends up on a VR beach with an alien disguised as her dear departed Dad so she won't be frightened. She then is allowed to have a 5 minute interview about the Meaning of the Universe - sort of. When she asks why the aliens are communicating to humans in such a...well, she's too polite to say, "in such a screwed-up manner!" The alien responds, "Because that's the way it has been done for billions and billions of years..." Sort of like a bad authority figure saying, "Because I said so, that's why!" But the really sad part is that  the courageous, iconoclastic scientist played by Jodie just gazes longingly into the cosmos, surrounded by radio telescopes and smiling children. Arrival's punchline is well within the same, vapid ballpark.
