I'll try to write this without spoilers and explain why I thought this film was an astronomical let down. If you're like me and you believe the success of a film hinges drastically on the ending (Ive found that a poor film can become a great one with a solid ending, just as a great film can become a poor one with a bad ending) then expect to be let down by "Arrival". 

Firstly, there is little doubt "Arrival" will get its hooks into you and most likely entertain and intrigue the hell out of you throughout (which is why I gave it two stars instead of one) but because the ending is so abrupt and the subsequent discovery of the premise is so obvious and disappointing it's hard to imagine anyone leaving the theater satisfied. If you don't care much for a premise, and endings don't effect your opinion on the quality of a film then stop reading this and go see it. you won't be disappointed. But if those things are important to you then read on.

I went with a large group and afterwards half of us gave it two thumbs down (including myself) while the other half gave it two thumbs up. I think it's interesting there was no one in the middle, we either hated it, or loved it. What's more interesting, is after I explained my thoughts (mainly concerning the failed ending) the half that enjoyed the film all decided to change their opinion.

As I said the movie does a great job (better than most) of entertaining you and pulling you in so you're intrigued, engaged and excitedly waiting for the story line to take off. And that's where it will leave you.

The premise of the movie is humans are incapable of working together and achieving unity without the assistance of a third party (aliens in this case), and without that unity we are destined to destroy ourselves and each other. Why do the aliens care? Because in 3000 years we save them, it doesn't go any deeper into the "why" than that... So in order to unite the human race the aliens travel back in time to give the leading nations 12 different pieces of a complex puzzle, all in the hope that we work together to solve the puzzle and achieve global unity. If that sounds like a bunch of BS then you'll feel the way I did.

Simply put, "Arrival" was created to profit off of humanities current shortcomings, mainly our inability to unite. In a world with unity concerts and a Trump/Hillary presidential ticket it's surprising Hollywood hasn't done a cash grab project to profit off of this topic sooner as they often do with sensitive topics relating to race, religion and politics. The worst part of the film is that this is all very obvious to the audience after only 20 minutes of the story. You'll spend the next 90 minutes thinking and expecting that there is going to be more depth than this, but there's not. You'll assume something, anything, is going to happen (like a war suddenly breaks out between humanity and the aliens) yet nothing does. There is no plot twist, no left turns, no right turns, no passing go and no collecting 200 dollars... And when they finally get around to spelling out the above premise, that's it, It's over! Exactly when you think something is finally going to happen, the credits start to roll.

In summary, this movie is anti-climatic and leaves you wanting, waiting and expecting more in the worst way possible. The strong acting and intriguing plot draws you in, but fails to take you anywhere. Almost as if the creators had plans of grandeur when they started production but ran out of money and just decided to call it a day. I recommend saving your money and renting this one. If you still want to go see a movie then I suggest Fantastic Beasts or Hacksaw Ridge.. at least in those you'll enjoy a great plot throughout along with a strong ending.

one of the worst movies I've seen in two years. had trouble staying awake. there's no redeeming value or common sense In this movie. they can travel across  the enormity of space, probably close to light speed, defy gravity, have vast portions of unused areas in their spaceship, land several ships simultaneously, but yet can only communicate with us with ink blots? really?

Short version:
Don't see it, unless you want to walk out about half way through. Leave at the explosion. You'll know it when you see it.

Long version:
This film is like going to dinner at an expensive restaurant that you recently heard of; Everyone said it was very good. You sit down, and enjoy some very nice appetizers, then start enjoying a very delicious main course. When you're half done with it, the waiter snatches your plate away, and gives you your dessert. Confused, you look down to see some angel food cake. You think this is strange, and also a bit boring, since it's just sponge cake, without any garnish, or even icing. You take a bite, and realize that they mixed up the sugar with the salt. It's not even poisonous or terrible-tasting, because the recipe wouldn't call for very much sugar in the first place. You didn't go to the hospital, but you still left with a bad taste in your mouth, spoiling the previously-enjoyed parts of your evening.

(SPOILERS from here on.)
This film wasted its entire premise, budget, and actors on two acts that seem to be setting up for something interesting, but end in deus ex machina. The main character literally solves the world's problems in the third act with outer-space time-travel magic. If you think about it after seeing the film, the nations and peoples of the world are probably *more* war-like, and distrustful of each other, because now they have magic time-travel technology to fight over. Nobody overcomes their past. Nobody grows as a character. In fact, the main character *literally* condemns her unborn daughter to die of cancer, because she can see the future, and knows how she will die.

I was left shaking my head and licking my wounds for wasting good money for this movie.  Just wait for it on home video.  It's definitely not a big screen movie.  I just hope it doesn't win any Academy Awards... because it's really "that" bad.  I'd really like my money back, if I could.  Stay home, you'll thank me later.

This movie can only be described as something that starts out with a very simple idea and ends up turning into a complex and exciting story. Arrival is a truly sci-fi movie that you watch with your mouth open in amazement that gets better by the minute with an unforgettable and unpredictable ending.  

Arrival begins when 12 UFOs touch down in random places on Earth. The whole world is panicking and the United States looks to a talented linguist named Dr. Louise Banks (Amy Adams) and a gifted Theoretical Physicist named Ian Donnelly (Jeremy Renner) to help translate what the aliens really want from us and what their purpose on Earth is. Once the new team starts uncovering the information about the mysterious species, they find very surprising things that go against everything we once knew. 

The movie is great overall but the ending is what really makes Arrival so legendary. The special effects are spectacular and the acting is extraordinary. Amy Adams excels in her role of Dr. Banks. What I most liked about the movie is how it all comes together. Without spoiling anything, I will say that the ending is mysterious and can be interpreted in hundreds of different ways depending on what angle you look at it from. The only other movies that have such perfect endings and make you actually think deeply about  what exactly is happening are Interstellar and Inception. Another thing about this film that blew me away is the cinematography. From giant aerial shots of 1500 foot UFOs to a fleet of battleships about to start an attack, the cinematography truly adds to the intensity and amazement of the film. My one small criticism has to do with the last few minutes. The creators stretch it out about five minutes too long in their attempt to show in very deep detail what exactly happens at the end. I feel like they could have shortened it and explained the ending instead of stretching it out, but that only lasts a couple of minutes and is hardly noticeable. Another huge perk is the sound editing and the soundtrack. The sounds of the UFOs and the aliens are intense and the music perfectly suits the story. This combination makes your heart thump and works wonders with surround sound. 

My favorite scene is when the aliens first start writing in their language. They write using something that resembles ink that stays in the air. It is truly beautiful and unique. It is unlike anything else I've ever seen before in a sci-fi movie with aliens. I also like this scene because it is when they start talking about their language and how they talk backward and forward at the same time. If they think like this, they can write and create a complex sentence in a split of a second, which amazed me. I also admired how the story treats their language almost like an art form and not just a way of communication.

There is a presence of some mature language in a few scenes as well as very intense and dramatic moments, so I recommend it for ages 13 to 18. I give it 5 out of 5 stars despite one small hiccup because of just how it makes you think about life and the future and gets your adrenaline pumping.

There's nothing scarier than the unknown, yet the unknown is the only sure thing. All that's real is what has already arrived; luckily, the truth of love can never fully depart. Though time causes the pain of endings, the love we experience is always worth it. 
What does all this have to do with alien-invasion-drama Arrival? Everything. A visually mesmerizing, aurally overwhelming, emotionally disruptive, narratively surprising, and thematically pulsing sci-fi film for the ages, it's not to be missed.
The setup is familiar: a group of UFOs appear over different cities all over Earth, and a small group of disparate humans must lead all humanity towards an understanding of their purpose. However, Independence Day this is not. More suspenseful than thrilling, it's high-minded science fiction whose slow and steady pace only emboldens its immense engagement. 
Think the best aspects of Kubrick and Spielberg: brainy ideas and complex visuals, mixed with spectacle and humanism. For example, on first entering the alien ship, we experience: characters' shifting sense of gravity, fear giving way to wonder then back again, the prescient difficulty of communicating across impossible boundaries. Villeneuve, who's becoming one of the greatest directors of our time, embodies such meaning into each of these moments. Even lines like, "I forgot how good it felt to be held by you," carry meaning beyond their clichés. 
Its intelligent sci-fi style brought to mind Close Encounters, Tree of Life, Interstellar, and fourth film I won't mention. Just know that time and awareness are huge throughout, leading to a final montage that brought me to tears for the first time this cinematic year. Arrival is an absolutely stunning achievement from beginning to end.

It is not my habit to give any movie five stars unless it just knocks my socks off.  Those movies are few and far between, to coin a cliche.  Arrival is not one of those movies.  In fact, though it kept me engrossed the whole way thru, I didn't leave the theater with a strong sense of how I felt. But I was satisfied. I really needed to ruminate on what I saw and heard in order to be able to express my feelings.  Having had a few days to think on it, I award it four stars.  The acting was top-notch.  The story was very good as well, but the movie is not about the story.  It is about the theme.  It is a wonderful theme, and it is the theme that is ultimately satisfying and ultimately why I gave "Arrival" four stars.  Go see it. You're going to have to think, but I think you'll find that the underlying message is what makes this movie a worthwhile way to spend your evening.

Another great film from Denis Villeneuve. Beautifully shot and masterfully acted by Amy Adams, it's truly one of the best films of the year 2016. 

Actually I had to watch it twice to make sure how I'm feeling about the film. The first act deals with the context it's written in very realistically and the second act felt and certainly looked very Terrence Malick-y. I just have to compare some aspects of the film to Malick's The Tree of Life. Perhaps he's one of Denis Villeneuve's inspirations or it's just me.

The overall look of the film is stunning, as with most of Denis Villeneuve's films. Bradford Young, the first African-American to be nominated for the Academy Award for Best Cinematography, made the film look real more so than real life. His shot compositions are stunning and the use of light, natural and effects, is great. He's worked on Selma before and I'm excited to see his work on the upcoming Han Solo film. 

As with most of his previous works, Jóhann Jóhansson does a great job with the score of the film. Almost seamless at times, it's difficult to differentiate if it's being played with the film or just in my head as I'm watching this beautifully shot and told film. I guess that seamlessness and the at times abundant music is also what makes Arrival a great film. He's also writing the score of Deni Villeneuve's upcoming Blade Runner 2049, which is another great reason to look forward to the long-awaited sequel.

On The Hollywood Reporter's Roundtables Amy Adams said that the first thing Villeneuve told her about the film was that it's a mother's story. A story about a mother. How true that is. But that's not to leave the questions that were asked and the messages we have to decode from the film. 

Hard to say if I have any criticism about the film, but if I had to nitpick, I'd say the film's first act is a bit of a slow burn but that's expected of Denis Villeneuve's films. So I guess that's that. 

Overall I recommend you to watch this film and hopefully it will spark some great conversations with your friends and peers.

"Arrival" is a science fiction thriller starring Amy Adams as a linguist working for the government who is consigned to communicate with aliens that have just landed at twelve sites across the globe. She tries to decipher their language and figure out their intentions before mankind is divided into the brink of war by the unknown threat the aliens may pose. This was a brilliant, masterful film! The message is sophisticated and tonally this movie is sound from beginning to end. Adams delivers one of her best performances and both her and the film will likely be blessed with Oscar nominations. You have to pay close attention to everything in this film as it is so complex and mysterious, but the payout is huge. This is arguably the best film of 2016 to date and will likely be up for Best Picture ---------------------------------------------------- A

As a painting this could hang in New York's Metropolitan Museum, or the Louvre in Paris. Beautifully crafted throughout by director Denis Villeneuve, who had impressed with Sicario last year, this is a triumph for his skills and for those appearing in front of the camera - none more so than Amy Adams, who embraces her role with the gusto of someone on the Oscar trail. After five nominations so far, this could be her year. 
No painting, as a film this falls slightly short for me, but that view is not echoed by all and I applaud those that appreciate such a work of obvious good intent. My problem was that, having been promised a film that would rock me on my heels, I was always waiting for something to happen. The pace is pedestrian but spooky. Gradually, as the clock in the dark of the theatre ticks by, it becomes clear that options for the ending are limited. On our journey we see mankind exhausting its usual stupidity (thinking creatures that have traversed a universe in a way we can only contemplate will be thwarted by tanks and missiles was surely poorly considered) until staring ineviatibilty in the face. And through the haze on set, I was not entirely convinced by the aliens, feeling that beings with an octopian shape would have a logistical  difficulty in building the machines they had arrived on, and wondering how a society could be built on their methods of communication. 
Perhaps I was taking it all too seriously. Perhaps I entered the cinema with too many expectations. To be fair, this is worth seeing but I don't feel it is the masterpiece that it has been labelled. In sci-fi terms that is a accolade that belongs to Stanley Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey - a work made forty plus years ago and yet to be surpassed.

"Arrival" directed by Denis Villeneuve, is an unconventional story about a linguistics professor, and a physicist who are trying to figure out why these giant alien ships have landed on earth. Opting to focus more on the characters, rather than the chaos that would ensue around the world. So go out to your local cinema and support a Montreal artist!

"Arrival" is the sort of movie that "The Martian," "District 9," and "Interstellar" (to name a few recent examples) so desperately (and futilely) wanted to be: sci-fi for the thoughtful. This is easily director Denis Villenueve's most accomplished American film, leaps and bounds beyond "Prisoners" and the wildly overpraised "Sicario", and it owes its laurels to its central cast of Adams, Whitaker, & Renner--three actors who lend instant credibility to nearly any role that they play.

Arrival: spoiler alerts are not necessary to review this movie.  No amount of description can dull the shock and surprise you'll feel seeing stale Hollywood formulas like this paraded around anew, albeit with the obligatory gazillions of dollars worth of big budget special effects.  But don't turn away yet.  I'll give Arrival a three out of four overall, for its eerie overcast ambience and especially for Amy Adams, but 2.5 out of four for sticking to trite "aliens visit earth" plot lines.  If the soundtrack alone doesn't evoke a very long trailer for all the sci-fi thrillers you've ever seen, you haven't seen enough movies. 

Our heroes, smart science nerds, are pitted against the usual suspect bad guys: trigger happy marines and creepy Henry-Kissinger-esque national security spooks.  There's even a little - Surprise!! - romance and some mildly interesting but basically barroom scientific theorizing thrown into the mix.   The overriding theme of Arrival is its gloomy, overcast ambiance of big bad things, waiting to happen, against slate-grey Montana skies, punctuated by the thunderous flatulence of the horn section in the soundtrack.  Nevertheless, Arrival is a fun way to blow a sunny afternoon.  You may feel like you'll never get those two hours back again, but you know deep down somewhere that, left to your own devices, you would have wasted the time even more shamelessly.

If anything, it is so refreshing to see a sci-fi alien invasion movie that doesn't resort to big effects heavy action scenes. Make me think and ponder and stretch my imagination..I don't always need the whiz-bang (in fact I am increasingly bored with it!), and in that regard, "Arrival" is one of hell of a rewarding picture.

Arrival has stuck with me in ways I didn't expect. I'm into sci fi and I'm into aliens so that was the hook. I didn't know I'd get a woman as a main character and that she would be highly skilled and respected for it and never really have to fight to prove herself. The details of the film felt really rich -- the shape of the language they use to communicate with, the way the mathematics of language is explained to the audience -- clear without being overwhelming. I straight up liked it. What stuck with me is this idea about knowing, or more specifically, about women's knowledge. The heaviness of certain truths sits with women in a way they never will on the men around them. I'm not going to break this down to patriarchal gender roles and conditioning or to the fact that women live in a society that oppresses them while they are often in romantic relationships with their oppressors. I'm not going to link this theme to the natural conflict that arises there, or to the need women naturally have to keep a part of themselves and their knowledge and experience of the world seperate from the men who are closest to them. Because the film doesn't make that link. The film has aliens to explain for the conflict. Amy Adams had so much dignity and wisdom in this film and I'm really grateful I got to see that character and consider her decisions.

Arrival is directed by Dennis Villeneuve and stars Amy Adams as Dr. Louise Banks, a language expert teaching at a university who is called upon by the U.S. government to establish communication with a mysterious alien race that makes contact on Earth. She is helped by another scientist, Ian Donnelly (Jeremy Renner).

I almost hesitate to write this review because there's so much to dissect with this movie that it almost requires multiple viewings to completely understand. Without giving anything away, I will say that Arrival is a brilliantly effective piece of Science-Fiction due to Amy Adams' performance and really powerful themes of understanding other cultures' points of view. While the pacing is slow throughout, the payoff is strong enough to forgive any lags. I was really drawn in during the middle act of the film when Adams and Renner were beginning to learn the alien language. The emotions of those scenes were incredibly palpable, and I caught myself grinning along with the characters when they made a breakthrough.

The ending of this movie is why I feel Arrival needs to be watched multiple times. Certain facts are made known, making the (somewhat) obvious twist ending much more complex than it seems. It reminds me of the ending of Inception in how ambiguous it felt once the credits rolled.

In the end, Arrival is a powerful movie and proof that big-budget films can still occasionally contain original content. Be ready for a thought-provoking movie and not an action flick, though. Ok, I'm going to go watch this again.

Final grade: A-

-Ben

From all of the excellent reviews and the enthralling trailers, I had
incredibly high expectations for the movie Arrival as I was walking
into my local theater. I left the theater almost on the verge of a
panic attack with my expectations obliterated after the movie ended.
Arrival was the most breathtaking and powerful films that I have ever
seen, and I can honestly say that I have never had so strong of a
reaction to a movie in my entire life. From the heartfelt cold open, to
the appearance of "Arrival" signaling the ending of the movie, I
believe that it was as close as a film can come to being perfect. The
emotional perfection of the movie's climax was almost too much for me
to handle, and it brought out a reaction in myself that I've only
experienced when reading books (mainly from Robin Hobb and Patrick
Rothfuss).

It was a joy to see a true Hard Science-Fiction story on the big
screen, and Denis Villeneuve has proved once again to be a masterful
director. Every frame of this film is incredibly gorgeous, and I honestly don't know how some of it was filmed, as things that have to be CGI look so real. There is so much I could say about the movie, but I want to avoid any chance of spoilers. However, I will say that the design of the aliens and their language was incredibly interesting, original, and beautiful. I loved how the creators of the movie embraced the fact that if we do ever meet any alien species, they are not going to look anything like us or immediately be able to communicate with Humanity. It's very interesting how the movie handles deciphering the Heptapod's language and teaching them our language, and while some could find these moments boring, for me they were engrossing. I wouldn't have minded even more scientific examination of linguistics and translating the language that bears no resemblance to anything created on Earth.

This movie may not be for everyone, but depending on how it holds up
after multiple viewings, I might have a new movie in my personal Top 10
Films of All Time. I highly recommend it, and if you want to see a
video of my full review where I go into spoilers for the second half,
it can be found here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=95ofAsrVZ6g

Well, I am an old cynic by now and very hard to please when it comes to my favourite genre 'sci-fi'. 
My, there have been some turkeys over the last couple of decades... 2010zzzz, Star-grate, non-Event Horizon, Promethaneous, Star Wars teh Phantom Plot.. I could go on.
Suffice to say this is not one of them.
You know that delicious feeling when you're in a cinema with an audience that is really gripped? So rare in these days of zero-attention spans... in the silent moments you could hear a pin drop... on a carpet.
Lots of shudders and silent' aaahs' too. You just know when people are collectively enjoying a movie and this is one of those movies and for a sci-fi flick that's exceptional.
The plot and the action are almost but not quite secondary to the beautiful and atmospheric way it is displayed and arranged... I have rarely seen a film that took so much pride in its identity and execution. The performances are top drawer and the casting near-perfect.
Some might balk at one or two lame lines towards the end but for me they just added a little light relief to a quite heavy story and can be more than forgiven.
As many others have pointed out, this is a cerebral film as much as anything. You're not just along for a flash-bang-wallop ride, this one makes you think right until the end.
As if to prove that point, as I was getting my stuff and rising from my chair, all around me were little pockets and pairs of people animatedly discussing what they had just seen. So, so nice to see.
Highly recommended.

Amy Adams is a linguist who must help translate the Aliens complex language in order to save mankind from itself. The movie begins with the arrival of 12 ships located across the globe. Each country shares the information they obtain from studying the Aliens until one word is translated and one by one they cut off contact with each other. The movie is a commentary on how individual countries in many ways are insular and self serving and require external influence to finally bring them together. There is also a very interesting twist in the final third which makes you think about what you have just watched for the first two thirds of the movie. The use of music is on a par with Sicario which is very effective in heightening the build up of tension. Well worth seeing on the big screen. Amy Adams is in excellent form.

I saw this movie, and was blown away. Each shot gripped my eyes where I didn't want to turn away. The cinematography was beautiful. It made sure the savor each and every shot. The acting was amazing! Do yourself a favour and go see this film. Thought provoking Sci-fi at its best. This is precisely the kind of science-fiction movie, at once epic and intimate, that Interstellar tried (and failed) to be. The entire cast is strong, but Arrival is Adams's movie from the first frame to the last. The performance she gives is mesmerizingly open, by turns uplifting and sorrowful. If you are unmoved by the film's conclusion, then you are made of considerably harder stuff than I.
At first, Arrival is seemingly too metaphorical, but the final act of the film wraps the story up in a very satisfying way.

Having said, it is incredibly well made, beautifully shot, and has some great performances. I would highly recommend it, but I doubt I will want to watch it again.

Arrival is a sci-fi mystery movie that makes you think about its plot and it lingers on long after the ending credits. We follow a linguistics expert, called Louise, who together with the army and a team of scientists try to communicate with aliens who have landed on Earth. All of this while under immense national and international pressure and hoping that other nations don't attack the aliens. The first part of the movie is mostly about learning and teaching, language from and to the aliens. It is in the second part that Arrival shines, when we find out not only language but also time acts completely different for these aliens. Then all of a sudden all those flashbacks shown throughout Arrival get a new meaning and become interesting and saddening at the same time. All credit goes out to the plot and story. It gives you all clues to solve the mystery, but makes you think about it before being baffled by the result. This with a great cast makes this a movie you should see.

"Arrival" is going to be either a clear-cut hit or miss for moviegoers, with passionate sci-fi enthusiasts more likely to place this film in the former category. Others will scratch their heads leaving the theater and rhetorically ask themselves "Can I have those two hours of my life back?" But few partakers of "Arrival" will put it into the middle-ground of mediocre.  It's a go big or go home formula for this edgy mind-bender.  The latest film by Denis Villeneuve (who directed last year's phenomenal "Sicario"), "Arrival" explores an alien vs. human showdown over Montana, as a dozen spaceship pods (or "shells") arrive unannounced in parts of the world. 

Viewers are cautioned to approach "Arrival" with the same mental acuity as a straight-A student sitting down to take their high school SAT test.  Serious cognitive stories require serious concentration to decipher linguistic relativity and its relative effect on a person's world views.  
The concept that thoughts are determined by language comes across like a philosophy lecture back in our college days.  And one's skillful ability to finish a BFF's sentence in mid-conversation is not nearly enough moxie to fully understand or apply the film's scientific theories.  Simply put, one must focus intently on the notion of linear time and how one would approach life if they knew how it all played out beforehand.  

Director Villeneuve orchestrates confusing mental gymnastics upon the audience, combining a stale present day storyline with a barrage of visual "flashbacks" into Amy Adam's Louise Banks character. Banks, a college Linguistics professor, is asked by the U.S. military (an Army Colonel portrayed by Forest Whitaker) to direct first contact negotiations with a pair of these squid-like creatures. 

The film begins with a plausible and well-developed alien arrival to Earth.  Between the mass hysteria and "Breaking News" mantras from the media worldwide, a gritty global response is initiated-only to be noticeably forgotten.  Boredom ensues when the film's trail of crumbs into the aliens is stopped to prolong the razor-thin, repetitive memories revealed from Louise's life role as mother and wife. 

Villeneuve's slight-of-hand filmmaking technique is both confusing to follow and too time consuming for many to care about by the last scene--wasting the movie's solid opening and top-shelf cast.  Faithful viewers are conspicuously kept in the dark until the film's anticlimactic and lackluster ending.

"Arrival" tries too hard to elicit a sci-fi equivalent to the shocking mind game from the movie classic "The Sixth Sense".  After a promising start, the movie slows to a cephalopod-writing pace and clumsily tests viewers' patience beyond what most humans should endure at a theater.  Despite having Oscar-winner Whitaker and over a half-dozen Academy Award nominations between Amy Adams and Jeremy Renner, the trio's sensational acting skills are not given roles to truly shine. 

Stay hydrated, get plenty of rest, and indulge in your favorite Starbucks drink before catching this far-out alien head-fake.  

Grade: C

Arrival is one of those personal movies for me. A thought expression, an idea that has always been on the tip of your mind but you've never quite been able to root out, brush the dust off of, and stare at clearly in the sunlight. Arrival is why the science fiction genre is important; it is why society needs such types of contemplative escapism. Science fiction allows society to observe and consider a narrative in abstract of reality. It allows for humanity to entertain and present ideas as entertainment in a non-threatening manner so as to suggest--in so doing--a reality which the world is not yet ready to acknowledge. With this movie director Denis Villeneuve has cemented himself among the ranks of the greatest to ever champion the science fiction genre. Bring a worthy adaptation of Ted Chiang short story. This movie, in my not so humble opinion, ranks clearly up there with '2001: A Space Odyssey as timeless and seminal works of the science fiction cinematic landscape; more specifically: a work dealing with a higher power and humanities context in the universe 
If you let the language of the movie sink in, if you accept the signposts that stake themselves in your mind, you may get a similar form of elation at the potential of a society which embraces both directions of time.

ARRIVAL-2016(PG-13)-Nov. 13.
By:Clem The Movie Guy.

Based on Ted Chiang's short story, Story of Your Life, Arrival stars Amy Adams as Dr. Louis Banks, a linguist expert recruited by US Army Colonel Weber (Forest Whitaker) to be part of a team that also includes mathematician Ian Donnelly (Jeremy Renner) working to establish communication with the mysterious cephalopod beings who have landed their twelve spaceships in various locations around the world. When verbal communication proves impossible, Dr. Banks discovers that a visual language is the key to understanding the alien's purpose. However, meaning in language can be mutable & there is the addition complication that each of the ships may be communicating only one aspect of aliens' intentions, requiring cooperation from the different countries hosting alien vessels. During the intense process of discovery, Dr. Banks is having some unsettling dreams that seem to be an essential element of understanding the alien communication. Directed by Denis Villeneuve from the screenplay by Eric Heisserer, Arrival is a thought provoking & beautifully compelling sci-fi drama with a stunning ending that left me wanting to see it again. Amy Adams gives an out-standing performance that is worthy of Oscar nomination. I also appreciated seeing a different type of alien represented. Arrival could end up on my list of Best Films of 2016 & for that reason it is a MUST SEE FILM.

Excellent acting, well thought out & thought provoking. A refreshing revisit to the sci-fi classics of the 70s and 60s interwoven with timeless human drama. Nay-sayers will cite some tropes but that doesn't diminish the overall impact of this satisfying genre piece. You can unpack it on multiple levels, worth a re-viewing but not in the theaters.

When twelve gigantic objects arrive from space and position themselves randomly over various points on the Earth, there is naturally a scramble to try to find out where they came from and what they want. Amy Adams plays linguist Louise Banks who is called on by the American military to try to communicate with the alien occupants of the ships. We share nothing in common with these aliens and despite the best efforts of Banks and the team she is working with, progress at understanding the creatures is painfully slow and incremental. Added to this, Dr. Banks is dealing with her own, personal tragedy and is seemingly bothered by flashbacks to various periods of her life. This is a thoughtful and thought provoking movie that is not so much about how we might cope with an alien visitation, rather it concerns itself with what it means to communicate and how we come to terms with difficult decisions which can have profound consequences. I really became engrossed in this wonderful story in which Adams is simply sublime. Her portrayal was well-observed and hugely affecting, evoking in me a real sense of sympathy. You can really sense her frustration at the task she is facing and I was really willing her to succeed. Jeremy Renner takes the role of scientist Ian Donnelly and is a quietly understated and totally appropriate supporting character and it is refreshing to have such a big movie, fronted by a pair of sympathetically played experts. There's no melodrama, no sensationalism and no dumbing-down. This feels like a real investigation of a genuine mystery which has an unusual and upbeat message. The look of the aliens is convincingly realised and their ships, simply hovering in the air, are an impressive sight. There's a wonderful and non-intrusive score that compliments the on-screen action perfectly and helps add to and maintain the atmospheric mystery that slowly unfolds. I'm not familiar with the work of director Denis Villeneuve but on the strength of this movie, I'd certainly like to catch some of his previous movies and I am quite excited to learn he is in the directors chair for the upcoming Blade Runner sequel. Definitely one to recommend.

i was worried this movie would have a vague abstract ending open to interpretation. when they started showing the play dough alien and her teaching the language i started getting so confused, wondering if it was time travel and she was affecting the past. then, in one climactic moment, the reveal. i went from not know wth was going on to understanding everything perfectly. the twist brought me to tears from how awesome it was. everything made sense at that moment. and it was a more perfect and satisfying conclusion than anything i would have come up with. and as with all great twists, they tell you the twist early in the movie, when they said something like "i thought this was the beginning, but they see time differently than us"

this movie also has a lot you can discuss afterwards. like the reason she got divorced (presumably because she told him their daughter would die and he was upset that she didn't tell him beforehand because he wouldn't have gone through with it). and the concept that the language is circular, and it doesn't matter if you read it forwards or backwards. that parallels her ability to now see time differently, not linearly. it also relates to the daughter's name being a palindrome. hannahannahannah. 

She got married and had a baby knowing she would get divorced and lose the baby. I think that's the difference with seeing time all at once instead of linearly. The way we see time we would be sad at every moment after she died. The way the aliens look at time they see all of time at once so they always see that she died, but at the same time they always see every moment while she was alive and loved each other. That's kind of like when people say I wouldn't have changed anything because I cherish the time we had together. Some people can handle it well, other people would rather not even deal with it if they could avoid the pain that comes after. But I think if we could remember everything equally instead of just remembering mostly the last thing that happened , it would change our mind (2 viewings)

"Arrival" is apparently based on the idea of aliens arriving on Earth. In fact, it is not. No spoilers, but it is clearly about the arrival of humanity at a certain level of existence, via language. The focus on language and linguistics is interesting to me because I teach English. But what is really interesting that someone has made a movie about language that is interesting, intellectual, paradoxical, and quiet -- and yet engaged audiences who like their science-fiction to be like Star Trek, Star Wars, Matrix, Avatar, etc. There is no action in this movie, as there is in the usual science-fiction movies. "Arrival" is full of silences and stillnesses. Nobody stands out. Yet every character is essential. The movie uses the idea of existential alienation (no pun intended) very well. It forces the audience to make  sense of things by forcing the audience to assume that the things make sense when, in fact, they never do. It's a beautiful movie. Watch it.

One of the most unique and original science fiction films I have seen in a long time.

Quoting T.S. Elliot, "This is how the world ends, not with a bang, but a whimper". 

"Arrival" is just this, but on a much deeper, more explained level. It deals not with weapons or defense of mankind in the classic manner, but with words and communication. 

Usually, when you hear science fiction or UFO you immediately think of what? Aliens, robots, mass destruction, technology, and the future, etcetera.  However, this film (while, yes a science fiction film) approaches the genre from a very new, a very original perspective.

The film follows Linguistics professor, Louise Banks as she catches brief impressions of what she initially understands as dreams, but turn out to be glimpses of the future, particularly her future. 

Almost immediately in the film, the plot is introduced. A foreign object appears across the globe in twelve different locations. The first contact with the UFO brings outstanding insight to mankind and hints at what they are really dealing with. The United States Government then proceeds by approaching Louise Banks, pulling her further into the bigger picture.

"Arrival" isn't just another sci-fi film, it's a dramatic revelation about humans and who we really are. There are no big explosions, life-changing disasters, or robots. This film approaches the science fiction genre on an entirely intellectual, psychological, and theoretical basis. Yes, the film is about alien life, but it is more so about communication and human life. The questions this film brings to the table are bold, upfront, personal, and somewhat mind boggling. It presents language barriers as a primary conflict between two foreign nations, much like humans and their incapacity to communicate clearly and directly with one another.

I believe this is what I love most about "Arrival". Its approach is incredibly scientific and factual. 

If you are familiar with any of Denis Villeneuve's films (i.e. "Enemy", "Prisoners", "Sicario") they always leave you wondering. "Arrival" does leave you with questions, but they aren't so open as they are with a film such as "Enemy". This isn't an experimental science fiction film. The ending although left fairly open still leaves you with a sense of closure. Enough to make sense while still retaining the enigma of what the audience has just seen. It's very subtle.

In the beginning, Louise is reluctant to use the words alien or UFO and I can appreciate this because it doesn't make the film seem like a science fiction film. Of course, it is, but you (or at least I, myself) don't feel that way. You feel that it's something much more, it deserves more than just a sci-fi sticker planted on the cover of the DVD. 

It's been a while since a film has pulled me in allowing myself to immerse my mind in such a way as "Arrival" does. It's thrilling, intellectual, inspiring, and daring. The dream-like sequences revealing flashes of the future are done so perfectly and naturally. 

You can't really compare this film to another. As I said above, it's so original and creative. The writing is phenomenal. The casting is perfect. At first, I thought Jessica Chastain might fit the role of Louise better, but Amy Adams struck it out of the ballpark alongside Jeremy Renner and Forest Whitaker.

This is absolutely worth checking out. Five stars without question.

'Arrival' is a different, semi-realistic take on the alien invasion film. It spends a little time introducing us to Louise (Adams), a translator, and then we get to see the UFO that's landed (technically hovering) in Montana. It's one of 12 - she's tasked with opening communications with the aliens. Some great shots of the ships (more like giant smooth rocks) and a good job of showing the different climate/atmosphere in and around them.

It's definitely not your typical alien film - there's a lot of tension and build-up, and no big battles or gory moments. Ian (Renner), a theoretical physicist and Colonel Weber (Whitaker) are there to help Louise, but it's pretty much up to her to determine how to communicate with the aliens (or giant squids). The music can be a bit overbearing at times, and the flashbacks seem to interrupt at times, but it all comes together at the end.

Didn't blow my mind, but it does delve a little deeper into how the world would realistically handle a potential threat of this magnitude. Would have loved to have seen more of the different perspectives from each site/country. An interesting enough reveal, if not totally unique (I've definitely read it in a novel or two before) and a nice message at its core.

In this case, I nominate the director for an Oscar! I He probably realizes that he has made the best movie of his lifetime! Acting..Amy Adams should win the Oscar and there is no question about it. A must must must and very highly recommended movie!!!!

To its credit, Arrival eventually answers all of its questions. The problem is that when the enigma is slowly disconnected, then so is the film.  Subplots become red herrings.  The narrative isn't ultimately preoccupied with the alien threat. It's fascinated by how language molds who we are. The idea is that people approach the world differently because of vocabulary. Reality varies according to the linguistic tools employed. Terminology frames our understanding. Dr. Banks is changed by the experience. That's the gist of the account, but I've purposefully omitted the closing truth. Your enjoyment of Arrival will derive out of how fascinating you think the final reveal is. Perhaps it will positively blow your mind. It has a philosophical gist. In keeping with the production's chilly tone, I found the ending too dispassionate. The denouement is rather underwhelming after such a promising introduction. Denis Villeneuve has erroneously created a drama left unfulfilled.

Arrival: This untraditional sci-fi film stars Amy Adams as a renowned linguist helping the government learn why mysterious alien spacecraft have suddenly appeared across the planet, sparking a global crisis. Those expecting a traditional alien invasion sci-fi flick will be DEEPLY disappointed. This is a mindful head trip, exploring thought-provoking themes in the space-time continuum. Like the alien language puzzle that Adams' character pieces together, at times it is tedious, but those who stick with the film will be rewarded with a deeper message that will become apparent at its conclusion. Adams is excellent. B+

Arrival is being called one of the best Science Fiction films in years. It is one of the best rated and reviewed films of 2016, and is drawing comparisons to Close Encounters of The Third Kind, but I have a question, did they watch the same film that I did? I wasn't crazy about Close Encounters, but that movie was leaps and bounds ahead of this one. Twelve alien crafts land in random places all across the planet, and the people are in a panic. Some countries react with hostility, but the U.S. Government decides to act cautiously (yeah right), and send Dr. Louise Banks (Amy Adams), the best linguist they have, to figure out a way to community with the aliens. The aliens, turn out to be giant octopus, whose language turns out to be ink that they squirt into the air. This movie features flashbacks and flash-forwards, that seemingly make no sense, until the end when you finally figure out what they mean and once you do, you realize that you just wasted two hours of your life. If that wasn't bad enough, the film moves at an absolute snails pace, I mean you could take everything that actually happened in the film and squeeze it into about twenty minutes. The rest is just people talking to each other about the same damn thing over and over again. Trying to figure out the same thing over and over again. Worrying about the same things over and over again. The characters have no personality whatsoever, and you might think that it's one of those slow moving weird films that all comes together in an amazing ending, but no, it doesn't. Once you can see the whole picture, as one lady in the theater so eloquently shouted out, "really, that's it, that was so stupid." Her uncontrolled outburst really sums up this entire film. Honestly I think the slower and more artistic a film is, the more the critics love it, but I am one critic who isn't fooled by great actors and emotional music, this isn't the best film of the year, this is the biggest turd of the year, and it should be avoided at all costs!

This movie is almost perfect.  Almost.  It comes so close, but there's a couple little nuances that keep it from reaching that point.  As it stands though, it's still one of the most original, intriguing, and gorgeous sci-fi movies I've ever seen.  The central premise is damn intriguing and wildly original.  I can't help but feel that any sci-fi movie with aliens must have started from a point like this, they just usually skip over that stuff because it's probably seen as boring, but when you really get into it it's fascinating.  The basic idea is trying to communicate with creatures who have a different vocal range, different alphabet, just all around entirely different way of communicating than we do.  That's damn intriguing.  Take away the alien aspect and you could compare this to what must have been early man's experience with people of other cultures.  And that's really the majority of the movie, just trying to communicate, but it strangely works.  Sure there's some twists here and there, the military being uncertain, terrorists wanting to blow crap up, but these are minor roadblocks that don't distract from the films primary point.  It's also just a gorgeous movie, with some of the most breathtaking cinematography I've seen in a while.  Without getting into spoilers too much, I gotta' also mention how I love the ending, and the sort of twist on the nature of the alien communication.  It creates some really interesting commentary on fate and knowing your own future that really intrigued me.
The problem I have with this movie, and it is a big one, is with Jeremy Renner's character.  He's really just kind of pointless, and he is unfortunately given an important place in the movie.  Again, without getting into spoilers, his chemistry with Amy Adams is a key component to the movie and it's twist, and I barely ever bought them having the chemistry of co-workers, let-alone anything deeper than that.  It left a bit of a sour taste in what was otherwise a movie that did everything right.  I can't deny the problems with Renner's character and the actors chemistry, it knocks the movie down a bit and keeps it from perfection.  Everything else about the movie is really really good though, sometimes amazing even.  If you're looking for an original take on the sci-fi genre, it's well worth a look.
Tons of potential, but in the end, a purposely convoluted and forgettable film.

If we're lucky, a handful of titles per year offer movie lovers a chance to get to witness something that's original, thought-provoking and full of heart.

They're rare movie treats in today's climate and events that should be savored.

Arrival is one of these such movie treats; an intellectually intelligent Sci-fi that's highly likely to be regarded as a genre classic in the years soon to come.

Directed by Dennis Villeneuve (who has quickly become one of the industry's greatest current filmmakers), who here worked with screenwriter Eric Heisserer in adapting Ted Chiang's short story for the big screen, has created a Sci-fi event free of what you'd call large scale alien infused spectacle but instead filled a film with a quietly powerful narrative and ultimately stunningly moving centre that drives this unique vision to grand and near close to perfect Sci-fi heights.

Centered around the intriguing prospect of Amy Adams language expert Dr. Louise Banks, whose battling to figure out a way to communicate with an alien race that has decided to pay earth a potentially deadly visit, Arrival's narrative is best left relatively unspoken about as its complexities will be enjoyed that much more by those that know only minimal details about where Villeneuve and his talented cast are taking us.

Anchored by what could well very be an Oscar nominated turn, Arrival rides off the back of Amy Adams central turn and while the increasingly impressive actress is ably supported by Jeremy Renner and Forest Whitaker, Arrival really is her film.

Giving us a character who consistently surprises, just like the film itself, Dr. Banks is a likeable and believable creation whose dealings with the newly discovered race will encapsulate you with nothing more than whiteboard, a finch and some stoic determination.

It's mesmerizing in an hypnotic like fashion in the way in which we are taken along for the journey of these other worldly language-filled encounters and it's  an added joy that we're never fully sure of the alien's intentions until very late in the piece or fully understand where Villeneuve's plan for this poignant tale has been taking us until it dawns on us like the aliens mission late in the picture.

Ever so slightly held back by a rather forgettable collection of supporting characters, Arrival is comprised of an on form cast, vividly captured images from D.O.P Bradford Young and a haunting Jóhann Jóhannsson score all that back Villeneuve's overall vision to great results.

This alien invasion film with brilliantly constructed differences is a cinematic joy and this top class 2016 experience is but a further reason as to why we should now be signaling out Villeneuve as a potentially all-time great filmmaker, and why we should be excited for his next Blade Runner film that should very well be, quite the big screen marvel.

You will hear and see many positive reviews about arrival - this is not one of them. I would suggest that before anyone rush to see a film, they read at least 1 positive, and 1 negative review. It is my intention to make sure you want to see the movie ... that you think you want to see. So please bare with me as I explain why this highly rated movie, is barely a movie at all. 

Arrival fits into a breed of movie whereby, one is far better off simply asking a friend about what happens, rather than going to see it themselves. What happens in the movie has virtually no visual component. I suspect that Arrival was a fantastic book. The premise is interesting, a new perspective on a famillar story -- and the twist is really quite clever. This movie does make you think -- it makes you think -- "Seriously? They made an entire movie where nothing whatsoever happens just for that one twist...? Well Okay" 

I suspect that most people who enjoyed this movie, enjoyed that twist. Indeed, its clever. But its just as clever to ask someone about. Save yourself 116 minutes of absolutely nothing happening, and ask someone. 

Of every movie I've ever seen in my life - Arrival might be the slowest, and most boring. There are countless pointless scenes where we watch Amy Adams sleep, watch her sit in front of a computer, watch her type random things, watch her stare at pictures, watch her think. You don't see any aliens. In fact, Arrival could have been shot and filmed in 1950, and saved in a time capsule, because visually, we see absolutely nothing the entire film. We see fields in Montana, a black egg, and some beautiful ink-art. 

One might say that the movie is rich with character development. I would argue that it has no character develpment at all. There are NUMEROUS flashback sequences of Dr. Louise Bank's daughter spending time together. In each of these scenes, they are essentially a montage, and by the end, Louise remembers something she didn't before. Thats the only purpose they serve. About 20 minutes of wasted screen time to have her think of things she could have just normally thought of without reminiscing about her daughter. I can't say anymore without spoiling the twist. 

Anyway. Think very carefully if you really want to sit through 116 minutes of daughter flashbacks, watching people think and sleep, and fields in montana before you go and see this movie just for the clever twist -- which frankly, is "Clever" but not "OMG THATS THE CLEVEREST THING IVE EVER SEEN".
I liked it well enough. The plot twist was interesting, but there wasn't enough suspense.

Beautiful, but with a terrible ending.  
This movie was beautifully shot, with careful attention to ensure the audience was more focused on Amy Adams's character than the fantastic events going on around her.  It's a much more personal story and this is made clear from the beginning.  The cinematography is great, each shot adds to the mood and frames the emotions of the scene.  
But in the end, the movie falls flat on its face. We're starting to get into spoiler territory, but I'll avoid the big stuff until a little later.  Mainly, it ends in one of the worst Deus Ex Machina that I've seen in a while, and the solution is effectively magic masquerading as science. And the tiny nugget of scientific theory that they base it on is largely no longer accepted as a linguistic theory, according to the linguist I saw the movie with. I don't have a problem with magic in movies, but you have to be made aware of it early on and be told about it as part of the price of admission.  But I was sold a ticket to a movie about science, not magic.  
Now that we've waded through the shallows of the spoiler sea, let's dive in.
*SPOILERS*
Fairly early on I was reminded strongly of the Tralfamadorians from Kurt Vonnegut's Slaughter House 5.  Their language has no linear structure, making their sentences designed to be read as a whole, a characteristic of the literature of Vonnegut's species as well.  But Vonnegut tells you what he's doing in the second chapter of Slaughterhouse 5, not the last 20 minutes or so of the movie. Once I made this connection I could see a lot of how the rest of the movie was going to go and I wasn't really looking forward to it.
She too comes unstuck from time, by learning the alien language.  But in this version, it's a superpower allowing her to see specific points in the future at exactly the right time in the narrative, building to an ending sequence that is downright silly and not quite done as well as it was at the end of Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure.  (I agree it's not exactly the same, but pretty close.)  
On a much more minor note, there was a sort of clunky explanation sequence where SOMEONE explains to SOMEONE ELSE (never fully explained who or why they were talking) that they've actually learned almost the whole language, rather than making that actually part of the narrative.  But glossing over some story that seemed like the point of the whole thing is nothing compared to the fact that learning a language gives the main character a magical superpower that allows her to make world peace.

Arrival could not have arrived at a better time to give the message it gives. It is a beautifully shot movie that provides a fresh new take on a stagnant genre of alien movies. The cinematography is breathtaking yet minimalistic. The camera work is slow and let's us the audience absorb as much as we can in every frame. Director Denis Villeneuve after giving us Sicario last year, gives us yet another back burner thriller that keeps us hooked and mesmerized throughout. Jeremy Renner and Forest Whitaker are good in their roles and deliver what is expected from them, but this movie belongs to Amy Adams. She is outstanding here and delivers one of her finest performances. The best thing about this movie is that it is not the over the top alien drama that almost all movies in this genre are. It takes a more human approach to the subject and delivers a beautiful movie that is worth your time and money.

The out of focus shots also creates an uneasy feeling and keeps the audience's interest/focus on the a specific character.  The movie isn't action-packed but constantly leads the audience on a journey of intrigue.  This is a thought-provoking movie about humanity and communication.  I didn't give it 5 stars because antagonist military and CIA characters weren't very believable, but they were good enough to keep the drama.

More like close encounters of the insipid kind....this movie was a bore fest, and once you see the aliens (which I have to admit are kind of cool - even though they just look like giant squids and never do anything exciting really) there isn't much left to see here. If you want to know what Arrival is without having to be bored to death by seeing it, it's basically the same "let's stop fighting and start communicating and all just get along" type of movie we've all seen 1,000 times from Hollywood. I give it 2 & 1/2 stars just because the story is somewhat interesting and touching, if not filled with the same type of "in-your-face obvious" Hollywood messages as so many others, and the special effects are fantastic as well. Other than that, unless you're an extremely intellectual person who doesn't need anything exciting to happen to be entertained by a film, you might actually like it. Interstellar is a great example of a film that could make you think and be extremely entertained all at the same time, while also presenting a deep, emotional story. Arrival? Not so much.

Arrival is a triumph of Scifi and Weird Lovecraftian fiction. A culmination of original ideas, classic tropes and an optimistic message, it succeeds where so many Hollywood movies have failed as of late. The story is well-written and brilliantly displayed on the screen to both dislocate the viewer, placing them in the strangeness of the character's situation, as well as pack an emotional punch that will have you choking back tears in the films climax.

For those of you who have not seen it yet, it may still be playing at the 2.00, matinee movie house. For those who want to see it, but is no longer available in the theater get the DVD, which I believe is being released on February 28, 2017. I already ordered mine, because I wanted to go back and see it again at the theaters, but missed my opportunity to see it a second time. There are so many things going on in this movie, that it will take me 2-3 more times of watching it to figure all of it all. Masterful acting, superior story-telling and thoroughly engaging from the opening scenes. This movie will make you weep and then warm your soul from deep inside.

A movie you will be thinking about long after the ending.

Top notch thinking Sci-Fi movie. Amy Adams is brilliant as a linguist who is put in charge of attempting communication with the aliens who have arrived on Earth. It might sound B-Grade, but its not. It's a very thoughtful and thought provoking story about how humans would deal with the arrival of an alien species, and the script is really clever in its approach to language and communication and the subtleties that can trip us up. The film also veers off into completely unexpected territory, as the best sci-fi movies tend to do, holding up a mirror towards humanity, rather than focusing on alien beings.

Here's my half-assed review in case I don't circle back: Solid 4 out of 5 stars. I recommend this film without reservation. The fact that I'm still chewing it over two days later and looking for interviews with cast and crew on the interwebs is telling. It's not without flaws, but overall Arrival is a refreshing film, especially for the sci-fi genre which lately has been mostly synonymous with action or horror. This is the rare sci-fi movie that is both emotional and thought-provoking. It's reminiscent of Contact (1997) but more graceful; less didactic.

I was hoping for something that recalled the "Darmok" Star Trek episode. What I thought was so great about that episode was that the audience actually learned a small piece of the alien language/way of thought along with Captain Picard. I really wished for some of that from Arrival. A few tired tropes and 2 throw away lines about Sapir Wharf isn't enough to make the movie "cerebral" to me (what, has the intelligence of people dropped that much in the last few years?). Yes, the story is basically a realization of Sapir Wharf, but only in the most minimal and shallow way. Also, can we just get over 2001 as a template for a "good" science fiction movie. A movie does not need to be full of portentous silences and rely on vague, vapid implications of "serious" questions (i.e. the writers are too stupid to think of anything to actually say) to be a "good" movie. In the end, I suppose that the problem with turning a short story into a movie is that we have to rely on the writers and other hollywood apparatus to create a more complete story, and that is just too much to expect from them.

arrival is a very good film.

the designs of most of the sci-fi elements were excellent. casting, cinematography, score - all good. here's the problem: it doesn't always play by the rules.

similar to memento, arrival presents itself in a non-linear fashion, working towards a few moments that together add up to a big revelation (the similarities to memento end there). however - whereas memento clearly establishes its timelines early on and sticks to its format, arrival does the following:

- skips important scenes to hide information from the viewer
- intentionally misleads you from the very opening

don't get me wrong, as a whole, it's a great film. it never shoves anything in your face, and does an excellent job of pacing itself early on. that being said, I feel that its reveal isn't fully earned. skipping over crucial scenes and revisiting them later on feels like the audience is being cheated.

it's a great, well told story - for me, there were just a few noticeable lapses in logic. would still wholeheartedly recommend to any fan of sci-fi (or amy adams, she's excellent)

(4.5 stars) ARRIVAL is an example of the increasingly rare story that is necessarily a cinematic experience. What I am trying to say is that meaning is communicated in a variety of ways and, even though humans primarily rely on  pictorial forms for understanding, there are arraying degrees of iconicity in pictures. Some pictures, such as words, have low iconicity, while others, such as abstract forms playing through light, are highly iconic. The higher the iconicity of a picture, the more room there is for the audience to fill the picture with their own experiences and mold the possible meaning of the image. Movies, being uniquely a medium of spectacle, maximize their special potential as a medium by communicating through both words and "visuals." Films which require that the audience attend to its "visual language" are particularly, instead of haphazardly, cinematic. 
In the case of Denis Villenueve's ARRIVAL, the movie uses multiple modes of language (verbal and highly-iconic "visual") to communicate about the value of language. Such meta-communicative work was impressive, to say the least. In fact, I will say little more on the subject out of fear that my attempts to describe the experience of the picture will be utter failures. Perhaps more pertinent to those who have yet to see the movie: the plot of ARRIVAL revolves around a cryptographer, Dr. Louise Banks (Amy Adams), who is approached by the U.S. government to help establish communication with an alien species after twelve unidentified vessels spontaneously appear around the globe. Dr. Banks is permitted to the meet the alien species, who attempt to communicate from behind a glass-like barrier from within their transportation vessels. World powers debate how to handle the presence of the strange vessels and fear escalates for increasingly violent civilians. Dr. Banks must race to learn the purpose of the alien visitors before a nervous world leader decides to attack the vessels. 
ARRIVAL, though tackling big issues and using a plot that unfolds on a global scale, is immensely intimate. The story is really and truly about Dr. Banks and how her personal pains become bound up in her ability to [not] communicate with a foreign Other. Adams is reliably subtle and nuanced in her performance, often conveying Banks' distraction and difficulty in the midst of seemingly unrelated circumstances. That is, Adams layers Banks on an emotional level with simple choices in micro-expressions and eye-movement. Her performance is, in my opinion, clearly worthy of consideration in the coming awards season. The rest of the ensemble is effective in their own way, but the movie is clearly dependent on Adams' ability to handle Banks' quiet, but affecting personae. 
Beyond having an excellent lead character and leading performer, ARRIVAL succeeds by being a wonderfully complex, but accessible piece of writing. Writer Eric Heisserer's masterful uses of meta- and hypo- narration to control the way information and exposition was filtered to the audience worked much in the favor of the film - especially in that the unique writing approach also provided Villenueve and cinematographer, Bradford Young, opportunities to layer additional visual communication to tell the story in ways that words would not have been sufficient for. Young should unquestionably be a strong awards contender for both his frequent use of direction and framing to create visual metaphors AND his wise decisions in blending CGI set pieces with natural shots, which created an aesthetically acceptable synthesis of the "false" and the "real" images. 
The content and arguments of ARRIVAL are perhaps the best testimony to the picture's importance and cinematic strength. Namely, the movie is "about" the ways that communication impact our life stories. The movie's central conflict is whether hope and courage regarding the intentions of a misunderstood, foreign Other would win out again fear and cynicism regarding said Other. Communication was both a barrier to be crossed (Banks did not know how to understand the aliens) and a tool to be productively utilized (by working with the aliens, progress toward understanding could be made). From scholarship in the communication studies discipline, we know that uncertainty is one of the primary reasons to communicate - we can ease our fear of the unknown by gathering information. However, we can never be one-and-the-same as another person, meaning that the Other will always have some element of uncertainty associated with them. ARRIVAL compellingly makes the case that it is better to be optimistic and gracious in our communication with others - even in the case of high uncertainty - than to let fear and paranoia cause us violently lash out against them.

One of the best, most thought provoking movies I've ever seen. Really well done. Cannot wait to see it again and pick up on all the little details. Right off the bat, Denis Villeneuve is one of those rare auteurs - like Ridley Scott, Steven Spielberg, Quentin Tarantino, and David Fincher - whose named attached to a project should get film lovers excited. His last three films - Prisoners, Enemy, and Sicario - are critically acclaimed and visually stunning works of art.

And needless to say, Arrival can be added to that list. It also should be added to the list of potential Oscar bait. Amy Adams gives her best performance as an expert linguist tasked with discovering the intention of the aliens who mysteriously arrived on Earth. But this isn't an action film or even as much an alien thriller. It's really a character study about this woman and her connection to these aliens and her own life. 

My only negatives are about loose ends that I wish were tied up, and a few brief moments of heavy-handedness about minor character intentions. But this is a gorgeous film in the vein of Contact that is truly mesmerizing and touching.
Well made movie but was confusing and a bit slow in some areas.  After the movie I had to read the spoiler to better understand.  And even still some parts don't add up.

With the concept of Contact and the philosophical grandeur of 2001: A Space Odyssey, this aims and succeeds in being a true science fiction movie for me. Go in with an open and focused mind.

Clever film. Well executed. Unexpected twist. The movie is less about the arrival of the aliens and more about what humanity attains from said arrival. It dwells upon the anxiety and apprehensiveness faced by mankind when intimidated by unknown life forms and how this fear of the unknown can tear us apart rather than bring us together. The twist is great -- simple, yet effective. The movie is entertaining and a pleasant surprise despite the boring, off-putting poster. It's a very well-put-together drama with a sci-fi edge.

9/10 - elegant and thoughtful, one of the year's best.

It's a bit like loving a depressive personality. Arrival starts with some mournful music, and takes us through the all too brief life of a linguist's daughter.  That language expert is played by Amy Adams, who does a wonderful job as the focus of this movie. This story is about people trying to solve a puzzle, so it is bereft of shoot outs and chase scenes. It is very difficult to talk about the narrative without getting into spoilers.
 
There are plenty of technical aspects to speak of. There are some first rate creature designs, language designs, and sound design. I thought however that the photography under DP Bradford Young had a few chinks in its armor.  It was not brightly lit in interiors or sun drenched in exteriors. The most common exterior motif seems to be a cloudy daylight backgrounds with unlit people in the foreground. So people were basically in silhouettes.  Much of the films is color graded to the blue end, so it feels cold.  Combined with the very deliberate pacing, the movie feels sad. It is smart? Kind of. Is it interesting? Definitely. Is it loveable? Oh,.. so close.

Arrival is another film that continues a legacy of thought-provoking science fiction entertainment Hollywood has managed to release in the last few years. Arrival's story, to me, felt like it was building upon Interstellar (the dramatic effects of time dilation), Gravity (fear and hopelessness without gravity), and the Martian (a respect for botany). And now we have Arrival, a film that explores the power of language. Yeah, of all things... language. Remember that moment in Batman v Superman where the name "Martha" unites opposing forces? It was that dramatic shift in reality, in one's perspective, over a word -- a name, that opened up a new way of thinking. Arrival manages to do the same thing throughout its entire narrative. The main character is a linguist who tries to communicate with aliens and the movie explores how an intelligent being communicates with others based on its biology, culture, and perception of time and space. It's an alien invasion movie that touches upon the human necessity to understand and work with other cultures - both human and alien. Arrival's story is a great escape from our troubled times... and there's a hefty dose of symbolism for those who are into digging deeper into its visual design. Hint... female reproductive organs...

An incredible and majestic experience that is as abstract as it is emotional. Movies don't get more original, unpredictable, or ambitious than this. Denis Villeneuve orchestrates all the visual and sonic elements of cinema to captivate and transport audiences in a way few directors can. Arrival is likely to go down as my favorite movie of the year and as one of the best sci-fi movies ever.

The wonder and awe of extraterrestrial life is extremely fascinating on screen when done right. Spielberg has certainly achieved it with Close Encounters of the Third Kind, and Denis Villeneuve is right on par with this film. It isn't one big crescendo like that film is, instead revealing the aliens towards the beginning, and building concept and story after. Arrival starts off as an awe inspiring experience and only goes up from there. The director's last film Sicario kept topping itself off, scene after scene, even when you think the last one can't be beat, and Arrival does the same, but on an even larger scale. 

One scene involves the characters entering the ship, where they travel up a lift and into a vertical cave with a white wall at the end that the aliens are behind. This scene is way longer than it could be, but it's done with such intensity and suspense to really make you feel like you're traveling with the characters into unknown territory, and it's beautiful. 

The atmosphere is so powerful from scene to scene, from the fog stretching over the mountains in the Montana location to the interior of the spacecraft. Johann Johannson's score is other-worldly, unsettling, creative, and majestic, adds a lot to the atmosphere without ever feeling intrusive. It often resembles the low moans of the aliens and the dark abyss of space. 

Amy Adams's character carries a lot of the emotional weight of the film without going for tears or obvious emotion. For how abstract and philosophical the film can get, it miraculously keeps itself grounded in reality and in humanity in a way most audiences should be able to connect to. It achieves exactly what Interstellar wished it did, and captures the same epic-ness of that film while mostly taking place within a square mile. There is political subtext about fear of foreign life that could easily be applied to the immigration and refugee conversations we're having today, about language and perspective, but even greater is the multidimensional lesson about our human condition. I would elaborate, but I certainly don't want to spoil anything.

This film unfolds in such a surprising way, it's among the most unpredictable and surprising movies I've seen, and the trailers certainly show very little. It reaches out so far and comes back with so much, managing to ground what it grabs in humanity. It's also surprising on a surface level, with twists that may shock you, but not in a way that draws attention to itself being a twist. The story takes you on a roller coaster and gives you absolutely everything you could ask for within its runtime, which is a concise two hours. 

Arrival has been getting a good share of critical praise, but I still feel like it's underwhelming compared to the experience I had. In every way, Arrival is the best of what cinema has to offer, and it's difficult to think of a film so simultaneously ambitious, thrilling, and emotional since Gravity. It gives you cinematic cake to eat up while you're watching, and afterwards gives you a lot to think about and discuss. One of the best of this decade so far.
A wonderfully engrossing mind teaser that pulls together the  poignant beauty of life, love and loss.
Very slow movie, don't understand the hype
Best film of the year

Do not expect an "Independence Day" this one is a thinking man's movie!  Really a great movie.  One you will be having great discussions about!

This is truly a cerebral film for sci-fi genre lovers but also brings home an emotional parallel for everyone and that's--enjoy the time you have while you have it.  

What makes this so interesting is that it's not like anything I've ever seen before. It's original in a way that makes the viewing experience unique. This is a huge acting task to take on and Amy Adams did it better than I could have imagined, displaying all the necessary emotions through her present and future scenes.

Her character lacked the engagement and emotions that would seem to be a natural part of her experience as the character in the film.  The shift needed could have been ever so slight, if it was the right shift, to make the performance phenomenal.

"Arrival" isn't a typical action-packed science fiction movie with heroes and villains.  Instead, language, time and emotion are woven together to create one of the finest science fiction films ever made.
