Incredible Movie! One of the best I've seen in years! Had a Christopher Nolan feel and it's a great take on what real steps we could take if aliens showed up one day. Quite easily my favorite movie of the year. Intellectual and thought-provoking sci-fi at it's highest level with gorgeous cinematography and beautiful minimalistic score by Jóhann Jóhannsson to boot. A must see by everyone

"Arrival" is one of the strongest and most thought provoking films of 2016 and that's a lot coming from one of the strongest years for film in some time. Taking everything that made "Close Encounters" and "Sign" classics and crossing over with the thinking mans aspect of films like "Inception" and "Memento", "Arrival" mixes strong acting talents with emotion and state of the art effects. Surely to divide some audiences with its intelligent and symbolic take on death and time; but those looking for a sophisticated film that warrents your full attention, "Arrival" is guaranteed to receive nominations at the Oscars.
This film gets better with every viewing. Haunting visuals, music, direction and performances...THIS is sci-fi done right.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

Fresh off 2015's "Sicario" Director Denis Villeneuve has created an even more well rounded movie, this time taking on the Sci-fi genre. It's breathtaking visually, and I genuinely felt smarter post-viewing. Amy Adams is sympathetic, yet strong. A combination in acting that is often difficult to pull off, and at this point there isn't much she can't do. The science will be difficult to understand for some, but they do a good enough job of explaining things for most people to grasp what they mean. It's tense, and surprisingly relevant in this day and age.
I would watch this movie again. Great storyline. Smart and believable. Messes with your brain a little! Great sound and visual effects. Draws you in emotionally.

"Contact" for dummies
Heavy-handed movie about dumb people and dumb aliens. Characters so dumb you want to strangle them, aliens so dumb they couldn't learn english, but can some tell something is a bomb from the digital clock counting down to zero. These "intelligent" beings from a far away planet are so far above us on the evolutionary scale, but they can't understand English or 11 other Earth languages. I would assume that the aliens knew they were going to visit Earth before they've got here, but did absolutely no prep for the encounter before they arrived. The whole plot of the movie us learning their language but the aliens insisted that we learn their language first. Wouldn't be easier if the "smartest" beings in the room, i.e. the aliens, the teachers, learned our simple language first so they can teach us their super complicated, trans-dimensional language later? One would think.

Cerebral but powerfully emotional, Arrival is affecting and intriguing utilizing a raw and masterful performance from Amy Adams to guide this Sci-Fi film. So often alien invasion movies rely on violence and worlds at stake plots to display what would happen if aliens touched down on Earth, but what is so lovely about Arrival is its sense of intimacy and the power of communication. On a technical level, the visuals in this film are fantastic laying a coat of grimness over the proceedings and Johan Johansson's score is moody and ethereal creating an atmosphere of intrigue. Arrival is thinking person Sci-Fi. Instead of frenzied action, Arrival delivers thought-provoking themes on humanity while delivering an emotional experience that feels relevant to our current political climate. Unity and understanding are necessary for a safe future and Arrival, when it hits its rather unbelievable ending, you'll be crying too hard to care. Rating: 92

With a unique approach to a fairly generic concept, "Arrival" is a pleasant surprise. 

When aliens land down on Earth, the question becomes, "Why are they here?". Led by Louise Banks, her team works to decipher the meaning of their appearance and how it'll ultimately affect the human race. 

Going into this movie, I wasn't that excited for it. I mean, I knew it would probably be good, but this concept has been used a billion times before. I knew there had to be something more and based on the trailers, it looked like it had something in store. However, I did not expect the huge twist in this film and I applaud it for the brilliant screenwriting. 

Amy Adams did a great job as the lead for this film. She brought a lot to her role and I'd love to see more of Amy Adams in the future. Jeremy Renner and Forest Whitaker were great supporting characters and everyone did a solid job in this movie. I don't think that anyone will blow you away by any means, but everyone holds up well and they all put up good performances. 

The visuals in this movie were solid for the most part. I loved the the CGI and everything looked great, I just wasn't the biggest fan of the concept/character designs. However, that doesn't take away from the fact that everything looked great in this movie. The camerawork was spot on and the use of certain angles helped add a complex tone to this movie that other sci-fi films fail to capture. 

The main thing about this movie is the screenplay and the story itself. The director, Denis Villeneuve, has a wealth of great movies under his belt. His most confusing movie, "Enemy', is certainly emulated in this movie. You can see the style and tone he directs with, and he's very intelligent. The story, without saying too much, was well written. It makes you think a lot and it adds an incredible aspect to it that I wasn't expecting. 

This movie is definitely more of a slow burn drama, and I don't think it'll be accessible for everyone. On a personal level, I recognize the ingenuity and rarity in this movie, but I personally didn't love it. There are still some confusing aspects about it and I'll be looking forward to the day where I can watch this movie again. The message is beautiful and it really makes you think, but I think I need another watch-through. 

In the end, "Arrival" is a great film. Some people will absolutely love this movie, but I also think it's one that everyone can respect.
Crazy good!!  Blew my mind!

Pretty boring. The beginning was interesting but for aliens arriving on Earth for the first time, I was expecting a lot more. The last 20 minutes or so was a big let down. The movie just fizzled out. Should have been a straight to DVD movie.

[7 outta 10] ~ Don't expect alien invasion action with 'Arrival' cuz you won't get any at all, it's not that kinda flick. It's a slow and cerebral movie, totally opposite of the brainless fun action of something like 'Independence Day' and way more realistic.

'Arrival' is also completely different from recent space flicks like 'Gravity' or 'The Martian' or 'Interstellar' and isn't as good as those three IMO. Don't get me wrong, 'Arrival' is a good movie, it's just not as entertaining as those.

'Arrival' is basically a sci-fi telling of first contact, a story we've seen many times over but much more mysterious than what you'd expect, the movie's intrigue and complexity kept my interest.

The directing was subtle and visually awesome; the music was a bit loud and made some dialogue hard to hear; I got a bit of a 'Contact' vibe at some points; no ships landed in Canada, bleh; her epiphany and the movie's ending were kinda abrupt and less than satisfying; it was fairly drab and grey, and also dark; cephalopods and black ink; China now the go-to bad guys in movies.

I guess my expectations were too high for 'Arrival' as I was hoping for 'Gravity' or 'Interstellar' or 'The Martian' awesomeness. But despite it's ho-hum story, it's good. I have a feeling it'll still be better than the next space flick: 'Passengers' with Chris Pratt and J-Law.

Arrival is a Science fiction film that I have been looking forward to for a very long time and after seeing it i can tell you that Denis Villeneuve once again does not disappoint. First of all,  I was a bit skeptical from all the advertising, 100% on rotten tomatoes, best reviewed movie of the year and the like. Of course, I kept thinking of the last two times I was sucked in by all the hype and absolutely hated the films. But I guess I am somewhat of a glutton for punishment  (at least when it comes to movies) and decided, what the hell, let's see what we've got here and it was absolutely... Brilliant! 
I love most movies for their entertainment value. Every once in a while one comes along that I love because it makes me think, Arrival is one such movie. It takes the very familiar sci-fi premise of alien arrival and turns it on its ear. It was fascinating to watch Amy Adams brilliantly portray a linguist figuring out how to communicate and then what to ask and when to ask it so as neither side is misunderstood. (We could probably use more of that) And then add a dose of physics to the mix in the form of the non-linear quality of time. All of the science was interspersed with very real human moments between a mother and a child. It may not make total sense how it all fits together as you're watching,  but the pay off for watching and paying attention is a huge and satisfying ah-ha moment, when it clicks and you get it. As for the rest of the cast Jeremy Renner is fantastic as the physics guy and Forrest Whittaker the military rep. This film is thought provoking, intriguing, and very well put together. I can see why this film might not be for everyone it but if you are willing to watch, pay attention and open your mind the pay off is spectacular.
One of the better movies in the last several years. No predictability and incredibly thought provoking.

My only gripe about the film are the alien designs weren't really that convincing to me and there's some pacing problems here and there. But overall it's a very good film for people who want to deep sci-fi movie.

This film didn't astound me quite as much as Interstellar, although the ideas behind the story are fascinating and more thoughtful and philosophical than most modern SF cinema. The basic plot is something of a blend of Arthur C. Clarke's novel Childhood's End (in which multiple giant spaceships arrive on Earth all at once and which inspired the opening scenes of Independence Day) and Close Encounters of the Third Kind, in which we have to figure out how to communicate with visiting aliens. In Close Encounters, the common language turned out to be musical tones. In Arrival, a linguistics expert (Amy Adams) must decode the aliens' spoken and written language, a language that appears not use tenses. The aliens' view of past, present, and future is a key plot element and I wont' say any more on that.

The film is beautifully shot, although most scenes had a gloomy pall and a muted colour palette. The pacing is probably slower than younger audience members are used to. In fact, the pacing, along with many visual images and some of the musical score, are reminiscent of 2001: A Space Odyssey, and it's clear that director Villeneuve is a fan of Kubrick's work. This is a lovingly crafted film that tries to tackle some deep ideas, but I suspect it won't appeal to everyone.

What an intriguing film. Not what you expect at all. 
Not so much a film about aliens (they are purely a plot device)..this is more about language and understanding and how our lives fit together. Its awe inspiring in places, emotional in others but at its heart it is really about acceptance and unity.
Adams and Renner are very good and have a fun chemistry as the scientist/linguist paired together to solve the reason for the 'Arrival'.
Nice performances as well from other bit parts and players, to help move the story along. Some beautiful cinematography used and the film does not throw the special effects in your face, as you might expect from 'epic alien ships desending to earth'. Everything is done with quiet subtley, so as not to detract from from the core of the story and the central characters. The film can be hard to follow, and so may confuse some, but stick with it till the end.

Expect "Arrival" to be a mish-mash of "Solaris", "Interstellar" and "The Day the Earth Stood Still", but with a major emotional impact. It works on many levels, including the excellent performance of Amy Adams, the great cinematography by Patrice Vermette (plus a whole team from Quebec) and the now legendary music composer Johann Johannson, who delivers a truly great soundtrack. Following the steps of a linguistics expert and a mathematician, they are chosen by the military to meet the Alien species who have landed on Earth, in 12 different ships across the globe. Their goal: try to communicate with them and learn more about their intentions. Of course, what they will discover will be breathtaking...

"Arrival" is not my favourite Denis Villeneuve film, but he succeeds once again to impose his own signature and deliver emotional thrills that remain unique!

Contemporarily relevant in that it demonstrates the global consequences of the misunderstanding of a nuance. I thought it was an outstanding performance by Amy Adams. Beautiful. Best film of the decade.

Grade:  A

Rating:   PG-13, 116 minutes

In a Nutshell:  Earning 100% score on Rotten Tomatoes, this intelligent sci-fi thriller features an outstanding performance from Amy Adams that already has garnered Oscar buzz.  This fascinating film will tickle your brain and warm your heart.

I didn't want to post my review right after I saw it, because I wanted it to percolate in my head and process it for a while first.  The more I thought about it, the more I loved it.   It's hard to write a review without giving too much away, so I apologize for the spoiler alerts below.  It's better to see the movie "blind", so to speak, so that you get to experience the unfolding of the story.  

"Arriving" at the end of the movie and understanding it is a satisfying journey when you have to work it out in your own mind.

You know a movie has done its job when the audience claps and then slowly walks out of the theater, as they try to contemplate what they have just experienced.  That's what happened when I sat in a packed theater Friday night.  I can't wait for you to see it and read your comments!

Uplifting theme:  
"Language is complicated and messy and sometimes it can be both." - Dr. Louise Banks
This is less about aliens and science fiction, but instead, more about humanity and working together.
"If you could see your whole life start to finish, would you change things?" - Dr. Louise Banks    I loved the movie City of Angels and how, despite life being hard and even heart-breaking at times, it's still worth living....every minute.

Things I liked:
Director Denis Villeneuve usually makes violent, profanity-laced Rated R movies like Sicario and Prisoners, so I was happy to see him offer something else more family-friendly and cerebral.  
The cinematography is fantastic.  One of the best takes is when we first see the alien spacecraft in a field in Montana with fog drifting over the ridge.  Gorgeous. The camera rolls in almost a 360 degree span that is absolutely stunning.
It reminded me a little bit of the movie  Signs , which I loved, because of the lingering uneasiness that lasts throughout the entire movie.  The tension is handled very well.  It also reminded me of Close Encounters Of The Third Kind and Contact, because of the lessons we learn about humanity and our connection to the universe.
I loved the no-gravity chamber inside the spaceship, especially when the people inside could look far down below at the people walking around.  Super cool.  
I'm such a nerd that when Dr. Banks' lecture on the Portuguese language was interrupted, I was disappointed that I didn't get to hear it.   Ha ha 
We've never seen aliens like this before.  We've never seen a spaceship like this before.  We've never seen a written language like this before.  Three cheers for creative writers!
I was mesmerized with how the spaceships left the atmosphere....soooo cool.  
Did you catch Louise's earrings at the fancy event when she was talking to General Shang of China (played by Tzi Ma)?  If you look closely, you'll also see that same image repeated on her daughter's notebook.  Pay attention to other places you see a bird in a cage too.
There is a little bit of humor, which audiences always appreciate.
SPOILER ALERT.  As a university professor who teaches English, I LOVE that the film revolved around language and trying to communicate with the aliens, yet was really about how we humans communicate with each other.  Amy Adams' character (also a college professor) wrote, "Language is the cornerstone of civilization."  The gift that the aliens brought was perfect.
HUGE SPOILER ALERT!!!!   I LOVED the way that time was used in the movie.  Because we're human, we view time as linear.  That simple fact makes us believe that what we're seeing at the beginning of the movie is the beginning of the story.  The movie folds over on itself, just as the language of the aliens does.  Once Louise realizes that, we also realize what is happening in the story.  Very cool.


 

Things I didn't like:
Some viewers have complained about the slow pace, but I didn't mind, because it gave my brain a chance to consider all of the different story angles and messages.
Each encounter with the aliens cut off too soon.  I wanted them to last longer.
Jeremy Renner delivers a good performance.  Unfortunately, his character doesn't contribute much and he admits that they wouldn't be anywhere without Louise.  He figures out one thing without her and he makes a really strange decision in the end that I didn't like.  
What was the deal with Forest Whitaker's weird accent?
There is a lot of quiet mumbling, making it often difficult to understand what people are saying.
Sometimes things were out of focus, which was annoying.  I recognize that was an artistic choice, forcing us to focus on a specific thing, but sometimes it just annoyed me; I wanted to see everything!

 

Interesting lines:
"If all I ever gave you was a hammer..." - Louise
"Every answer is a nail." - Colonel Weber (Forest Whitaker)

"Memory is a strange thing.  It doesn't work like I used to think.  We are bound by time, by its order..." - Louise
"There are days that define your story beyond your life." - Louise

Funny lines:
"You made quick work of those insurgent videos." - Colonel Weber
"You made quick work of those insurgents." - Louise
"When was the last time you did something stressful?" - Army doctor
"Does this count?  Just saying..." - Ian Donnelly (Jeremy Renner)
"Yeah.  That just happened." - Ian Donnelly
"Trust me.  You can understand communication and still end up single." - Louise


Tips for parents: 

Kids will think the aliens are cool, not too scary.
Yay for science and math!  
There are some subtitles your kids will need to read or have read to them.
The one and only person who dropped an F-bomb happened to be an Avenger...Jeremy Renner.

Pretty much all of the negative reviews are from uncultured cretins who can't enjoy a movie without an explosion every 5 seconds. Arrival is a thoughtful and emotional movie, very reminiscent of the works of Bradbury and Asimov. The exploration of philosophical as well as practical problems makes this a brain teaser from beginning to end.

A good scifi movie has a strong story arc and intriguing characters. This movie has neither. The story is muddled and the characters are poorly developed. "Arrival" should not even appear in the same sentence as movies like "Close Encounters" (strong characters and plot) or "2001" (intriguing plot line). The review rating to date is surprisingly strong, but don't be fooled. This is not a particularly good scifi movie-not even close.

I don't toss around the word brilliant much when it comes to movies, but Arrival is brilliant in every sense of the word. It's a deep, intelligent sci-fi flick for adults and thinking moviegoers who want more than special effects and spectacle. Director Denis Villeneuve has crafted an exciting film that will blow your mind without big action scenes. This is a human story about language, time, life and hope, but I'll stop there because saying too much could take away from a first-time viewer's experience. Amy Adams is soooooo good. Ditto Jeremy Rener and Forest Whitaker. There isn't going to be a better movie this year, or this decade for that matter. Villeneuve is hands down one of the best directors working today. His visual style is gritty and real, and watching this movie, I just knew I was in the hands of a master.
Intelligent, realistic and fun!

If your expecting a fun child's film like Independence Day then you will be disappointed. 
This film has a great story and is quite emotional with a powerful message.
Excellent story and fantastic acting by all.

For a film ostensibly about communication, it sure struggles to communicate its central thesis. For a time, it's a somber, cerebral tone poem seemingly about the place of human joys and sorrows in a universal scheme much larger than we'd considered. But, then the larger scheme reveals... what exactly? Whatever the film wants to say, "I don't understand."
A powerful performance from Amy Adams who is in practically every scene of this film. Don't expect a Star Wars type sci-fi; this movie will make you think...

What if the way we thought about 'time' is completely wrong? I can't articulate a my thoughts, it just felt eerily similar to an episode of Black Mirror.

Mind. Blown.
AMY ADAMS what a talent. So unbelievably believable !! Put on your thinking cap and GO SEE this movie.

Arrival sets a great atmosphere and with that slow burn and great score, sets up the movie to be one of the years best, but ultimately falls short of greatness. Adams is wonderful as Dr Banks and Renner does a decent job in a support role but for me Forest Whitaker is not used to the best of his ability in this movie. I loved Director Denis Villeneuve's previous movies, and the tone and journey he takes you on in his movies but was very disappointed with Arrival. We have seen similar movies about humanity having to over come differences in the face of impending alien invasion and can more or less guess how it will end, Arrival is no different. Visually stunning with a fantastic score, I would highly recommend Arrival but caution people to be prepared for a slow burn that may pay of for some, but did not for me. I am now less excited for the Blade Runner Sequel

The Arrival is very slow paced revolving around 1 key message shown multiple times as if the audience wouldn't understand it from the 1st time. It would have been better if they made it in 1 hour and  1/2 instead of 2.  The acting is good, the effects are well made but overall it is an acceptable movie for me.

Hands down, the worst movie I've ever seen.  Phenomenally slow paced, uninspiring, predictable, and just boring.  I kept waiting for it to pick up pace or something intriguing to happen.  Never did.  A complete waste of time.
Beautiful thought provoking,
Emotionally beautiful and cintamatograhy stunning. The arrival creasy a brilliant concept and amazing acting. This movie will keep u thinking for years. And will hopefully not be forgotten

What a waste of 2 hours. The ending leaves you wanting more. The story line continues Hollywood's pandering to the Chinese government (Hollywood's largest movie grossing country).
I rather watch a rerun of Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventures.

Great movie, awesome story, fantastic effects, and the scripts were good as well!
One of the greatest UFO movies ever!
Very disappointed.  The acting was sub-par and story line slow and boring.   I like the genre but this was one of the worst movies We saw this year.  Don't understand the other reviews.

I found Arrival to be overall too much of a slow burn to give it a higher rating but that doesn't mean that I didn't have a great time figuring this film out.  It is definitely one that makes you have to think, especially after leaving the theater to decide if it all holds together at the end.  Of which I think really worked, a reveal at the end could have fallen on its face and ruined what came before but it flowed easily with the film as a whole.  

Amy Adams carried Arrival on her shoulders, the rest of the supporting cast were fine but if she didn't sell her performance than what unfolds wouldn't have had the impact that it managed to.  Jeremy Renner's character though didn't have enough to do here, felt more like he tagged along as Adams did all the heavy lifting.  Would have been nice to make him more useful throughout.  

Of course the special effects were fantastic, the opening shot of their approaching the spaceship was the best in the film imo, incredible on a theater screen and was quite intrigued with how the film decided to make these "arrivals" both visually and with how they communicate.  I can say that Arrival is not a film for everyone, those who need more action will be very disappointed here, it is not that kind of film, not an Independence Day or War of the Worlds at all, closer to Contact if a comparison must be made.    Arrival is certainly more on character and plot which is hardly a bad thing now is it? :)

If you could see your whole life before you, would you change a single thing? This is cleverly thought out and played Sci-Fi. The Aliens arrive, much in the same way as 'Independence Day', dotted all over the Earth, but whereas that idea had gone stale by the sequel, 'Arrival' offers something fresh. We start with Louise Adams (Amy Adams) grieving the loss of her daughter - you assume in flashback, but hey could it be in flash forward? The army want a linguist to try and help communicate - and here it is wonderfully inventive ... our Aliens are ink squirting hepta-pods communicating in splodges, how in the hell is anyone meant to understand that!! They also have a much more fuzzier concept of time than we do. Suspense is nicely paced and we are all left to ponder the films core message. Fab.

Arrival is a phenomenal film with beautiful cinematography and a deeply moving storyline about the choices we make in life. It may not be your average si-fi film, but I encourage anyone who is thinking about it to go see this film. It is quite possibly the best film of the year.
Over hyped, terribly boring love story, stupid ending.
Pretty good until the ending that sucked!
Arrival has just about the right pace, its interesting and captivating. The ending leaves something to be desired but overall its a good watch. Amy Adams is brilliant.
The overall idea was interesting but the character development and acting was sadly quite lacking.  The science was incomprehensible and really corny at times.

I often read the bad reviews just to see what the critics are thinking. One said this wasn't as good as M. Night Shyamalan's 'Signs' which makes me think the critic didn't watch this movie or Signs; probably neither. Anyway now that I have that out of my system I'll say this is a terrific movie. Every few years a SciFi movie comes out for people who want to think and not just be thrilled. Don't get me wrong, I love thrilling SciFi movies as much, maybe more, than anyone, but this is a movie that sticks with you. My son and I were still talking about over tacos two hours later. Amy Adams is spot on here and deserves, and will not get, award nominations (SciFi movies are rarely nominated for anything other than special effects). The rest of the cast is excellent as well, albeit definitely in supporting roles, Adams is the focus of the movie. While not an action movie it had enough suspense to give me sweaty palms at times. The movie poises interesting questions about time, and the ability to understand the complex. There were a few odd moments and it is easy to get lost if you don't pay attention, but this is a very good movie and I strongly recommend it.

Very disappointed.  Extremely confusing ending and a lack of character development, especially the aliens.  I am still wondering the movies point and major details of this movie.  We like Amy Adams very much.  This movie unfortunately, was a waste of time and money.

Quella di Arrival non è uno sci-fi muscolare ma è una fantascienza al contempo politica e sentimentale. Villeneuve (il regista, ndr) è bravo a bilanciare queste due sfere senza cadere nel banale o nel patetico e sfrutta appieno la struttura narrativa non lineare per coinvolgere e sorprendere lo spettatore. Menzione di merito anche per la potente fotografia che sa giocare con prospettive e (mancanza di) colore. Al di là dei paradossi temporali e delle inesattezze scientifiche in cui rischia di inciampare, Arrival è un film riuscito che si fa portavoce di un messaggio non proprio di moda in questo periodo storico: la mancanza di comunicazione porta alla rovina, solo aprendoci allo "straniero" l'uomo può raggiungere un nuovo stato di pace e prosperità.

I think that this movie was an okay, one time watcher, and I probably would recommend waiting till it comes out on video. Although this movie was probably the most realistic when it comes to what would likely happen if/when we tried to communicate with aliens it was somewhat slow, and boring at times.

Spoiler Alert: If you are planning on seeing the movie ABSOLUTELY DO NOT READ PAST THIS POINT AS THE WHOLE MOVIE IS DISCUSSED AFTER THIS POINT

**************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************

The plot of the movie could have been much better. I mean the whole movie could have been summed up in the first five minutes. The Army pulls in a world renowned linguist to communicate with aliens that have landed. After some dialogue with the aliens they give her their language as a gift in return for help in the future. She finds that the Alien language allows her to see the future, and may also be the key to interstellar travel. This is where the plot could open up, and do just about anything, but obviously the writers failed us. She could have then used the power she gained from this alien language to change the world, stop a war, end world hunger, save mankind from a hostile invasion that the first aliens were there to warn us about (the help that they asked for in return for giving her the language), travel the universe, save mankind by finding a new planet after inventing interstellar travel. I mean the sky is the limit when you can see the future. Anything she wanted to do would always be funded because all she would have to do is fill out a lottery ticket and the next day she would have money. This movie could have went so many ways, but instead she chose to live out her normal mundane life, have a child that she knew was going to die of cancer (because she could see the future) and write a book even though she knew all of that would cause her to get divorced. Who in their right mind would choose this existence!?!
Good movie, wait for the DVD.
A different spin on Close Encounters. Great if you love Amy Adams who gives a superb performance but I found the pace too slow and is there a point to the rest of cast being there?

This is definitely one of my favorite movies this year! Hard core Sci-fi to the max with a bizarre and thought provoking story-line. Visual and acting are great. This was a slow movie , but never dull; think of stoofvlees.  The ending especially makes you question everything thatt you've seen before

I have to admit that I let out a every large, audible sigh when I first saw that they they were making another first contact style movie with A-list actors. I thought "Oh here comes another movie where all the effort is put into the special effects and acquiring the flavour of the month actors and none is put into the script". But I was very much wrong. THIS IS THE SCI-FI BENCH MARK FROM NOW ON, audiences want smart sci-fi. 

The script has gentle twists and turns to keep you engaged, thinking and believable. Yes, the writing and tone of this movie along with the great acting actually made me feel that what was happening on screen could actually happen in todays world. Which is absolute nonsense but the movie pulls you in enough to believe it.

Different in many ways from the man from outter space movies but very similar. The twist is how do you communicate with the aliens and are they a menace. The movie moves at a leisurely pace. So I took a 30 minute nap early on. Guys should see Hacksaw Ridge instead and ladies should see Girl on the Train first. Couples should see the Accountant instead. Scott

Good 20 minutes of a movie - if you can skip the 60 minutes of heavy breathing, 20 minutes of face closeups (why?), 20 minutes of boring scenery and flashbacks.  No good CGI, some plot holes, of course the view of the aliens is obscured by clouds.  So much of the dialog is whispering - how can someone behind you or on the other side of the room hear you if you whisper?  The main character can't seem to speak up and it's extremely creepy.

This is one of the best films I've ever seen. A movie not about fighting aliens but trying to communicate with one another. Don't expect it to be action packed but it will keep you interested with intrigue. Really well done.
Awesome movie! I loved every minute of it. Recommend it to all ages and preferences. I will definitely be buying this one. It's the interstellar of the year

A smart movie that keeps you on your toes. It unfolds like a complex origami, making you wonder and guess what' s going to happen next, right along with Amy Adams, Jeremy Renner, and the rest of the world. Loved it!

Went to watch this with anticipation with my wife and 19 year old son.  Came out bored and wishing we hadn't bothered.  Very few scenes are in bright sunlight and so the mood created is morose. This is compounded by very slow ponderous ''action''  -  and little or no outcome at the end of it all .  The whole film seemed a pointless exercise  other than demonstrate how man might have difficulty in communicating with an alien race  - which, since we can't even  really communicate with dolphins or whales   - we all knew.  We could have all fallen asleep through this film to be honest.
Slow moving and very overrated in my opinion.

I loved this. Taking an appropriately bleak view of how our current governments would approach this type of encounter. But shining a light on a more enlightened scientific approach. Also, Amy Adams is terrific as always.

Too confusing and slow going.  Don't see how it got such a high rating.  Maybe my spouse and I just had higher expectations, but even still, this was just a bit too much; now instead of big headed aliens, we have octopus type aliens...really?????

I generally liked this film, although it wasn't as good as I thought it'd be after the glowing reviews. The story is fairly slow and some people may get bored along the way. What I liked about the film is that you're never quite sure where the plot is going or what will happen. This is definitely a film where you need to concentrate throughout and is as far removed from other alien encounter films like 'Independence Day' as you can get - there is no 'action' in Arrival. What it does offer is a puzzle that you will think about afterwards and try to piece together. It doesn't really give you all the answers, which again some people will like and others won't. I liked it, although I'm not necessarily recommending it as this is one of those films that isn't for everyone. 3 stars out of 5

Arrival has a new interesting way of playing with the science fiction genre. Instead of typical alien invasion, it centered the entire plot on communication and languages. All of this mixed with the amazing performance from Amy Adams !

Superb! Best movie I've seen in years. In the vein of Interstellar in that the concept or perception of time is the mystery and Contact in that there is on going communication with extra-terrestrials. However, the emphasis of Arrival is the art and necessity of communication. It is timely in that it rejects the instinct that we so easily fear what we don't understand and too quickly resort to violence. The smart quip by the doctor to Amy Adams' character when the impressionable soldiers attempted to blow up the space ship, "they watched too much tv" was simply poignant, highlighting one of the subtle themes of the movie which is to think circularly rather than linearly; to think with a more global perspective. This Arrival has set a standard for the genre.
IBrillant film, definitely fir someone who has a brain

In my top 3 sci fi films the past decade. A great movie for those who like to have to think during movies. Similar to Interstellar. Far better the watching the same boring plots over and over in marvel movies.
This was a 30 minute plot stretched out into a 2 hour movie

Denis Villeneuve is building quite the resumé for himself these days. Following acclaimed films like 'Incendies', 'Prisoners' and 'Sicario', the Canadian director now brings us this chilling sci-fi drama that documents Earth's first contact with an alien race whose twelve shell-shaped spacecraft loom ominously over various locations around the globe. Charged with finding a way to communicate with the aliens and uncovering their true intentions, linguist Louise Brooks (played by a terrific Amy Adams with equal parts heart and grit) finds herself racing against the clock as the world's governments press for the use of military force against these mysterious visitors. Make no mistake: this is decidedly NOT an action movie, finding much in common with more cerebral, personal movies like 'Interstellar' and 'Contact'; it eschews FX-heavy battle sequences in favour of adult conversations, both human and alien. While its murky ending may mute its overall impact for some, the spine-tingling ARRIVAL is a welcome respite from your average alien invasion movie.

In many ways, this movie is something of a one-trick pony, an appreciation that you don't fully make until the climactic 15 minutes, but, to be fair it's a great rick and very cleverly revealed. As for the rest, for me the the intentionally dulled cinematography was the star. Amy Adams is great but her part is reactive and I've always thought that 'easier' for any actor. Don't think is the Oscar winning performance.

Boring, very slow moving, confusing storyline, and did I say boring, would have been better st 90 minutes. Save your money for DVD. And does NOT compare to great space movies like Gravity and Interstellar which are classics. This was an overrated dud

Now I know why I don't pay to see Sci  Fi movies.Avatar, Gravity and now non Arrival.Decided to go after seeing great reviews.Underwhelming in every aspect.Do people honestly believe that humans can decipher what looked like black squid ink messages.For Sci Fi buffs you might get it.?My review  has to be taken on face value as I only really only witnessed 3/4 of the movie.I was snoring for the rest of it and had to be woken up by wife!
The Worst Movie I have ever seen. There must have been a lot of money behind this movie for the cast and production company for it to have been promoted so heavily.

Finally an new take on ET coming to visit.  
Refreshing new movie from hollywood.  Some parts are deep and having seen it once I want to see it again to experience it more now that I know the story.

Seriously, go see it.
Enjoyable film.  Same type of movie as Interstellar which sets the benchmark.

Brilliant! There have been a lot of aliens-making-contact-with-humans movies, so it is pretty difficult, I imagine, to come up with something that breaks away from cliches. But ARRIVAL is just that! I was riveted by this movie. Amy Adams is excellent as the linguist and the exploration of language is very intriguing. And the sound track - wow! Eerie and powerful. Reminded me a bit of a didgeridoo - maybe that was the inspiration - very ethereal. The aliens are superbly crafted and presented. While the plot is more important in this movie than special effects, it is still a must see on the big screen. This is an intelligent, thinking person's sci-fi. Loved it!

Quite disappointing, had potential to be a really good movie, starts out that Louise (Amy Adams) had a tragic past, and was lost in life, when an alien race touches down, and she's tasked to translate their language, and break the code by the military. The  first half of the movie reals you in and makes you hope for this "DaVinci Code" type of deal where she cracks the code to the aliens, and it's this big shocker of what they are here for, but soon after the half way point the movie takes a turn from trying to crack the code, to her love life and how she can see the future. The movie pretty much just drops off the fact that she is translating this alien language to save the world. It practically changed genres from Suspense/Thriller to Sci-fi/fantasy/drama/romance? If you are being taken on a date, or work at a movie theater and don't have to pay for the movie, I'd say go see it for the sole fact that Amy Adams is in it, because well she's a dime, and amazing in everything she does, but if you're at the box office wondering what to see, I do not recommend this movie.
Total waste of money and time.  Unless you liked Beaches.  Then by all means pull up your your man buns and your lensless glasses  and go.

Arrival is hugely overrated and in no way a blockbuster.  From the reviews and trailer this was described as the type of movie I generally love but it was a big let down.  To respond to some of the reviews stating this was so intricate it was hard to follow, full of engaging twists, possibly requiring multiple viewings to fully get it, etc...  NOTHING of the sort!  

This movie is slow to develop with shallow characters you never really get to know.  It has only one small plot twist that any thinking person will figure out 2/3rds of the way through.  The very premise used for why the aliens are "arriving" is childishly simplistic.  Despite 2 hours run-time, the film lacks depth, ending up just a shadow of what it tries to be.

Very thought provoking, amazing! I'm a lifelong sci-fi gal, and this just blew me away. If you're looking for a brainless  action packed popcorn alien flick, skip this.  You can't look away for more than a second, you might miss a piece of this well crafted puzzle.
An amazing movie - so much more than a sci fi!!

Favorite movie of the year, maybe even the past couple of years. Can't believe people are so confused by this movie! If you love sci-fi, have half a brain and a better attention span than a gold fish, you'll love this movie.
I just came back from watching this and honestly I think this film has been one of the most boring I have seen in a long time. It is so pointless and confusing that I just wanted it to end.

This movie was horrible...wanted to fall asleep in the first 30  minutes, and it only got a little better afterwards.  I have no idea how this has such a high score on here.  Great acting, terrible movie.  I was going to shove my popcorn bucket down my throat, if that scene at the end about her and her daughter went any longer.

I love SciFi, but this movie plot is beyond bad, extremely boring, put audience to sleep. When the movie was over, I heard so many complained. 
It puzzled me and my friends how the critics could rate it so high.

Not bad, i would say it was more interesting than entertaining.  It was like a good episode of The Twilight Zone and I am not saying that as a knock.  Make no mistake though, it is more like Trouble with the Curve than say Independence Day.  So in short we have Romance, heartbreak, social commentary, scientific investigation, China plays a pivotal role and the "You've always had the power to go back to Kansas" moment.  All the check boxes have been marked off.

Do not waste your money on this incredibly long and boring as hell movie. It's basically an adult version of the last mimzy. Not only is it boring there is no point, conflict , climax or plot to this film. I had more fun listening to the music in the credits than I did the entire film.
Boring, boring, and did I mention boring.
Must see. What a fantastic film.

I really wanted to like it but boy was I bored.  It reminded me of someone on drugs trying to tell a story and thinking how insightful their being.  Five minutes in I knew exactly what was going to happen.  Up to the very end I kept thinking I must be wrong, but sadly no.

So not what one would expect in the traditional sci-fi movies previously known. But very simplistic and futuristic in the sense of thought, seeing and listening. It's almost a sign of the times movie if you will. To bring light to all that has occurred and/or taken place over time... to help bring the one true method of moving forward together spite the potentials of consequences and concern... Love and communication have never failed when hand and hand. And neither did this movie, fail. 
A must see and will be a welcomed addition to my family's movie collection for the present (once available) and future. Nothing like a simple yet common sense reminder of all that's required no matter who you are, where you come from or where one may be headed. Life is too short to hold grudges and miscellaneous misconceptions and miscommunications of bullshit and ego trips. Time is of the essence and love, communication is key.

Wow. Didn't expect the ending based on the trailer, I liked it though. My main issues with the CG were that they reused too many cars on the packed road leading up to the ship. You could see they only used like 3 cars. The CG hair was a bit weird. I liked how you could tell it was someone with curly hair that had straightened it, but it behaved weirder than the already weird setting it was in. SPOILER: I'm a bit confused if this means everyone that learns the language can now see everything, or just her. Would also hope that she would try and change some of the things she did and not just let it all play out.
Terrible... just terrible.
Awesome effects, great performances and concept

One of the most original movies I've ever seen. With all the reboots and such this was a breathe of fresh air. I was on the edge of my seat, I cried, I laughed. 10/10 would see again; recommend to a friend.

This movie was horrible. I saw it with two friends who agree. It was slow and boring. They had the potential to have some depth with the plot but it jumped all over the place. Do not be fooled by the other ratings. Do not see this movie
Great and instigating movie. Much more philosophical than sci-fi. Very well made. One of the best movies I've watched in years!

Was loving this up until the end where it gets a little too busy and uses plot elements I'm tired of at this point. Most of it is smart and thought-provoking sc-fi that happens to be awe-inspiring and abstract due to a great slow build-up. I don't think this shits the bed like Interstellar for instance but the ending was still a little disappointing for me.

i have to say I love this kind of movies! movies that makes you use your brain, and with such a smart script, Arrival reminded me a lot Interstellar movie while I was watching it, maybe cuz it is trying to explain the same but in a pretty different atmosphere.
when some space ships arrive on earth, a very selected team leading by Louise (a linguistic professor) are recruited to try to make contact with them and to communicate and know their intentions. it may be that premise is not hte most original in the world, but this film is very clever and with such outstanding performances from Amy Adams and Jeremy Renner, also the score is awesome. 
if you like smart science fiction, of simply movies that make you use your brain, this one will be an unforgettable experience for you.
Loved it.  Riveting  from the get go.  One of the best movies I've seen in a long time.

Sleep inducing dud.  Like other reviewers have mentioned, I checked my watch several times during the movie.  I thought that if the movie was under 2 hours, the pace might move along.  Instead the first hour goes almost nowhere.  The theater should have had a decontamination booth so I could wash all trace of this movie off me.
It was great, a work of art
Overrated by critics
It was a very slow movie. It was okay but I could have watched this on DVD

This is a brilliant piece of film making that keeps you guessing and wondering all they way through. It was guided by a heart warming performance by Amy Adams that keeps you glued to the screen in every scene she's in.

I don't disagree with 4 stars, but I don't agree with them either. Something just seems wrong with the rating. I'll give it that rating so people go see the movie. That way we can talk about it, which I think is the best part of this movie. It gets more interesting after it's over. I want to talk about why I didn't not-like it. I can't talk about this movie without spoilers. I will say, there's something there I want to talk about.

I define Sci-fi as a genre that uses fictional science as a framing device to explore the human condition. In Arrival, the fictional science isn't aliens giving a human the ability to perceive time differently. Instead, that ability is learned through understanding the alien's language. 

The fiction of changing your perception of time through language is an interesting one. Perception of space time is one of my favorite Sci-Fi frames. What they decided to frame is what doesn't resonate with me, although they framed it well. 

Consider the life of a human. Life gained and lost. Love and divorce. Gaining the ability to remember your life's future doesn't change that. On reflection, not granting the protagonist omniscient powers shows what sorrowful creatures we are and grounds the sci-fi. 

The included diplomatic tension and shock jock proselytizing serves as an accent to the theme of human frailty and gives just enough tension so people don't leave their seats. The cost of these devices is using the fictional science into a mcguffin to neatly tie up the story right when it was getting interesting. This detracts in a world where beings that can remember the future have a word for "death process".

Instead we are left to explore the concept remembering the future on our own. We are given some glimpses into the future of humanity in that this ability is shared. We are left on our own to consider what this means. We are alone to consider how language shapes our understanding of the world. The deeper and more interesting themes are left to the audience. I really just didn't "not-like" this movie.

An often mesmeric film of grand proportions and beautiful nuance, "Arrival" builds a compelling narrative without relying too heavily on SF cinema archetypes and succeeds in transcending them.  

Themes both political and relational are explored thoughtfully and meaningfully, as lead performers Adams and Renner imbue their performances with great emotional depth and vulnerability.  There is some of Spielberg's "Close Encounters" to be found (of course), with director Villeneuve also (very effectively) focusing more on character reaction to events rather than bombarding us with effects, and shades of Nolan's "Interstellar" and Zemeckis' "Contact".  

Yet the overwhelming feeling is that of a singular vision as executed by a visionary film maker, one which although is not as immediately impactful as, say, Villeneuve's "Prisoners" or Nolan's "Interstellar", is one which slowly continues to seep in after viewing and provoke thought in the days which follow.

Overall, go check this movie out and and really try to interpret it after you see it.

Arrival's analysis of human communication is both entertaining and thought-provoking. As you watch, you become more self aware of the means of current communication on earth, including its flaws. While the movie didn't leave me feeling for days about its implications, it was very entertaining to watch and is done REALLY well. I'd recommend any sci-fi fan see it, but to others showing interest I'd recommend waiting until it's available to rent.

This is definitely one of the most unique films I have ever seen. It's an emotional, cerebral sci-fi movie that will most likely bore and frustrate the casual movie goer but should definitely entertain those who like films that provoke discussion and post-viewing analysis. It reminds me of "Close Encounters of the Third Kind," "Signs," "Contact," and "2001: A Space Odyssey," yet it, as a whole, is entirely different from each of those films. It's definitely a one-of-a-kind sci-fi film that will most likely be imidated but never duplicated, but will leave its mark on the genre.

If you are looking to see a movie with lots of action and badass aliens, then you should skip "Arrival." But if you want a movie that will definitely give you an immersive experience and will leave you thinking about it long after it's over, this is it.

First Hit:  A very inventive and powerful film effectively illuminating the complexities of non-liner time.

This was my kind of film; it had suspense, was beautifully presented, the sound, including the music, was dynamic, and was it intellectually challenging. However, none of this would work without a clear commitment from the actors and the production team. They are to be commended.

The basic story is that 12 alien ships arrive on earth and hover in different countries. Each country having a ship assigns a team of people to try to figure out why they are here on Earth. Heading the military led team for the United States is Colonel Weber (Forest Whitaker). His focus is to communicate to the US Government and the rest of the world what his team has learned. Looking for experts he approaches Dr. Louise Banks (Amy Adams) who is a professor of communication and linguistics at an unnamed College/University. She has certain criteria of how she will work on this project and when Weber rebuffs her, he searches out others. However, a short time later he has a change of heart, she is the best.

This scene, for me, sets the tone of the whole film. How Weber's team picks her up, the noise of being inside the helicopter, the tense excitement of the assignment ahead of them, had me ready for an adventure. The filming and sound were perfectly industrial and presents a sense of realism, the kind that tells you that you are in good hands under the direction of Director Denis Villeneuve. In each scene he beckons the audience, to sit back, open your mind, and enjoy the ride because this will be like no other alien invasion film you've ever experienced.

On the helicopter ride she meets her working partner Dr. Ian Donnelly (Jeremy Renner) who is a physicist. Although their ways of finding out and interpreting the information is they gain from the aliens is very different, they both agree it starts with communication.

There are a number of amazing scenes when they enter the alien ship; how gravity is upended, how they view the aliens through a glass like structure, and the fascinating scenes of Ian and Louise learning the alien's language. All through this film we are treated to Louise's memories of her daughter and little do we know how all of this comes together until the very end when she and Ian "get" the picture the aliens want to share with all of us.

Although I cannot say more about the plot, I will say the screenplay, cinematography, the concept, the acting and directing are top notch. But what really got me, was the ability of everyone who worked on this film to commit to the vision and present an amazing way to help people think more about understanding non-liner time.

Whitaker is the kind of man and actor that elevates every film he is in. For me he is one of the very best living actors and in this movie he's no different. He knows just how much of his intensity and kindness to put into every role and every scene. Adams is sublime. She plays a very complex character and there are few that could have pulled it off as well as Adams. I'm not sure how she felt about the role, but for me it was a role of a lifetime. Renner did a fantastic job in support of Banks. He led when he needed to and buttressed Banks inroads to the science of communicating with aliens. Eric Heisserer wrote an extraordinary screenplay. His ability to create a cohesive, engaging, entertaining and intellectual story while tackling the concept of time was amazing. Villeneuve had a clear vision of what he wanted and how this film was going to get there. From the odd look of the alien spaceships (they looked like large contact lenses), to the music striking the perfect background sound and mood, to how he got so much from each actor, his clear deft hand took us on an amazing journey for which I applaud him.

Overall: This was an extraordinary film and based on all the movies I've seen this year, this one is one of the top three.

This 4-Icee movie (out of 5) is not your typical alien invasion movie.  This is extremely well-done, but I have to confess this is one of those movies where I enjoyed the journey more than the destination.  If you are looking for a typical movie of this genre where there's all types of battles going on, you will be very disappointed.  If you are looking for an intelligent, thought-provoking film, then this is the one for you.

Amy Adams does an excellent job with her character. You feel her pain throughout the film, based on something that happens in the first 15 minutes.  Jeremy Renner does a stellar job in a non-action role (which it's good to see him in that type of role). He's actually a science guy in this one!  Of course, Forrest Whitaker gives his normal exceptional performance.  

Telling what I like without giving out spoilers is difficult, but here's my best shot.  I love the story of how the planet reacts when the aliens arrive. I can see everything that happened in the film happening in real life should such an event occur.  As I mentioned before, the pain felt by Amy Adams' character is well-done throughout the film as well.  As you're watching this you'll think, "Why did they put that there?  That doesn't make any sense."  Trust me that it will once you get closer to the ending.

Speaking of the ending, that's where I thought the movie let us down.  There was a huge drop off of things not articulated, and I think that perhaps the movie (just under 2hrs long) could have done a better job if they spent just a little more time.

In any event, I recommend this movie if you like thinking while watching a film.  If you only like action movies, step clear of this one.  No scene after the credits.

The film holds its mystery to the end.  It would have been a 5 Star movie with more humanoid-like aliens.   The unity theme juxtapose to violence worldwide demonstrates the deep divisions between nations and suggest that it will take a creditable threat of earth anhialation to replace distrust and hate with cooperation  and unity.
As a scientists myself, I found this film quite refreshing. The film was void from the typical "alien invasion" genre -  which resulted in a very refreshing experience.

A fantastic sci-fi premise with minor setbacks, hold the movie shy of greatness. While the movie delivers an emotional deep personal story,  it's convoluted non-linear storytelling can be off-putting for some. While the movie tries holds itself to something greater, it ends up being somewhat "cerebral,"  but doesn't quite pull it off. Definitely worth checking out though. 4/5

One way of making me watch a film, is by calling it "cerebral"; And "Arrival" is as cerebral as it can get.

First, it asks the question what is this thing called "language" we are using? Language is our thoughts and words based on the reality we experience. What "is" Reality? 

If you enjoy questions like that, not weirded out easily by philosophical musings, you will appreciate Arrival.

I'm not gonna make a detailed movie review here since the movie has the basic ingredients of film. But I will take note of the insights inferred by the dialog and as the story unfolds.

If you are an alien and you have a different perception of "time" or maybe your reality of "time" is different (for example: time for you is not linear - not the typical past, present, future), you have a different way of expressing it and probably bound to be misunderstood from the get-go by a different species like humans, at least in this context. 

To use a less abstract example, science tells us that Time is linear since when you cook or make coffee, you can't unmake the coffee or uncook the food.

In the same vein, if in the human experience, "memories" are scenes or experiences from the past that we "remember" in flashbacks; what if you have "flashbacks" of the future? What if as an alien, time for you is like that?

Perhaps one would think this is all just fiction, but if you're the type who find it interesting that Time is now known to have a beginning, and what could there before time"? What if these aliens come from that Reality?

Actually, if you have seen Interstellar and Contact both "serious" sci-fi films, Time also played a significant part in which it becomes distorted or the future, present and the past become one and the same.

This reminds me of a recent scientific finding that the human consciousness moves on to live (aka a soul) in the quantum field. Experts who back this theory argue that our physical universe is just a perception, and that once our bodies die there is an infinite life beyond. Is this the science's term for "eternity". I guess at some point science and religion becomes one and the same too. But that's enough musing for now.


I don't know but this is enough musing for now.
full of sound and fury signifying nothing - sorry didn't work for me

Arrival lacked the solid sci-fi moments I anticipated. Very high concept which results in little to no action and thus a pretty dull film. I liked the narrative but felt the ending was rushed so they could squeeze in a sappy 10 minute montage instead. Good soundtrack!

I enjoyed it.  Amy Adams consistently delivers, and I felt Jeremy Renner delivered as well.
But movie of the year?  No, the story was told in a fragmented and out-of-order way (which was the whole point of it) and so it was somewhat anti climatic.
For me it came across as a Signs wannabe, but here the big reveal per se was out in the open and the fragmented story telling "hid" it in plain sight.  Except I've watched and read so many stories like this that I recognized the reveal very early, so I kept trying to look for some other way it could play out with a different reveal.  I enjoyed it, but was dissatisfied by how it basically used fragmented story telling to try to get me to accept a pivotal cause/effect paradox (which was only pivotal in resolving plot tension that was secondary to what it wanted me to view as the real story -- some confusion in story telling priorities, I felt).  That didn't ruin the story, but it wasn't as satisfying as I wanted, either -- but I'm a Sci Fi nerd.
This film is a combination of Interstellar, Contact, & Lucy. Should get at least 3 Oscar nominations. This film is what every sci-fi film wants to be!
Pleasurably linguistic sci-fi. Turns out the Sapir-Whorf hypothesis did it.

Slow action movie is not popular genre - what a shame, because this movie shows that such genre has huge potential. Nice idea behind movie, calm narration and beatufil steady pictures. All this makes this movie unique in modern popular cinema.

With alien/ sci-fi films making a jump over the last few years, Arrival delivers an intriguing, dramatic piece with Amy Adams leading the way with an emotional performance. As twelve alien 'pods' randomly appear in various parts of the world, nations are tasked with understanding their intent and if they present harm to the human species. A terrific score to coincide with visual mastery, Arrival helps draw the same fear and emotions the other characters experience throughout, making this a must see film. Although it seems like the film is leading up to a larger finish then what we get ultimately, the terrific contributions from Jeremy Renner and Forest Whitaker alongside Adams still leave the audience satisfied and give them something to think about once they leave the theater.

Very little action.  Disjointed but still very predictable plot.  Glad when it was over.  The aliens were elongated octopus.  Male lead Jeremy Renner was a terrible actor, no charisma at all.  Forest Whitaker played his typical stereotype roll.  CGI was ok but not thrilling.  All in all I wish I had seen Fantastic Beasts or Doctor Strange.  I wasted my money seeing this in the theater.  I would advise you to wait till this one comes out on Netflix.
Highly recommend it! Strong female character and a powerful message! Very well done.

I love SciFi but this leaves me lost.  There isn't a lot of action but I don't need that for a movie to be interesting.

It tricks you with scenes in the beginning which you can have no idea what they are doing and the movie makes no sense.

You know as much about the plot and what's going on as I do and I've seen the movie.  Very disappointing.
All been done before, very slow.
I didn't get it....but it wus gewd!
Saw this movie last night.  It was the worst movie I have seen in a real long time.  Just awful!!!!!
Amazing!  Thought provoking, profound & well acted !
Emotionally balanced and well executed, Arrival, like Prisoners and Sicario, sets out to ask and answer an intriguing, morally-laden question.

Perfect. Absolutely perfect..:. I loved the lense the director uses,  making me feel truly a part of the experience. Beautiful  cinematography. Any Adams and of course my boy Jeremy Rener do an AMAZING job. My husband and I were crying off and on throughout the whole movie. I love how the play on time really makes you appreciate  your loved ones. I don't want any spoilers but this movie is the best movie of the year....

Most thought provoking science fiction movie of our time.  Deep, reflective and emotional.  Well written and directed.
Magnificent - Amy Adams is the star of the film.

"The miracle of "Arrival" is it's incredibly uplifting, despite not shying away from the darker realism of life. The movie takes no shortcuts, yet never loses it's optimism and sense of hope."
One of the best movies in 2016. Great plot, and excellent payoff in the end. Loved the complexity of the narrative. So much more to it than just aliens.

Methodic and contemplative, "Arrival" takes its time (so to speak) letting the story unfold. Unfortunately, the story relies too heavily upon cliched fallbacks to provide drama and antagonists. The conflict amongst the different government factions seems unnecessarily forced, as does the inevitable conclusion. Amy Adams does a terrific job as the lead, carrying the movie's emotional arc through its entirety. As with "Gravity" before it, the main character is able to grow and find peace. Unlike "Gravity," "Arrival" is nowhere near as exciting. 

And what was up with Forest Whitaker's weird Bostonian accent? That was very distracting.
Beautifully acted & directed. Based on a short story by David Chiang.

Lousy film.  Poor script, atrocious acting, one-dimensional characters.  The basic idea - the difficulty of communicating with those who don't see the world as you do, and the idea that language shapes the way we see the world - are both worthy ideas.  But the sentimental, brainless way in which they have been developed in this film is breathtaking.   Dead on arrival.
Well, this was a lovely surprise!

It's like Nolan if he tried to understand human beings and had a sense of humility. I love that how within the first three or four shots, there are rigid aesthetic rules being established (it's either super tight/shallow focus on Adams or ponderous wides). We are 100% in Louise's perspective throughout, which I can't praise enough for a movie like this. The most personal sci fi film since Solaris maybe? (Hard to overlook Upstream Color if it qualifies). Fav Villeneuve I've seen so far

Yes, it is slow. Yes, there is no thrilling ET action. None of that detracts from this being a more than satisfying movie. A 'what if' love story set to a SF backdrop, with a bit of clock ticking overcoming paranoia thrown in is how I would describe it. What I want to know is what happens in 3,000 years.
I think that nearly all of the motifs and themes were ripoffs of Slaughterhouse Five.  It was too easy to predict, and parts were BORING.

98% Arrival is one of the best movies of 2016. One of the best science fictions ever made and Director Denis Villeneuve is now one my top 10 favorite film  directors. After watching his last 3 other movies (Prisoners, Enemy & Sicario) he deserved. Each one of them had been masterpieces, and Arrival is no exception. A profound movie with a lot of hidden messages that will take you deep into it, and sometimes making you feel goosebumps all over your body. A very intelligent script, with great performances by Amy Adams and Jeremy Renner, with an astonishing soundtrack. Arrival is a slow paced film, that little by little will be putting together the pieces of a complex puzzle. It tries so hard to make you understand that one of the biggest things we have as human beings are the amount of ways we have to communicate with each others, even with the existence of so many different languages, we born in this world to learn from others, and to understand that life and death through time are connected. Communication is the key to succeed. Two thumbs ups. Go and see Arrival!
Smarter than it needed to be. Better than I expected it to be.Will be thinking about it for weeks. Stunning.

What a disappointment.  Talented actors,  the plot is interesting, special effects good, but slow moving, boring and no real satisfying development of the characters, the aliens, and reasons..so many unanswered questions ....bring a pillow and have a nice nap at the theatre. Don't be fooled by the critics high ratings.

Denis Villeneuve delivers another touching, cerebral masterpiece.

Obviously everything in the movie is a work of fiction. But it lets you imagine if there are aliens, how differently their minds might work, and how they might think. It also lets you imagine how esoteric and different their body structure / environment / language might be. This is the best alien counter movie I've ever seen.
By far this best film of the year - Denis Villeneuve proves he's one of best filmmakers working today.
You can pick it apart or just enjoy the idea.  Was an enjoyable movie, gripping at times, ridiculous at times, left me wanting more in a variety of ways, including a sequel.

Denis Villeneuve once again has made a brilliant film and for the second year in a row has made easily one of my favorites of the year. Brilliant performances, stunning visuals, great score, expertly shot and even though it deals with complicated ideas they don't leave you feeling baffled but invite you to look at the ideas and think heavily on them.

The future of science fiction is here. An extraordinary, poetic and thought-provoking movie that defies description. Beautifully shot, incredible soundtrack and perfectly pitched performances from the cast. More than a must-see, a seminal piece of modern film-making.
Not an SF movie. I consider this as drama with an alien taste. It was boring all the way to the ending. Even the ending was a pretty big impact but not strong enough.

If you are expecting a thrilling alien action packed movie, this movie is not that.  It was a bit slow paced with parts that you really need to focus on to understand.  It's more for the brainiac type that like puzzles and hidden messages.  I liked that it really kept you guessing as to why the aliens were there and you will only find out the real reason at the end.  I may need to watch it again to really fully understand. Was a great movie, but took away a couple of stars because of the lack of excitement and action.  Aliens were not that scary and the visual effects for an alien movie was sub par.
This is a mediocre movie masquerading as something cerebral and deep.
A must-see sci-fi thriller - deals with abstract ideas without relying on any action movie cliché. Made me think of Interstellar with its contemplative tone.
Bland and boring. I just don't get the high reviews.

A well crafted and smart sci-fi movie. Encourages the viewer to think by reducing the amount of exposition one would typically see in any other movie of its type. It sets a foundation of breadcrumbs that actively engage the viewer. I haven't seen a movie this engaging in a long time and having seen it twice, it holds up much more on further viewings compared to other "mind-benders" like Inception and Interstellar. Could be called 2016's Ex Machina in terms of craft and intelligence, but also has a surprising amount of emotion with a beautiful payoff that is both hopeful and relevant considering today's growing international tensions and stubbornness. Arrival is about communication, but also pre-destination, grief, and stoic anti-nihilism. Arrival is not a typical alien movie and I am so very happy that it isn't.

This movie was surprisingly slow moving and straightforward. My wife and I were disappointed given the high rotten tomatoes rating. Bland movie without much nuance, although Adams does do a great job in her role.

At times this is a bit of a chore and does drag on, but the final half an hour is fascinating and the sound and special effects are excellent (definitely one for the big screen). A great twist and nice ending.

Finally a movie that makes the audience think and ponder in 2016. Arrival is not your typical alien invasion movie with laser guns and explosions but instead explores the tension and mounting pressure in the event of first contact with a species we cannot understand. It explores human decision making and rationality more than anything in the wake of a panicked nation. When you think you understand the movie, it turns your expectations on its head and makes you rethink everything from the start.

They did a great job picking the cast.  Amazing heart felt soundtrack.  This is a movie that you could take your kids to if they can handle the alien aspect.  It had a great story line too. I loved it. If Kurt Vonnegut's "Slaughterhouse-Five" were mixed in a movie-making blender with Carl Sagan's "Contact" with a few dollops of Stanley Kubrick's "2001: A Space Odyssey" thrown in this great film would pour out as a nutritious cinematic smoothie.  It made me think, it made me wonder and it made me glad that great films are sometimes in the theaters in contrast to the typical commercial movies full of product placements and simple plots.

If you did not like the movie Contact you will not like this one. Like Contact it has great cinematography and special effects. They do actually show the alien in this one, but the main part of the story is something that has very little to do with the aliens. It takes awhile to get interesting.The pacing is slow. I know some people with like the fact that it is not a classic alien human interaction movie, but I did not enjoy the flashbacks and the underlying moral question.There are many continuity plot holes.

A fully realized piece of adult sci-fi, that trumps all other recent cerebral attempts at the genre (i.e. Gravity, Interstellar). While a thriller (at least at times), Arrival carries a much more universal context to it in how it is primarily a film about language and communication, and it presents itself in a way that feels both palpable and legible. Also, the film takes ample time with its slow-burn in the first two-acts, resulting in insurmountable payoff in the final one. It simply has one of the most subtle and somber plot twists I've seen in any genre film, that also never lets up on tugging on your heart strings. Since 2013, Director Denis Villeneuve has put out a film annually (all of them great or near-great), and Arrival is proof that he isn't running out of creative stamina, or visual energy.

A very thought provoking movie. If you are expecting an action movie then this movie may bore you. If you appreciate the movies that make you wonder how these writers come up with this kind of plot, then you will love it. I would equate it to Interstellar, but much better.
They ruined a perfectly good et movie by making it a chick flick.
must pay attention to every scene
interesting...a little mysterious, but kept me involved til the end
Arrival proves that first contact films can still blow your mind. It's a timely movie that has something to say about ourselves as a human races. Lets learn how to listen and talk to each other.

like chrisopher nolans interstellar, this movie is cinema gold. the ending=goosebumps factor. amy adams hits a home run. the best part is leaving the theatre and asking yourself...would you choose what amy chooses to do? knowing the hurt thats to come.

Amy Adams stole the show. She was authentic and understandably stunned as the story unfolded.

I love how the movie doesn't focus too much on the science or any theological argument and instead focuses on the relationships that develop in the story between humans and between aliens.

I especially enjoyed how the movie sets you up with questions before the meat and potatoes are served and the questions they force you to consider only serve to force you to ask more and more questions.

By the end of the movie, if you were paying attention to the story you will have an answer to nearly every question in the story and it will only leave you wanting more, but in spite of this want-feeling satisfied.

Arrival felt like the start of a beautiful friendship....and now I want to go on the second date already....
