Great film! The different country's governments initial reactions are the same as what's going on in America and the rest of the world today. Instead of communication, all there is is fear, and reacting to that fear. But I'm hoping that just like in this movie, our world, governments, people, will start to listen to each other, communicate and come up with a solution that will make our world a better place. Again, great film! I really enjoyed it!
How did this get 93%?  Slow, boring and silly story line.

More an an introspective on the human condition than an alien invasion movie. A bit too plodding and slow at times, and excessively reliant on dream sequences and flashbacks (spoiler alert...flash forwards). Nonetheless, thoughtful and well acted with out a doubt an Oscar caliber performance by Amy Adams. The sub plot around all the world politics was interesting to observe unfold, and the director was definitely making a statement about the our trigger happy global readers.

Let me start by saying that any reviewer who thinks this film is "unconventional" or "unique" or "cerebral" in its storytelling approach, does not have much knowledge of the science fiction genre.  There are numerous movies, and a plethora of books that explore the ideas presented in this film with far more depth and complexity.  I love thoughtful sci-fi, but the story here turns out to be utterly simplistic.  There's only one big twist and you can figure it out about half way in.  It's the classic sci-fi blunder of having an interesting premise, but failing to build on it.  If you remove the predictable premise then you are left with undeveloped characters and a tedious story.  There is no real "exploration of the nature of language" as many would-be intellectual reviewers are claiming.  The main characters slowly figure out what certain alien symbols mean, without ever explaining how they figured this out.  And the second form of communication explored in the film is memory, and it is done in a very vague way that relies solely on the use of the "big plot twist", which as I said, is entirely predictable if you have half a brain and any experience with decent sci-fi.  (Check out the book "The Godgrave Initiative" if you don't believe me.  It used the idea of flashbacks/flash-forwards to far greater effect, and years before this movie script.)

The production and emotional value, however, are generally enough to carry you through the rather tedious narrative.  Thematically it presents an introspective look at the nature of memory, and the value and/or lack thereof of prescience.  Unfortunately, because the storyline is ultimately so simplistic, it will not retain any rewatchability or further dissection as others of its kind, like the far superior movies, 2001 (the bench-mark), Contact (thematically brilliant), or Interstellar (flawed but mind-bending).

I am admittedly a sci-fi snob, but it's humerous to me to read many user reviews who laud this film as being so "thought-provoking," and "cerebral."  Beware of these user reviews, most of whom fall victim to the same issue professional reviewers face--namely that they get so caught up in the egotistical idea of appreciating something the average person doesn't understand, that they end up applying far more meaning to this film than it deserves.  One user review said the movie had "pedigree" because it's the same director who filmed SICARIO.  Well SICARIO has a similar problem in that it takes a very complex issue, the Mexican/American drug war, and dumbs it down into a simple revenge story.  So I suppose that if you found SICARIO "thought-provoking," or "an eye-opening view of the war on drugs," then you'll probably have your head explode with the totally "cerebral" (yes, that's sarcasm) exprecience of ARRIVAL.

More Contact than Independence Day. Don't go expecting battles with aliens. (The women next to me brought her 10-12 year old kids. They were bored silly). This is a thinking person's movie and well done.
the concept and acting is totes delicious!
Awesome movie. One of the absolute best alien movies ever.

Do not be fooled. This is NOT a science fiction movie. This is a chick flick set in a science fiction arena. 

Edit: I just remembered that there is a slight fender-bender which takes place early in the movie. I estimate $500 in damage. That's the peak of action in the film.

If you want action, save your money. Nothing happens in this movie. It is boring beyond words.

If you want to be able to see anything, save your money. The entire film is shot in the dark. It's nearly impossible to see a darn thing. The lighting is awful, on purpose. You can only see the aliens' feet, as though that adds to any intrigue.

All of the men in the movie are written as dumb, violent, or baggage. Only Adams' character is given wisdom, and eventually superpowers (in her own head).

But most importantly....NOTHING HAPPENS IN THIS MOVIE. Nothing. Zero. Zilch. 

Honestly, I fell asleep for 20 minutes, and I'm sorry I woke up. The ending is terrible.
one of those great movies that only come once every few years. LOVED it!!!
Great film! A thinking man's sci-fi film. Watch it twice!
A very thought provoking movie, which I did not expect. It doesn't seem eventful but somehow it is and whilst watching it keeps you engaged throughout. Another great film from Dennis Villeneuve.

Amy Adams has a great screen presence and draws you in to the movie, delivering a compeliin performance with a less than perfect script. The linguistics and semiotics are sometimes clumsy, and I think Renner is not plausible as a scientist, and miscast in this role; the screen chemistry between "Louise" and "Ian" is lacklustre and somewhat contrived. The experience of the movie in XTreme Screen is brilliant, with the CGI providing a similar ambience as did Prometheus in its opening scene. The large obelisks are impressive and the unfolding plot in and out of the alien spacecrafts made this an enjoyable 116 minutes. I am a sci fi aficionado and Trekkie, but this was much better than Start Trek Beyond.

Firstly, the trailer was misleading. But that wasn't the issue, the film tried to be at least four disparate  ideas stories, was it about Lose, was it about first conta, t in a Day the Earth stood still way, the nature of communication,  and  should you change the future if you knew it? The film doesn't hold up, trying to say to much it says nothing
this movie was so damn boring.

Mind-bending and gorgeous. Nearly every part of the movie was put in there for a reason, and I couldn't believe how well done this movie was, right from the beginning to end - never mind that there technically wasn't a beginning or end. Louise was a strong female lead, and I loved how the movie capitalized on her, focussed on her abilities, her courage and mind and character. Simply amazing.

This is Hollywood trying to do too much. On the plus side, it wastes no time drawing you into the reality of alien arrival as experienced by the character of Louise, thanks to an efficient screenplay, quality production and Adams' thorough performance.  Its message is that the world needs to work together. The first third of the film is thrilling and fascinating when it enters the world of linguistic analysis of the alien language. The second third however swerves predictably onto the war footing taken by the impatient humans against the aliens. The guns come out.  China is blamed for starting it, followed by Russia, and Sudan, of all places - well at least Sudan is not part of the usual stereotype for this kind of thing. There are grabs from various countries. Unfortunately, to illustrate early on the danger of miscommunication, the script implies semi-jokingly that the near-genocide of Australian Aborigines was the result of misinterpretation. The final third of the film resorts to deus ex machina to solve the problem of the various countries taking the world to the brink.  It ties up the loose ends magically, but these were what gave it charm and depth, and should have been left well enough alone to hang there, while Louise became the world's messenger. The circle can only be closed with a horribly depressing element: an unhappy ending that is hard to relate to.  You got the feeling that people went to see this genuinely interested in how humans might learn to talk to aliens, but it only gets as far as chapter one of the manual.
What a let down. It was a great ride until they brought in the time manipulation. No resolution at all.
Never before has a movie filled me with the feeling I get when ready a top quality scifi short story. Arrival does that.  It is amazing.

What a disappointment what with the excellent leading cast, the enticing trailer and the now inexplicable R/T rating up in the stratosphere. This is like getting J K Rowling to re-write 2001 only with 12 rounded monoliths, music you don't notice, totally inept aliens, and glowering, unimaginative, one-dimensional world-wide military figures with a Limbaugh-like figure egging them on from his gold microphone, advising our side to fire one across the bow--Gah!

But the worst of it is the reason they came to Earth, which completely abandons any science in the fiction, in favor of a magic wand. And to complete this train come UFO wreck, they have a general's dead wife saying something supposedly so profound it has to be whispered out of our earshot. And then post-climactically, poor Renner has to deliver an oh-no-please-tell-me-he's-not-going-to-say-that line, and then doubles down with another embarrassingly trite follow up, both coming out of nowhere. 4/10, and I'm being generous.

Go see "The Accountant" (again), instead.

Excellent movie that is not a CGI adventure.  This movie is for thinkers and addresses not just communication with an alien race, but also communication among human races.  I don't want to be a spoiler, but the aliens have a method in their madness.  This movie will especially appeal to those who meditate or have experienced the place between consciousness and sleep, where the mind is its most powerful.
Travail impeccable !

I just saw the film: "Arrival" and if I were to describe it in one word, it would be: BORING!!!!!!

The first rule in making a movie is: "Thou shall not be boring".  Obviously, the makers of this film forgot this rule.

The scenes drag on forever. 90% of the film focuses on one woman and her emotional problems.  This is not what most people are looking for in an alien movie.  Despite what the previews imply, there is no action in this movie.  The whole film is about them going in and out of the ships and trying to translate the alien language.  

We then learn that the aliens want to reveal some powerful secret, but just when you think the secret will be revealed, it isn't and then the movie is over.

The CGI was also weak.  The aliens look like a combination of a tree and an octopus.  Close Encounters of the Third Kind, Alien and a few other past alien movies were vastly superior.

People were making jokes about how bad this film was as they left the theater.  Do your self  a favor and don't waste your money on this dull awful film.

"Arrival" is a science fiction film that came out yesterday and really has not made too many splashes as far as publicity goes. Many of you probably have heard the title but not much else. I would say that it is worth your time in the sense that it is unique as far as science fiction movies go. In short, "Arrival" deals with an alien visitation to earth. I want to highlight the term "visitation" because this is not one of the many alien invasion movies that have been churning out since the 1950's (possibly earlier). Rather the film focuses in on the struggles of contact that Earth would have should an alien visitation occur because of an obvious language barrier. Enter Amy Adams who plays a celebrated linguist commissioned by the Defense Department to assist in making contact with these aliens who have landed their ships in twelve locations around the world. In her quest to learn more about the extraterrestrial anomalies that have arrived on our planet she makes many discoveries the greatest of these being within herself.
Visionary director Denis Villenueve (director of Sicario) tries his hand at the sci-fi genre and succeeds in creating a unique and thought provoking take on globalism, communication, time, and perspective all wrapped up in the mystery of the unknown. 
Caution: This movie requires you to invest in it in order to have the best experience, both intellectually, and somewhat emotionally. Do not zone out during this movie otherwise you will miss something key. If you're looking for an action flick with tons of explosions, laser beams, abductions, and burning cities this movie isn't for you. However if you're a fan of philosophy and the science fiction genre--not just the invasion thriller, you will appreciate the unique perspective that "Arrival" has to offer. Also if you're a fan of linguistics you will also appreciate this movie as it really focuses on the study of language and how incredible it really is. It was very eye-opening for me.
Horribly slow, worst movie I have seen in years.

So much more than I expected. Trippy, deeply moving. I sobbed. Not delicate tears dripping down my cheeks but can't catch my breath sobs. I was trying so hard not to disturb the people around me, but I couldn't help it. Bring a thick washcloth or handkerchief to sob into. I can't stop thinking about the movie. Can't remember the last time a movie affected me this profoundly.
Arrival is a thought-provoking and layered film. It's a little too slow-paced for my taste, but there is a good payoff for the patient viewer.

WARNING: If the recent Independence Day movie is your idea of a good scifi movie, this film is not for you. Of all the alien encounter movies in the genre, Arrival may be the most believable, and surprisingly moving, entry yet.

A very enjoyable movie- I loved the cinematography and the bleak moodiness. Amy Adams, my favorite actress, was really wonderful.
I had a few problems with it, though. First of all, they seemed to mumble a lot and it was often hard to catch what they were saying ( maybe it was the theater's speakers). Also, why, in this beautiful and profound film, did they call the two aliens Abbott and Costello? I found this to be demeaning and disrespectful to these brilliant, sensitive beings. Quite a thoughtless choice. And finally, as much as I enjoyed it, the ending was disappointing. 
Couldn't it have been left that she was an extraordinary linguist and compassionate woman who has the intuition to understand what's happening? Suddenly it seems that the most important thing is that she finds a man and has another baby. What?? C'mon Hollywood!!
give me back my 2 hours....

This movie was absolutely horrible!! It was a waste of two hours and $12.50. This dimly shot confusing mess of a movie drags on and on. Every time you think it's over it just continues on. The only reason I saw this cinematic disaster was because of the husband. We have different tastes in movies but I decided to give this one a chance and unfortunately, we were both left thoroughly disappointed. Between Amy Adams's heavy breathing, Jeremy Renner's pointless character, and Forest Whitaker's bad accident I was left hating life and Rotten Tomatoes for giving it such high reviews.

This film is one of the most brilliantly written Science Fiction films I have ever seen.  This film is more than just about meeting aliens.  It's about the three ideologies of globalization around the world, particularly Constructivism where ideas are the main exchange.  It shows how governments would likly react based on culture and language.  Language is the biggest aspect of the film and shows that the main thing that makes us who we are and makes us as intelligent is that we have them.  They are all linear languages, from a start to an end, which is how we think of time.  But the way these other beings think of time is soon exposed in their own language...and it's so complex that I am amazed at how the concept was even born.  It is estimated that humans can only comprehend 4% of every concept we have, the spectrums of light, sound, waves, etc.  That aside, it may take several viewings to get more and more out of it to discuss it because this is a thinking man's film.  I plan to for sure.

This sci-fi  movie delivers more than aliens. Thoughtful, intelligent and well-acted. An updated version of The Day the Earth Stood Still (which in the midst of the cold war was ahead of its time) with restrained  special effects and careful pacing.

It's hard to imagine having a film about aliens and not dealing with the same cliched plotlines.  "Arrival"  is a thoughtful and mesmerzing sci/fi drama that is wonderfully acted, especially by Amy Adams.  It is hypnotic and hard to firget.

Was very much looking forward to seeing this.  The optics are great, alien storyline interesting but nothing crazy out of the ordinary.  I was waiting for something more fantastic to happen but it never came.  The 'mystery' of the whole movie came and went too softly imo.  Still recommend but those expecting something like "Contact" may be a bit disappointed.
Amazing just amazing
The movie of the year.

If you are at all interested in this film, please go see it in theaters and support the film and the filmmakers so we can see more original movies instead of remakes and reboots. I promise you won't be let down.

I very much appreciate what this movie is/was going for. It takes a lot influence from 2001 as far as its tone and its aesthetics, which is a huge plus for me, but it just lacks the level of craft necessary to pull it off all the way. The cinematography of the movie isn't... bad, per se, but it's very very distracting. The director really REALLY likes putting things in and out of focus for seemingly no reason, and It made me very angry the whole time. As far as the story, I'm so happy that we got an alien invasion movie that was not an action movie. it has a lot of fantastic ideas, but never really got as deep into those ideas as I was hoping it would, especially as the 3rd act was beginning to show its hand. The characters in this movie are about as flat as you can get, which was the film's biggest flaw considering that the emotional punch of the film was treated as the centerpiece. All in all, I'd say worth one watch for fans of Sci-Fi, but it's not required viewing.

Dos frases clave para "entender" este bello filme: "Si pudieras ver tu vida de principio a fin, ¿qué parte escogerías volver a vivir?", y "Quizás la razón por la que estás solo, es que cada vez sabes más". Las referencias a "Contact", "2001", "The tree of life", "Solaris", y tantas que no menciono, son ínfimas con la belleza que esta peli es por sí sola. Amy Adams nació para hacer este filme (y tan gorda que me cae). Y lo mejor de todo, como fan de Umberto Eco (como semiólogo, no tanto como novelista) puedo asegurar que si viviera, estaría orgulloso de esta obra maestra, como también lo estaría Carl Sagan. TENGO que verla de nuevo. OJO: No es para cualquiera.

1.5/5.  Technically marvelous.  The first two acts set up a very intriguing tale.  However, the 3rd act ruins everything because Arrival refuses to acknowledge that Amy Adams' character is a terrible human being with such revolting morality that it spoils any positive qualities the film has.

Close Encounters with the killer clown tomatoes from outer space except that this time the tomatoes are eggs.  Well, half eggs...

Do you remember Close Encounters of the Third Kind?  A movie that while you watched you were just hoping it would get better if you just waited a bit more?  Then the end came and you walked out thinking "well that sucked, but at least I have a cool song in my head".  Remember that?  It's the same thing here except you don't get a cool song.  You leave wanting those last 2 hours back.  When I left the person in front of me looked at his girlfriend and said "next time I pick the damn movie".  She agreed.  Yes, it's that boring.

Now these critters that look like the yip yips from Sesame Street got it on with a 7 legged giraffe land ships in 12 different places on the globe.  Their ever so clever spaceship can travel space in an instant and appear out of nowhere.  They hover above the ground without any energy being used.  They can do all that yet the people in the ship have to be taught to communicate using a white board and a glorified version of "Dick and Jane".  Ok, maybe a little more advanced.  Let's say a glorified version of "On We Go!".  Google it.  You'll understand.  These highly advanced creatures are her toooooooo:  help us work together.  See that's it.  They sit there looking cool and making cool drawings and then just when we figure out what they want, they disappear.  Toss in a wibbly wobbly timey wimey worst Dr. Who episode ending and you get Arrival.  The ONLY reason to see this is Amy Adams.  Not because she does some great acting job.  No.  Because she's a hot redhead with cute eyes.  Or if you're a woman, Jeremy Renner.  That's it.  It's boring as hell if you take out the eye candy.

I guess the best way to sum this up is this:  Let's say, you see a van.  On the van it says "Free Candy" and you go into the van.  But there's no free candy.  Far from free candy.  Only tears and wishes that you never went into that van.  This movie is that van.  Don't go into the theater for this movie...

What a pleasure it is to watch a well-rounded sci-fi flick. They are few and far between. With reminders of Chris Nolan's underdeveloped yet drawn out Interstellar, and Jeff Nichol's semi-decent addition to the genre with Midnight Special -- Denis Villeneuve takes first place with this film. It has the right tone, story progression and development, and an entrancing score by Jóhann Jóhannsson that makes the aliens' presence all the more real. I definitely have taken great interest in all of Villeneuve's work and can't wait to see what is ahead for him.

Arrival is not for everyone. This film really takes its pacing seriously and that might not mesh with many viewers. I personally felt that the film offers moments wonderfully so that we can experience these phenomenon in real time. Moments in the first half of the film moved very slowly and felt much like "a day in the life" which works well with these realistic depictions of fantastical circumstances. So many films feel rushed and crunch down moments of great significance so the film has a shorter run time...and thus appeases the masses. While only running just under two hours, Arrival did not feel rushed at all. This allows for the viewer to really engage in the story and really the fascinating social sciences of language.

Ill end this here...go see it.

This movie has been added to my "All-Time Favorites" list. It communicates the problem of intra- and inter-species communication so eloquently, poignantly, and succinctly, that I was inspired to use these aforementioned adjectives in an admittedly vain attempt to convey how much this movie meant to me. Not to mention the artful display of the underlying theme of our perception of time versus a more alien perception of time. There's so much more I could say, but I think it'd be better if you just watch the movie for yourself -- definitely a must see!
So well done... So well done.  No cheesy bullshit, just straight up real and clean sci-fi with solid acting and dialogue to boot.  This will be one of the greats.  Must see in the theater!

First off the critics - They must love Arrival because it's brainy. Terms like "non-zero sum game" and "non-linear time" among a ton of other "brainy" ideas are tossed about. Second off - the pacing. This is a movie about ALIENS THAT HAVE COME TO EARTH and yet, nothing and I mean nothing exciting happens in the first 45 minutes until we see what they look like. Most of the movie is spent getting to know the aliens. It's very sweet but I had trouble staying awake. 
     The "message" - The reviews I read got all gooey about this. "We will see TIME in a whole new light. At the end I was going, "Huh" What's the big point I was led to believe would come just before the credits. There is one line - "If you knew how your life would go, everything that will happen to you, would you still live it?"  Interesting point. They should have posted that meme on Facebook and dispensed with all the trouble that went into making this clinker.

Absolutely adore this movie. I found it refreshing, intriguing and thought provoking, especially for a science fiction movie. I loved that the movie really delved into communication and time. This movie was soooo slow and bad that I can't imagine how boring the book is, I really feel like the movie studio should refund my money. I loved interstellar, gravity, contact, 2001 and many others in this genre, but this was horrible. So bad I was actually mad I paid for it.

those of you who don't like to think, then pass on it because it is a deep and thoughtful movie that makes you really work at figuring it out. I liked it a lot...probably a 4 but as much as I am still thinking through it I may raise to a 4.5./ But the pace is slow with some excitement here and there, and it makes a global statement as well as a sociolofical statement. WORSTE_MOVIE_EVER OMG I Seriously cannot recall a movie this bad in my entire life. Visual effects: Terrible, Sound: Terrible, Story line: Terrible. When we did finally leave, I mentioned how bad it was and a lady in the hallway said that she had walked out it was so bad.

If you're the kind of person who looks at their watch if something hasn't exploded after five seconds, you'll hate Arrival. If you're the kind of person who spends their evenings questioning existential paradigms about the complexity of human relationships and our reliance on abstract notions of free will and adherence to fate while pretending to like indie films that you have to think way too hard about, you'll love Arrival. I loved Arrival, so I'm not sure what that says about me, but it probably explains why I have Godzilla posters in my apartment. It's best seen blindly, and by that I don't mean you should blindfold yourself, but you should go see it without reading any reviews. Which you just broke by reading this review. You ruined it. Hope you're proud of yourself. It's moving, beautiful, and I'm pretty mad at myself for not coming up with it first. One day...

Just a phenomenal, fairly straightforward (if you're paying attention) sci-fi film that is elevated by beautiful cinematography, heady ideas, taut and slow building tension, and incredible star turn performances. The visuals are truly notable, like all of Villeneuve's films - but especially here, the shot composition and long takes are very different from the typical fast-cut and frenetic style of science fiction. There's nothing I can say about Amy Adams, I think, that hasn't been already, but she really is charged with carrying the movie and does so flawlessly.
The ending introduces some plot holes, or questions perhaps that the film can't fully answer, but is smart enough to leave room for audience interpretation and allow us to interpret certain aspects the way that we'd like to. Arrival isn't world-shattering, and I think that's to its benefit. Sometimes people just want a fantastic, well-crafted *movie* that treats its audience with respect instead of prioritizing indulging the director or screenwriter, and Arrival does exactly that.
Thought provoking. It's quiet and cerebral. It challenges your thinking of alien encounters and our humanity. My husband and I will be talking about this for weeks.

ARRIVAL is an excellent film. Four stars (out of 4).
Amy Adams should get an Oscar nomination for her leading role as a linguist - all others are supporting parts to her strong performance as a world leading linguist. I was surprised how closely the movie stayed to the original novella by Ted Chiang - the story is in my original anthology book "Starlight 2" which I bought in 1998; the story, "STORY OF YOU LIFE" by Chiang won the Nebula in 2000; it's the highest/most prestigious award a science fiction author can win. The story and the movie are moving and proper adult science fiction. It exceeded my expectations seeing it on its premier day in USA. The actual running time of the movie is 1:50 (8 mins. are closing credits, so it totals 1:58). The aliens are radially symmetric septapods and rather advanced. Please see this movie if this is the type of stuff you will enjoy, talk about, and appreciate. Time & gravity are twisted as well and language and communication (written and "spoken") concepts and understanding between the alien visitors and nations of the earth. Go see this -- go think and reflect on what this story has to say.
Excellent movie!  Thought provoking and engaging from beginning to end.  Can't wait to see it again!

An intellectual's science fiction. It eases you slowly into a sense of the vast, with deep thoughts about language and physics. Based on a short story by one of the best writers around now, Ted Chiang. Worth it to both read the story and see the movie. Why are you still reading this? Go see this movie!
Arrival doesn't rely on flashy special effects and action to please sci-fi fans, but rather through intelligent storytelling, a star-powered cast, and a strong emotional experience!

When a movie is such that its genre is difficult to nail down, the combination of words used to describe what kind of movie it is are significant. There is a difference between a crime drama and a crime thriller, and between an action fantasy and an adventure fantasy, and between a horror thriller and just plain horror. The difference is usually a matter of focus and emphasis. So, when you go on imdb.com and see "Arrival" (PG-13, 1:56) categorized as "Drama, Mystery, Sci-Fi", you can be sure that distinguishes it from, say, the "Star Trek" films, most of which are listed as "Action, Adventure, Sci-Fi". "Arrival" is one of those movies that's hard to pigeon-hole. If it helps, I'll tell you that I see this film as 20% "Independence Day", 50% "Contact", 10% "It's a Wonderful Life" and about 20% other movies which I can't mention in this review without spoiling the movie's twists and reveals... even if they are kind of predictable.

"Arrival" centers around Dr. Louise Banks (multiple Oscar nominee Amy Adams), a brilliant linguistics professor at an unnamed university. The film opens with a montage of Louise as a single mother raising an intelligent and creative daughter who ends up tragically taken by an unnamed disease before reaching adulthood (not a spoiler, because this all happens in the film's first five minutes and is used mainly as character development). These scenes show Louise to be a doting mother, who is devastated by her daughter's premature death and has an understandably difficult time getting on with her life.

When 12 huge objects which look like filled-in canoes arrive from outer space and park themselves vertically just above the surface of the earth in seemingly random and mostly remote locations all around the globe, people panic, riot and... wonder. These things are just sitting there, not doing anything. The militaries which protect the countries where these objects are hovering discover that every 18 hours, a door opens at the bottom of each space ship, allowing humans to enter and attempt to communicate with the 7-legged, octopus-like beings which "speak" in seemingly random sounds.

Army Colonel Weber (Oscar winner Forest Whitaker), who is in charge of the site around a ship floating over the state of Montana, comes to the office of Dr. Banks (who had previously done some translation for the military and still holds a Top Secret clearance) to enlist her help. Louis is paired with theoretical physicist Ian Donnelly (multiple Oscar nominee Jeremy Renner) and, within hours, the two of them are accompanying Col. Weber and several military technicians into the Montana ship every  3/4 of a day, interacting with two large septapods (as they label them) floating in a cloud behind a transparent wall.

The process of communication goes frustratingly slowly. After Louis and Ian decide to remove their protective suits (so the aliens can better "see" them), the septapods begin communicating by spraying onto the barrier an ink-like substance that forms circles with different combinations and configurations of bumps and swirls on the outside of each. Louise and Ian painstakingly figure out the meaning of these circles and how to use the heptapods' written language to find out why they came to earth. Meanwhile, U.S. military and political leaders, whose concerns are voiced by an on-site C.I.A. representative, Agent Halpern (Michael Stuhlbarg), are growing impatient, while international military officers, following the lead of China's General Shang (Tzi Ma), are pushing for decisive action.

"Arrival" offers up an original and very human, but rather dull sci-fi story. It's more intellectual than action-packed in nature and doesn't need battle scenes or imminent threats to the survival of mankind to make its point, but it could've used a more engaging plot. The movie ends up being not much more than a 2-hour sermon about embracing life with all of its ups and downs, which isn't enough to justify the film's long, slow build. Director Denis Villeneuve and screenwriter Eric Heisserer (adapting Ted Chiang's multiple award-winning 1998 novella "Story of Your Life") arrive at the moral of the story in a way that's creative and memorable (and the cast is outstanding), but the journey is too tedious. "B-"

So many film these days follow predictable beats and a standard predictable formula. This film though, is a real breath of fresh air, with an intriguing and thought provoking plot and some unexpected surprises. 
The premise sounds like an easy sell - aliens arrive on earth and languages expert Amy Adams must help decipher their communications. So, loads of explosions and a mega fight at the end right? Macho heroes with big guns? What we get instead is a decidedly cerebral drama, that owes more to 2001 than Independence Day (thank goodness!) with a quietly wonderful central performance from Amy Adams. I loved the look of this film (and desperately want Amy Adams' gorgeous lakeside house!) but equally great was the elegiac soundtrack and the dazzling production design of the alien ships. Just as the aliens language redefines our ideas of structure, the film cleverly plays with our ideas of storytelling and chronology.
Possibly a bit lacking in action to be a mega hit, this is  more of an art house sci fi epic, with less bullshit than Interstellar!

Arrival is one of those movies where you understand you're waiting for the resolve to see if it justifies the journey we've taken to (pun intended) arrive there. This doesn't mean the one hundred minutes prior aren't fascinating and worthwhile, but it's clear we're ultimately waiting to see what bigger picture these pieces are painting. This can of course be something of a double-edged sword given how the approach effects the re-watchability of a picture, but by the time we come around to the conclusion of Arrival it only seems repeat viewings will do nothing but make it more moving if not add shades and complexities to small nuances we may not have noticed upon that initial viewing. In other words, Arrival is a masterfully told narrative that deals in themes of interpretation and perspective through conveyors such as language and the guise of an alien invasion movie. What's interesting though is, despite the marketing, Arrival is hardly about an alien invasion, but more a film about communication and figuring out one another before jumping to conclusions based on cultural precedent or expectation. Arrival is about that fear of what we don't know and how such a phrase manifests when a genuine situation arises that it can be applied to. In the barrage of CGI summer blockbusters that depict alien invasions more as mass extinctions it's become easy to feel nonchalant about the ramifications of proof of life beyond our earth and solar system legitimately existing and furthermore, showing up in our backyard. In Arrival, director Denis Villeneuve conjures not only a palpable fear and panic that would sweep across nations in light of such events, but more he and specifically Amy Adams in an absolutely stellar performance highlight the sheer incomprehensibility of the situation. Giving insight to the smaller moments, recognizing the first time Jeremy Renner's Ian Donnelly touches the material this alien craft is constructed from as a major moment rather than choosing to ignore its significance speaks volumes. In this way, moments that are actually bigger play as that much more profound. Villeneuve is a master of restraint and the slow burn as he has shown in previous features such as Enemy and Sicario, but Arrival may be his most accomplished work to date as not only is it visually enrapturing, but the larger ideas the film has on its mind are applied to its precise visual sense giving the experience an all-around aura of awe.

Wow.  This was one of the best movies I have seen in years. Moving and thoughtful sci-fi from the Director of Sicario.
When mysterious spacecraft touch down across the globe, an elite team - led by expert linguist Louise Banks - is brought together to investigate. As mankind teeters on the verge of global war, Banks and the team race against time for answers - and to find them, she will take a chance that could threaten her life, and quite possibly humanity.
An oscar worthy turn by Amy Adams is the films main talking point but everything on display here is expertly crafted. The cinematography & score are brilliant as well as the riveting screenplay. The aliens themselves look great too and the way they communicate is excellently realised. In fact another strong aspect of the film is its realism.
This won't be everyone's cup of tea, this is not about aliens levelling famous landmarks but what you get instead is a film full of ideas and genuine emotion.
There are scenes here that will make you shed a tear and it has an emotional gut punch of an ending.
Director Denis Villeneuve is fast becoming a major Hollywood player. Sicario is excellent but this is his finest film to date, it bodes well for his Blade Runner sequel due next August.
Arrival is a film that will be in your thoughts long after you have left the cinema, its uplifting quality is just the tonic we need after recent world events.
Believe the hype.

So I liked this movie, but maybe not for the reasons you may think.  It's slow and atmospheric and about problem-solving and communication.  The trailers show the alien spacecraft descending on Earth and parking themselves in various places, so you may think it's a typical sci-fi action-type flick.  It's most definitely not.  It's more sentimental and thought-provoking.  There's not a lot of tension, although the film tries to inject some.  It's different and I admire that; too often, alien invasion flicks are all templated schlock.  But I have a feeling that many people will go into this expecting one thing and come out disappointed because they don't get it.

The one thing I always look for in science fiction films whether they challenge our current viewpoints on reality, humanity, and time.  Arrival manages to do all of these things and more.  It's yet another masterful job of directing from Denis Villeneuve.

I have seen all of Villeneuve's feature length films except for his first, but I think Arrival may be his best work to date.  Yes, that includes the beautifully tragic Incendies.  And the gripping and visceral, Prisoners. Or the twisted Enemy.  And even last year's hit, Sicario.  Villeneuve brings the best qualities from all those films and brings them to one of the best sci-fi films in recent memory.

What makes Arrival so impressive is that it never forces the audience to take a leap of faith in logic or principles.  You know from the very beginning that it's going to be a grounded story told in a slow-burn style, and it delivers.  I was never sitting in my seat hoping for a groundbreaking twist or a shocking death, I just let the story be told.  And it's quite the story.

Amy Adams stars as a linguist who begins to work with the military once 12 massive and mysterious shells appear hovering around different areas of the world.  Adams is expectedly amazing and balances vulnerability and strength so incredibly well.  The film also balances a surprisingly human story with a global scope well.  I knew the original title for the film was titled "Story of Your Life", but I can't say I expected such a grand idea to feel so personally important, especially for Adam's character.  But this balance, was what I enjoyed most about Arrival.  It makes for some surprising and satisfying reveals later on in the film.

The entire sound department and production design team also deserve a ton of credit.  Sometimes you forget how important sound is in films, whether that be a score, random noises, or the lack of sound altogether.  I can't tell you how impactful the sounds in this film have on setting the tone and feel of each scene.  Equally as important are establishing the visuals appropriate for the tone you're going for.  The cinematography by Bradford Young as well as the production design from Patrice Vermette deserve some serious recognition come awards season.

Arrival in many ways is an extremely important film right now in our world.  It exemplifies what we can do together if we overcome our differences globally.  That togetherness is something the film tackles in a refreshingly unique way.  Normally, when sci-fi's attempt to tell a story about a potential alien invasion, Hollywood chooses to focus on merely America's side to things.  Rarely do we get to see the entire world have to work together to overcome whatever issues the film presents, and that was pretty cool to see.  For me, this film is not only important but groundbreaking.  Some of the storytelling devices Villeneuve uses to convey language, communication, love, time, humanity and many others are unique and gratifying to see in this particular film.  Go see this.

+Villeneuve does it again

+Adams deserves an Oscar

+Use of sound and visuals

+Unique

+Global and personal

10/10

Brilliant, lyrical, interesting, and original scifi movie on Alien first contact. Amy Adams is brilliant and carries the bulk of the movie as she learns the Alien language and keeps replaying memories of her daughter, which somehow connect to the Aliens. It is surprising and smart, and probably a bit slow for some scifi fans. Director does a great job bringing the films' plot and the actors together in what becomes a surprise ending.Best new film out, so don't miss it.

I really don't know how this movie get those amazing scores... it is BORING! it's so slow, and the plot is so dull. only 2 positives - it looks good, and the soundtrack is good. don't waste your time in cinema. watch at home only if you have to...

An extremely intelligent film that's more about fears of our own humanity than it is about an alien invasion. Arrival makes you think and pay attention and never panders to an audience looking to be handed over the answers to all the questions this film poses. 

The journey of figuring it out as the scenes played out was one of the most satisfying parts of Arrival. It was one great big puzzle.This is Amy Adams' film with a great support from Jeremy Renner and Forest Whitaker. Superbly acted. 

Poignant but so very relevant to what has transpired in our real lives recently. 
The message...  Humanity needs to work together, resolve their differences, in order to find a solution from an unknown, alien threat. It's time to communicate.

So imagine if aliens come to earth and what our response would be if they opened their spaceship doors and wanted to communicate.  This is the basic premise behind The Arrival, and much like Director Denis Villeneuve's film Sicario last year, I liked this one very much but just a little less then that one.  The Arrival is a real thinker of a film and with that I would say there is a time it plots along in the middle, but you will find out that it is pretty much necessary for the payoff in the final act.  I really would like to watch the final 30 minutes again as I've been putting all the pieces to this movie puzzle together for the last 12-18 hours.  This is Amy Adams's movie and make no mistake about it.  She shows a ton of vulnerability and I think it comes of very genuinely.  The rest of the cast is also very solid.  The score and scope of the film is beautiful and will raise some goosebumps at least it did for me.  I've seen comparisons to Close Encounters and Contact and Interstellar, but I don't think that does this movie justice.  I thing there is some real authenticity here and no cheap stolen moments from other films which I really appreciate in this world of sequels and retreads.  I'm not saying everyone will enjoy this film, but man I sure did.
This movie was not what I expected, slow not that interesting and confusing. Wait for the DVD to come out save your money.

Arrival is definitely in the running for the most interesting piece of the year, possibly the last five years. An interesting narrative with an even more interesting way of telling it, Arrival keeps the audience engaged and at the edge of the seats the whole 2 hours. Although the central idea of the movie-what time-space really is-has been explored in recent years in pieces such as Interstellar, Arrival tackled this theme with a completely opposite and extremely refreshing angle. Instead of trying to save a near apocalypse world, Villeneuve asked the question perfectly summarized by a line in the movie: "If you can see your life from start to finish, would you change anything?" Arrival also remarkably avoided the trap of letting the star, instead of script, carry the plot, as often seen in recent space movies, i.e. the Martian with Matt Damon, Interstellar with Matthew McConaughey, etc. However, that is not to take anything from Amy Adams, who delivered a fantastic performance in the lead role. She truly captured the brave yet terrified emotion a normal human would exhibit during an alien encounter. All of these made Arrival, although a scifi/fantasy, an extremely relatable and thought-provoking piece. You'll leave the theater not thinking "that was a bad*** man/woman saving the world" as in most similar pieces, but contemplating life and thinking what you would have done in the situation. The only blemish is that towards the end it felt a little rushed, too overly dramatic, and fell to the cliché "the world is in trouble and I have to save it," but it quickly came back to deliver the ending it deserved. Overall, if you want to be entertained, if you want to be kept at the edge of your seat for 2 hours, if you want a piece that will make you smile, gasp, cry, and think for days, go see Arrival
brilliant! Only reason it didn't get a 5 is because of all the unanswered questions

Films like Seven, Signs, The Sixth Sense, Babel, 2001: A Space Odyssey, The Others, Fight Club, Psycho (Alfred Hitchcock's Masterpiece), De JÃ¡ Vu, Saving Private Ryan, Inside Man, Cast Away, Good Will Hunting, etc. Speaking of the past, this movie tackles such narratives as that but in a subtle and interesting I will not get into any details since I do not want to spoil the film. What I am going to say about this film is that it's a must watch. Here's a tip: pay 100% complete attention or you will be lost. The ending is worth all the information you will have to follow and it will deserve a second viewing guarantee it. 9/10

How can I possibly explain this without saying too much? Okay, no spoilers.

1)-This film is beautiful in every way: it's visually stunning, yet simple, realistic, yet also fantastical in an almost tangible way. The sound design, ship effects and creature effects are all minimal and yet timeless and perfect. The script is creative, technically strong and different than most anything else out there.

2)-But it has one weakness and that weakness is the same one that most "deep" films have: it isn't as deep as it thinks it is and it presents certain human problems at certain key plot points very two dimensionally, but not as badly as many other sci-fi films (like Trek)... it's more that certain philosophical concepts pivotal to the film are deep and cool, but they're ultimately absurd and are a real reach. it's almost a New Age optimistic fantasy.

 But don't get me wrong, it's all handled so much better than most films with a similar philosophical problem that it can almost be forgiven.

advice: if you love the ideas in The Fountain, Interstellar, Memento and Star Trek TNG, you'll love it. My philosophical problems with it might not be shared with most people, but it's core doesn't extend much further than this philosophy... which limits how much you can enjoy it.

I was so looking forward to this one! Couldn't wait to go see it! To say that I was disappointed is a gross understatement! I am not the type who needs high-paced action, sex, or special effects overload to be satisfied with a movie; quite the contrary! I enjoy a good love story from time to time, and I love a good think piece anytime! However, I do not enjoy movies that come off as incoherent or paradoxical (Interstellar and Prometheus come to mind as the kind of rubbish I'm talking about). If you liked Prometheus or Interstellar then perhaps you'll like Arrival as well? I thought all three were mostly a waste of time! I found myself sapped of energy by the time Arrival was over; wondering what in the helli I just saw - and wondering why so much money was spent making a film based on such a 'meh' story?! In a word, I was bored! At the end I was confused and left without enough energy or enough concern to even try to sort it all out. This is not the director's fault, It's just that the storyline promises great interest and fails to deliver. If you go to a movie with the express purpose of coming away being able to say things like "the directing was first rate!" or "the cinematography was breathtaking!" or "the musical score was fantastic!" or "the CGI was out of this world!" --all worthy considerations to be sure - then this is the film for you! However, if you're looking for a story with a climax or a satisfying plot twist then you might want to look elsewhere!

Arrival is a very good film, but it isn't genre redefining. 

It is a bit sad that a script like this passes as "for the thinking person's sci-fi" because any thinking person will scratch their head as two why there is only one language specialist, no biologist, etc. in the team.

Any person who knows real scientists will also find the characters to be Hollywood fantasies (as usual), i.e., artificial constructions that tick the "movie scientist" box but are pretty far removed from reality.  

The film takes its time regarding the communication with the aliens first (good) but omits basic principles of communicating with someone (why did the script not take clues of human kind's authentic attempts to communicate with an alien species?) with a different language, and unsatisfyingly very suddenly jumps to complex forms of communication. 

Also, script writers seem to help themselves from same ideas box all the time. Can we have a sci-fi movie that does not play on the Interstellar theme (which was not new then and does not explain how the paradoxes of non-linear time are avoided)? 

I don't want to complain too much because I enjoyed the film which was in large parts to Amy Adams' fantastic performance. She easily carries the story which is saying a lot (no spoilers, but only a very few select actors could have made it work like Adams did). 

I also enjoyed the film because it was about more than aliens arriving and trying to learn to speak to them. But a 96% critics rating is just putting up the expectations in regions that are not justified for this effort which is very good (if you can accept the basic premiss which not everyone will be able to do), but not excellent as in flawless.
Sometimes it is not entertaining to have to think that hard to follow the plot. It was not  at the level of Contact or Interstellar there was no WOW moment.

Breathtaking on every level, anchored by Amy Adams at her best, and a much needed story of hope in our trying times. good. Villenueve fans are in for another treat, as he hasn't made a single bad 
film yet. Overall, Amy Adams magnificently carries this film, it is her film, and altough the supporting cast was great, it is her film.
When the moment of truth arrives, it can peak one's curiosity in riveting ways by commenting on the nature of human perception paralleled to nature of film perception.

Arrival wants to be profound, and it is.  It wants to have a deeper meaning, and it does.  It also wants to get the audience emotionally attached to its characters, and here is where the film fails miserably.  2/3 isn't bad, but emotional attachment can make or break a film like this.  Amy Adams does her role justice, but the supporting characters around her make the film fall apart.  In other words, I feel that restricting the audiences view so often to only Adam's point of view is the reason there is no emotional attachment to the characters.  Interstellar made you care about Murph, not just because she was Cooper's daughter, but because you actually got to know Murph.  You loved her inquisitive nature, and you felt the connection between them.  In Arrival, Hannah is just Amy Adam's doomed daughter.  While you naturally feel empathy for a parent losing a child, you don't actually know Hannah.

There is something to be said for a film wanting to be profound, but that does not mean that having no comic relief is a good idea...comic relief helps with character attachment.

It's basically Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventure when nobody knows who steals Ted's father's keys.  In that movie it's hilarious when Bill & Ted find out that they in fact took the keys, but in a serious movie like The Arrival, it's a plot hole that I can't get over.  Hard to describe it without ruining the movie but it's maddening.

Non-action science fiction films are becoming rarer than hen's teeth in mainstream cinema, usually skipping the big screen for a video-on-demand release due to their tight budgets. The one-two punch of this year's Midnight Special and Arrival will hopefully change that. Fresh off the modern masterpiece that is Sicario, director Denis Villeneuve again showcases his incredible talent by crafting a deeply thought-provoking motion picture that credits its audience with the sort of intelligence and maturity so few movies are willing to do. When alien spaceships appear in 12 random locations around the globe, the international community must band together to figure out who controls these vessels and, more importantly, what their purpose on Earth is. Enter Dr. Louise Banks (Amy Adams - amazing), a professor of language who is brought in to communicate with the extra-terrestrials aboard the spacecraft situated in Montana. Banks has her own personal problems though, with memories of her dead daughter permeating throughout her thoughts. These two coinciding plots are handled with immense care and precision, ultimately bringing an intense poignancy to the overall story that culminates in a fantastic final act twist. The unpredictability of the reveal is inarguably clever, but it's the extra layer of emotional depth it adds that really hits home. The imagery is spectacular too: the alien vessels are simple yet beautiful; the squid-like creatures are simultaneously frightening and graceful; and the gravity-defying environment inside the ship is presented with subtle wonder. The icing on the cake is the profound auditory experience that the film offers, with the glorious, otherworldly sound design and an affecting, sonorous score conducted by Jóhann Jóhannsson (whose Sicario score should've won the Oscar earlier this year). A contemplative movie that eschews big budget action for provocative musing, Arrival is a tense, emotional and utterly gripping sci-fi drama.
A mind-blowing and thought provoking cinema experience. Very satisfying and visually beautiful.

When Sci-Fi is implemented on screen in a auteuristic manor, from a director who has been known to make viewers think long and hard about what they have just witnessed, it goes without question that you should be going into Arrival expecting something profound. I will start off by admitting that there is no way everyone will be happy with this film. If you lose interest in any moment, the final impact of the finale will have you bored and scratching your head. That being said, the underlying message that is slowly being revealed throughout the course of this film is more than worth the price of admission. If you are sucked into this story, it will be very hard to find any glaring flaws with its narrative, but it is told in such an unconventional way that viewers may check out 20 minutes in. For myself, this is one of the smartest and most profound viewing experience I have had all year. Here is why Arrival is modern cinema at its finest.

To put it in layman's terms, Arrival is simply about an alien race that lands on multiple areas of the earth. A team of scientists and a linguist are recruited to explore the ship in order to discover the purpose for their visit. Flashing back and forth to scenes that makes no sense until the conclusion of the film, it requires your undivided attention and possibly multiple viewings to full grasp everything that is being shown to you. Average moviegoers who expect to see an exciting alien invasion picture might as well stay as far away from this film as possible, because although it may seem like a simple story of a group of people trying to learn an alien language, there is much more going on behind the scenes, making this one hell of a roller coaster ride if you follow every frame and line of dialogue.

My first word of advice before entering a screening of Arrival would be to make sure that you are completely awake for the proceeding two hours to come. The third act, revealing why everything had been shown in a certain order is out of the world genius. Some people may not feel the impact if the film did not have your attention from the very beginning, but it will remain in your thoughts for days to come. There is so much to absorb in the final act, but it helps when you enjoy the presence of the story's core characters. Amy Adams and Jeremy Renner work very well together and although it seems like they are meant to be on the same team together, there is so much more to come. For a film that is about an alien race coming down to earth, I am surprised that aspect was the least necessary portion of the film, while simultaneously being the most essential to the plot.

Many people will walk out with different opinions on this picture hands down, but it is all about how you interpret the film for yourself. Yes, there is a specific message being told, but there are so many other aspects that require your attention that you may just find yourself lying in bed at night trying to decipher it. I almost feel that I am reviewing this film prematurely, but I think I will still feel that way after 5-10 viewings of it. Arrival is a one of a kind film that I will find myself revisiting many times to try and get the most out of what director Denis Villeneuve has created. Due to the way this film was adapted by Eric Heirsserer, I was captivated from start to finish. How he was able to tell multiple stories that made no sense throughout the entire film, only to explain that those scenes are what made the most sense all along, is a twist within a twist if I've ever seen one.

I truly believe that hardcore fans of cinema will get the utmost out of this picture. The average moviegoer who does not know what they are getting themselves into, may not be too thrilled with the finished product. Arrival requires you to expand your imagination, as well as remember every single moment of the film in order to feel the full emotional impact. With jaw-dropping cinematography, impressive visuals for such a small budget, characters that you come to really care for by the end, and a perfect overall story when completed, Arrival is easily one of the most spectacular experiences you will have at the theatre this year. As much as I love this film, there will be many people who find it boring and uneventful, which I totally understand. The pacing of this film requires a lot of patience from its viewers, but I was so sucked into the experience that I forgot I was watching a fictional story at times. Arrival is one of my favourite films of the year, easily Villeneuve's best work in my opinion, and you will definitely be seeing some nominations come Oscar season. Once you know what you are in for, I honestly can't recommend checking out this film enough.

Denis Villeneuve (Prisoners [2013], Sicario [2015]) brings us Arrival a film about a linguis named Louise (Amy Adams) who is brought in by the military to communicate with aliens inside of a ship floating above Montana. Alongside her is a scientist named Ian (Jeremy Renner) who helps coordinate with the team and other scientists around the world trying to figure out why these aliens suddenly appeared. The film is shot beautifully. Some really great shots here and the score is excellent conveying a ton of emotions. The film itself runs a bit too slow though for me! It's literally segments of Louise trying to communicate with the creatures and figuring out their strange way of communication. The thing that make the movie worthwhile is its incredibly strange and bizarre twist! I won't say it here, because its a really good payoff. It ties everything together so well and as long as you pay attention during the film its really a beautiful ending. The movie won't be for everyone. It's very slow in the middle and you may be confused by the end. Give it a chance though and you may find a slightly sci-fi film that you can enjoy!

Anyone who likes an amazing nail biting drama has to see this hands down.

Another year, another highly anticipated film from acclaimed director Denis Villeneuve, the director of "Prisoners" and "Sicario" is back at it again this time in the science fiction genre with "Arrival" starring Amy Adams and Jeremy Renner. "Arrival" based off of the novel "Story of Your Life" follows expert linguist Louise Banks played by Amy Adams, who during an extraterrestrial invasion is contacted by the U.S. military to try and decipher their alien language, trying to find out what their purpose on earth is, do they want peace? Do they want war? Or maybe something else? Well that's for Louise to find out, but "Arrival" isn't really about that, it's a love story, it's a sort of coming of age story, a film about healing and revelation, beautifully told by Denis Villeneuve and writer Eric Heisserer. "Arrival" doesn't quite measure up to other works from Villeneuve, but it stands as one of the best science fiction films of the last 5-10 years.
A Must-see for cinema lovers.
8,6. Phenomenal Ending
This would make a perfect double-feature with Contact. This is that fantastically thought-out alien scifi gem that comes far too rarely. .. but that just makes it all the greater.

There are few movies from the sci-fi genre (or any genre, mind you) that take a step ahead and decide that maybe they should do something a little bit different. You know, introduce something old that maybe has been explored in cinema before, but from a new perspective. Arrival is a very human movie, a very realistic movie that takes its time to set up characters, that allows for some realism within a very unpredictable and controversial plot. The movie of course, is about human beings coming in first contact with aliens, almost entirely from the general perspective of a successful language interpreter. That's all I can say.  Science fiction is a genre that one day although has the word fiction in its name, could possibly come true (minus a few quite "over the top" exceptions). This film has such an incredible sense of emotion that is extremely affective thanks to terrific performances (Amy Adams' best, might I add) and an exceptional soundtrack with dark, yet perfectly fitting music. I wanted to save this for last. Denis Villeneuve is one of the best directors working today, and this movie confirms that. Every single shot is so pristine and works so well, adding to the overall tone and mood that the audience should feel. The ending is also very well done, and leaves plenty of thoughts for us as viewers while also having a chilling resolution. I can simply now say, Arrival is one of the greatest movies this year, and one of the greatest sci-fi movies of recent memory. Definitely see this one in theaters while you can.

Fascinating and wonderfully addictive. I couldn't take my eyes off the screen. This was the first time in a long time That I didn't start falling asleep in the theater. The acting was superb. The story was fresh and special effects were flawless. The events in the movie  made me feel like I was in the movie. I felt as though I was experiencing the moment of what it would actually be like if aliens did come to earth. There were no obvious holes in the story. The story felt real. Can't wait for this one to come out on DVD.

It's clever, I'll grant you that but it's slow. I went in expecting a cerebral sci-fi film and this is that but everything takes too long to happen, laboured by pretty but inconsequential shots that surround moments of happening. Jeremy Renner's character should have had more to do - some more back-and-forth with Amy Adams's character. As it is, he is merely a sounding board for her and someone to hang a plot point on. It lacks the oomph that recent high concept (or high octane) sci-fi outings such as Looper, Gravity, Interstellar and Ex Machina have had. A good story that could have been told better.
it's a lot like Contact. if you liked that movie you will like this one.

In the last few years we have seen an increase in intelligent films about space exploration and the possibility that something else may be out there. Arrival is one to add to that list with its insightful probe on how we communicate with extra-terrestrials. Don't worry; this feels more Close Encounters of the Third Kind than say the dreadful Independence Day Resurgence. This is the first of two high-profile films for Amy Adams this year. She also stars alongside Jake Gyllenhaal in Nocturnal Animals. Here she plays Dr. Louise Banks, a college professor who specializes in linguistics. What seemed like a normal day on campus is anything but that when she arrives to class to find that a majority of her students are gone or buried in their phones. There is breaking news that twelve space pods have landed across the world. They are egg-shaped and massive in size. Little is known about the pods but the U.S. Army has been able to successfully enter the pods and note the presence of an alien species. Dr. Banks is approached by Colonel Weber (Whitaker) of the Army to join their team and translate the communication that has been captured from the aliens. She's partnered with Dr. Ian Donnelly (Renner), a theoretical physicist who has a slighter different way of thinking about the origin of a species. Together they risk their lives by getting right up close with the aliens in order to bridge the gap of communication between each species.

Director Denis Villeneuve continues to push his way through the pack as a director who deserves to take notice. His 2013 film Prisoners shook me up, and he was on many "best of" lists last year with Sicario. I would expect Arrival to be part of the awards season banter due to the complex nature given to this story, as it is so much more than a simple sci-fi popcorn flick about aliens crashing down to earth. The short story "Story of Your Life" by Ted Chiang serves as the basis for the film, which has been expanded by screenwriter Eric Heisserer (The Thing, Lights Out). That title makes more sense when you learn about another aspect of Dr. Banks's life. I'm not about to get into that, as it would prove to be a huge spoiler.

Villeneuve hooks you right from the beginning. It's a tender opening but accurately sets into motion the intensity of what's at stake. Dr. Banks is the only character given any sort of exposition and that's kept fairly minimal at most. It's a film that lives very much in the present for its characters and the audience. Bradford Young's precise cinematography keeps the mystery going with its limited scope at any given time so the audience never gets ahead and sees more than what Dr. Banks or Dr. Donnelly are experiencing as they learn more about the aliens. The whole look of the film is intriguing to the point where I could never take my eyes off the screen. I feared I would miss out on some little detail or discovery.

The film has a plethora of lofty concepts that can't all necessarily be answered or given equal measure on the first viewing. The basic concept of communicating with aliens is at the forefront, but Dr. Banks goes about it in a very elementary way using visual clues and tactile gestures that are at the forefront of attempting communication with anyone that doesn't speak the same language you do. Banks' continual exploration of communication challenges her outlook about life and how we view the time we are given. I'm being vague for a reason, but it all comes full circle in the film's conclusion. Arrival also tackles the global impacts of such an unexplained occurrence by placing the twelve UFOs all around the world. It forces global communication and teamwork on what they are learning and experiencing at each station. As you can imagine it escalates quickly to a war-like atmosphere based on the doomsday fear mongering that spreads.

There are moments that are driven by the intimacy at hand with Amy Adams' character. You'll quickly notice Jóhann Jóhannsson's score come into play to emphasize this in contrast to the vastly unknown happenings around her. Adams has that maternal side to her that embodies the heart of the character all the while having that direct nature to prove she knows what she's doing and can be taken seriously in male-oriented workspace. It's by no means a showy performance but one that packs the punch needed for the ending. She's partnered with her American Hustle co-star Jeremy Renner who made me take notice in what could have been a thankless role for another actor. He exudes just enough personality as Dr. Donnelly as to not overshadow Adams. The same can be said for how his character compliments the work done by her character.

Recent films like Gravity, Interstellar, and The Martian all made my best of the year lists. As of now, Arrival is on that list. They each pose such fascinating ideas of what the depths of space may behold. Arrival takes a slightly different approach by keeping it grounded on Earth, but it still asks those weighted questions. It fires on all cylinders as its stunning visuals, score, and the questions posed by Dr. Banks mirror the exact dialogue about communication that the film seeks out. It's not necessarily a film that will leave you cheering afterwards, but I bet it will be that thought-provoking movie that sits with you longer than expected.

Is It Worth Your Trip to the Movies? Don't be surprised if you find yourself wanting to see it all over again.

Arrival is a dramatic and thought provoking take on the concept of alien first contact.  The story is a well written and acted journey of what it means to truly communicate and understand humanity, as well as ones' self.

Arrival is one of those films that after watching it the first time you want to watch it all over again immediately afterwards. Not only because of the thinking involved, but because Denis Villeneuve and his DOP do such an incredible job of telling you a story with their visuals. Arrival is beautiful and intelligent. A lot like Amy Adams who is stunningly beautiful in her performance while keeping herself so grounded in the character that it is impossible to imagine her as anyone else. 

Overall Arrival is stunningly beautiful in perception and concept. It is a must see for all Sci-fi fans, and should be a must see for any movie lover.

'Arrival' is a Sci-Fi Drama starring Amy Adams and Jeremy Renner and directed by the amazing Denis Villeneuve ('Enemy', 'Prisoners', 'Sicario'). When alien spacecrafts descend down to Earth the race is on for Dr. Louise Banks (Adams) to decipher their language and determine whether they are friend or foe in what is a must-see film for 2016. This film is amazingly directed by Villeneuve, features great performances with captivating on screen chemistry, a thrilling plot, and like all of Villeneuve's films features stunning cinematography. I was so pleasantly surprised by this film as i went into it hoping for greatness but also a little worried this was going to turn out to be a fairly average Sci-Fi invasion film. But this film completely amazed me as it had so many layers, was incredibly thought provoking, and had amazing plot points with things going on under the surface that you have no idea about when you see the trailer. 

The main cast in this film were fantastic with their amazing performances increasing the dramatic tension, injecting plenty of emotion and also a tad of humour. Forest Whitaker and Jeremy Renner were great elements of the main cast but felt like secondary characters when compared to the performance Amy Adams gave in this film. She was so captivating and really delved into what turns out to be an increasingly more complex character as the film went on to the point where i think everyone in the theatre forgot about her as Lois Lane. She has great on screen chemistry with Renner's character and it did make for some more relaxing slightly humorous scenes. Apart from those 3 performances the other very minor characters were more stereotypes than anything but during the film they all command so much attention that you will very barely even notice. 

There is so much i cannot talk about when it comes to the plot of this film because so much of it is very secretive.... and it is a lot more than you may think. What i can say is this really does get to parts that will require you to put your thinking caps on and figure out what is happening and why. But the payoff is HUGE as the revelations that occur throughout the film i definitely didn't see coming and makes the whole film tie together so well that this commands a second viewing much like Villeneuve's previous films. And just like his previous films the Cinematography here is beautiful. Some of the shot choices and the angle at which certain scenarios are viewed had me in awe more than once throughout the film. This time it was not Roger Deakins it was in fact Bradford Young helming the cinematography who is younger and definitely has a lot of talent and a good eye for beautiful shots. 

So in the end i cannot stress enough how much of a must see film this is if you are a fan of Sci-Fi and more specifically the thought provoking kind. The plot is fantastic, the cinematography is on point, and the performances helming the film are very enjoyable to watch as they add to the drama of every scene. And it is all tied together by Denis Villeneuve in a nice little package creating what is most definitely one of the best films of the year. 

9.8/10

Too much hype, too much expectation based on the 10/10 scores given by a lot of the critics. Does not outdo Interstellar or Contact.

Movie of the Year with ambitions to be the movie of the Decade. Definitely, it's going to be Legend.

I love stories. Always have. And to me, film, is one of the best, and, sometimes, worst methods to get a story across. When done expertly, and with passion, film can create in it's viewer an orchestra of emotion. 

The very best films, to me, are the ones that people can open a dialogue of great conversation over that lasts for hours afterward. They are the true artful films, and they are what fuels my passion for the medium.

I am, and always have been, a sit around the campfire and share sort of person. I love the nuance and intimacy of just being socially in touch with fellow humans and sharing thoughts, ideas, laughs, food and drink with whomever is there. That interpersonal communication, to me, is the spice of life. 

I want to talk about an amazing film that I just watched. It pulled all of those things together. It pulls the tiniest details out and scrambles them into a tapestry of concepts and emotions, and it is very powerful. That film is The Arrival and, to me, it's really fantastic. 

This is not really a sci-fi movie, and yet it is. Its a complex and yet simple tale that is told in a truly unconventional manner and it is resounding in how it sneaks itself into your thoughts for much longer, afterward, than you think. 

There are many facets of the movie that will certainly make you think about things. And there are enough details that once revelations are made, will propel you to want to re-watch it. I'm certain there are answers that are within it that are proposed in the presentation and that is profoundly beautiful. It's not finger food for the brain, but a complex mix of tension, love, emotion, confusion, and detail.

If you are looking for a simple straightforward sci-fi movie, this really isn't what you are seeking. It's a movie about the importance of communication, about time and relativity (in very abstract and diverse connotations, and about the details. 

This, for me, is this year's Ex Machina. It's a beautifully painted picture of what the balance of mankind is and of where the significance of our societal and cultural differences are collectively bound and paved by our ability to communicate, not only with ourselves, but with others. 

If you're looking for that heady and thinky film that will leave you inexplicably thinking about the gravity of it's story for a bit afterward, this is that movie. 

Amy Adams is really fantastic in it and it is a story that really breathes.
This film is brilliant! Amy Adams gives a superb performance, Denis Villeneuve's direction is masterful, and the story is captivating and spectacular.
Arrival tries to improve what's seen on the screen by doing whatever it takes from the plot to read the fellow person's mind and flood it with sci-fi events happening on the screen. It's foolproof.

A well conceived and actualized multi-level suspense sci-fi thriller, that keeps the audience at the edge of their imagination from its realistic beginning to the very end.
