Profoundly satisfying, suspends disbelief and introspects, Arrival is a sci-fi that makes one want to savior that echoing taste in the brain. [Spoiler alert, maybe] Racing thoughts: Tralfamadorians, deja vu, perception, editing, those uuuerrrrrrvvvvv sounds...

Arrival

Denis Villeneuve, director of last year's looming, dark Sicario, has a dabble with science fiction, about some otherworldly visitors with unclear intentions. It's central to Amy Adams' Dr. Louise Banks, a linguist who is enlisted by the U.S. Military to attempt to communicate and understand the visitors reasons. 

Recruited by stern, demanding Col. Weber (Forest Whitaker) and teamed up with scientific mathematician Ian Donnelly (Jeremy Renner) they travel out to a remote beautiful part of Montana to start conversation with the extra-terrestrials. 

Something that is always a challenge for this particular genre is the creativity, as there can be endless possibilities but also that danger of becoming so unbelievable it becomes ridiculous or possibly annoying. Fortunately it's a believable story and has a deeper meaning than just the usual alien encounters with an unknown purpose. Are they friend or foe and if they're no threat then what do they want? 

What is an integral part of the plot is that the this isn't the only encounter and is actually one of twelve hovering above supposedly strategic locations around the globe, which still remain a mystery. As usual, Hollywood has to give the American point of view with the rest of world taking a back seat or worse, being disgruntled, fearful trouble-makers. In fact, there's possibly more of a threat from our own actions. 

It's tackles how we, as a human race might deal with an unexplored situation like this and begs to question humanity as a whole, hoping that our stupidity does not get the better of us. There's so much more to the plot than what any trailer suggests and whilst almost agreeing with the hype of being "the greatest sci-fi movies in years" it isn't entirely original or unpredictable having elements of Signs and Contact. 

Things get weird, and like with Interstellar, all isn't what it seems and while some of it is predictable, it's clever enough to not give everything away, even at the end, some questions remain unanswered, leaving viewers in wonder and discussion. 

Darkness is no alien to Villeneuve's style and his use of light is brilliant, especially during the conversations and visions. But what is incredible is the sound, the language sounding like whale song or elephants. Again reminding me both of Signs and Contact where sound was a key element of the films. 

The score is also amazing, Villeneuve's usual composer Jóhann Jóhannsson composes an immersive soundtrack especially the vocal/choral songs like "Kangaru" and the build up like "Hydraulic Lift" that raises the tension tenfold but there's a certain ambience about it as well. 

Superbly paced, it's suspenseful and engaging. While there are plenty of moments where viewers might get lost, it rushes to its conclusion before it gets complete confusing. Intriguing plot, strong performances and good creativity makes it's a definite must-see, even for non-sci-fi fans.

Not for everyone, it's a very emotion-tied and philosophical type of sci-fi movie. I loved it but plenty of people were asleep in the theatre or complained that it was boring- which is a shame as it was a well thought out take on Aliens coming to Earth and the response from the population.

When mysterious spacecraft touch down across the globe, an elite team--lead by expert linguist Louise Banks (Amy Adams)--are brought together to investigate. As mankind teeters on the verge of global war, Banks and the team race against time for answers--and to find them, she will take a chance that could threaten her life, and quite possibly humanity. It was an engaging story, but certain elements were drawn out.
A movie in 2016 left me speechless. Go see it.

Sci-fi? Love story? Time travel? Alien movie? Yes to all of the above and this film does it in such a beautiful way that I can't possibly stress it enough that you should go see it when it opens this weekend. A great story for all ages, very deep and extremely profound. I had goosebumps while watching parts of it. The acting is impressive, the musical score and soundtrack are "out of this world" (pun intended). I expect you will love it as well...!!!

I saw an advanced screening of this film last night and am sorry to report it is unable to sustain the sheer weight of the subject matter it attempts to tackle. In this sense, I was reminded of A.I., which earnestly tried to capture an almost unfathomably large scope, and just could not sustain the appropriate tone without coming off as goofy. Both movies should really get credit for trying, but time and infinity are just not going to be captured in 120 minutes without subjecting the audience to an uncomfortable amount of graveness. Plus, this film suffers from all the problems any sci-fi movie encounters when dealing with this particular central trope (no spoilers). Finally, Forest Whitaker's character was just plain dumb, unable to grasp very simple concepts in a way that became distracting.
Not as good as the critics make out - the end is the beginning and that's the movie. Does not really tell you why the Aliens came to earth! Overall ok!

An incredible film, it is a must see. The story and how everything plays out is just perfect! Seen at a special screening.

Somber, melancholic and absorbing.  From the dark tones on screen to the music score, this movie is mesmerizing and thought provoking but, will it be commercial?  Some of the screening attendees were disappointed because, as many people do, went in with no idea of what they were about to see and expected another "space invasion" spectacular.  They found it long and were disappointed.

Fans of "Intersteller", "War of the Worlds", and similar movies will fall in love with the unique narrative that "Arrival" gives viewers. From the first scene to the last, as the story unfolds in pieces of a jigsaw puzzle, "Arrival" keeps your mind reeling even after the movie has wrapped. The emotion pulled from you during the nearly two hours will leave you raw and unsatisfied in the best way. An ending that is truly worth the journey and raises questions that never receive a full answer. 
Amy Adams, Jeremy Renner, and Forest Whitaker deliver some of their most gripping performances; a true wonder to see acting at its finest with a story to keep you captivated to the end. See this movie.

un-freakin'-believable
This might be replacing my #1 fav movie. Incredible film. Go see it now.

My beef with this movie is mostly about writing, plot, pacing and substance. The acting in this film is well done. I'd say Jeremy Renner did the best job of making something out of what he had. The role of Ian wasn't that much in and of itself, but he gave some depth and warmth to it. Adams was okay as well. Forest Whitaker deserved more time looking into his character. 

That said, I had a problem with this film. Or the two films that are ham handedly twisted together. 

There's a film about a woman who knows she'll have a daughter who'll die of an incurable disease, but elects to have that child anyway. It's a slow drama with heavy handed violin music in the background and lots of out of sequence snippets of her dead daughter doing things that are meant to be poignant and haunting but feel manipulative after a while because they're clumsy and have no subtlety. I felt like, "Okay, we get it. She used to run around laughing and draw pictures and it's really sad that she's dead and it makes Louise cry". It's slow and syrupy and ultimately boring. Especially given that Renner's character (Ian) had the more interesting POV on that situation but all we learn is that he's mad about it and divorces her. 

And this could be it's own separate magical realism-based drama with sad music.

(Side note: the beginning and ending tracks are music that I heard on the Shutter Island soundtrack, so they're recycling apparently??)

Then there's a sci-fi film that actually had potential, but didn't quite stick the landing. It took the idea of first contact and went somewhere uncommon with it. Not entirely unique, but not the usual way Hollywood presents us with a first contact scenario. The linguistics and science of it were accessible, I think, to the average audience member. It also shows how language is less concrete and absolute than we think

The most interesting part of the film is the aliens and what their ultimate goal is and the mystery of why they're just hanging out in big ships. It frustrated me as a viewer that when we do find their eventual plan, we literally only get a hot minute of it before we go back to the cliched "the military is incompetent and doesn't understand science" plotline. Their way of communicating is fascinating and I would've loved for a biologist or two to come in and comment on them. Especially because they're not symmetrical. Most life on Earth with limbs/fins has an even number, half on each side (see also: dogs, whales, centipedes, your mama and so on).

However, that's the smallest part of the film. And it's laced with this heavy handed portrayal of military and international politics. A portrayal that didn't make sense. 

The movie wants the audience to believe that China would obviously be the ones to turn on the heptapods in an act of short sighted aggression, and would be unable to see anything but a threat in the heptapods because apparently they're using mah jongg tiles to talk to them and since mah jongg is a game with a winner and a loser, this means China for sure will only interpret it as threatening. 

Unlike our sad white lady heroine who's making friends with them and proving that if the Chinese leaders/teams would just try to be more like her (and the U.S.), it'd all be fine. 

It only makes sense if you set aside critical thinking and allow negative stereotypes of China to guide your assessment of the situation. 

The ending of the movie failed it more than any other part. The conclusion of the conflict over the aliens didn't feel plausible or even part of the same movie.

So, as I said. There are two films. One was overwrought and melodramatic. The other was underdeveloped and like the aliens themselves, could only be seen behind a foggy barrier. Only, this barrier was made of cliches, half baked secondary plots, and melodramatic interruptions in a sci-fi film to go watch Amy Adams be sad about her dead child. 

(Side note: SHE CAN SEE THROUGH TIME. She has lots of forewarning. She's a scientist, so Ian. Did they even try to dig into the problem and find doctors researching the disease and say "hey, here's two million in grant money because I translated alien circles and I can damn well pull strings to make that happen now, why don't you start working on a cure. Now. Oh, and me and my genius husband are gonna learn every single thing about this disease and be right there with you trying to think of something.")

Overall? It's a good movie, worth the price of admission. Nothing I'd want to rewatch or tell someone to run out and buy a ticket for. It's arty and the cinematography is pretty and it's sparse so it feels like a smart high brow film, but really? It's two movies that don't taste great together.

I admit that when I saw the commercials for Arrival I was like, "yawn another let's be friends with aliens movie that's angling for an Oscar nomination" but I was pleasantly surprised. The movie starts slow but crescendos into a fast-moving and really fascinating story of love, loss, and understanding. 

Amy Adams plays cunning linguistics (sorry I couldn't help myself) professor Dr. Louise Banks who gets drafted by Colonel Weber (Forest Whitaker) to attempt communicating with the aliens in one of the 12 pods that have landed on Earth. Dr. Banks is aided by fellow smarty-pants Ian Donnelly, played by Jeremy Renner, who is an astrophysicist or something science-like.

The science firm of Banks and Donnelly represent the US of A as they make their case to the alien Heptapods for why Earth is a great place filled with nothing but love and unicorns. The squid-like alien race of Heptapods look like Cthulhu or kinda like hands walking on fingers. Our home team relays their language findings to the other alien host nations, most of whom are less successful with their translating trials and super suspicious of the visiting E.T.s. Naturally Dr. Banks is able to put the pieces together and communicate with the Heptapods, but is mostly ignored by the men in the movie because of course a woman couldn't crack the secret alien code if they couldn't.   

I was sleepy and this movie still kept me awake and enthralled so it gets extra credit for that. It's a refreshingly intelligent alien movie that encourages the audience to think rather than bludgeoning them into submission with special effects.

Inspiring... Mind-bending... This is no, low IQ, spoon feed graphics overload session. You're not gonna like the show if you've shown up for a mindless, predictable, gun slinging, superpower train wreck... sorry-ish. This is fresh and new and awesome. This challenges both the director and the viewer in a way that is visually stunning, mentally satisfying, while inspiring hope in humanity. I believe, that for most people, the level of enjoyment from this movie is directly related to your ability to understand it.
Great film - slow start but nicely wrapped up - looking forward to the directors next film (Blade Runner 2049)
What was all that about? I could literally have switched it off 5 minutes before the end and not cared. Can't understand why people rate this so highly.
Very original and thought provoking

Another "aliens making contact with Earth" movie, Arrival is about a linguistics translator being called to try and translate an alien language from twelve unidentified objects to determine what their purpose on Earth is. Before I continue the review, I must warn you that I've specifically stayed up late at night in order to write this. Arrival is quite simply the greatest piece of cinema I have seen in recent memory. I'm tempted to say, it is on par with Gravity as my favourite sci-fi movie of all time. Damn, that was exciting to say. Now before you say I'm over-exaggerating, let me give you the reasons for this grand statement. Firstly the acting was powerful from every actor. Amy Adams deserves a nomination for this, she pulls in the emotional heft of her character whilst maintaining an intelligent persona. Jeremy Renner was also good as the witty scientist who accompanies Adams and Forest Whitaker was superb as a military colonel who has the weight of America on his shoulders. Then we go to the direction, Denis Villeneuve has yet to make a bad movie. Prisoners was flawless as a thriller. Sicario was excellent and now Arrival has just topped both of these. If he does not get a nomination for Best Director, something is clearly wrong. The way he slowly pans the camera to create tension, the way he focuses in and out of objects in the same shot, heck even the landscape shots are beautiful. Cinematography was captivating, the fact that the alien objects (that the characters refer to as 'shells') look so photorealistic that you can't determine if they are computer generated or not...is just insane. The musical score was beautiful, switching between a string arrangement for the more emotional scenes and a more sci-fi sounding tune for when the characters enter the 'shell'. It definitely pulled me in as a viewer. This brings me to best part of the film, the story. For a film involving a linguist and decoding a language, one would imagine it would be boring. Quite the opposite, I was so intrigued by the methodologies behind the linguistics and how they were used to decipher the language that it just enthralled me. There are some turns that the film takes that some might not agree with, but in my opinion they worked well. It's good to see a sci-fi film that does not insult the audience's intelligence and it's also good it does not require action to be interesting and thrilling. I could go on for hours...I really could. I've never been so happy for a film to be so good in all my life, and I can't wait to watch it again. Overall, Arrival is intriguing, beautifully composed, confidently directed and is quite simply the greatest piece of cinema in recent memory. I seriously hope everyone watches this.

- Review at: http://www.themoviediorama.com

Having a woman as the main focus is unusual, but appealing. It's a bit chilly and quiet--not a lot of explosions and action--but worth checking out.

The exceptionally rare film that gets it all right. Arrival is expertly written, filmed, directed, acted, and even scored. IFTTT: "Darmok" (ST:TNG), Close Encounters of the 3rd Kind, Solaris, Contact, The Man from Earth,  Interstellar, Waking Life, The Fountain, Primer, 12 Monkeys
Not 100% sure what was going on nor do I get it completely after I watched. Good acting, but I don't completely understand!!

"I wish there had been more about advanced linguistics": not a sentence you hear  every time you come out of the cinema. But that does basically highlight the movie's strength. It takes the concept of an utterly alien language and makes deciphering it if not entertaining then at least interesting. The aliens are suitably... alien, as is there method of communication. A few smaller words might have helped explain some of the high-concept material, but on the whole you understand what you need to and appreciate the cleverness of what remains. Yeah, this film does rather pat itself on the back over how clever it is. But the linguistic stuff is interesting enough. It's when the film starts to veer unexpectedly into time travel that logic and credulity go out the window. I've always hated serious films about time travel. I don't mean ones that just use time travel as a plot device, but ones that are actually about the mechanics of it. That's why Back to the Future, Part II is the worst of the series: despite some fun future hijinks it gets too involved in how everything works instead of just hand waving it away. Films that do this invariable end up being too silly, too arbitrary, or too confusing. This film is the latter with hints of the former.

This is one of those films that's easier to admire than to like. I do respect it for discussing some very advanced concepts and the sheer amount of effort that must have gone into inventing an utterly alien language and design, but at the same time it never  really grips you. I thought the opening scenes were great at showing us what it feels like to be ripped out of your mundane lives by an extraordinary event, but that's the last time they really make a serious play for your emotions as opposed to your intellect. The whole film is slow as molasses, not really doing anything for the middle section and constantly interrupting to show us Amy Adams and her doomed child. It was based on a short story and feels like it. I don't regret watching the film, but I can't say I'm ever likely to watch it again.
Make time this year to see this movie. It must been seen. A classic that will age like a fine wine.

Arrival is a breath of fresh sci-fi air, intelligent in all the right ways and aware enough to not be overly preachy. It's great all around, forwards and back.

Arrival blends together incredible cinematography, a brilliant performance by Amy Adams, impeccable directing from Dennis Villeneuve, to deliver a gut wrenching, beautiful film with a twist that only makes the film soar even more.  Simply put, Arrival is a Sci-Fi masterpiece.

'Inception' meets 'The Martian'. The global political differences create a real sense of authenticity, while the plot itself offers a unique thought-provoking concept. This is a new shaped slice of Sci Fi pie and almost laughs in the face of the generic, modern day alien films that we have all become accustomed to. The tone and tempo have you hanging onto every word, although you are never quite caught out of breath. Amy Adams delivers a flawless performance, while Jeremy Renner's presence as her co-star feels both restricted and a little unnecessary.

Director Denis Villeneuve (Prisoners, Sicario) proves yet again how much skill he has in disorienting you without having to manipulate the screen with IMAX magic, as his choices of framing gives an overwhelming feel of scale in comparison to this unidentified object. The color palette used by cinematographer Bradford Young (A Most Violent Year) gives a stark feel of loneliness in a world separated by language barriers. The stressful sound effects complement the sad melodic music scored by Jóhann Jóhannsson (Sicario, The Theory of Everything).
Inside of the object, the gravity is perpendicular to our own; then at the end of the object, these eerie, faceless, squid-like lifeforms behind a white veil await the approach of human investigators. Dr. Banks leads the interaction with these beings, later named "Heptapods," who communicate through painting abstract black rings that make up their language. So she, as a college professor, applies her history in English to vigorously study their language, which they call "nonlinear orthography." The process in figuring out their form of communication is absolutely brilliant and inspirational in how it's created and discovered.

Strange, Strange and finally Strange. Someone doing hand shadows onto a screen, while being taught remedial English by a confused wannabe couple. I wish the Aliens had done more with their tenticles .

CHILDHOOD'S BEGINNING, MIDDLE AND END - My Review of ARRIVAL ( 4 1/2 Stars)

Director Denis Villeneuve favors deliberate pacing in his films.  Despite trying out a variety of genres with such films as PRISONERS, SICARIO, ENEMY, and INCENDIES, he puts his stamp on them with precise visuals, haunting, quiet performances, and what seems to be his patented slow dolly-in on scenes.  In PRISONERS, for example, I felt that every scene seemed twice as long as it needed to be, but that Villeneuve's confidence in his tone made the film memorable.  His latest, ARRIVAL, firmly demonstrates that he can apply his voice to any type of story, and the results are sublime. 

Based on Ted Chiang's short story "Story of You Life" , screenwriter Eric Heisserer has adapted and expanded upon the science fiction tale of the appearance of 12 alien ships hovering over different locations on Earth.  Heard that one before?  Arthur C. Clarke's novel "Childhood's End" did it back in 1953 and without it, we wouldn't have had INDEPENDENCE DAY or DISTRICT 9.  With ARRIVAL, the influences may seem obvious, with nods to that novel as well as to INTERSTELLAR, ALIENS, TREE OF LIFE, THE DAY THE EARTH STOOD STILL, THE ABYSS, CONTACT and CLOSE ENCOUNTERS OF THE THIRD KIND, but the Villeneuve has infused it with his own distinctive style, an intimate film about huge ideas.  

Amy Adams plays Louise Banks, a preeminent professor of linguistics, who at the beginning we learn has lost a young doctor to a rare disease.  With shades of Ripley finding out about a daughter who lived an entire life while she was kicking ass out in space, this prologue sketches in just the right amount of emotional depth we need from our heroine in order to follow her on this journey.  Adams, perfectly cast here, as opposed to her role in NOCTURNAL ANIMALS, shows us Banks' bravery and vulnerability all at once in a largely nonverbal performance.  I haven't seen someone make more out of huffing and puffing since Sigourney Weaver did for Ridley Scott all those years ago. Her performance evokes strength, empathy and profound vulnerability to create a totally original, indelible character.  

With a sly feeling of inevitability, the world changes in an instant with the appearance of the aforementioned ships.  This sequence sneaks up on you with the perfect mundanity of college students getting one text after another, or when Adams walks to her car as military jets buzz overhead.  It sets the stage so perfectly that this will be a grand story told in a hushed, lovely way.  Because of her past government assignments, Banks has pre-existing security clearance which allows her to get on a helicopter right away with Colonel Weber (Forest Whitaker) to fly to the Montana visitation site.  The economy and precision of the setup excited me in the way James Cameron's best work has done. The best of Hollywood blockbuster filmmaking has made me sit up and take notice like no other films.  We're so on board with Banks, we know her Achilles Heel, and we feel confident that if anyone can talk to these aliens and find out why they're here, it's her.  

On the ride over, she meets Ian Donnelly (Jeremy Renner), a mathematician also recruited to break the aliens' coded language.  On paper, it may seem a little cheesy that we're basically given Science Vs. Language  as a source of conflict between these two characters, but I was delighted to see that the filmmakers didn't go in that direction.  Banks and Donnelly work beautifully together and establish a gentle, humorous, two-of-us-against-the-world rapport.  

And then we're there, at the base of a giant oblong disc, with Banks and company rising up into it with the help of a cherry picker.  We feel the bravery of this group of people who have no idea if the aliens come in peace or....something else.  No spoilers here but the film's second act focuses on Banks and Donnelly trying to figure out the aliens' peculiar, possibly nefarious communication style.  Like any great screenplay, there's a secret story happening underneath the main one.  In the back of our minds, we know that many plot elements remain unresolved, but it's easy to put your trust in Villeneuve and Heisserer.  Every setup pays off and every emotional truth gets explored.  

Cinematographer Bradford Young, who did such as stellar job on SELMA, has worked so well with Villeneuve to elevate this film to a true work of art. Shot after shot has the ability to surprise or unsettle the audience.  Perspectives shift often, revealing bits and pieces of the true story, and I joyfully went along for the ride. The depiction of the aliens are haunting, reminding me of the photos people take of palm trees on a foggy day in LA.  Young also captures the landscapes of Montana with such an unassuming grandeur, allowing Adams and Renner a truly lovely scene outside the ship.  It reminded me of Terrence Malick's work, where nature always seems to nudge its way into a scene.   

Adams has often come across to me as a theater arts major who made up for in spunk what she lacked in depth, but throughout her career, she has chosen roles which tap into a darker side filled with quiet rage and disappointments.  In doing so, she's accumulated 5 Oscar nominations and has become one of our most endearing, accessible actors.  When she misfires, she comes across as a little too reticent, as if her LDS upbringing has kept her from breathing real fire into her roles.  When she nails a performance, such as what she did in THE FIGHTER, it's as if she unleashed a torrent of blowsiness she had hidden from the world.  Adams' work in ARRIVAL isn't showy, and like Melanie Griffith in WORKING GIRL, she seems to always be on the verge of tears.  What's so fresh and unusual here, however, is our ability to watch a somewhat tortured soul think through tough problems.  Jodie Foster and Laura Linney have that innate ability to show us women who bare their brains before baring their souls.  Adams does both simultaneously and this film is her showcase.  Reiner offers gentle support and the rest of the cast produce nothing more than functional roles. 

For most of the running time, ARRIVAL plays out as more cerebral than emotional.  Its lack of anything cornball or Spielberg-ian works in its favor.  While dropping hints throughout the film that it possesses a real beating heart, the 11th hour revelations caught me by surprise.  Yes indeed, I got a lump in my throat as I felt the emotion and beauty of its message.  Those expecting giant alien battles and epic scope must be warned that ARRIVAL feels almost like a chamber piece, but its ideas are earth-shattering.  It left me stunned and challenging me to reflect on deep questions in my own life. It's rare that a film can bring you to such a place, and ARRIVAL, surely one of the best pictures this year, does just that.

Arrival may be one of the best science fiction films to come out in a generation, and it deserves every single bit of praise it has received. The heir to masterpieces like 2001: A Space Odyssey, Contact, Interstellar, and Ex Machina, Arrival is a thinking-persons' sci-fi flick. If you're looking for loads of action, scary monsters, or lots of laughs, this is not the film for you. If you enjoy reading the works of Robert Heinlein, Charles Sheffield, or Isaac Asimov, you're going to have a fantastic time.

Amy Adams is at the absolute top of her game, as are supporting cast members Forest Whitaker and Jeremy Renner. Director Denis Villeneuve (Sicario, Prisoners) brings absolutely stunning visuals. The writing is superb, and will leave you lost in though. While the Oscars tend to snub genre pictures, this is one science fiction movie that truly deserves recognition. From the cinematography and sound design to the writing, direction, and acting, it's one of the best films I've seen in a decade. Go see it.

Arrival 2016 M (1hr 56min)
Review by Peter Walkden (Finesse Movie Reviews)

Please note - This film has no connection to motion picture "The Arrival" which was released in 1996 and starred Charlie Sheen.

In case you have never heard of this film, Arrival is an alien film without the over the top action/chaos such as in films like Indepence Day. Arrival will require patience. This is a visually stunning film and I suggest to the audience to be patient and enjoy the clever and creative shots. Fans who have previously seen Sicario will be able to appreciate this director.

Lucky enough, the movie trailers for this film showed very little of what the film is about. The only tag line we have ever heard is "Why are they here"...

The film opens up with Louise Banks (played by Amy Adams) who appears to have just given birth to her daughter. We are then shown their life, progressing quickly through a moving sequence. Then we flash to present day where Louise is a expert linguist and lectures professionally.

While she is teaching a class it is soon discovered that earth will change forever. People panic when multiple spacecrafts land on earth. Louise is shortly requested to join (and lead) an elite team to investigate further.

Amy Adams provides an outstanding performance (no surprise here, duh!) but we are forced to put up with a couple of characters that really don't hold any major purpose in the film. There are many moments where I even question Jeremy Renner's role- I felt he was some what wasted as an actor.

Arrival, I must say is a top sci-fi film. As an audience we have questions from the word go and to top it off, the viewer's questions only pile up as the movie progresses. Even when the film is over you will still be thinking about it- seriously, give it the next day or two. But is that a bad thing?

After thinking about my total score for this review for a couple of days now, I'm pretty sure certain things with the film's plot (and ending) simply just don't add up. But then again, I remind myself.... it is a sci-fi film after all.

7.5/10

Arrival is now showing in Cinemas.

Strong, moving and poignant. The cast of Arrival gives genuine and powerful performances that keep the otherworldly context of the film grounded and heartfelt. Arrival is one of the best films of the year by director Denis Villeneuve. The film has an outstanding lead performance from Amy Adams. She steals the show, and definitely is an Oscar contender. Jeremy Renner and Forest Whitaker are also good in their roles. The film explores a lot of ideas about humanity and time. The film is very thought-provoking with these ideas. The film also has beautiful cinematography. The film looks absolutely stunning. I was also a big fan of Johann Johannsson's score. It fit every scene it was in. The film also has a very interesting story with the aliens and Amy Adams' character. While the film does have a deliberately slow pace, I was entertained throughout. Overall, this is a dazzling sci-fi film that is beautifully made and wonderfully acted.

"Arrival" significa otro clásico contemporáneo de la ciencia ficción que se equipara a las obras maestras "Interstellar", "Gravity", "Ex-Machina" y "The Martian".
Cuenta de una manera pausada e inteligente la llegada misteriosa de una raza alienígena a la Tierra y cómo una lingüista (una magnífica Amy Adams) y un científico (un grandioso Jeremy Renner) intentan comunicarse con estos visitantes extraterrestres para comprender el propósito de su visita.
El enfoque de "Arrival" no es bélico ni tecnológico: es un enfoque comunicativo (semiótico y lingüístico) que a su vez explora el fenómeno del tiempo. El resultado es una película dirigida magistralmente por Denis Villeneuve, quien con sus obras "Incendies", "Prisoners", "Enemy" y "Sicario" nos ha demostrado, al igual que Christopher Nolan, que el cine de género y el cine experimental no tienen por qué oponerse.
"Arrival" es una película formalmente bella (que evoca los trabajos de Terrence Malick), con una banda sonora impresionante a cargo de Jóhan Jóhansson y una fotografía imponente a cargo de Bradford Young ("Selma"). Y presenta un giro que no solo tiene que ver con la historia relatada sino con el lenguaje del cine mismo.
Esta es una obra que los espectadores acostumbrados al cine fácil que les permite chatear durante toda la película van a encontrar lenta, aburrida y extraña. Aquellos que todavía vamos a cine para pensar, contemplar y buscar belleza, encontraremos en "Arrival" una película perfecta.

Like other reviewers on this site, I decided to see this movie because of its interesting trailers and it's very positive Tomatometer rating (It was at 100% at one point!).  However the movie that I thought had some potential when it began, turned out, for me at least, to be the most disappointing and overrated movie since "Zero Dark Thirty."  The movie is very confusing and even more hard to follow.  A tremendous waste of very talented cast.  If you want to see a science fiction movie that is thought provoking (As "Arrival" was meant to be.") and entertaining to the max, skip this and instead see Christopher Nolan's "Interstellar."

So far the best movie of 2016.

Arrival is the antidote to all those CGI-heavy alien invasion movies. It's a more realistic take on what would happen if aliens visited Earth. Director Denis Villeneuve captures the grandeur and suspense of these alien encounters without relying on classic tropes such as high tech violence and destruction. Leads Amy Adams, Jeremy Renner, and Forest Whitaker do excellent jobs in their roles. Yet what truly makes this a movie compelling to watch is a very familiar third act revelation that is done so well, it will resonate on an emotional and a cerebral level.

Secondly, the trailers made it seem like it would be more thriller like than it was. Instead, it's a slow, thoughtful drama.

It was also much more complex and thought provoking than I thought. It wasn't just another alien movie - it was about really seeking to understand another culture with which you have no common language, and trying to understand their overarching purpose.

MOVIE INFO
When mysterious spacecraft touch down across the globe, an elite team--lead by expert linguist Louise Banks (Amy Adams)--are brought together to investigate. As mankind teeters on the verge of global war, Banks and the team race against time for answers--and to find them, she will take a chance that could threaten her life, and quite possibly humanity.
Rating:	PG-13 (for brief strong language)
Genre:	Drama, Mystery & Suspense, Science Fiction & Fantasy
Directed By:	Denis Villeneuve
Written By:	Eric Heisserer

Matthew Samuel Mirliani Matthew Samuel Mirliani
 Super Reviewer

 1/2
I guess it doesn't take much to make an amazing movie. Just an incredibly original story by Ted Chiang, great directorial choices by Dennis Villeneuve, and a great performance from Amy Adams. The film's pragmatic approach to an alien landing really separates it from other sci-fi films, and then the story hits another gear and separates itself from all other films of any genre. A couple of pacing holes are present but can't come close to bringing this movie down. I have always believed the best films are the ones that have you thinking well after you've left the theater. This is one of those films.

Sanjay Rema Sanjay Rema
 Super Reviewer

Your enjoyment of this film probably depends on how you deal with the reveal of the underlying concept. You could call that a twist, although the hints are there throughout. In the film's own logic all that makes perfect sense and makes for an ending both unsettling and deeply satisfying. The cinematography and production design as well as the music set the tone, but it is Adams' great performance that carries the film. A smart, beautiful, engaging and optimistic Sci-Fi-movie that will make you think for days.

Contact w/ Jodie Foster) and probably be better off. 

Spoiler Alert
-----------------------

The whole point of this movie, the whole driving conflict was the question "what are these aliens doing here?". We get a kind of sort of answer on this at the crisis action but then spend the rest of the last 3rd of the movie tying up various subplots that snuck themselves into the movie. The problem is, during these subplot resolutions, we are totally neglecting the main conflict which is still, why SPECIFICALLY are these aliens here. We get the vague answer "we need humanity's help in 3000 years so we came here to give you the power to see the future". And YET we have no indication that Louise Banks (Amy Adams) shares her new found future telling powers with anybody or that this revelation was communicated anywhere. We don't know how being able to tell the future helps the Aliens in 3000 years (presumably they already have this ability) and what specifically they need help with. The entire juice of conflict resolution was taken out the plot. This is the movie equivalent of the patronizing "Because I Said So" rhetorical technique.

When I first saw the trailers for this movie, I was a bit skeptical about it. I thought it was just another alien movie that was similar to all of the others. These thoughts were continued until the reviews came out praising this film and I was then interested. I had no idea Denis Villeneuve was behind the camera for this film, so I figured that was the reason why it was doing so well. I eventually watched it towards the end of its stay in theaters, and wow was I impressed. Denis does a masterful job of crafting this beautiful film showing the bigger picture and bringing up the possibility of extraterrestrial life having a different motive for arriving. I thought the language aspect was brilliant and brought a fresh flavor to the alien genre, and Amy Adams is powerful in her role. It is honestly a shock that Adams wasn't nominated for neither this film or Nocturnal Animals, but I digress. I also enjoyed Forest Whitaker's performance greatly, and I was all in on the bizarre and thought-provoking ending. Great scope and beautiful storytelling is what brings this film home.

If you are looking for an action sci-fi adventure to enjoy while you wait for the next Star Wars, this is not the movie you should watch.  But if you're looking for a movie with great emotional payoff and a truly surprising ending, then you should go see Arrival now.  But you need to be prepared for what you're getting into.  Arrival expects you to think to fully understand it.  It also has a deliberately slow pace, but I never once found it boring.  I felt that the pace made the movie drip with tension and when matched with some awesome visuals, it became a genuinely unique experience at the theater.  I will admit that I only partially understood the ending of Arrival.  I had to Google it when I got home.  But I now realize that I should have understood it; I just needed to pay more attention.  And now that I know the twist, I honestly think the movie will be even more rewarding a second time.  Anyways, I really recommend this movie.  It was suspenseful, intelligent, and still managed to have a few moments of humor.  If you're in the mood to give your mind some sci-fi twists in between the magic of Doctor Strange and Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them, then go see Arrival.  You won't regret it.

'Arrival' is a sci-fi movie in the style of 'Contact' and 'Interstellar' that exceeded my expectations. Villeneuve works wonders and builds up tension in the first act and releases it in a nuanced and almost intimate way in the third act; unluckily, during the middle section the film loses a bit of the initial steam, but works fine either way. Amy Adams proves that she is one of the finest actresses working today, and gives life to her character with a tipically compelling performance. The cinematography is brilliant, and the score is perfect in that it helps creating the atmosphere in the best way possible. The 'brainy' part of the movie works just fine, and even if it suffers from some clichès here and there, the final result is still outstanding.

Adams is Magnificent in this Mind-Bender!

When mysterious spacecrafts touch down across the globe, an elite team - lead by expert linguist Louise Banks (Amy Adams) - is brought together to investigate. As mankind teeters on the verge of global war, Banks and the team race against time for answers - and to find them, she will take a chance that could threaten her life, and quite possibly humanity.

Since this incredible film premiered at the 2016 Toronto Film Festival, it has been widely praised as one of the best science fiction movies in decades. It presents many clues without revealing its hidden truth until the film's shocking conclusion. The success of the movie's masterful storytelling is owed to director Denis Villeneuve and author Ted Chiang, whose sci-fi novella "Story of Your Life," served as the film's source material. Adams is magnificent in the role of Banks as well. If you are a fan of movies that make you think, you will love 'Arrival!'

Arrival is unlike any other film I have ever seen. I went into this expecting a cool alien suspense film with some clever plot points. Instead I got all of that, plus a completely unique twist that I have never seen attempted and I'm not sure ever will be attempted again, at least for a while, (you know Hollywood). It was an incredibly bold idea from Villeneuve but it paid off, this was a unique experience and I thank him for that. Amy Adams gives one of her best ever performances and Villeneuve really took time to romanticise her character but he did it subtly instead of trying to force it. My only real fault with the film is Jeremy Renner's character because he isn't really needed up there if Amy Adams goes up there. I still liked his character and his performance but I just felt his character was unnecessary for what they were doing. I have already mentioned how well directed this is and Villeneuve holds the suspense beautifully, the score is enchanting. The visual effects are very good too but you'd expect that from a big budget film like this one. This could end up earning the academies token sci-fi best picture nomination.

Embedded into its marvellous and intricately woven science fiction prospects, "Arrival" is forcefully carried by the heft of its premise, generously assisted by one of Amy Adams' most touching appearances and, as always, the steady imaginative hands of repeatedly successful director, Dennis Villeneuve. What is weaved through the Hollywood-esque visuals (which never call attention to themselves) and twists and turns is a firm thread of humanity so visceral and encapsulating you may wonder how a movie about aliens could possibly teach us this much about humanity. Through the linguistics at the heart of this film, we are invited to observe a story whose lesson says so much more about the way the world works than words could ever manage.

Arrival is a tough one for me. It's probably the first social realism/alien invasion mashup movie ever made, and kudos for that. Amy Adams is always pretty, pretty believable and relatable. It's fascinating to consider the communication angle to the eclipsing of all other considerations (action sequences, technology, spacey stuff). There is also a really intriguing commentary on free-will, predestination and foreknowledge. So far, so excellent.
But... Jeremy Renner is a craggy, cratery Tommy Lee Jones Jr, but he is a bit of a spare part in this, along with Forrest Whitaker and Michael Stuhlbarg (who reminds me of a charisma-free Bradley Whitford). The aliens themselves are a bit annoying as they are shrouded in fog, literally and metaphorically. A lot of people have criticised the somewhat rushed uses of deus ex machina. And although the idea of the film is genius in principle, I found the execution (along with the omni-grey colour palette) to be dull in the first half, and I actually nodded off in places.
It's a 5 and it's a 2, so that averages out at 3.5. Recommended, but frustratingly falls short of what it should have been.

Amy Adams has had a terrific year, and even though I loved "Nocturnal Animals," "Arrival" is her standout film of the year. Led by the directing of Villeneuve, a great cast, and an incredible story, there is not much to complain about in regards to this film. 9.3/10

Fresh out of Odeon Leicester Square after a 9AM screening and, despite some beautiful moments, I'm left with a familiar sense of disappointment with the big budget Sci-Fi movies of recent years. There's no doubt this has some thought provoking moments and an originality to the look and feel of the 'visitors'. There's a heart-rendering subplot and twist which adds a different ingredient. However, visually, so much is familiar with this genre, borrowed from the Sci-Fi classics - from the textures, to the technology, to the sound design - that it's hard to see originality for too long. Amy Adams' performance is strong and weighty, but secondary characters such as Forest Whitaker's are thin, with poor, stereotypical military dialogue and weak lines of questioning (illustrated in his first scene when the audience laughed at his 'serious' question). All too often these days, the thought provoking Sci-Fi movie descends into overcomplicating the story before warring nations, faux news reports and Chinese generals enter the fray to take us back to Independence Day. Sensitively filmed, good performances by the leads, strong music, but too much 'story' and Hollywood cliche crammed in left me realising I spent just under two hours watching what I've watched before.

Arrival is that science fiction film that you would like it or hate it when it comes to the ending. Amy Adams does give an outstanding performance as Louise, a linguist that has to work for the government. When several alien spacecraft hovers above in several continents. The spacecrafts are at standstill. At certain time, the alien are trying to communicate using their language symbols. Louise and Ian (Jeremy Renner) are trying to solve the mystery with the aliens purpose on earth before the government and other world leaders decide to face against them using weapons. Are the alien species the real threat? Or is there a hidden purpose? 

Arrival is a stunning film. Denis Villeneuve direction is remarkable yet again. Especially with his work from films like Prisoners and Sicario. Denis can create a suspenseful tone and the build up towards the climax. The plot works with the less you know about it. May not be an action packed alien invasion movie. More of a character human study as how would governments react when they have an unknown spacecrafts flying over their lands. And unable to communicate with them without giving the wrong message. The ending does give a lot to think about and may frustrate others or be something to talk about. I think it works well with the hidden message that its trying to portray. The music composer Johann Johannson was beautiful and haunting in the film. 

My only issue with the film is the pace. It is slow moving and does slow down when characters are going up to communicate with the aliens and coming back down to study their language and figure out what the symbols mean. It does get repetitive for a while and slow. 

Arrival works well in delivering a remarkable sci fi film with a hidden message and a haunting beautiful direction.
This is an amazing sci-fi movie.
Can't say enough good things about this one. Science fiction done right. Best movie of the year.

I actually did get more out of this than 'Prisoners' and 'Sicario'
director Denis Villeneuve this time tackles the sci-fi genre 
it's a terrific character-driven flick with a bigger emphasis on the science of it all
Amy Adams gives a truly remarkable performance as a linguistics professor called in to investigate the sudden appearance of several alien spacecraft around the globe
she says language is the foundation of civilization, it's the easiest way to create conflict among one another
she also works among Donelly (Jeremy Renner) and Colonel Weber (Forest Whitaker) to get some legitimate answers
the film signifies this event as a way for humanity to come together and forget all of our petty differences
the two big questions everyone wants answered: why are they here what is their purpose?
the film is a cool slow-burner making us ponder the real reason the aliens have come; are they explorers? are they here to help? or are they more sinister than we're led to believe?
the other trouble is that Villeneuve has us open our eyes in that language in itself is more tricky than we know, the wrong translation or interpretation can come across as friendly or potentially hostile
that's why Louise urges her team to realize that there is a big difference between a tool and a weapon
if the history of mankind has taught us anything it's that sometimes it can be viewed as both plus the whole world has no single leader making it impossible to follow several others
the movie also flashes back and forward covering Louise's traumatized past of losing her daughter to what essentially could be the key to finding out the visitors' true intentions
the ending is a bit of a stretch but the rest of the film builds such dramatic tension while also delivering fascinating visuals
I think it's also a realistic portrayal of how we as a species would react to such a phenomenal occurrence such as this
some are on board with the idea of first contact, others choose the route of fear even violence 
all in all it's communication that determines who we are and how things transpire from there
this is one of the best films of the year!
I was really looking forward to see that movie.  After watching it, I am mostly just confused...
A bit trippy but very rewarding.

The screen adaptation of the acclaimed story, by Ted Chiang, is an atmospheric sci-fi mystery with ambition. The rare example of hollywood production where special effects serve the plot and not the other way round. Forget about the demolished metropolises and the White House reduced to ashes with a laser. Most of the action takes place in several rooms and the main character,  nonstop, experiences extrasensory phenomena.

Louise Banks (Amy Adams), an appreciated linguist is recruited by the military to assist in translating alien communications. But our heroine doesn't have much time. Mankind - according to the rule "shoot first, think second" - hangs by the thread of global war. As the world submerges itself in madness (which can be seen in television broadcasts), Louise along with physicist Ian (Jeremy Renner) and Colonel Weber (Forest Whitaker) tries to communicate with heptapods.

Scenes, when the main character views the extraterrestial spacecraft and later explores it, are the examples of a top class cinema. The director Denis Villeneuve once again reaffirms us that he is unmatched when it comes to appalling the audience and filling the screen with terron. Touched by a family drama, Louise is another - after Kate Macer in "Sicario" - strong female, forced to find her place in the world run by men. The doctor isn't just the passive observer. She is not affraid of taking risk and questioning wrong decisions made by superiors. As the plot goes, it turns out that the potential threat to the humanity are not only aliens, but humans themselves.

Villeneuve is one of the most talented and visionary directors - a great pick for the next "Blade Runner". He reaches fo screenplays from which, peers out profundity and gracious form. "Arrival" does not lack intriguing ideas and aspirations through which, it shows a substantial essence of human nature and modern world. What sets this film apart from others in the genre is the way it approaches the problem of loss and fear. The thing that is escalated by the great performance from Amy Adams.

And it doesn't end here. What's left is, the crucial to the film, relativity of time - a real minefield of spoilers. The notion of time is a treat for fans of thinking person's sci-fi and an agony for those seeking clichéd action. "Arrival" with its form and story leaves the audience a field for interpretation.

Not every story or representation of a possible fictional event has to play out like we think it will. Arrival bends the imagination and focuses on the beauty of extra terrestrial communication and the endless possibilities of what "actually" might occur if our species is challenged in figuring out what more the universe has in store for us.
Awesome score and special effects and I really liked that after you find out the twist you feel like you should've know all along. Chemistry was good too and Amy did a good job.

I cried in a movie. Yes, I, who have not cried in a movie in at least six or seven years, cried in a movie. That happened. Arrival delivered one of the most thoughtful, well-directed, well-shot, and unexpected cinematic experiences I have ever seen. It's an experience I won't forget, and it's an experience I recommend to any thinking moviegoer out there. Here's why.

Arrival is a science-fiction film directed by Dennis Villeneuve, the acclaimed filmmaker behind last year's action thriller Sicario. It stars Amy Adams as a prestigious linguist, who is brought in by the American government to assist in their dealings with the appearance of twelve disc-shaped UFOs that have landed across the planet. Jeremy Renner and Forest Whitaker co-star as a theoretical scientist and an American Army colonel, respectively. First, I'll mention the most obvious great things about the movie: the acting, to start. In Arrival, Amy Adams delivers one of the most emotional, compelling performances of her career. She portrays someone who is easy to sympathize with and someone who is broken due to events in her past, and she owns the movie with the passion that she puts into her character.

There are several other things in the film that stood out to me that don't typically stand out in movies. For instance, it delivered some incredible cinematography, with many breathtaking shots of the UFOs and very carefully filmed scenes that highlight little details and plot points that become important as the plot progresses. The sound editing and sound quality also blew me away: the soundtrack accompanying the introduction of the UFOs and the aliens, the chilling, electrified hums that became common with shots of Adams' and Renner's characters inside the ships, and even the deafening sounds heard with jets and helicopters early on in the movie; they were all things that enhanced Arrival even further beyond its incredible quality.

Now, my favorite part of the film, and probably the part that distinguishes Arrival from the many sci-fi films that have come before it, is the writing and the thoughtfulness of the plot. Even from the beginning, there were things about the story that impressed me. Aliens in popular culture tend to be portrayed as evil, destructive beings who seek the destruction of humanity. Indepedence Day, Alien, Skyline, Battle: Los Angeles, War of the Worlds... these are all very stereotypical alien flicks that portray extraterrestrials in the same light. They're unrealistic, corny, repetitive. This is the first way that Arrival distinguishes itself: it focuses on what could ACTUALLY happen upon the appearance of aliens in our world: it very realistically portrays how world governments would probably deal with that sort of situation, and how the public response would follow, influenced by media and panic. I also loved how it focused on something BESIDES the action, destruction, and military of most alien movies. Instead, it showed how a linguist and team of scientists would attempt to peacefully communicate with a race beyond our world.

However, the most fantastic part of this movie is something I can't discuss in depth without spoiling things. Arrival introduces pieces of a puzzle as the plot progresses and thickens, and as the movie progresses, it makes you think. A LOT. It makes you think about how those pieces fit together. It makes you think about life beyond us, our culture, our world, and humanity in general. As I said in the beginning, it's a film for the thinking moviegoer. Arrival made me think, and I had to discuss it with my friend for half an hour after it ended to digest everything and satisfy my thoughts. I loved it. And above all, it was emotional. Like I said, I cried. The movie's conclusion made me an emotional wreck, due to the investment I felt in the characters and the sympathy I shared with them.

Arrival surprised me in ways I couldn't imagine. It went in completely unexpected directions, and I was blown away by the conclusion. Tears were rightfully shed, and I struggled after its conclusion with the possibility of replacing Gravity with Arrival as my #1 favorite movie of all time. And that's because Arrival is truly amazing. I recommend it to any thoughtful person, science fiction fan, or movie fanatic out there. It's one of my favorite movies ever, and it's the most well-earned five stars that I've given a movie in a while.

Before I give my thoughts on Arrival, I want to share an amusing anecdote.

2 and a half minutes before the movie was over (yes, somebody timed it) the fire alarm went off because of a kitchen incident at the connected P.F. Chang's. We all had to evacuate. But when we got back in they gave us free passes and let us see the end of the movie right where it left off!

Arrival was good. The mystery and suspense was great, and the reveal was cool. That being said, there is no emotion in this movie. Seriously, it's like a Vulcan wrote the screenplay. Pure logic. OK, there is emotion, but it all comes from the news on TV, Skype calls, and people on the phone. Aside from being nervous/afraid, everybody on screen is a blank slate.

And even when exciting things happen, the very next scene brushes it aside and deals with it off screen. Literally, after something major happens, one of the characters says "Oh yeah, it was just [two nameless guys]." and that's it! Nothing but the main event holds any weight!

So if you want good suspense and don't mind the lack of emotion and dealing with major events off screen, check out Arrival. Just be prepared.

P.S. The editing is unconventional. That's not a complaint. There are a lot of holds on one person while the person they talk to is off screen. This was directed by a French Canadian man, and it shows.

More and more, every year, especially in the late Fall into Winter, there are movies that are released that have a message or agenda, sometimes hidden, usually not. Often these movies are described or intended to be marketed as "Oscar Buzz Movies" I'm not saying that promoting action or change is a bad thing, I'm just saying these things exist. Sometimes the message is diversity or social justice, sometimes it's a comment on political corruption or journalistic integrity. Whatever it is its almost a lock that a movie will get recognized for it.

This year, a movie called Arrival demonstrated a message that called for its audience to, for once, don't speak, just listen. In an era of global communication through countless channels, we sometimes take for granted our ability to understand one another.   More than ever people are told they have a voice and they have a platform and they need to use it, and while in moderation that can be true.  However, the ability to listen and objectively think, to proceed with caution instead of just attacking with what you think is right, that notion is losing ground. More than anything else the ideas of listening, thinking, and understanding before acting is what the movie Arrival is about. Science Fiction has a way of molding philosophy, like clay, in a way that we can use our imaginations to better understand ideas. While the movie isn't perfect (Jeremy Renner's character is basically a plot device and some of the conflicts seem forcefully thrown in without any real catalyst) as a whole, Arrival is the most optimistic and imaginative movie I saw this year. Amy Adams' performance though subtle was incredibly powerful, and the nuances in her delivery are worthy of multiple revisits.

Thought provoking and a real neat take on contact with aliens. Another great performance by the lovely Amy Adams. Moves along kinda slow, but the content keeps you captivated.  Fascinating in how the film depicts humanity, the way we think and how communications affect our way of thinking

Don't mind the people giving this movie a 1 or 2 star rating. People who lack the capacity to understand this movie should not be trusted in their review because this movie is in no way confusing or incoherent if you just pay attention. Arrival will not babysit the viewer and doesn't mind taking its time to develop it's characters and plot in proper fashion. On top of this, the writing is spectacular, from how Amy Adams character explains and conveys every little nuance in the writing and language to how there is a complete disconnect between Amy Adams character, a teacher, and the uptight government agent types. The cinematography is some of the best this year and this movie knows how to establish a proper opening shot. From the beautiful vistas spanning Montana's mountains, to the close up and personal shots of Amy Adams character's house, this movie uses its visuals to help tell its story in a capacity I've seen in few other movies this year achieve. To fully understand Arrival, the viewer must pick up on small clues laced throughout the movie that ultimately come together to give one of the most compelling and satisfying revelations in a movie this year, or any other year for that matter. This movie is a thinking man's movie, much in the same vain of movies like 2001, and it must be seen to be understood. Just give it a try with an open mind and your full attention. If you're looking for a fast passed action film, then this isn't the film for you. But I would hardly say the movie is ever boring. Slow? At times. Boring? It's really up to you to decide. Just don't have expectations of an Independence Dat type movie.

ok, i enjoyed the movie... however, i expected it to be so "universal" in it's very simple message. The cinematography was good, acting was good(even though I am not a huge Amy Adams fan and Renners character was pretty pointless), story was fine, and the message... well, the message was pretty cliche. The message was no different from Independence Day or the Avengers... the world must unite and work together to defeat a possible threat outside of ourselves(in this case, through communicating with one another). It spoke somewhat on freewill and the concept of fatalism, yet kept the story so much on the surface, I really felt like there was little to delve underneath, to give the film any depth. All the depth was on the surface, which pushed cliche, and there was nothing really underneath to chew on after the film.
The time travel concept, which i guess was the "wow factor" of the film, was done better in Memento... and the "open your eyes" concept, was touched on much more intelligently, in 2001: A Space Odyssey... and the symbolism, which i expected to be extremely rich in the film, as Denis' previous films, was unbelievably light to the touch(his past film Enemy was ripe with symbolism and thought... and handled much in the same was as Arrival, but done with a stronger hand, and less on the nose).

Arrival is Denis Villeneuve's masterwork. I cannot speak enough praise for the heights in beautiful cinematography, narrative pacing, intelligence, universal relevance and raw emotion this film achieved. Arrival is the thinking man's Sci-Fi epic. In Lieu of action set pieces and high octane thrills (don't get me wrong I love that shit when it's done properly) but Arrival uses it's intellect and philosophy to it's advantage with flawless execution. This film speaks volumes in very blatant but also very subtle ways and this is a film that needs to be seen. Arrival carries a heavy weight of universal relevance and uses its narrative to stir up issues we face not as a specific nationality, nor an individual country but as a species as a whole and is also one of the most well thought out and emotional narratives I have seen in recent memory. I absolutely adore this movie and will be praising it for years to come. Easily the best film I have seen all year. Arrival reached a height of intelligence, emotion and universal relevance similar to Ex Machina and Sunshine (two of the greatest movies of the past decade)

Arrival squanders it's beautiful premise with a plodding, messy, and ultimately unsatisfying plot. This is a disappointment after three fantastic films from director Denis Villeneuve. Those films were filled with tension, held up by strong character development. Arrival, on the other hand, never builds to anything. I admire the film's thought-provoking themes, the compelling theory on the way language shapes our understanding of the world, but it just doesn't work on a narrative level.
Those expecting a whiz-bang film should be prepared for a more cerebral and emotional experience, admirable for its ambition and tone, if not wholly satisfying in its payoff.

A nearly perfect sci-if film. Denis Villeneuve's direction, with a great script, feels so natural and sleek. The cinematography is absolutely beautiful. Amy Adams gives one of the best performances of her career; Jeremy Renner and Forest Whitaker are very good as well. In a genre that is overwhelming filled with movies about blowing things up and shooting everything, it's a big breath of fresh air to have a film so thoughtful, that takes its time to tell a story; the aliens are almost a backdrop, while the characters and their development are at the forefront. Arrival does get a little clunky and a bit rushed with some details in the final act, but all in all, this is a fantastic film.

What a remarkable movie. It is one of the few times where I believe the source material is expounded upon and improved in the film. Amy Adams is astounding, and this I hope, is her breakout performance. The film does a remarkable job of letting the audience figure it out, and you really feel more accomplished as a film goer than having them spell everything out for you. It's a really powerful introspection into life, love, time, and our existence. But never does the film spell out how you should feel about these things, rather it shows you that we only have our interpretations of them, and it is up to us to do with that as we will. The film also is powerful not in it's action or violence, rather in its lack of action. It truly is the most innovative and intelligent science fiction film that we've had in a long time. It's a slow burner, and there are pacing issues toward the end of the film, but overall this is not only one of the best films of the year, but probably of the decade. Denis Villeneuve has created a film that is emotionally riveting without relying on common tropes, and turned it into an instant classic. This movie rises above the rest in 2016 as something truly remarkable. I could write essays about this movie. Please see it.

A brilliant piece of sci-fi, Arrival is an ambitious, intelligent and consuming movie which will provoke you with its concept, stun you with its aesthetic attention to details and keep you thinking over what you have just seen long after the final credits. Emotionally loaded and terrifically acted, this latest Denis Villeneuve masterpiece is also a philosophical take on the limits of human understanding and personal choice turning this movie into the best sci-fi delivery since Interstellar. 
Dr. Louise Banks (Amy Adams) is an elite linguist who is asked to lead a team of top scientist after the arrival of 12 UFOs on earth. Tasked with the unthinkable mission of establishing first contact with the a mysterious alien vessel and creatures, Dr. Banks has to co-operate with Dr. Ian Donnelly (Jeremy Renner) and Colonel Weber (Forest Whitake) and delivery quick answers amidst the constantly escalating international tensions.
First  and most importantly, Arrival is not the mainstream sci-fi action thriller, which relies on the concept of alien invasion and all in military actions. Restrained and very intimate at moments , it is not only a scientific mission, but also a personal journey of Doctor Banks. A journey which will lead to a challenging philosophical exploration on the limits of communication and human condition. 
Typically for director Denis Villeneuve (Incendies, Enemy, Prisoners, Sicario), the pacing is slow and yet the tension build-up is steady and leads to a twist which will open space for much more questions rather than to provide you easy answers. Amy Adams succeeds to be a convincing centre of Villeneuve's exploration of human mind and perception to an extend in which not only the philosophical part of movie, but also the emotional one will stun you in the end. 
In conclusion, Arrival is another masterpiece by the talented Canadian Denis Villeneuve which could easily be considered one of the best movies of 2016. Worthy of being a major Oscar contender, this mesmerizing sci-fi thriller is a must see and a true sci-fi classic!
While "Arrival" may slow down to a crawl at times, it is a beautiful, original, and intelligent take on the traditional first contact story.
not a movie for everyone, smart, some great ideas...but a bit predictable.

Ian Donnelly: You know I've had my head tilted up to the stars for as long as I can remember. You know what surprised me the most, it wasn't meeting them. It was meeting you.

Arrival es la historia de una mujer llamada Louise, que es reclutada por el gobierno cuando unas naves extraterrestres aterrizan en varias ciudades del mundo. Su trabajo es descifrar a que vinieron, de manera que tiene que tiene que utilizar todos sus conocimientos en lingüística para conseguir comunicarse con ellos.  

Denis Villeneuve, quien en mi opinión, es el mejor director trabajando hoy en día, logra la combinación ganadora de presentar una película estéticamente hermosa con una historia rica y profunda. Arrival logró hacer lo que Interstellar trató y no fue tan exitosa.

Los protagonistas de Arrival no son los extraterrestres, sino de Louise y de como utiliza su pasado/futuro para unir al mundo de manera que empiecen a trabajar por el bien común. Esta película es fascinante, y completamente única en este género, en las cuales la llegada de estos seres siempre es objeto de pánico y temor, pero en este caso lo maneja con una calma tensa  y de hecho, los hechos son tan realistas, que probablemente así reaccionaríamos en el caso de que alguna vez llegaran. Definitivamente de mis favoritas del 2016.
A cautionary tale that was meant to be told in these factious times.

It is definitely a movie that feels like an experience when you're watching it. Plus, the performances, cinematography, direction, musical score, emotional (and suspenseful at times) moments, editing, and visual effects were all some of the best of the entire year. It is also one of those movies that requires a lot of brain power to fully understand what's going on, and I love movies that can do that, and it surprising to see a movie like that in a year with too much reboots and sequels. Overall, it is definitely worth the time and money to watch.

Needless to say, I did not think this film skipped a beat. The panic and confusion that would occur from an event such as what happens in the first 15 minutes was masterfully shown on screen, as well as a plethora of gorgeous shots mostly concerning the alien ship. I really enjoyed the way the frustration of communication between the two species was fully fleshed out and the tension between countries and people inside the US base. There was a real sense of wonder and awe when witnessing the aliens and their technology for the first time, and a few moments that made the whisper to myself "holy shit". The acting was great, Adams was fantastic, but I feel like there was difficulty finding something very useful for Renners character to do. Despite this, I had a blast with Arrival and it is another fantastic film for 2016

Quick Review: Denis Villenueve for those who've known me decently enough know is someone that I consider maybe one of my all time favourite up and coming filmmakers right up to par with Christopher Nolan; In that they're people who put as much time into whether storytelling, emotions, and heart to their craft more so than the stunning filmmaking that goes with it. Since Incendies i've seen Villenueve really create his craft vert meticulously and so effortlessly that, it really makes me wonder how a film like this with a relative medium budget and earns 100 MILLION overall doesn't wake up more filmmakers to branch their films on this scope than keeping to the same IP's. Whatever the case may be, Arrival was certainly one of the films back in 2016 I mean to watch on the biggest screen I can, but due to its overbooking I decided to wait on watching it. Now that I have, WOW was that certainly a wait well worth spent, because Arrival certainly delivers on a solid adaptation to Ted Chiangs short story and has a lot that really makes it well defined on its own.

Minus perhaps some plot points (specifically with the introduction to how Louise is asked to join when Colonel Weber goes to her office and with some issue with the end of how oddly convenient its set up and kind of ends a bit with a weak payoff) being tweaked somewhat and with the occasion wish they'd add just a little more of seeing Louie's story go on, I must say the film really just shines thanks to its amazing directing by Denis Villenueve who before the cusp of Blade Runner 2049 this made the journey to that SO MUCH more satisfying to see work his craft so flawlessly, beautiful and really atmospheric cinematography from Bradford Young that can really get him some work done after, must be noted really creative and welt built iconography and sets for both locations and especially the alien ship that really help give it this feel and look that gives its honour to the source material, super solid writing from Eric Heisserer who really knows how to pace and balance his story and dialogue and arcs and themes for someone being the only one doing the adaptation, terrific performances from just about everyone and obviously the bigger highlight of Amy Adams who as always manages to give herself character with each performance, and holy shit the score by Johan Johansson being JAW droppingly limited but so freaking well done and subtle that it makes me wish and wonder what prevented him from doing Blade Runner 2049's score (and oh shit as of writing this I forgot he passed away, rest in peace his soul he was a fine composer). So overall I think its safe to say this was a pretty great watch first time around, and definitely looking back before the wow factor of BR2049 this was definitely the right stepping stone to direct a film like that, and im glad it could be Denis; proud of him. 

Score: 8.5 / 10

So good, so smart and so awesome. Arrival is another acomplishment by director Dennis Villeneuve, an incredible study of human behavior this movie is one of the most strong sci-fi dramas of the decade. Plus: Amy Adams performance is from another world, so great. (4,5/5)

Arrival is a drastic change of pace from the average alien invasion film we see nowadays. This isn't a big action blockbuster about alien invasion but instead a story about trying to communicate with the aliens and understand their purpose. The film is incredibly well made and is a ingeniously crafted story. Amy Adams is in the lead role and she's excellent. Her character is very well written and she has a lot to her, Adams does a superb job at playing her and it's one of her best in a very long time. Jeremy Renner is very good, it's a different role for him and his character is very interesting also especially by the end. Forrest Whitaker is good also though his character is a cliche. The film is directed by Dennis Villeneuve, who previously directed Prisoners and Sicario. He does a fantastic job here as this is an incredibly interesting film with lots of twists and turns that advance the film instead of making it stupid. The ending of this film is brilliant and will make you look back on the rest of the film. It really is a movie that will be a completely different experience if you watch it again. The film is very well written also. The screenplay is very tight and intricate and luckily there aren't too many plot holes. This film is a technical masterpiece. The cinematography by Bradford Young is spectacular, the movie looks amazing and the shots of the aliens themselves really are beautiful. The musical score by Jóhaan Jóhannsson is also amazing, it's tense but also beautiful at the same time. The films ending as I mentioned is fantastic and has an absolutely superb twist. It's one of those twists that completely changes the rest of the film and makes everything click into place. Now while this is a superb film I do have a couple of problems. As I mentioned with the exception of Adams and Renners' character all the others are massive cliches. Also some aspects of the films ending are a bit predictable. However Arrival is an extremely well made and clever movie. It's a brilliant new spin on the first contact sub genre and further cements how brilliant Dennis Villeneuve is as a director. I can't wait to see what he does with Blade Runner 2049 because he is a fantastic director. A
