Villeneuve's latest effort solidifies him as one of the most interesting talents working in mainstream cinema. He takes this high concept sci-fi premise and explores it without dumbing it down, but giving enough to comprehend, all while developing a fascinating lead character that serves as the films emotional anchor. 
The way the narrative developes feels fresh and is exalted by the tension and atmosphere created by the outstanding sound design and the beautiful cinematography, both which play with perspective and scale, enthralling in an almost visceral way. 
Even though some plot elements and dialogue seem to dwell in the melodrama. and if some storytelling decisions feel a little bit lazy, Arrival manages to be gratifying on an intellectual and emotional level, positioning itself as one of the year's top moviegoing experiences.

Arrival is a rarity not just in regards to its content and execution, but in terms of what's included in a mainstream movie. Although being marketed as more of a typical thriller, here we have what is, at its core, much more of an art film--but that doesn't make it any less engaging. Denis Villenueve's latest has more of his steady direction in a dreamy, layered, and beautiful meditation on the progression and uncertainty of life, and with its unorthodox structure, it's very well fit for a repeat viewing. Dr. Louise Banks (Amy Adams) is a linguist and college professor who is brought to Montana by the United States after 12 extraterrestrial ships, which look like giant floating onyx beans, come to various locations across the world. She works with Ian (Jeremy Renner), a physicist, and two attempt to understand why the aliens have arrived and what they want, trying to understand their language and science. What turned out to be a pleasant surprise is that all of this is really a backdrop to the real core of the film, which is about life, time, and growth. It's based on a story called "Story of Your Life" written by Ted Chiang, but the real surprise is that the screenplay was written by Eric Heisserer, who wrote movies such as Final Destination 5 and Lights Out and co-wrote the awful 2010 remake of A Nightmare on Elm Street. He really brings something special to the table here, taking a rather overexposed premise and placing the scope on its protagonist with a very intimate look at her and her life. I won't spoil anything, but the way that the movie uses its structure to manipulate the viewer and reveal more and more about the main character is surprising and satisfying. We begin the movie just by seeing Louise's profession and her losing her young daughter to cancer, but there's much more in how the plot unravels. It reminded me of Donnie Darko in a way, and the way that Heisserer presents his themes are fittingly aloof, but that adds to the intrigue and gives them a greater effect. With its nonlinear structure, it's one of those films that will have a noticeably different effect upon a second viewing, and smartly enough, that in and of itself plays into the film's themes regarding knowledge, progress, and time. The filmmaking is also a great fit for the material. This kind of stuff is in Villenueve's (versatile) wheelhouse, allowing him to bring his dark yet fantastical mood to the world of the film. It's far more Enemy than Sicario both in terms of the execution and the artsiness of it, and there will be people put off by that, but Villenueve's direction makes it accessible enough without compromising its artistic integrity. Adams is always great to watch, but she really brings a vulnerability and strength to her character in non-obvious ways. The movie looks absolutely beautiful from its use of fog and colors as well as long takes and environments. The spaceship that Louise and Ian go into several times to communicate with the aliens is pristine and minimalist, and the design of the aliens are also interesting--they look sort of look octopi mixed with tarantulas. The sound work done with the aliens' noises present some great sound work. There are two minor issues with Arrival, though, and ironically, both of them have to do with the script. One is that Renner's character is a little underdeveloped and I can't tell if that was intentional or not. I could see why it would have been a specific choice, but I'm not sure that it came through. The other is that there's one moment in the film that seemed a bit irrelevant to the film overall; maybe more could have been done with it. Nonetheless, Arrival is one of the best movies of 2016 so far, and it's great to see a movie this big have so much going on beneath the surface. There's a little Stanley Kubrick, a little Jonathan Glazer, and a little Terrance Malick, but it still feels original and the movie won't leave you after you leave the theater. 8.8/10, terrific, A-, far above average, etc.
Pretty good, not too fantastic and decent acting

Even after Amy Adams' abysmal performances as Lois Lane in the past few years' worth of horrid DC comic movies, director Denis Villenueve had already sold anything he was ever going to do the minute I walked out of last year's "Sicario". Fortunately, when given a real character to work with, Adams knocks it out of the Montana valley in which this film is set. Blending a monolithic hard sci-fi a la "2001: A Space Odyssey" with the emotional depth that characterizes Villenueve's oevre, "Arrival" is so much more than just the plot or the visuals.For the film's "Independence Day" meets "Close Encounters of the Third Kind" overtones, (without going into spoilers) the film isn't about that, surprisingly. It touches on a lot of similar themes as "Interstellar" in that there is some sort of multidimensional "love transcends time" deus ex machina. It might seem like that's it, but it's really more about the necessity of communication, the ambiguous nature of language, and one's ability to choose their future. A small gripe I have with the movie is that Forest Whitaker's character is at first vehemently against bringing Amy Adams to the extraterrestrial "shell" because he thinks she's just manipulating her way on board a space craft. But he would have to take her to the site anyway to do any meaningful linguistic analysis of the alien language, plus Whitaker just plays a run of the mill gruff army type which doesn't really do him justice as an actor. But the stark beauty of the film and the emotive performances otherwise make up for any shortcomings. If you get a chance to see it in theater's, don't miss it.

"Quebec's own Denis Villeneuve has crafted a fine sci-fi thriller that's challenging, involving  and imaginative"
Movie Review: Arrival
Date Viewed: November 16 2016
Directed By Denis Villeneuve (Incendies, Enemy, Prisoners and Sicario)
Screenplay By Eric Heisserer, Based on the short story "Story of Your Life" by Ted Chiang
Starring: Amy Adams, Jeremy Renner, Forest Whitaker, Michael Stuhlbarg, Mark O'Brien and Tzi Ma.

"Arrival" plays with it's ideas thoughtfully but it's not as groundbreaking as I imagined it would be. Still, this is another home run for Quebec filmmaker Denis Villeneuve (Incendies, Prisoners, Enemy and Sicario) and Amy Adams delivers one of her best performances. It's another alien invasion story but this sci-fi epic is more about communication, mystery and suspense than just your usual slam-bang action. The screenplay by Eric Heisserer (A Nightmare on Elm Street (2010) and Lights Out) is challenging and thought-provoking and this movie has echoes to sci-fi classics like "The Day The Earth Stood Still", "Close Encounters of the Third Kind" and "2001: A Space Odyssey".

It is far from being a great movie but the intensity of it and it's ingenious ideas are hard to ignore here. Villeneuve has crafted a fine sci-fi thriller that's exceptional and imaginative. "Arrival" stars Adams as Louise Banks, a linguist who gets assigned by the U.S. Army to join a team of scientific experts in unraveling the mysterious events that are occurring around the world. They are talking about the 12 cocoon-look-a-like extraterrestrial spaceships that have emerged all across the continents.

On the verge of starting a war of the worlds, Banks and theoretical physicist Ian Donnelly (Jeremy Renner) get assigned by General GT Weber (Forest Whitaker) to go inside the spacecrafts and see if they can communicate with the octopus-like aliens which they call "heptapods". Before the alien invasion, Louise Banks was a single mother to her daughter but she tragically died from cancer.

The Chinese and the Russians are already communicating with the aliens, from a show of military power but Louise has had success in communicating with them by showing up and again and again and by knowing the alien translations. The aliens communicate with her and Ian by revealing circular symbols to the glass which is separating them from the humans. Louise gets to ask them "What do you want?" and they say "offer weapon". What does it mean? Could it be a sign of a show of force or a tool in helping them with their spacecrafts? However, the media and the news sites are dubbing it as "use weapon" and military and political leaders around the world start to freak out as they prepare themselves for possible invasion.

Many of my fellow critics are already calling "Arrival" another sci-fi breakthrough and one of the best movies of the year but again I have to challenge them. Is there anything here that's beyond original? No. Nevertheless, the acting here is terrific.
The performances from Amy Adams, Jeremy Renner and Forest Whitaker are how can I put this: Out of this world!

Again, it's not as ambitious as I was hoping for it to be and it could've been something more but thanks to fine actors, compelling drama and great special effects, "Arrival" is one of the more entertaining blockbusters this holiday season.

Artistry Story Performance 
ALL PERFECT!

Arrival mostly succeeds as the sci fi think piece of the yea which the occasional heart tug, focusing on Amy Adams playing a university linguist professor brought onboard to help the US government make first contact with a recently arrived spacecraft, one of 12 across the world. The film strongly brings its tone by way of the Kubrick acolytes and Kubrick himself and another title (2001, Contact, and Intersteller come to mind) aiming for big ideas and erie atmosphere and a sense of dread as humanity attempts to interpret the meaning of the extraterrestrials purpose. The performance and technical aspects really do hit home, keeping the audience on the edge through the entire film, and has reliable Renner and Forrest Whittiker in supporting roles. The intriguing thing is what to take a way from the end moments and the somewhat cirrcular arc in a way of the film since by learning the language Amy Adams seems to be able to forecast the future eriely, so the normative arc or establishing beginnings and ends are a little heh? But if left as is for a trippy and engaging film, this one is for you :)

Ok, so this past weekend I saw the latest Denis Villenueve Film "Arrival" and I have to say, it is by far this decades best film. Everything in the film is absolutely perfect. This is the only film that has ever made me cry within the first 3 min of its runtime. Arrival is everything you want in a movie; great performances, a compelling story, suspense, drama, amazing visuals, and most of all it makes you use your brain from the second the film begins. The musical score set to the film really encaptures the events that take place from scene to scene; setting to setting etc. The basic story behind the film is the first encounter between aliens and humans occurs, and Amy Adams character and Jeremy Renner's character are brought in to try and communicate with the foreign species, but it's so much more. I wish I could delve into the film more, but that would require spoiling, and there is a lot to spoil. Long story short is go see this film in theaters, go support it so we can get more films like it in the future. Take it from me you won't regret it. I give Arrival 5/5 stars.

Arrival

The military enlists a linguistics professor to aid in deciphering the language of newly arrived extraterrestrials. 

Prepare yourselves for something different. 

Denis Villeneuve, director of Prisoners and Sicario, helms this refreshingly intelligent film that will drop your jaw. There's nothing wrong with popcorn movies about an outer space hero like Superman or a chest bursting monster from Alien, but occasionally, albeit rarely, we get treated to an enlightened and clever tale that tickles the gray matter. 

One of my favorite films of the year.

I wasn't expecting this to be an action-packed alien invasion movie or anything, but was still surprised at how mediocre and slow it is. It was too overhyped, and it moves at a snail's pace. I found it really difficult to stay awake through the first half. The latter half and particularly third act make it much more engaging, but not enough to save an overall lackluster experience.

Time and time again, Denis Villeneuve proves that he will not let you down. This man has yet to make a bad or even sub-par film. Arrival left me speechless, literally -- me and my buddy didn't say anything for about 2 minutes after the credits rolled. We just sat and pondered about what we had witnessed. I have never felt this way about a sci-fi film since Interstellar (another thought provoking genre film that evoked true human emotion albeit less successfully). 

There's something about this film that keeps you on your toes. Whether it's Villeneuve's mysterious directing style that unfolds right in front of you or perhaps the structure of the narrative itself, everything is held together by Amy Adams who puts on a show. This movie would not have worked without her leading the charge time and time again. 

On a final note, I think this is one of the best and most realized sci-fi films I've ever seen. Parts of it reminded me of Interstellar, and other parts District 9. Those are 2 of my favorite films in the canon, and Arrival is right there with them -- except Arrival is one of the best films of the year (if not the best I've seen so far). It's truly an unbelievable and deft blend of thought-provoking themes and actual human emotion that speaks to the dispersive nature of humanity as well as language's ability to unite and mend our differences. Fantastic movie. 

(Shoutout to Eric Heisserer for an incredible adaption of "Story Of Your Life". A little forced at times, but it plays out with an incredible payoff.)
With a genius script, focused direction, and committed actors, Arrival's pacifist intentions are helped by tense emotion and electrifying commentary on modern culture.
A beautiful move with a much needed message in these times.

Arrival is directed by Denis Villeneuve, and it stars Amy Adams, Jeremy Renner, and Forest Whitaker in a science-fiction film about alien spacecrafts that come on to earth, but they haven't done anything yet but stand there, and the military come to Louise Banks (Amy Adams) for help as she's the best linguist that they have got for her to understand the aliens about why are they here, what their purpose is, and if they are friendly or not. Seeing as the Academy Awards are over and we finally know what film won Best Picture, I decide to go on a route of watching films that were nominated for Best Picture. There are definitely going to be some times that I watch something else and review it, but I'll try to watch all of them in that category, and with this, Arrival is one of the films I was most excited about of 2016 as I enjoyed Denis Villeneuve's work like Prisoners and Enemy, and with his next work being Blade Runner 2049 after this, I was curious to see how he can handle science-fiction, which I believe he did a bang up job on it. Amy Adams gave a great performance given from what she has to do whether it be her horrific backstory, or that she's really tired dealing with world stuff. It's cool to see that we actually have no idea about whether the aliens are friendly or not because this is Denis Villeneuve's first science-fiction film, so it's not quite a certain to where it's leading until later on. There's also the short story by Ted Chiang called "Story of Your Life", but I haven't read it, and even if there's a clue about it as Eric Heisserer wrote horror films like Final Destination 5 and Lights Out, it still has that mystery feel that is unpredictable. It's also interesting that writer Eric Heisserer wanted to get this made for years, and finally got the dream that he wanted, while also some rewrites from producer Dan Levine and even the director himself. With that on topic, the writing by Eric Heisserer is probably the most well-written that I've seen from him as it deals with the themes of the film very well, and asks questions that you don't usually see in a science-fiction film, and manages to answer them in a way that is very satisfying. It is also the main part of the film as it's a talky flick and it doesn't have any action scenes, so it's only the dialogue that you have to be invested in it, and for me, I was intrigued enough in the movie. The score by Jóhann Jóhannsson is well-orchestrated that has some beautiful music to listen that felt poetic with what the movie needed, especially towards the ending. It's very smart that it shows that you can get lots of progress from a linguist that I have never heard of until now. The effects look spectacular that has a great blend of practical and computer effects from the design of the spacecraft, the aliens, and even the language that the aliens speak which has a lot more variety then I thought. I was also glad that some of the characters wasn't going to the "shoot first, ask questions later" approach which is refreshing to watch when seeing movies like Independence Day: Insurgence. The cinematography by Bradford Young is really good that I thought that Roger Deakins did it, but since he wasn't the one, but is doing Blade Runner 2049 which also has the same director as this, it's interesting to see where that is going to lead. With that said, Arrival is just a beautiful film that I understand why it was nominated of Best Picture, and this might be the one where the director's finally going to be recognizable.

'Masterpiece' is not a word I use often when reviewing films, but Arrival has definitely earned that title. This is genuinely the most enjoyable cinema experience I have had since Interstellar, and placing it as my second favourite film of all time was one of the easiest decisions I have made recently.

I feel obliged to mention Jóhannsson's beautiful score, most notably the track 'Hydraulic Lift' and the brilliant use of 'On the Nature of Daylight'. Although, as a synecdoche for the films themselves, it still doesn't quite beat Interstellar's score (No Time For Caution being my favourite piece of music from any medium), but is easily second best.

A misleading title, but what a shocker.  12 alien ships arrive around the world and teams mobilize.  The US need a linguist to attempt communication with the heptapods inside.  Language becomes the key to survival.  Different societies have a different connotation for "war" and "weapon."  Dr. Louise Banks is the only one who understands this--that is why she is chosen.  Now she must race against a clock to prevent interstellar aggression because the aliens want to give us a weapon.  But the story is not truly about the arrival of the aliens, but the arrival of a new future.

In an era where every space oriented movie comes out in the fall of every year (i.e Gravity October of 2013, Interstellar November of 2014, The Martian October of 2015) we have Arrival another epic sic fi movie that came out in November of 2016 not saying its bad just wanted to point that out, now without further ado lets review Arrival:

Arrival is about a brilliant linguist professor Louise Banks, who leads an elite team of investigators when these mysterious alien ships land in 12 different locations around the world in order to communicate with them. Amy Adams plays Louise Banks and right off the bat this is her best performance to date, I have been a fan of Adams for a while but she does a great job with the role. Forrest Whitaker is another great actor that does a good job in this film along with Adams, although Whitaker and Adams do great in this film I can't really say the same about Renner, however his performance wasn't terrible it just could have been better, but because I'm happy too see that he is not just doing Avenger films I will let it slide (not saying I hate the Avengers its just good to see him in another film). Denis Villeneuve is famous for directing films in the action or mystery genre such as Sicario (2015), and Prisoners (2013) so to see him craft a film in the sic fi genre is really refreshing, this is my probably favorite film from him. Arrival is not a perfect film, in fact I had my hopes high for it because I thought the premise was cool, and the cast and director were all great, but honestly I was kind of disappointed in it. Don't get me wrong the first half is extremely cool and interesting but as the film progresses you have to really pay attention well because this isn't a straight forward film and you will get lost. I also thought the film had a lot of flashbacks now don't get me wrong those are extremely important to the plot line of the film but they were kind of overly long too me. I also want to point out that do not watch Arrival expecting an action film, because this truly is a thinking persons movie. Though I expected Arrival to be a little better I still enjoyed it a lot, its a smart film with beautiful scenery, and some pretty great performances. If you are looking for an intelligent sci fi film that doesn't follow the usual cliches to the genre, with a cool tone, and smart dialogue than I highly recommend Arrival for you.

"Arrival" is the type of movie that the second you finish it you can't stop thinking about it. The more I thought about it, the more I was impressed by it. It's a sci fi for people looking for a more intellectual and emotional experience. I think the movie does build tension very well but it does payoff in a way that I definitely didn't see coming. The movie is directed very well and the performances are all great, especially Amy Adams. The movie is about aliens on the surface, but there's such a beautiful message it's trying to convey that makes it different. However, if you appreciate the ability of movies to make you feel and think on a deeper level, you really need to check this one out. It has secured spot in my favorite movies of 2016.

Director, Denis Villeneuve (Prisoners, Enemy, Sicario) directs a superb and intense film about communication with aliens. This film is easily the best of the year, and once again, Villeneuve succeeds to amaze since his 3 previous masterpieces, Prisoners, Enemy, and Sicario. This film is a smart, and cleverly put together. The score by Icelandic film composer, JÃ³hann JÃ³hannsson, fits the atmosphere perfectly, and the cinematography is immaculate.
The plot and subplots are interestingly entangled and the movie waits until the last act to reveal it's direction and purpose.

I enjoyed Arrival's meditations on connections between language, time,  and perception, it's playful interweaving of personal and cosmic stories. The conception of the aliens surpasses most attempts to portray truly unearthly language and technology, although they did bodily resemble certain area creatures. Amy Adams also really shines here as a problem solver, a scholar, a truth-seeker unmoved by the public panic and military paranoia crowding in around her. In a country woefully known for anti-intellectualism and xenophobia, we need more role models like her curious and conscientious Prof. Louise Banks.

Denis Villeneuve's Arrival is fascinating from start to finish. The direction is beautiful and intriguing just as a good sci-fi movie should be. But don't walk into this film expecting a traditional science fiction movie. Arrival takes a familiar concept but it asks unfamiliar questions that make us think about how we would deal with this as a united people. Sure it has a plot twist, and it has fancy cgi, but what keeps you going through the film are the questions it asks about humans and our way of thinking. This is not Denis Villeneuve's best but it sure as hell makes for a great time for anyone who enjoys finding meaning in movies. I recommend it to Villeneuve fans and sci-fi fans alike.

  Arrival is truly something else. There hasn't been a sci-fi film like this in YEARS. It's philosophical, interesting, intelligent and extremely thought provoking. Amy Adams commands the screen as Dr. Louise Banks and she delivers one of her very best performances. She's a force to be reckoned with lately and she brings her A game with this one. I would love to go super in depth about this plot and all it's mechanisms, but I definitely don't want to spoil anything. This is a film that you need to go and see in the theater to fully experience it and form your thoughts on the story and it's deep meanings. I won't get into anything, but i'll just say you need to see the film. The execution is flawless, the writing is whip smart and progressive. The directing by Denis Villeneuve again cements him as one of the most original and brilliant directors we have working today. All the films i've seen of his have been incredible and have topped my best list at the end of the year and Arrival is destined to do the very same. I saw this film a few days ago and really haven't stopped thinking about it. It's themes are important, it's emotionally affecting, and it's a film that will make you think and one that will be analyzed for years to come. It's pace is slow but that's the type of movie it's supposed to be, slow and demanding. Stick with it and you will be rewarded with one of the most blazingly original and thoughtful sci-fi films i've seen in a long time. First, I feel that movies with a circular plot like this are a little misleading. The twist toward the end changes the stakes and who the main character is. Still the cast is strong, the aliens are unique (something which is difficult to pull off in the sci fi genre), and the mystery will keep you engaged.

Arrival is severely over-hyped but better than I expected. What does that say about Villeneuve and Bladerunner 2049? Hard to say but it seems like a warning sign. I came into the theater fresh off (relatively), Villeneuve's last film, Sicario, another grossly over-hyped early bird Oscar contender that flopped commercially, with the average viewer and eventually, with Oscar voters when it counted (and is now going on to become a gross trilogy like the finest pieces of faux-indie). Previously, I had been impressed by Villeneuve's Prisoners, although I wasn't awestruck. Safe to say that I haven't been riding the ridiculous hype-train this director took to get to the seat of the new Bladerunner sequel so my expectations coming in were tempered. Right off the bat, it became clear that Adams was a poor cast, remaining incapable of playing highly intelligent, logical, non-quirky characters (she's either intelligent and quirky or dopey and goofy, not much range beyond that). Her facial movements and tonal inflections continue to put her in a different role, even as she struggles (nobly I might add) to convey the dramatic heft of her character. It's an issue that gets better as the film goes on and it isn't anything against Adams (I've enjoyed her quirky work in American Hustle and Big Eyes and go no farther than Helena Bonham Carter to see just how well the typecast can work for a thespian) but it was on Villeneuve to cast correctly here and he chose (predictably) trendy as opposed to right. Thankfully, intentionally or not, the movie is extremely minimalist with Adams, especially in dialogue and as soon as we get past the necessary exposition, her character becomes much easier to watch. And this central portion of the film is where Villeneuve shines. The panoramic shots, the horn based soundtrack, the gripping emotional moments, all are there to great effect. Mind you, Forest Whitaker is a constant distraction, with an accent that fluctuates between deep South and embedded New Yorker quicker than you can say Kentucky Fried Bronx (it's clear that whatever you take from this film, his days of acting are mercifully drawing to a close, as his eye condition and poor inflection have hijacked all of his recent performances). Also distracting is the liberal lean of this film. In all my years of watching film, this is never a complaint I have had (even with Avatar proper, although it did play into my analysis after). I appreciate both a clear liberal lean in tone (as is the case with so many indie films) and the many liberal directors, who can still create well balanced works with many political facets for many viewers. The problem with Arrival is that Villeneuve isn't the least bit subtle and he's clearly been watching the 2016 election season way too much. As such, moments where the film might have subtly touched at some of the attitudes that impact it, we are instead jarred with an actual foray against fake news, a nearly there jab at Fox News and a bizarre redneck soldier bomb mutiny that is an improbable wink to posh leftists who prefer to stereotype the military from afar. Now to be clear, I don't disagree with Villeneuve on all of these points but the film is a subtle, artistic commentary on language and humanity. The ungainly hammer of these moments conflicts so strongly with the tone of the film that it puts the viewer off. It's going to be amusing to the average well-off, white faux-progressive but these moments aren't really good art or good taste. The idea that a scientist working on the first contact with non-human intelligent life would spend time surfing conservative alt-right fake news sites or that a rogue redneck soldier would be able to cobble together a Christian bomb brigade at the most important military site in the United States isn't just jarring, it's ludicrous. Villeneuve is a long way from the political artistry that directors such as Kubrick, Scorsese and Nolan managed with each film (try telling me Taxi Driver isn't a seamless liberal critique of the Vietnam War wrapped up perfectly in a coherent and artistic storyline). Great art has many facets, Villeneuve's art has few thus far. But getting through that, I appreciated this large chunk of the film. The core twist has been properly saved for the end, the flashbacks (or forward) are inserted coherently and when things come to a head, the appropriate emotional gravity is definitely there (a testament to Adams' effort here). And then unfortunately Villeneuve veers off the tracks. Just as I thought the movie would close into what honestly was, in my mind, a nearly great film, Villeneuve forgoes the ambiguity and beauty of a straight ending and goes full Peter Jackson. There's a barrage of flashbacks, a cobbled-together romance, a literal lets-make-a-baby line and just like that, the movie slips back into just good. It's the tipping point away from greatness that I also felt with Prisoners and Villeneuve's failure to make it here may just define his career at the end of the day. Instead the ending forces us to reflect on the logical and emotional inconsistencies of the film and trust me, that isn't a good thing in a time themed science-fiction film. And speaking of reflection, another reason why Villeneuve may want to avoid letting his audience do that is his propensity for copycatting recent work. Not only does Arrival bear striking similarities to Contact (antisocial, asexual female scientist with deep seated emotional needs stares pensively into the sky) but the cues from 2014's Interstellar are painfully obvious. The color palate, the soundtrack, the shot angle, the portrayal of alien landscapes and most importantly, the time based themes all feed directly from Nolan's previous (and original) masterpiece. Unfortunately Arrival lacks the heart, vision and humanity of that film, not to mention the tremendous mastery Nolan brings to all his work. It's a tacky feeling realization and although Arrival still stands out somewhat and has language as an important new theme, like any copycat, it loses some of its luster. Arrival is worth the watch but not worth the hype.

What makes Arrival so poignant is not simply the terrific compilation of superb directing, acting, and music, nor is it simply the creative genius behind the premise, but it's the, dare I say, perfect arrival time for this movie with its themes and messages that make it hands down the best film of 2016 so far.
